Alex Telles' sending off after 27 minutes proved to be Porto's undoing in the end as their resistance was finally broken, with Juventus taking a massive step towards the quarter-finals.
FULL-TIME: PORTO 0-2 JUVENTUS.
There will be two minutes added on at the end of this match.
Frustration setting in now as Marcano goes into the book.

HOW UNLUCKY! Khedira has put in such an impressive display tonight and you really couldn't say he doesn't deserve a goal for his efforts. He tirelessly chases a throughball, arriving just ahead of Casillas as he slides in to send an effort towards goal, missing the far post by mere fractions.
The final Juventus change of the night sees Claudio Marchisio replace Dybala.
Back the other way come Juventus on the break, and Herrera takes one for the team, sliding in to foul Pjaca and stop a break as he's issued a yellow card.
It took 84 minutes, but Porto finally have their first corner of the night. Layun takes it, as the hosts pack bodies in the centre, but it's seen away smartly by Mandzukic.

The tempo is slowing a great deal with Juventus content with their advantage, knocking the ball about as they look to milk the final minutes off the clock. The last thing they want now is to give Porto a glimmer of hope. They need not worry about scoring a third goal.

STAT: Juventus are unbeaten against Porto (W2 D1). They beat them in the 1984 Cup Winners' Cup final (2-1), and recorded a win (3-1) and a draw (0-0) when they met in the 2001/02 Champions League first group stage.

Fatigue is creeping in as well now for Porto, who are barely hanging on as Juventus control possession and poke and prod in search of a third goal. The hosts' resistance has been broken and their resolve is being tested.

Well you get the sense that the tie is about settled now. It could have been very different had Alex Telles not gone and got himself sent off so early on, but that's the way it works sometimes. Goals from a pair of Juventus substitutes have likely put this tie to bed.
Alex Sandro has been exceptional tonight and he deserves that assist.

TWO GOALS FROM THE SUBSTITUTES! He's hardly been on the pitch for 60 seconds, but Dani Alves gets on the end of a cross from Sandro, chests it down and just manages to tuck home a finish with Marcano late arriving!
Porto's third and final change sees Diogo Jota replace Brahimi.
Dani Alves replaces Lichtsteiner, a likey precaution with the Swiss full-back on a booking.

JUVENTUS HAVE THEIR BREAKTHROUGH! It's a vital away goal and the substitute provides it! Dybala's stray pass is inexplicably sent into the path of a sprinting Pjaca, off the boot of Layun, and the Croatian makes no mistake, driving a sensational first-time finish into the bottom corner!

Almost into the last 20 minutes now and it has to be said, this would be a big result for Porto. They would have liked to get a win to take back with them to Turin, but given the circumstances surrounding this match, a scoreless draw would be a real moral victory for them, denying Juventus the away goal.
Marko Pjaca is the first Juventus substitute of the evening as he comes on to replace Cuadrado.

HOW CLOSE WAS THAT?! Good work from Khedira to win the ball in midfield before Higuain is eventually picked out higher up the pitch. The striker opens up as he cuts onto his right, but bends a strike agonisingly wide of the far post with Casillas rooted to his spot!
STAT: Porto have only failed to score once in their last 12 Champions League games at the Dragao, it was against Dynamo Kiev in November 2015 (0-2).
A second Porto change on the night sees Jesus Corona replace Neves, a positive switch indeed from the hosts, as Tiquinho will have a bit of support now.

NOT FAR AWAY! A stunning hit there from Khedira, who got all of that effort on the half-volley, but just couldn't hit the target in the end as it was dipping and swerving the whole time, inches wide of the near post.

The tempo is ramping up to high gear as we approach the hour mark. It's not just one-way traffic now, as Porto loosen the shackles a bit as they throw some caution to the wind. They've instilled a much more positive approach here as they chase a goal of their own to take with them back to Turin.

Porto are being very brave here as they adopt a bit more urgency in the hopes of stealing the opener, and it's an admirable approach, but they're looking increasingly vulnerable as a result. They can't afford to leave themselves exposed like this.

STRAIGHT AT CASILLAS! Again they threaten, and again they're denied! A punishing drive from Dybala once again from 25 yards, but it's right into the waiting arms of Casillas. The Argentine forward is really in the mood for a goal, and appears more than capable.
STAT: Juventus are the only team to have won all three of their Champions League away games this season (8 goals scored, 1 conceded), their best ever run of victories on the road in the competition.

Lichtsteiner tries to win the ball in the Porto penalty area, and does arrive first, but he goes hard through Herrera, rather dangerously, on the follow through, and is booked as a result. A mocking cheer from the Porto fans rains down on the referee, who has actually done an expert job thus far.
NOT FAR AWAY! A rare chance for Porto at the other end as Layun bends a delightful ball in towards the far post for his fellow countryman, but Herrera sends his header wide!

OFFSIDE! Oh that's a big mistake there from the Juventus forwards! A delightful flick over the top from Pjanic sends Mandzukic through on goal, but he leaves it for Dybala, who smashes home an accomplished finish... only he was offside! Had Mandzukic taken the chance himself, the play would have been onside and Juventus would likely be ahead!
Here we go again...

Juventus well on top, despite what the score may indicate, as we're through 45 minutes at the Estadio Do Dragao. Porto have their work cut out for them, down a man following the sending off of left-back Alex Telles for two senseless challenges in the space of 90 seconds. Juventus have pressed hard for the breakthrough, but they have been denied so far by Iker Casillas and the woodwork.
HALF-TIME: PORTO 0-0 JUVENTUS.
ANOTHER BAD ONE! Maxi Pereira is lucky not to get his marching orders here as he obliterates Mandzukic with a tackle! The yellow is produced, but there really was a case for red.

OFF THE POST! A superb strike, that, from Dybala! He takes one quick step to his left, before driving an effort back across goal from 25 yards that beats Casillas clean, but stays out off the woodwork! That close to an opener for Juventus.

The duo of Felipe and Marcano are being given a real test tonight, but they have passed with flying colours thus far, not fading at all in the face of relentless Juventus pressure. They have done an excellent job of keeping things in front of them and limiting the visitors' looks at goal.
STAT: Porto have kept a clean sheet in each of their last three Champions League games, the longest current run among all 16 teams left in this season’s competition.

Brahimi's work rate is proving important for Porto as they fend off threat after threat. The hybrid midfielder-attacker is covering a lot of ground as he's consistently back to lend a hand in defence, while piecing together some decent, direct runs forward to provide little moments of respite for the defence.
SMART SAVE! Excellent reactions and strong hands from Casillas to palm away Higuain's effort at the near post. Juventus pouring the pressure on here as they inch closer to a breakthrough.

Porto desperately need to see this game into the half scoreless. There's no respite for them at the moment. Juventus are first to every ball and they have much more spring in their step. Porto are demoralised a bit. They need a rallying cry and something positive they can build off.

GLANCED WIDE! Acres of space for Telles on the overlap, and all sorts of targets to aim at in the centre. He picks out the high-rising heading of Khedira, but the midfielder doesn't get the contact he desires as he sends a header glancing inches wide of the far post.
STAT: Porto have lost only one of their 14 Champions League knockout games at home (W7 D6), it was against Manchester Utd in April 2009 (0-1).
Nuno Espirito Santo is forced into a change here, as Miguel Layun comes in to fill the vacant spot at left-back, with striker Andre Silva replaced. Tiquinho will be the lone man leading the line now.

Well how does this change things now? Juventus, who were already in complete control of the match, are now full of life and confidence as they pepper the weakened Porto backline. This is going to be a real test of Porto's strength, fitness and character over the final hour of the match.

WHAT WAS HE THINKING?! Less than 90 seconds after picking up his first yellow card, Telles stupidly flies into another challenge on the flank, this time on Lichtsteiner, sending him hard to the ground. Porto players gather around the referee to plead for his leniency, but they really don't have a case. The full-back is sent off and Porto are down to 10 men!

A reckless and altogether needless challenge from Telles, who goes crashing through the back of Cuadrado on the halfway line. He will have to go up against the pace of the Colombian the rest of the night now on a yellow card.

FIRST REAL CHANCE! Khedira and Higuain both flick the ball on smartly, as it falls kindly for Dybala on the edge of the box, but he skies his first-time effort with his weaker right foot! Had that been with his left, it might have produced the vital away goal Juventus crave.

Casillas looks bright as ever though, which is a good sign for the visitors. Twice now he's come darting off his line to clear the danger, the latest intervention to see away the threat of Mandzukic, who was nearly slipped through on the end of some clever interplay.

Porto are showing no inclination of trying to press high up the pitch, which has made for some very easy possession for the likes of Chiellini and Barzagli, while affording Lichtsteiner and Telles the luxury of getting forward with great regularity on the overlap.
STAT: No Italian side has won any of their last five trips to Porto in the Champions League (4 draws followed by 1 loss). The last victory dates back to March 1993 (Porto 0-1 AC Milan).

It's all Juventus for the time being, a drastic switch from the first 10 minutes where Porto were taking charge. The hosts have a lot of defensive minds in midfield and it's seen them drop a bit too deep off the ball, allowing Juve to get up the pitch with relative ease.

ALMOST! Lovely running from Khedria, who shows good initiative to take on the Porto defence. He drives into the area and pulls it back for Higuain, but Marcano is just able to stick a foot out to divert it away from the striker's path, or he would have been through!

Momentum has shifted a great deal now as Juventus are dictating the tempo here, enjoying the lion's share of possession. Porto have reverted into a defensive shell, but they're organising themselves quite well, which has made it difficult on the visitors to try and find a way through.

Juventus seem to have weathered the early storm as they're beginning to knock the ball about with a bit more purpose and confidence. A nifty turn from Khedira sees him win a free-kick about 40 yards out, which Pjanic ambitiously strikes for goal, but he rattles his effort off the wall as the danger is averted.
STAT: Andre Silva has been directly involved in two-thirds of Porto’s goals in this season’s Champions League (6 out of 9), scoring four and assisting two.

Brahimi has a real strong ability from these set pieces and he gets the crowd going as he stands over to take this one, but can only let out a wry smile as he gets under his final effort, sending it over the bar.

Plenty of possession for the hosts in the early stages as Juventus struggle to get a foothold in the match. Andre Silva makes a delightful run following a clever link-up with Tiquinho, and he wins a foul just outside the area following a foul by Chiellini - though the replays indicate it was a clear dive, and thus not the correct decision by the referee.

A bright start from Porto sees them apply some early pressure, which only amplifies the noise in this stadium. It's far from a friendly atmosphere for Juventus, one which they will have to be sure to manage as the match progresses.
AND THEY'RE OFF! Porto are in their black home strip as they get the game underway, attacking right to left, with Juventus in white and black.

Massimiliano Allegri rotated his squad for Friday's victory over lowly Palermo, resting many of his regulars, with Sami Khedira, Paulo Dybala and Gonzalo Higuain the only outfield players to keep their place. Mario Mandzukic and Juan Cuadrado are restored to support Higuain with Miralem Pjanic partnering Khedira. Andrea Barzagli and Giorgio Chiellini start in defence with Leonardo Bonucci left out of the squad as punishment, following an argument with manager Allegri during Friday's match.

Nuno Espirito Santo has adopted a cautious approach to tonight's match with the defence-minded trio of Ruben Neves, Danilo Pereira and Hector Herrera all in the starting XI, ahead of Jesus Corona, Oliver Torres and Diego Jota. Danilo will drop deeper in midfield, but figures to have plenty of support in Neves and Herrera, with Yacine Brahimi on hand to offer a link between midfield and attack.
SUBS: Benatia, Marchisio, Pjaca, Asamoah, Alves, Rugani, Neto.
JUVENTUS (4-2-3-1): Buffon; Lichtsteiner, Barzagli, Chiellini, Sandro; Khedira, Pjanic; Cuadrado, Dybala, Mandzukic; Higuain.
SUBS: Boly, Sa, Corona, Jota, Andre, Layun, Oliver.
PORTO (4-4-2): Casillas; Maxi, Felipe, Marcano, Telles; Herrera, Danilo, Neves, Brahimi; Andre Silva, Tiquinho.
CONFIRMED TEAM NEWS:

Massimiliano Allegri’s side cruised to first place in their Champions League group, all the while maintaining their impressive form in the league, building a seven-point cushion at the top as they pursue a sixth successive Serie A title – though the aim this season will be to end a 20-year hiatus on lifting a trophy in Europe.

Porto’s surge in form on the continental scene has resulted in domestic success as they cut Benfica’s lead atop the Portuguese Primeira to just one point – though the standard for domestic dominance has been set by their opponents tonight, Juventus.

After stumbling through their opening two matches in this season’s competition proper, Porto turned their campaign around, going four matches unbeaten, winning three and conceding just one goal, to close out the group stage in second spot, behind Leicester City.

Yesterday’s excitement has set the scene for what should be another wildly entertaining night of Champions League football between a pair of white-hot teams in Porto and Juventus, having won six and seven successive matches, respectively, entering tonight’s clash.
Hello and welcome to live coverage from the Estadio Do Dragao in Portugal as the first leg of the Champions League round-of-16 draws to a close tonight when Porto hosts Italian champions Juventus!
news: Marko Pjaca scored his first goal for Juventus and fellow substitute Dani Alves was also on target as they won 2-0 at Porto to take control of their Champions League last-16 tie.
Faced with the prospect of playing more than an hour with 10 men after Alex Telles was sent off for two yellow cards in as many minutes, Porto coped well as Juve saw a host of chances go begging.

The game appeared set to end a highly frustrating draw for Juve, but Massimiliano Allegri - who dropped centre-back Leonardo Bonucci in the wake of their spat at the end of Friday's win over Palermo - made a pair of inspired changes in bringing on Pjaca and Alves.
Pjaca finally broke the deadlock in 72nd minute, powering a half-volley into the bottom-left corner to end his wait for a maiden Bianconeri goal.
And just two minutes later Alves put Juve in complete command by converting from Alex Sandro's left-wing delivery to the far post.
The hosts never looked like mounting any sort of response and they now have a mountain to climb in the return fixture on March 14.
Porto started brightly and saw Yacine Brahimi go close when he curled a free-kick narrowly over after Giorgio Chiellini was dubiously adjudged to have fouled Andre Silva.
Juve soon began to dictate play without creating much in front of goal, Paulo Dybala spurning their best chance as he fired over on the stretch from Gonzalo Higuain's flick-on.
And the visitors were handed a huge boost as Telles lost all composure and committed two rash fouls in the space of as many minutes.

After raking his studs down the back of Juan Cuadrado's leg, the left-back needlessly slid into Stephan Lichtsteiner on the right flank, leaving referee Felix Brych with no choice but to issue a second yellow.
Cuadrado then immediately drove wide of the left-hand post before Miralem Pjanic forced Iker Casillas into action with a long-range effort.
Sami Khedira could only manage to turn Alex Sandro's left-wing cross wide, with Casillas then required to pull off a fine reaction save after Higuain's close-range effort deflected off Felipe.
The Juve onslaught continued and only the left-hand post prevented Dybala from breaking the deadlock with a fierce effort that had Casillas easily beaten.
Dybala did beat Casillas shortly after the restart when he lashed in at the near post from a clever Pjanic pass, only to be denied by the offside flag.
Juve were almost punished for their profligacy by Hector Herrera, who perhaps should have done better as he nodded wide from substitute Miguel Layun's excellent cross from the left.
A dipping volley from Khedira was only just off target and Higuain saw a sublime curling effort drift agonisingly wide as Juve's frustration grew.
But Allegri was able to breathe a sigh of relief when Pjaca lashed in after Layun inadvertently deflected Dybala's pass into his path.

Moments later Alves made an instant impact as he stretched to turn in the ball from the excellent Alex Sandro and, although Khedira missed a late chance to make it 3-0, Juve will head back to Turin extremely confident of progression to the quarter-finals.

commentary: Full-time at the Etihad. An absolutely sensational game of football sadly comes to an end as Manchester City defeat Monaco 5-3 in the first leg of this Champions League last-16 tie. Falcao and Aguero were the star men for their respective sides in what proved to be a topsy-turvy affair with all emotions being registered by the managers, but City gain the advantage before the second leg, which can't come quick enough. Thanks for joining us!

The fourth official wastes everyone's night now and announces that there will only be three minutes of stoppage time added on. Every viewer watching this wants at least 10 more minutes as it has unquestionably been one of the games of the season!

The last five minutes of play has been fairly underwhelming considering the circumstances, but this will play straight into the hands of City who want the final whistle now. Another time wasting substitution sees Sterling come off to be replaced by Jesus Navas.
Last throw of the dice from Monaco as Dirar replaces Bakayoko for the final change.

Pep Guardiola makes a change now as Aguero leaves the pitch to be replaced by Fernando. It is no exaggeration to say that this is the first negative, defensive, or pragmatic tactical change made by either manager all evening.
Another positive change from Jardim. A Portuguese comes on for another as Bernardo Silva makes way for his compatriot, Joao Moutinho.
Unselfish work from Aguero as he assists Sane whilst on a hat-trick.

GOOOOOAAAAAAAAAALLL FOR MAN CITY! That is FIVE! With Monaco all over the place at the back, Silva clips a gorgeous pass in behind for Aguero, who shows superb composure to simply square to Sane, who passes home into the empty net! FIVE-THREE! This is a quite unbelievable football match.

Phew. We can all breath in a little now as the play has just calmed down ever-so-slightly. Germain goes forward into the box, but Stones defends with strength this time and comes in to make the excellent tackle to win possession back for City inside their own half.
Yellow card Fábio Henrique Tavares

Jardim reacts almost immediately to going behind and introduces another talented forward in the form of Valere Germain, with the impressive Mbappe coming off for the last 10 minutes. The latter has been so impressive tonight. Certainly one to watch as he is only 18-years-old.
Good physical presence from Toure inside the box as he flicks on for Stones to score.

GOOOOAAAL! GOOOAAALL! GOOAAALL FOR CITY! WHAT A TURNAROUND! Another corner kick is the source of a goal for the hosts as it is curled to the front post for Toure who rises high to flick on to the danger area. Stones gets just ahead of Aguero to pop a finish home, and atone for his mistake for Falcao's second in the process! FOUR-THREE.

Even with all the beautiful football on display here tonight, the game has been littered with cheap fouls and subsequent yellow cards. The latest guilty party is Bernardo Silva who cynically hauls back De Bruyne to halt a City counter.

Just over 15 minutes to go in this utterly enthralling Champions League last-16 clash at the Etihad. We have already seen six goals, but the way this game is going you would be VERY surprised if this finishes at 3-3 before the second leg. Both teams are still going for it - incredible!
This game is being played at break-neck-speed and as Monaco are awarded a cheap free-kick, Zabaleta goes into the book for some dissent towards the referee, who is having none of it.
Silva assists the equaliser with a corner.

GOOOOAAAALLL! GOOOAAAALLL FOR CITY! The hosts equalise again! Silva curls in a beautiful corner from the right wing and Aguero meets it at the back post to cushion a lovely first-time volley bouncing into the bottom corner. Three-three! WHAT. A. GAME.

Sterling has been a real bright spark for Manchester City tonight and goes on another marauding run cutting inside from the right wing. He makes his way into the box and then goes down under the challenge of Mendy, but the referee correctly waves away the protests from the hosts for the penalty as the left-back cleanly won possession.

There is an entertaining duel going on between Stones and Falcao so far. Well, if you can call the Colombian bullying his opposite number for the majority of the game a duel. However, he takes it a little too far on this occasion as he goes in late for the nasty tackle to receive a booking.

Zabaleta gets involved positively shortly after coming off the bench as he exchanges a neat one-two with De Bruyne before bombing through to the byline. The cross is drilled to the front post but before Sterling can get the finish in, Gilk puts behind for a corner-kick.
Guardiola reacts quickly to going behind so quickly after equalising and it is Fernandinho who comes off to be replaced by Zabaleta, who is of course more comfortable at left-back than the Brazilian.
Lemar gets the assist, but that goal was all-Falcao!

GOOOOAAAAAAAAALLLL FOR MONACO! What an INCREDIBLE bit of skill from Falcao! Another speculative ball is sent down the channel from Monaco and the Colombian collects before bullying Stones off the ball and delicately dinking a chip over the oncoming Caballero from 12 yards. The most gorgeous finish you will ever see! Three-one.
Excellent work both defensively and offensively from Sterling for the assist.

GOOOOOAAAAAAAAALLLLL FOR MAN CITY! We are back on level terms! Sterling does superbly well to nick the ball off the full-back down the right before sprinting forward at pace to release Aguero into the box. The resulting strike is poor from the former Atletico man, but it doesn't matter as Subasic allows it to go cleanly underneath him! Awful goalkeeping! Two-two.

It was quite the storm that City managed to weather in the first 10 minutes of the second period from Monaco, albeit fortuitously after that missed penalty. Everything is just a bit more calm and collected from the hosts, much to the relief of the Etihad crowd.
The yellow cards are coming thick and fast for Monaco now and the latest guilty party is Bakayoko who is forced to bring down Sterling after being outpaced by the Englishman down the right touchline.

There really is a nervous energy in the Etihad at the moment as the City fans just do not trust their defence to shut out Monaco any more. The hosts have already conceded two, but the way things are going it could easily be three or four!
MONACO MISS THE PENALTY! Falcao, who missed a spot-kick against Tottenham earlier on this season, fails to score again as he sends a tame strike down to the right which is easily saved by Caballero.
Otamendi is booked as he concedes the penalty!
PENALTY TO MONACO! As Falcao misses that chance, Otamendi is booked and penalised for the despairing tackle to try and stop him.
VITAL save from Caballero from the pen.
FALCAO! HOW CLOSE WAS THAT?! Mendy gets down the left AGAIN before curling a cross into the box for the Colombian, but the resulting strike on goal goes JUST the wrong side of the post!
The second half is under way at the Etihad! Keep the goals coming.

Half-time at the Etihad. A quite brilliant first half comes to an end as Monaco go into the break with a slender 2-1 lead. City took the lead through Sterling, but the visitors continued to threaten and eventually netted two through Falcao and then Mbappe, who has lit up the stadium at times. An unmissable second period coming up.

Monaco are looking increasingly dangerous on the counter here which isn't ideal for City who have been less-than-convincing at the back this season. On this occasion, Falcao threatens again, but ends up slamming an attempt into the side-netting from the left.

VITAL CLEARANCE FROM RAGGI! City look to respond quickly to going a goal behind as they pepper the Monaco backline with balls into the box. Subasic makes a mistake with one which allows Sane to smuggle a strike on goal, but the Italian defender is on hand to clear with the commanding overhead kick.
Superb assist again for Fabinho!

GOOOOAAAAAALLLL FOR MONACO! The visitors complete the turnaround, and in simple fashion! Fabinho clips a speculative ball over the top of the City defence and Mbappe easily gets to it before Otamendi which allows him to burst into the box and smash a finish into the top left corner! Two-one.
Second booking in quick succession for City and it goes to Fernandinho.

This really has been an outstanding game of football so far between two sides who simply just want to score as many goals as possible. Yes, the defending could be better, but the forward play is making for a hell of a good watch!

Monaco go route one right over the top and it is Mbappe who collects before opening up his stride with a gliding run to the edge of the box. From a difficult angle, he fires a strike towards goal which flashes JUST over the top of the left-hand top corner. Really unlucky.

A really controversial moment now as Aguero goes through on goal one-on-one with the goalkeeper, only to go down under the challenge of Subasic. The referee books the Argentine for diving, but there did appear to be contact on him, even if the Monaco stopper got the ball slightly too.
Now THAT is what you call service for a striker! Superb assist from Fabinho.

GOOOOOAAAALLLLL FOR MONACO! A superb equaliser from the French side! Caballero, in his attempts to play out from the back, sends a wayward ball down the left which is eventually picked up by Fabinho, who subsequently curls an absolute beauty of a cross to the back post. Falcao makes no mistake and scores with the diving header! One-one!

Mendy gets into an advanced are down the left flank and gains a yard of space on Sagna before whipping an absolutely sensational cross deep towards the back post. Falcao typically lingers looking for a predatory finish, but a superb interception from Fernandinho sees City survive at the back! Still 1-0.

A vital opener from City, then, who have actually not took the lead in too many European matches this season. However, Monaco will not stray away from their gameplan of flooding men forward so Guardiola's men still have to keep their composure at the back under the barrage of red and white kits.
Fantastic work from Sane for the assist as he takes three defenders out the game with a fabulous, penetrating dribble!

GOOOOAAAAAAALLLLL FOR MAN CITY! The hosts take the lead! Sane takes on Sidibe, who has just been booked, with a penetrating run and bulldozes his way through before eventually receiving a pass back from Silva near towards the byline. The German then smashes an emphatic cross along the box for Sterling to stab home! One-nil.
Another booking for Monaco as Sidibe is penalised for a cynical foul on Sane after previously being unpunished for a similar foul on Silva.

A MASSIVE MISS FROM AGUERO! Sterling, who is becoming increasingly more prominent as a threat to the visitors, picks up the ball on the right wing again before curling a teasing cross along the six-yard box, but the Argentine striker is unable to stick out a leg to turn a strike on goal, seemingly put off by the oncoming Subasic.

The game has been pretty open so far with both sides enjoying some decent periods down the wings and in behind. The only surprising thing is that neither goalkeeper has been tested to a particularly high degree in their respective goals, even with the impressive build-up play.

City get the corner on the right which Sane will take. The German takes it quick before receiving the ball back from De Bruyne to leave a couple of defenders in his wake with a cracking turn of pace to hit the byline, but the subsequent cross into the box is very easily intercepted by Monaco. A disappointing end to a promising move for the hosts.

Mbappe leaves Otamendi for dead with a scintillating turn just outside the centre circle before powering ahead ominously. He threads a ball to the left for the onrushing Mendy who sees a drilled shot towards the front post saved by Caballero, who spills the rebound. Falcao springs into action, but is flagged as offside.

Sterling attempts to utilise his tremendous pace to try and get in Mendy down the right and into the box. Subasic comes off his line to clear, but only as far as Aguero who collects the loose ball before popping a cross-cum-shot into the box, only for Raggi to head behind for a corner-kick.

Absolutely wonderful play in the middle of the park by Bernardo Silva as he bounces off the tackle of Sane before cleverly nutmegging Toure. The talented Portuguese then slides a lovely pass through the centre for Falcao, but some excellent defending from Otamendi sees the Colombian dispossessed.

City manage to get the ball in the back of the Monaco net after some neart interplay from Silva and Sterling near the byline. The Spaniard receives the ball back before popping a finish home, but the flag is up very quickly to penalise Sterling after he just went ahead of the play. Good decision.

Mbappe picks up the ball on the left channel and quickly makes his way into the City box with a twisting and turning run. A few Monaco players wait to try and get the shot away, but the hosts manage to clear before Caballero is forced into making a save between the sticks.

We see the first booking of the match now and it is a damaging one for Monaco as Glik will now MISS the second leg after taking out Sane down the right-hand side. Not only is he out of the return leg, but he will have to play 80+ minutes left in this fixture whilst on a yellow!

A cracking tempo to the game in these early stages and one thing is for sure, neither outfit is looking to sit back and soak up the pressure. City know they need to do well with the home advantage, but to be fair to Leonardo Jardim and his charges, they are typically showing no fear going forward either. Why would you when you have scored over 100 goals already this season?!

De Bruyne takes the early pressure off his defence with a marauding run deep down the right wing before cutting back to pass inside to Toure. Sterling is eventually fed into the box where he forces Subasic into the save, but the former Liverpool winger is quickly waved as offside by the linesman.

A positive opening to proceedings from Monaco who are looking to press City high up the pitch. As expected, Guardiola's men are playing the ball patiently out from the back but the frontline of the visitors certainly aren't making it easy at the moment.
We are under way at the Etihad!
The teams are making their way to the pitch and we are almost ready for kick-off!

We are witnessing a little bit of history tonight as this will actually be the first time that Man City and Monaco will face each other in a competitive fixture. The French side actually have an impressive record against English teams in the knockout stage of the Champions League, and have come out on top on all three occasions against Manchester United, Chelsea, and Arsenal respectively. The Citizens have only faced Paris Saint-Germain from France, and are unbeaten in three games against them.
Monaco subs: De Sanctis, Diallo, Toure, Dirar, Moutinho, Carrillo, Germain.
Monaco (4-4-2): Subasic; Sidibe, Raggi, Glik, Mendy; Fabinho, Bernardo Silva, Bakayoko, Lemar; Falcao, Mbappe.
Manchester City subs: Bravo, Zabaleta, Fernando, Nolito, Navas, Delph, Iheanacho.
Manchester City (4-1-4-1): Caballero; Fernandinho, Stones, Otamendi, Sagna; Toure; Sane, Silva, De Bruyne, Sterling; Aguero.
TEAM NEWS...

Leonardo Jardim's charges have been in scintillating form this campaign, especially going forward, and made it to the knockout round after topping Group E ahead of Leverkusen, Tottenham, and CSKA Moscow. Over all competitions, the Monte Carlo side have netted an extraordinary 107 goals this season, including 76 in 26 games in Ligue 1, with the renaissance of former Manchester United and Chelsea flop, Radamel Falcao, key to their successes so far.

When the group stage draw was made, Pep Guardiola's men were up against the unenviable task of trying to topple the might of Barcelona in order to earn the top spot. They failed to do so, despite beating the Catalan side at home, and have paid the price here as they take on a top-seeded outfit in the form of Monaco, who have been scoring with absolute ease this season. Without putting the commentator's curse on proceedings, we should be in for some goals between these two impressive sides over the two legs!
Good evening football fans! Welcome to LIVE coverage of the UEFA Champions League last-16 encounter between Manchester City and Monaco from the Etihad Stadium.
news: Manchester City claimed a remarkable 5-3 victory over Monaco in an all-time Champions League classic at the Etihad Stadium on Tuesday.

The first competitive meeting between the two sides will live long in the memory after goals inside the final 13 minutes from John Stones – atoning for an earlier error – and Leroy Sane put City in command of the last-16 tie.
Monaco overtake Barca as Europe's top scorers this season
Sergio Aguero and Radamel Falcao had scored two apiece – the latter also missing a penalty – while Raheem Sterling and Kylian Mbappe also got in on the act.
Leonardo Jardim's side, who have scored over 100 goals in all competitions this season, will rue the moment Falcao squandered a chance to make it 3-1 from the spot, as City hit back.
It was Sterling who opened the scoring 26 minutes in, but City quickly surrendered their advantage to Falcao's diving header following a poor clearance from Willy Caballero.

The hosts were incensed when Aguero was booked for diving instead of being awarded what City felt was a clear penalty and their frustration grew when teenager Mbappe put Monaco ahead before the break.
Having been denied a spot-kick, Pep Guardiola's side conceded one early in the second half, with Nicolas Otamendi the guilty party, but Caballero redeemed himself by denying Falcao.
While one goalkeeper was restoring some pride, another was about to have his dented as Danijel Subasic allowed Aguero's tame near-post strike to creep past him just before the hour mark.
But a remarkable game took another twist just three minutes later, Stones failing to defend a long ball and Falcao producing a stunning chipped finish.
2 - Falcao has scored as many goals tonight in Manchester as he did at Old Trafford for Manchester United (15 games). Homecoming.
Still the drama continued to unfold and, in a scarcely believable script, Aguero levelled before Stones went from villain to hero and Sane capped it all off.
The return leg in three weeks' time has a lot to live up to, but Monaco will have little choice but to go on the attack once more.
Kamil Glik, whose early booking ensured he will miss the second leg, headed narrowly wide amid a high-tempo start that set the tone for an enthralling contest.
Monaco hearts were in mouths when Kevin De Bruyne's teasing cross flashed across the face of the goal, with Aguero failing to apply the finishing touch.
And the deadlock was broken soon after, David Silva feeding Sane, who delivered the simple square pass from which Sterling tapped home.
‘Nothing is finished’ - Falcao warns Man City
The lead lasted only six minutes, though, with Caballero punished when he failed to clear his lines and Fabinho's superb cross was met by Falcao's header.
Referee Antonio Mateu Lahoz had a big call to make after Aguero took a tumble when trying to round Subasic and the Spanish official opted to pull out a yellow card for the Argentina international.
Monaco rubbed salt in the wound five minutes before half-time as Mbappe sprinted in behind a static defence and lifted Fabinho's throughball past Caballero.

Things looked to have taken a turn for the worse for City soon after the restart when Otamendi fouled Falcao in the box, but the former Manchester United loanee's effort was poor and Caballero easily kept it out.
Aguero's 58th-minute leveller was a moment to forget for Subasic, but Stones was next to embarrass himself with an error that allowed Falcao time to fashion a beautiful dinked finish.
Another City penalty appeal was waved away when Sterling went to ground under pressure from Benjamin Mendy, drawing deafening boos from the home crowd.
Those jeers turned to cheers after Aguero expertly volleyed in Silva's corner with 19 minutes remaining and Stones prodded in at the back post from a corner to put City ahead.
The final say on a crazy evening went to Sane, who turned in Aguero's selfless assist and the full-time whistle afforded an enraptured crowd to finally exhale.
8 - Manchester City 5-3 Monaco is the highest scoring first leg ever in a Champions League knockout tie. Bonanza.

commentary: FULL-TIME! Atletico close out a thrilling 4-2 away win over Leverkusen, which sets the tie up interestingly for the second leg in Madrid. Goals from Saul, Griezmann, Gameiro and Torres give Simeone's men an advantage, but a second-half strike from Bellarabi and a Savic own goal haven't ended this as a contest. That's all that we have time for, we hope to see you again next time.

Bailey is picked out by a great cross from the right-hand side, but can't convert, before Atletico respond. Torres lumbers forward and drills in a low cross, but Leno is able to push the ball behind ahead of Correa.
There are four minutes of stoppage time.
Filipe Luis makes a cynical challenge which earns him an automatic yellow card.
Gabi now gets a booking for fouling Aranguiz, which rules him out of the second leg.
Torres gets a late booking for his troubles, not that he will mind after that goal.
Brandt is replaced by Bailey for the last few minutes, as Schmidt searching for a late goal.
Vrsaljko scampers to the byline and lifts a wonderful cross onto Torres' forehead.

GOOOOOOOOAL! TORRES MAKES IT 4-2! What a huge goal for Atletico. The Spaniard is picked out by a great cross from the right-hand side and directs a good header home from close-range. What a relief for the away side.
Correa is found making tracks in behind the Leverkusen back four, but a bad first touch from the Argentine substitute allows for a defender to get back goalside and deny the Atletico forward.

Wide from Kampl! The Slovenia international threatens from the right-hand side and dip a cross-cum-shot towards the back post, but the ball flashes straight out for a goal-kick. Atletico are remaining very deep indeed.

Atletico's defending is getting gradually more desperate, with Leverkusen pushing on and growing more in confidence. The hosts break down the left-hand side, with Wendell dancing to the byline, but a low cross is gobbled up by Moya. So close to picking out Hernandez!

Close for Hernandez! Savic makes a vital block to make up for his own goal. The Mexican star shoots from close-range but is denied by the central defender, with Moya slightly out of position! Moments later, the same man is found near the front post by a cross from the left, but he strikes Filipe Luis with the goalkeeper flummoxed.
Correa is brought into the game, with Griezmann given a rest. Simeone is clearly thinking about the next leg already.
Carrasco is withdrawn, with Torres introduced. The Spaniard will go up top, with Correa going out to the right flank.

Leverkusen scamper down the left-hand side, before whipping in a delivery, but Moya isn't tested as the ball skips away from the danger zone. Atletico are living dangerously, and Gameiro's withdrawal might have sent out the wrong message to his players.
Gabi goes down after a painful challenge from Aranguiz, with the Chilean midfielder given a booking for his trouble. The Leverkusen player disagrees, but that looked to be rather fierce.

That change from Simeone has shown what Atletico will be doing in these late stages. Partey drives down the right and attempts to angle in a teasing cross, but Leno claims before Dragovic can do anything wrong with his clearance.
Gameiro is withdrawn for the away side, after a fantastic performance, as Partey comes into the game to shore things up in midfield.

Atletico are making things very hard for themselves, as Moya didn't appear to need to flap at that cross in the build-up to the own goal. It wasn't too long ago that he made a similar mistake against Celta Vigo in LaLiga. Simeone's men have given Leverkusen some hope.

OWN GOAL! That makes it 3-2! Brandt drives down the left and whips in a great low cross, which forces Moya to come out. The Atletico goalkeeper parries the delivery onto Savic's knee, with the ball then rebounding into the back of the net.
The goalscorer takes his leave, with Pohjanpalo adding a different attacking presence into the mix for Leverkusen.

The home side continue to see more possession and ask questions of a resilient visiting defence, but Moya is being protected expertly. Even with Juanfran and Godin missing out due to injury, and with Oblak not fit yet, Simeone's men are making this look easy.
Wendell is the latest man to go into the book, with frustrations continuing to rise for Leverkusen.

The second half started so well for Leverkusen, but that penalty conversion from Gameiro has taken the wind straight back out of their sails. Yet again, Atletico get forward at pace. Gameiro and Griezmann combine on the edge of the box, but a return pass into the clear finds the former straying narrowly offside.

Half an hour remains for Atletico to see out, but as Leverkusen push forward in an attempt to close the gap they're only going to give Griezmann and Gameiro more space in behind to wreak havoc in. Schmidt might have to alter his defensive personnel or system, as they're far too open at the back.
GOOOOOOOAL! GAMEIRO MAKES IT 3-1! The Frenchman takes the penalty that he won himself, thundering a powerful shot straight down the middle. Simeone goes crazy on the sideline.
Dragovic gets booked for tugging on Gameiro's shirt on the edge of the box. A penalty may have been harsh.
PENALTY! Gameiro manages to sprint clear of Dragovic, before checking back and nutmegging the Austria international. The first contact appeared to be outside of the penalty area.
Havertz is withdrawn after a quiet evening, with Volland introduced to try and aid Leverkusen's resurgence.

Koke tries to lift a cross into the box from deep on the left-hand side, but Leverkusen clear, with this contest remaining extremely open. Simeone won't be pleased with how Atletico have been dragged into trading opportunities since the restart. Carrasco checks in from the left, before shooting with his right, but the Belgian belts a terrible effort off-target.

Atletico find themselves sitting very deep indeed, which is inviting the away side to get forward on the break when they can. Gameiro is released down the right-hand side yet again, and uses his pace to burst away from Kampl, but a low cross from the Frenchman narrowly evades Griezmann at the far post.

OFF THE ANGLE OF POST AND BAR! Gameiro is found in some space inside the penalty area, before mustering up a shot with his left foot. The France international clatters a powerful shot into the frame of the goal. That was close. This second half has started at a great pace.
Henrichs is found at the right byline and cuts back a smart cross.

GOOOOOOOAL! LEVERKUSEN ARE BACK IN IT! Henrichs is fed down the right-hand side and whips in a good cross, finding Bellarabi in a pocket of space inside the penalty area. The German forward tucks a lovely finish across the goalkeeper and inside the far post. Game on!

Leverkusen have a lot of substitutes warming up, despite making no changes at the break, which probably sends the message to the hosts that if they don't improve soon, they'll be hooked off. Koke tries to hook a pass over the top towards Griezmann, but the Frenchman is caught offside.

We are back underway in the second half! We will have to see how the home side shape up, as Schmidt might have to consider some wholesale changes to try and muster a response out of this sorry Leverkusen side.

HALF-TIME! Atletico go into the interval with a 2-0 lead over Leverkusen, which leaves the hosts in a rather precarious position heading into the second leg already. Saul and Griezmann grabbed the goals, and it could have been more, but for a good save from Leno. Schmidt has a lot to say at the break, you'd imagine.

Leverkusen are a little low on ideas, it seems, as this first half threatens to peter out ahead of the half-time whistle. Brandt sprints down the right and tries to combine with Havertz, but the teenager misplaced his end of a planned one-two. Atletico respond with a counter, but a pass from Gameiro is intercepted.

Bellarabi tries to race down the left-hand side and get beyond Vrsaljko, but instead the Germany international is penalised for catching the heels of the former Sassuolo defender. That pretty much sums up Leverkusen's first half.

Leverkusen are seeing more of the ball, in an attempt to muster up a response, but Moya hasn't been threatened. A Bellarabi cross sails out of play at the back post, before a quick pass towards Hernandez is played beyond the hosts' forward and through to Moya.

Kampl tries to find Wendell out on the left-hand side, but the pass from the ex-Dortmund midfielder isn't quite right. Not that Leverkusen can hold it against him, he's been their best outlet. Moments later, Hernandez threatens from inside the box, but a shot from the Mexico international is deflected over the bar.

Leverkusen need to try and tighten things up at the back, as their defensive four are all at sea. Dragovic and Toprak are being dragged all over the place by Gameiro's pace, intelligence and movement, with Griezmann drifting through this contest unchecked.

Over the top from Griezmann! That was so nearly 3-0 and potentially goodnight to Leverkusen. Gameiro races down the right-hand side and cuts back a lovely ball to his compatriot, but the ex-Real Sociedad striker shoots over the crossbar with the aid of a deflection. Atletico are destroying their opponents on the break. That was an important stop from Leno.

Leverkusen just can't quite offer any kind of cutting edge in the final third, with Hernandez feeding off scraps as a lone striker. Young Havertz is also having trouble finding space in the hole behind the Mexican. Atletico are defending well, with Moya having answers to everything that has been thrown at him so far.

Moya makes a good save to deny Kampl's long-range shot, but the ball was heading wide already anyhow. The Spaniard pushes the ball behind for a corner, which is half-cleared initially, before Kampl shoots a long way wide of the left-hand post.

Leverkusen threaten on the counter-attack, with Brandt using his speed to threaten down the left-hand side once again. Kampl has been looking great when attacking from deep. The German cuts a cross into the box, which forces Koke to slide in and make a block that deflects the ball just beyond the far post. Nearly an own goal there!

Atletico are full of confidence now, with those two away goals bound to be invaluable for the second leg at Estadio Vicente Calderon. The visitors have been clinical, and Dragovic looks as though he wants the ground to swallow him up. Not a good start to this contest from Leverkusen.
Gameiro goes on a good run, before showing the intelligence to find his compatriot at the back post with the goal gaping.

GOOOOOOOAL! GRIEZMANN MAKES IT TWO! Gameiro is allowed to scamper forward on the counter-attack, and does well to wriggle away from Dragovic. The ex-Sevilla striker drags two defenders out of position, before finding his teammate in acres of space in the back post. He slots home and that's 2-0 Atletico. Poor mistake from the Austria international to start the whole move off.

Brandt and Kampl combine in midfield yet again for Leverkusen, with Wendell then found on the left. The Brazilian cuts a cross into Brandt, who tries to open his body up, but the young winger is tackled simply. Atletico's two banks are four are hard to break down, as ever.

Kampl has been the only man to make a difference for the home side in the final third so far, with Atletico appearing to be much more dangerous when allowed to mount attacks. A few misplaced passes are going amiss for Schmidt's side, as their keenness to answer Saul's goal struggles to translate into any impressive interplay.

Atletico are doing well to keep Leverkusen in fairly nonthreatening areas of the field. Brandt races down the left, but Vrsaljko is protected well by Saul and the goalscorer dispossesses the pacey German with ease. Moments later, Hernandez has his first say in this game, but the Mexican striker can only curl a tame effort straight at Moya from 16 yards out.

Leverkusen can't seem to put on any consistent pressure, with his game being characterised by breakaways and some impressive dribbling runs in the early stages. Simeone will be overjoyed with that away goal, and the travelling fans have responded by making even more noise. The hosts have to respond.
Gabi slots a simple pass into Saul, and his younger teammate does the rest!

GOOOOOOOAL! WHAT A FINISH FROM SAUL! The Spaniard cuts in from the right-hand side, as he did in last year's Champions League final, before curling an unstoppable left-footed effort into the top corner from an awkward angle. That is glorious stuff and Atletico lead.

Kampl works his way into the penalty area for Leverkusen with some lovely footwork, but the Slovenia international's low shot is denied on its way to goal by Savic! Moya might have struggled to get there, without the aid of his defender. The home side get themselves a corner as a result, but Atletico's goalkeeper claims it simply.
Henrichs picks up the first yellow card of the match, as the young right-back is penalised for catching Filipe Luis in the face with a stray arm. He will miss the next leg of the tie.

Good clearance from Wendell in the end! Atletico break down the left and Filipe Luis does brilliantly to beat a man and whip in a cross, forcing the Brazilian left-back to concede another corner awkwardly. He almost netted an own goal as the ball cannons off the crossbar! This time, Griezmann manages to flick Koke's set-piece delivery towards the back post, but Jose Gimenez can't rise high enough to convert the second ball.

Vrsaljko does brilliantly to burst down the right flank and battle his way beyond Wendell, but the Croatian's cross from the byline is charged down. Simeone will be pleased with how Atletico have looked to do their damage on the break. After a good opening surge from Leverkusen, the away side have settled in and are now trading blows.

Great play from Atletico! Griezmann scampers down the right-hand side, with the Frenchman holding his run and then finding Carrasco on the overlap. The Belgium international dances to the byline and cuts back a dangerous cross, which forces Aranguiz into a near-post clearance. The resulting corner doesn't get whipped in at the first attempt, but Leno claims the eventual delivery.

Atletico lift a long free-kick down to the right-hand side, but Gabi eventually gives the ball away. Simeone's men are yet to piece together a dangerous attack. Leverkusen's tails are most definitely up, and their fans are making plenty of noise. This is a tough start to proceedings for the away team.

Brandt wriggles beyond a sliding tackle, before finding Bellarabi on the right. The German winger cuts infield and opens play out to the other flank, but Wendell is held up by plenty of Atletico shirts. Leverkusen maintain their pressure and find Brandt in space, but Henrichs' overlapping run comes to nothing due to a heavy pass into his path. Schmidt's men are manipulating their opponents well.

Leverkusen work the ball out to the right-hand side, before Heinrichs whips in a cross from wide on the flank, but his cross fails to meet anyone in the penalty area. Moya doesn't even have to make a simple claim, the ball sails out of play harmlessly. Atletico are sitting quite deep to try and settle into this contest - but the hosts look in the mood.

We are underway in the first half at BayArena! Atletico will be hoping to put in a professional away performance with their two banks of four, but Leverkusen will be trying to force their home advantage.
Atletico substitutes: Oblak, Correa, Partey, Lucas, Torres, Henrique, Gaitan.
Atletico starting line-up (4-4-2): Moya; Vrsaljko, Savic, Gimenez, Filipe Luis; Koke, Gabi, Saul, Carrasco; Griezmann, Gameiro.
Leverkusen substitutes: Mehmedi, Volland, Pohjanpalo, Jedvaj, Bailey, Ozcan, Baumgartlinger.
Leverkusen starting line-up (4-2-3-1): Leno; Henrichs, Toprak, Dragovic, Wendell; Aranguiz, Kampl; Bellarabi, Havertz, Brandt; Hernandez.

TEAM NEWS: Jan Oblak isn't rushed back from injury to start for Atletico, with Miguel Angel Moya continuing in goal. Jose Maria Gimenez starts at centre-back, with Sime Vrsaljko at right-back, as Diego Godin and Juanfran miss out due to injury complaints. Yannick Carrasco and Koke start out wide, with Kevin Gameiro and Antoine Griezmann making up an intimidating partnership up front.

TEAM NEWS: 17-year-old Kai Havertz gets the nod for his Champions League debut in midfield, with Charles Aranguiz offering some fire alongside him. Javier Hernandez is deployed up front, with Kevin Kampl and Karim Bellarabi tasked with offering some invention up front. Halkan Calhanoglu is still suspended for Leverkusen, which gives Havertz and Julian Brandt more opportunities to impress.

Both of these teams have picked up their form in the last couple of weeks, with Kevin Gameiro even scoring a five-minutes hat-trick in LaLiga action at the weekend. That flurry of goals means that Leverkusen will have to keep their eye out for him tonight, although the hosts have Chicharito to call upon up front themselves. The Mexican star already has six Champions League goals under his belt at his current club, and will be looking to add to his tally.

Hello and welcome to live coverage of Atletico Madrid's away trip to face Bayer Leverkusen in the Champions League, as Diego Simeone's men look to hark back to their round of 16 win against the same opposition back in 2014/2015. Los Colchoneros needed penalties to do it two years ago, but those won't be happening tonight. What we can promise you is a hard-fought battle at BayArena.
news: Atletico Madrid are in pole position for a Champions League quarter-final berth after recording a 4-2 win over Bayer Leverkusen in the first leg of their last-16 tie at the BayArena.

Leverkusen were gunning for revenge after their European elimination at the hands of Atleti in 2014-15, and they had every reason to be confident following an eight-game unbeaten run in the Champions League, with only Real Madrid on a longer streak.
However, the visitors made an electric start, Saul Niguez and Antoine Griezmann putting them two goals up at half-time, before Karim Bellarabi pulled one back early in the second half.

Stefan Savic's own-goal after a Kevin Gameiro penalty prompted a late onslaught from Leverkusen, but Atleti were always dangerous on the break and Fernando Torres' late header restored their two-goal cushion.
A heavy home defeat leaves Leverkusen's chances of progression hanging by a thread in an underwhelming season that has seen head coach Roger Schmidt fight off reports that he could be sacked.

Diego Simeone's side have also struggled to replicate their best form this term, and their new-found defensive frailties were on display again, but a scintillating attacking display bodes well for the weekend's clash with Barcelona.
Atletico immediately pinned Leverkusen back in their half from the off and came close to opening the scoring twice in rapid succession after just 12 minutes.

Griezmann first called goalkeeper Bernd Leno into action with a low show from a narrow angle, before Wendell hit his own crossbar moments later with a clumsy clearance after Filipe Luis' cross from the left.

There was no such escape for the hosts five minutes later, however, as Saul handed Atletico the lead with a stunning strike, cutting inside onto his favoured left foot and curling a beautiful shot into the top corner past the helpless Leno.

Things went from bad to worse for Leverkusen as Aleksandar Dragovic inadvertently sent Gameiro on his way with a poor clearance on the halfway line and the Frenchman raced clear before setting up Griezmann for a composed finish inside the box.
Griezmann should have made it three following more good work from Gameiro after yet another rapid counter-attack, but Leno pulled off a sharp save to deny him.

Leverkusen seemed emboldened by that life and Bellarabi gave them hope when he pounced on Benjamin Henrichs's low cross from the right and beat goalkeeper Miguel Angel Moya with a clever finish in the far corner.

Gameiro rattled the crossbar soon after as Leverkusen's vulnerability on the break was laid bare and the France striker had his goal in the 58th minute - slamming home from the penalty spot after he was hauled to the floor by Dragovic.
Again Schmidt's side were back in the contest when Moya could only palm a cross into Savic's shins and the ball bobbled home, but Leverkusen's desperation to level the tie would ultimately cost them.
Torres dealt Leverkusen a hammer blow with five minutes left on the clock, heading smartly across Leno and in from a sublime Sime Vrsaljko cross to give last season's runners-up control of this tie.

commentary: Boos rain down from the few Arsenal fans that remain in the ground. This was a toxic second half to witness, with the crowd completely disengaged, and some of the players displaying an indifference to matters on the pitch. A few Gunners like Walcott and Oxlade-Chamberlain commendably stay on to applaud the support. Take noting away from Bayern though, who were miles ahead across both legs and take their spot in the quarter finals. That's it from us, thanks for tuning in.

Arsene Wenger surveys the scene with a grim look on his face. He gets up off the bench, zips up his jacket (in one smooth stroke), and prepares to face an unsympathetic media horde and quite a few furious fans.
I'd almost forgot that Arsenal were in this game. They put together a nifty little passing move against Bayern, leading to a Bellerin shot from inside the penalty area that flies narrowly wide.
He was played in behind the defence and was unselfish to set up Vidal.
IT'S FIVE! Vidal is on the scoresheet again, collecting a pass from Costa to slot into an empty net. No mercy from Bayern.
The fans are filing out of the Emirates Stadium in droves, and the only voices are those from the travelling support. The humiliation isn't over yet though.
Alonso set that one in motion.
IT'S FOUR! Bayern are stumbling over themselves to score, as they press high and win the ball in the Arsenal half. Vidal is clean through, and makes no mistake with the finish.
Ribery will head off and on comes Renato Sanches.
Thiago is replaced by Kimmich.
Xhaka is the latest player to be booked.
Rafinha played the early pass down the line.
COSTA ADDS A THIRD! Bayern break on the counter and they outnumber the Gunners rather glaringly. Mustafi is no match for Costa, who skips past him and curls an admirable finish home.

HEAVY TOUCH! Walcott clutches his face after losing the ball on the edge of the area, but the referee stands pat as Bayern release Lewandowski on the break. He was through on Ospina, but a bad first touch handed it to the keeper.
OFF THE POST! Douglas Costa, fresh off the bench, has too much speed for Bellerin, accelerating past the full-back to square for Lewandowski, who strikes the base of the woodwork on the slide.
The home fans are unhappy after an apparent opportunity for the referee to play advantage is squashed as he brings play back for a foul on Oxlade-Chamberlain. Just over 15 minutes to go.
Third change from Wenger as Lucas Perez steps in for Alexis Sanchez.
Ozil also returns to action in place of Giroud.
Ramsey is off and Coquelin is on.
That goal was the way for Robben to sign off from this game. On comes Douglas Costa.

It's now 7-2 on aggregate to Bayern and at this point, it's simply a matter of how much misery the Germans want to inflict on the Gunners. The second half has been played almost entirely in Arsenal's half.

THERE'S ANOTHER ONE! Ospina's clearance is poor, and presents Bayern with the chance to attack quickly. Arsenal come out second best in about three challenges as Robben skips ahead of Sanchez to prod home.

Strange sequence as the ball is played over the top for Lewandowski, who is offside but doesn't touch the ball. Time seems to stand still as Robben and Ospina race for it, with the former rounding the latter before his cross is deflected out.
SAVED BY OSPINA! Lewandowski and Vidal combine to carve Arsenal apart, and the striker hammers his shot right at the Colombian keeper, who sticks up two hands to divert it over the bar.
Clever flick from Thiago to deceive the Arsenal defence and get Lewandowski in the air at the near post, but the striker can't add to his tally as he guides his header onto the roof of the net.

Oxlade-Chamberlain bursts through the centre, beating one man and then two, but is robbed of the ball by the covering Rafinha. He trips the Brazilian and screams at the referee when he calls a foul, earning a yellow for dissent.

Bahyern must surely be licking their lips now for the remaining half-hour. They were already looking the superior side in the second half, and now have an undermanned and demoralised Arsenal to feast on.
LEWANDOWSKI SCORES! The Polish striker calmly sends Ospina the wrong way and that may be it for Arsenal.
KOSCIELNY SENT PACKING! The defender was initially awarded a yellow card for the foul, but after consultation with his assistant, the referee has changed his decision to a straight red.
BAYERN HAVE A PENALTY! The visitors carve their way into the box once again, and Lewandowski gets his body in front of Koscielny, who drags him back just as he's about to shoot.
Twice now Bayern have attacked down the left-hand side, but both times, the final ball has been dreadful, with both going out for throw-ins on the far side. Bayern looking dangerous here.
OFFSIDE! Alonso tries a quick free-kick that finds Hummels in the box, but as the centre-back side-foots the ball home, the flag is up on the near side. It's the correct call, too.
OVER THE BAR! Giroud is on the end of another glaring miss, as Ramsey stands a cross up to the centre of the box. The Frenchman gets up just a little too soon and plants his header over the top.
Off we go again.

And that will do it for now as we head into the half-time break. Plenty of positives for Arsenal to take from the opening half, not least Walcott's opening goal. However, with three more still needed, the Gunners will have to continue on this upwards trajectory, and limit Bayern, who have also looked dangerous when they're ready. Stay tuned.
Sanchez fires a free-kick right at Neuer, and that may be it for the half.
Some danger from Bayern in the closing stages of the half. Robben works the ball out wide for Rafinha on the overlap, but his lifted cross is poor and right into the arms of the keeper.
Martinez sees yellow for taking out Ramsey near the edge of the penalty area.
Sanchez takes a hard hit from Vidal, who raked his studs down the quad of his compatriot. Strangely, the referee doesn't show a card even though it happened right in front of him.

Oxlade-Chamberlain flies forward on the counter, but his pass out to Bellerin takes the Spaniard a little too wide. He hoists a cross into the area that's cleared, leading to a Bayern counter that ends with a Robben shot down Ospina's throat.
BIG OPPORTUNITY MISSED! After Giroud's miscue at one end, Lewandowski follows suit with a terrible fluff, volleying wide after being put clean through by Robben inside the area.
Alaba also sees yellow for his part in tht incident.
Walcott goes down in a challenge with David Alaba, and angrily shoves the ball into his chest. He gets booked for that.
OVER THE TOP! Giroud wins the initial knock down from a long ball, which finds its way to Monreal. The full-back returns it to the striker, who tries a first-time shot that flies horribly over.

Walcott is starting to get a little too excited here. The Englishman's hunger is admirable, but after being put through by a wonderful Mustafi pass, he attempts to make lightning strike twice with a near-post shot instead ot teeing up one of three better-placed teammates. Ends up in the side, instead of the back of the net.
Oxlade-Chamberlain skips past his man and gets the ball to Walcott on the byline, but he goes down under a fair challenge from Alonso. The referee isn't interested in the appeals for a penalty.

A fortunate deflection presents the ball to Giroud, who squares it wide for Walcott and continues his run into the box. Not for the first time, the forward's cross is poor and into the first defender.
The home fans aren't happy after Rafinha runs into the shoulder of Ramsey, leading to a foul against the Welsh midfielder. The Gunners have simmered down slightly in the last few minutes.

There's some real belief in the Arsenal fans, and it's permeated the 11 on the pitch. Walcott is running around like a madman and Bayern would do well to calm things down here like they did in the opening five minutes.
The ball is sent over the top by Thiago towards Robert Lewandowski, who manages to hold off Laurent Koscielny as he inches into the penalty area, but David Ospina is out quickly to clear.

Is this the start of something special? Arsenal have one, but they need three more. Given their second-leg history against Bayern, it was always likely that they would score, but that's only the first step of a daunting journey.
Giroud linked up with Walcott out wide.
FIRST ONE'S ONE THE BOARD! No surprise to see Walcott on the end of that one. He burst through down the right, lifted his head and smashed a lovely finish high into the back of the net!

Great period this from Arsenal as Walcott twists and turns in the box, taking one too many touches before losing possession. Moments later, the Englishman rises to meet a cross and inadvertently takes it off the head of Giroud.

NARROWLY WIDE! Arsenal keep the pressure on after a failed corner, and a cross from Monreal on the far side is deflected into the six-yard area, where Giroud towers up to put the header the wrong side of the post.

Alonso lifts a languid ball out to the right flank for Rafinha to chase, and the full-back tries to use his first touch to burst past Monreal, but the Spaniard gets his body in the way to make the interception.

GREAT PLAY BY MANUEL NEUER! Walcott this time keeps himeslf onside as he races onto an early ball down the middle, but his first touch, combined with the Bayern keeper's proactive closing down, means that the ball is cleared.
Granit Xhaka does well to maintain possession in the middle of the park, and he pings the ball out to the right flank for an open Walcott, who failed to time his run and is called for an offside.
Robben gets the ball on the right again, and tries to beat Nacho Monreal by turning him inside out. However, the Spaniard is on his game to block the effort out for a corner, which comes to nothing.
Rafinha plays the ball down the line for Robben, who scored the first goal in the opening leg between those two sides. He goes to the byline and dinks a cross in that's headed away at the near post.

This is the start to the game that Ancelotti would have wanted. Bayern Munich are dominating possession and making Arsenal do all the defending. Not the greatest atmosphere at the Emirates so far as well.
There was a delay in the game as toilet paper was thrown from the stands by some Bayern Munich fans, presumably to protest the ticket prices at the Emirates. We're back underway though.
Off we go.
Welbeck has been injured during his warmups, and Giroud replaces him.

Philipp Lahm is suspended, meaning that Rafinha steps in at right-back. Arjen Robben and Franck Ribery keep Douglas Costa and Kingsley Coman on the bench, while Thomas Muller also sits in favour of Thiago. All in all a fairly predictable XI from Carlo Ancelotti.

Alexis Sanchez is recalled to the Arsenal starting 11 after he was benched against Liverpool. Aaron Ramsey and Theo Walcott also begin this match, with Francis Coquelin and Olivier Giroud dropping to the bench. Mesut Ozil is also fit enough to be among the subs.
Bayern subs: Douglas Costa, Bernat, Muller, Ulreich, Coman, Kimmich, Renato Sanches.
Bayern (4-2-3-1): Neuer; Rafinha, Martinez, Hummels, Alaba; Alonso, Vidal; Robben, Thiago, Ribery; Lewandowski.
Arsenal subs: Gibbs, Gabriel, Lucas Perez, Ozil, Giroud, Cech, Coquelin.
Arsenal (4-2-3-1): Ospina; Bellerin, Mustafi, Koscielny, Monreal; Ramsey, Xhaka; Walcott, Oxlade-Chamberlain, Welbeck; Sanchez.

By contrast, things are looking rosy for Bayern Munich. Since a disappointing 1-1 draw with Hertha, they've reeled off three wins in all competitions by a combined score of 14-0. Second-place RB Leipzig are seven points behind them in the Bundesliga, and they're through to the semis of the DFB-Pokal. Barring a historic collapse here, the last eight of the UCL is also in their future.

No club has ever made it through a Champions League knockout tie after losing the first leg by four or more goals. To the frustration of an increasingly large section of their support, it seems like Arsenal are imploding right on schedule this season as they come into this Herculean task on the back of a demoralising 3-1 loss to Liverpool at Anfield.

Hello and welcome to our live commentary of the Champions League fixture between Arsenal and Bayern Munich in London. After the 5-1 pasting at the Allianz Arena, the Gunners need at least four goals tonight to qualify. Who's putting money on this?
news: Bayern Munich matched their 5-1 thrashing of Arsenal last month to inflict a 10-2 aggregate pummelling upon embattled boss Arsene Wenger at Emirates Stadium.
It meant a seventh consecutive last-16 exit for Arsenal, who had Laurent Koscielny sent off after Theo Walcott rewardrd a spirited first-half display with the opening goal.

Robert Lewandowski won and converted a 55th minute penalty as Koscielny was dismissed and, as at the Allianz Arena, Arsenal collapsed in the absence of the French defender to suffer the heaviest aggregate defeat inflicted upon an English team in Champions League history.

Wenger was the subject of fan protests asking him to step down both outside the ground and at the site of Arsenal's former Highbury home before kick-off and the sight of Arjen Robben and Douglas Costa picking off his feeble defensive line before Arturo Vidal added a late brace heightened the sense that his race is run.
Carlo Ancelotti's Bayern are still in contention to repeat their 2013 treble, standing in stark contrast to Arsenal and Wenger as they stagger from one disappointment to another.
Alexis Sanchez returned to the hosts' starting line-up three days after being benched for the 3-1 defeat at Liverpool amid widespread reports of a training-ground row.
The Chile star was set to line up at centre-forward but Danny Welbeck was taken ill during the warm-up, meaning a reshuffle with Olivier Giroud coming in to lead the line.

Sanchez's commitments to his hastily assigned defensive duties on the left was tenuous at best during the opening stages as Bayern found joy down that flank – albeit after the action was delayed by the away fans throwing vast amounts of toilet roll on the field.
Visiting goalkeeper Manuel Neuer was out to thwart Walcott after the England winger sprung the offside trap, while Giroud grappled with Mats Hummels to glance wide in the 13th minute.
But Neuer was caught out by a rasping Walcott strike that he could only punch into the roof of his net.

Xabi Alonso was fortunate not to be punished for an ill-judged challenge on the goalscorer before the 27-year-old attempted to repeat his earlier finish by thrashing Shkodran Mustafi's throughball into the side-netting.
Lewandowski should have restored Bayern's four-goal aggregate advantage but pulled Robben's chipped pass wide on the volley and they went in behind at the break.
Early in the second period, Mustafi fizzed another fine low pass towards the Bayern box, although Giroud could not get over Aaron Ramsey's chipped cross and headed beyond the crossbar.

Faint hopes of the improbable we extinguished when Koscielny pushed Lewandowski to the floor 10 yards from goal and the additional assistant official advised Anastasios Sidiropoulos to upgrade his initial yellow card to a red.

The Poland international kept his calm to drill home the spot kick, sending David Ospina the wrong way, and he almost had a second on the end of a slick one-two with Vidal – Bayern turning on the style in front of their buoyant travelling support.
Robben gave them the lead on the night, intercepting a poor Ospina clearance and capitalising on the resulting disarray to slot into the corner.
Lewandowski then hit the post and the leggy 10-man hosts did not welcome a fresh Costa coming on to gallop towards goal from the right and make it three in the 78th minute.

Vidal's classily chipped fourth as the Arsenal defence crumbled terribly demonstrated the swagger of a side still chasing glory in three competitions and the Chile international had the brace his compatriot Sanchez might have hoped for five minutes from time, accepting Costa's pass with Ospina once again horribly exposed.

commentary: FULL-TIME! Juventus are held to a 1-1 draw against Udinese, which is the first time that the visitors have shared the spoils this season in Serie A. Zapata opened the scoring for Delneri's men, with Bonucci responding in the second half, but the hosts will be disappointed to have not taken all three points. Allegri's side struggled to get out of first gear and consider themselves lucky to have avoided defeat. That's all that we have time for, we hope to see you again next time.

Great block from Agyemang-Badu! The Ghanaian midfielder slides in fantastically to deny Higuain's goal-bound shot the chance to test Karnezis. That could be a game-defining intervention from the Udinese man.

Juventus patiently probe from side-to-side, as Allegri's men try to craft a late chance. Alex Sandro feeds the ball into Khedira, but Hallfredsson shuffles across well to pick up possession. The visitors are still trying to take all three points, were it not for their passing letting them down.
There are four minutes of stoppage time.

Udinese are happy to wind down the clock a little, with Karnezis taking his time over his kicking now. Given that Rincon has come into the game for Dybala, Allegri might even be happy to just protect a point at this stage of proceedings, as the hosts haven't been afraid to stream forward on the counter.
Dybala is withdrawn for the away side, with Rincon coming into the midfield for the last few minutes.

Karnezis is able to easily claim a cross into the box, with Udinese escaping immediately on the break. Ryder Matos goes forward and slides a pass forward into Jankto, but the hosts' onrushing midfielder is caught offside. Delneri's men are still searching for a winner.
Perica takes his leave after a busy performance, with Ryder Matos having the dying stages of this game within which to make an impact.

Pjaca breaks down the left and flights a great cross towards Mandzukic at the back post, but Jankto tracks back brilliantly to direct a headed clearance away. Juventus win themselves another corner as a result, but Pjanic's ball is headed away by Angella. Udinese try to launch a break immediately, but Dybala recovers to put the ball into touch.

Dybala tries to bend a cross in from the right-hand side, but the Argentine's delivery balloons wildly high and wide of the target. He won't want to see a replay of that. We're well into the last 10 minutes and it appears that Udinese are going to be able to secure a valuable point.

Zapata drives down the left-hand side, following a mistake from Benatia. The Colombian striker tries to pick out Jankto at the back post for the hosts, but Bonucci tracks back and slides in well to direct the ball wide of his own post. The resulting corner is swept in towards the near post, but Mandzukic nods clear.

Jankto angles in a free-kick delivery from the left, but Benatia half-clears, with Udinese unable to generate any late opportunities. Juventus are really looking hurried now, with the visitors having around 10 minutes to try and avoid drawing their first game of this Serie A campaign.
Pjaca gets booked for making a stupid challenge on almost the edge of his own penalty area.
De Paul is withdrawn for the home side, with Angella taking his leave. That may mean that Udinese are going on the defensive now.

Juventus are showing a little more urgency now, as we head into the final quarter of an hour at the Dacia Arena. Samir makes an easy headed interception to deny a ball over the top from Khedira, before the Brazilian does well to prevent Pjaca from angling a cross in from the right-hand side.
Cuadrado jogs off after a frustrating afternoon, with Pjaca given a chance to make himself a hero.

Great challenge from Danilo! Higuain manages to feed a throughball flick into the path of Cuadrado, with the Colombia international threatening to shoot from a tight angle. The Udinese defender covers across and slides in well to make a flying block. Juventus have looked a lot more dangerous in this second half.
