SAVED! Smart run from Rashford, but a bit selfish in the end as he tries to beat Schmeichel from a tight angle, when he had Mata in all sorts of space at the far post, again getting behind Fuchs.
It was a nice pass from Mkhitaryan to provide the assist, but Leicester didn't exactly make it hard on him.

HOW SIMPLE WAS THAT?! The champions are being torn to bits! Mata has all the time he wants on the right to pick out Mkhitaryan in the area, in all sorts of space, and he threads a return pass through with Fuchs neglecting to track the Spaniards run. Mata takes the througball in stride and produces a simple finish to probably put this game to bed.

Leicester need to find their voice again. They appear to be playing with more of a 4-3-3 formation now, but they haven't exactly come out of the break with the sort of urgency you would expect to see from them.
Back underway at the King Power!
Not entirely clear if this is by choice or force, but Jose Mourinho brings on Daley Blind at the expense of Rojo.
Demarai Gray is also brought on, with Okazaki giving way.
Two changes made by Ranieri at the interval, the first of which sees Andy King replace Musa.

The match looked poised to head scoreless into the interval following what was a largely nondescript first half, but quick-fire goals from Henrikh Mkhitaryan and Zlatan Ibrahimovic have the champions in turmoil, and United heading for a big three points.
HALF-TIME: LEICESTER CITY 0-2 MANCHESTER UNITED.
There will be two minutes added on at the end of this first half.
Valencia did very well there to beat Fuchs and get the cross through to Ibrahimovic.

MAKE IT TWO! That's the class he provides! As smart a finish as you'd like from Ibrahimovic, who places a first-time strike through the legs of Morgan and back in at the far post, on the end of a smart pick out from Valencia!
Smart flick from Smalling to pick out the run of Mkhitaryan, as he's credited with the assist.

UNITED HAVE THE BREAKTHROUGH! Huth makes a very poor judgment call as he tries to step forward and challenge Mkhitaryan, who latched onto a flicked-on header from Smalling, but the United forward nudges the ball beyond him with ease before beating Morgan for pace and finishing coolly into the top corner!
Fuchs clatters through Mata to pick up a yellow card, the second for a Leicester player and third haneded out total in this first half.

Leicester are starting to get hemmed in at the back, largely due to a gulf of space between midfield and attack. Drinkwater and Ndidi are dropping deep to defend, but neither Okazaki or Vardy is following their lead to offer a link out from the back.

United remain in the ascendency as we approach half-time. They're poking and prodding in possession, but full credit to Leicester who are making them work really hard to carve out even the slightest of openings.

SMART SAVE! That's much more like it from the visitors! Some crisp, forward passing sees the ball worked into Rashford in the area. He cuts inside and drives a low strike towards the near post, but Schmeiched does expertly to get down in a flash and parry with a strong hand.

United are enjoying a prominent spell in possession, but it doesn't look as though anyone has that gamebreaking ability right now. They need someone to take charge and it hasn't happened yet. Leicester aren't keeping as much of the ball, but Vardy certainly looks in the mood today.

STAT: Manchester United are currently on the longest unbeaten away run in the Premier League (six games – W4 D2 L0). This is their best away run in the competition since a run of seven games between November 2014 and February 2015.

DREADFUL CHALLENGE! That had some elements of a sending off in it from Mata, who flies through Vardy at full speed to send the striker dangerously to ground. Luckily Vardy is able to pop right back up, and that may have been what saved Mata from a red.

Simpson really labours off the pitch, visibly in a lot of pain as he limps toward the touchline. It could be a case of having to walk off the pain, much like when you stub your toe, but it does look a bit ominous for him at the moment.

Simpson fouls Ibrahimovic at the halfway line, but it's the right-back who comes out worse for wear. It looked like he had his toe stepped on by the United striker following the challenge, and he goes down in a heap after the whistle sounds, before requiring some attention from the training staff.

VITAL CHALLENGE! Vardy makes a tidy run forward before turning and playing through Musa. The winger has space in the area, but he's unable to open up and get around Bailly, who puts in a terrific challenge to send the ball behind for a corner. United break the other way following the set-piece, and Rashford is presented with a decent chance, but lifts a first-time effort over the bar.
STAT: Leicester City have won just one of their last 17 games against Man Utd in all competitions (D3 L13) – 5-3 in this exact fixture in September 2014.

BETTER! Musa wins a free-kick on the right following a Rojo foul, and the subsequent delivery is flicked on by Vardy at the near post before being met by Morgan, but his header smacks off a red shirt and drifts behind for a corner!

United need to adopt more width into their approach. Their full-backs have hardly been afforded the chance to get forward as possession has been sporadic at best. Leicester are starting to work it out wide a bit more and they're growing in stature because of it.
Okazaki and Vardy have hardly been involved thus far, and the same can be said about Ibrahimovic, whose only real impact has been an off the ball scuffle with Drinkwater.

It's getting a bit congested as neither side has been able to find the quality needed on the front foot to get into the final third. Mahrez is looking lively for Leicester on the right, but even he's struggled to pick out a good final ball.

There's an excellent atmosphere inside the stadium, one which these Foxes need to capitalise on. This place proved to be something of a fortress for them last season. They need to recreate that magic once again and give their supporters reason to celebrate.

STAT: Leicester are only the fifth Premier League team to fail to score in their opening four matches of a calendar year, following Newcastle (2008), Swansea (failed to score in their first four Premier League games in August & September 2011), Hull (2014) and Aston Villa (2015) – no team has ever failed to score in their first five.

Rojo produces the first shot of the match, but it winds up proving a comfortable stop from Schmeichel on the volley, which lacked real pace or direction. There's been a nice tempo to this match in the early stages.

Leicester apply some decent pressure with subsequent corners, before United eventually win the ball back and look to break. Mata skips forward before being tugged back rather cynically by Drinkwater, who picks up an early yellow card.

Bit of a timid start from the Leicester backline. United are unable to take advantage, or really create anything stemming from that bit of miscommunication between Huth and Fuchs, but it's a clear indicator of the fragile mental state of the Foxes at the moment.
AND THEY'RE OFF! United, in red, get us underway, attacking right to left, with Leicester in blue.

Jose Mourinho makes three changes from the draw with Hull on Wednesday. Eric Bailly makes his first start back from international duty, replacing the injured Phil Jones, while Chris Smalling also comes into defence, pushing Marcos Rojo to left-back and Daley Blind to the bench. Michael Carrick is also dropped from the XI, with Juan Mata taking his place.

Claudio Ranieri makes two changes from the defeat at Turf Moor on Tuesday. Ahmed Musa comes in on the wing in place of Marc Albrighton, while Shinji Okazaki is brought on to form a strike partnership with Jamie Vardy, at the expense of Demarai Gray.
SUBS: Martial, Lingard, Carrick, Blind, Young, Romero, Fellaini.
MANCHESTER UNITED (4-2-3-1): De Gea; Valencia, Bailly, Smalling, Rojo; Herrera, Pogba; Mkhitaryan, Mata, Rashford; Ibrahimovic.
SUBS: Chilwell, King, Albrighton, Kapustka, Zieler, Gray, Benalouane.
LEICESTER CITY (4-4-2): Schmeichel; Simpson, Huth, Morgan, Fuchs; Mahrez, Drinkwater, Ndidi, Musa; Vardy, Okazaki.
CONFIRMED TEAM NEWS:

Despite their lengthy unbeaten run in the league, Jose Mourinho’s outfit remain four points back of the Champions League places, and have hit a bit of a rocky spell with three successive draws. Needless to say, a win is crucial for both these teams, which should make for some excellent viewing.

Similarly, Manchester United were held scoreless by Hull City on Wednesday, however, contrastingly, the Red Devils have not lost a Premier League match since late October, a run which has extended through 14 league games.

The Foxes are still looking for their first Premier League win and goal of 2017, as they have been held scoreless with just one point through four matches. They’re just one point up on the bottom-three as a result, but can create a bit of breathing room with a win today.

Leicester created some magic in this fixture two years ago, securing a famous 5-3 win over Manchester United on the back of an inspired Jamie Vardy performance, the same bit of inspiration they must have today to get their season back on track.

Hello and welcome to live coverage from the King Power Stadium as Leicester City desperately try to distance themselves from the bottom-three when they host a Manchester United side aiming to close the gap on the top-four!
news: Manchester United gave their top-four aspirations a major boost as they cruised to a 3-0 win at Premier League champions Leicester City on Sunday.

Goals from Henrikh Mkhitaryan, Zlatan Ibrahimovic and Juan Mata brought an end to a run of three consecutive league draws for Jose Mourinho's side, who are now two points behind fourth-placed Arsenal.

Leicester had lost their last three games in the top flight and only beaten United once in 17 previous meetings, but Claudio Ranieri's side produced the kind of combative display that underpinned their stunning success last term for much of the first half.

That was until United seized control of the match with two goals in the space of two minutes, Mkhitaryan breaking the deadlock with a powerful run and finish before Ibrahimovic became the oldest player to reach 15 goals in a Premier League season at the age of 35 years and 125 days.

Leicester fans had called for Mata to be sent off for a first-half challenge on Jamie Vardy and their frustrations were compounded when the Spain international made it 3-0 after half-time, having combined brilliantly with Mkhitaryan.

The match became a procession for United in the second half as they responded to weekend defeats for Arsenal and Liverpool to give themselves real hope of clawing their way back into the Champions League places.
For Leicester, a defeat in their 2,000th game in England's top flight leaves them firmly in a relegation fight, with the gap to the bottom three still only one point.

United interestingly opted to match Leicester's 4-4-2 from the start, with Marcus Rashford pushed up alongside Ibrahimovic, and both sides cancelled each other out in a scrappy and uneventful opening 20 minutes.
It was Rashford who missed United's first presentable chance, side-footing over the crossbar after a brilliant run from Mkhitaryan and some good interplay with Mata.

United's frustrations were beginning to show against an initially impressive Leicester rearguard, with Mata a little fortunate to escape with only a yellow card for his late lunge on Vardy, although Kasper Schmeichel made an excellent save low to his right from another close-range Rashford strike.
But just as the teams looked set to go into the break level, United struck in ruthless fashion.
Mkhitaryan netted first, prodding the ball past Robert Huth, racing into the penalty area and firing right-footed beyond Schmeichel despite the goalkeeper getting a touch.
Eighty-eight seconds later, Ibrahimovic doubled the lead, steering Antonio Valencia's low cross from the right back across Schmeichel and into the net after finding clear space 12 yards from goal.
Ranieri brought on Andy King and Demarai Gray at the interval in a bid to inject some life into Leicester's fight, but United needed only another four minutes to quell that resistance.
Mata fed Mkhitaryan on the edge of the area and ran through to meet the Armenia captain's sublime reverse pass, before slotting beneath Schmeichel from six yards.
Riyad Mahrez whipped a free-kick narrowly wide but Mata should have made it 4-0 when he contrived to lift the ball into Schmeichel's grateful grasp after springing the rusty Leicester offside trap.

United knocked the ball around with ease in the closing stages, though Mkhitaryan skied a half-chance to make it 4-0, while Leicester now turn their attentions to a potentially crucial week in which they face an FA Cup replay against rivals Derby County and a league showdown with fellow relegation candidates Swansea City.

commentary: That's all from us for today folks, thanks for joining us and we hope you'll be able to join us again soon.

Lyon take a two goal lead into the second leg in Rome in a week’s time thanks to a superb second half fightback, led by Nabil Fekir and Alexandre Lacazette who both scored outstanding individual goals.
Full-time: Lyon 4-2 Roma
Substitution Edin Džeko Stephan El Shaarawy
Valbuena with the assist for that goal as he rolled the ball into Lacazette’s feet.

GOOOOOAAAALLLLLLL!!!! A stunning goal from Lacazette!!!! The striker finally gets on the scoresheet with a fabulous goal, as he fires the ball into the top corner from 25 yards out with a ferocious strike.

Emerson steals possession away from Lacazette inside the Lyon half and hits a powerful left-footed effort towards goal from 25 yards out, but once again it’s straight at Lopez who catches it in with ease.

The ball breaks to Tolisso after bouncing off Strootman and the midfielder goes for goal from 30 yards out, but his well-struck effort goes narrowly wide of Alisson’s goal. Lyon certainly look the more likely of the two sides to score in the closing stages.

Manolas brings down Lacazette 30 yards out from goal with a clumsy challenge but Valbuena’s shot from the free-kick comes off the head of Dzeko in the wall. Manolas was pretty fortunate to avoid a second yellow card there though.
Chance! Lacazette is played clean through on goal and goes round Alisson, but his touch is too heavy and forces him wide allowing Roma to get back and defend in numbers.
Another change for Roma as Nainggolan is replaced by Diego Perotti.
Valbuena puts a cross in towards the back post but Lacazette isn’t on the same wavelength as his teammate and the cross goes harmlessly out for a goal kick.
Another change for Roma now as De Rossi is replaced by Leandro Paredes.

Strootman picks out Dzeko at the far post with a first-time cross with the outside of his boot, but the ball is too high for the striker who can only head it straight up, allowing Lopez to rise highest and catch it above his head.
Huge appeals for a Lyon penalty as Tolisso goes down inside the box under a challenge from Manolas, but Anthony Taylor decides there wasn’t enough contact and points for a goal kick.

Half-chance for Roma! Peres is picked out by Nainggolan inside the right-hand edge of the penalty box and the winger ignores the support of Dzeko and Salah in the middle and goes for goal, but his left-footed effort is too close to Lopez who hangs on low to his right.
Lyon are making a third and final change now with Maxwell Cornet replacing the impressive Ghezzal.

GOOOOAAAAALLLLL!!! What a goal from Fekir!!!!! The substitute has only been on the pitch for a matter of minutes, but he turns away from Fazio 25 yards out from goal before driving into the box and cutting inside onto his left foot, before slotting the ball into the bottom corner from 15 yards out to give Lyon the lead once again.
Tousart played a simple pass into Fekir's feet, but that goal was all his own work in truth.
Nabil Fekir is coming on now for his 100th Lyon appearance. He's replacing Mammana with Gonalons dropping into defence.

Two wonderful saves!! Alisson makes two superb saves within a minute, first denying Lacazette with a flying save high to his left from a well-struck long-range effort, before tipping Valbuena’s curling 18-yard effort narrowly over the bar.

Gonalons steals possession away from Peres as he looks to get in behind the Lyon defence down the left-hand side, before Fazio has to turn the ball awkwardly behind for a corner moments later to prevent Lacazette being clean through on goal at the other end.
Manolas becomes the latest player to go into the book for a late challenge on Valbuena.

Save!! Gonalons drills a low effort towards goal from 25 yards out which takes a wicked deflection, wrong-footing Alisson, but the Roma keeper reacts well to get down to his left and palm the ball away from danger.

Valbuena picks out Ghezzal who is in space 25 yards out from goal on the right-hand side. The winger chooses to ignore the support outside him though and curls a left-footed effort towards goal, but it’s straight at Alisson who holds on to it with ease.
Salah shows his pace there as he turns away from Tousart just inside the Roma half and the Lyon midfielder cynically pulls him back, earning himself a yellow card.

Lyon have all the momentum in their favour at the moment and look as if they could score every time they go forward. Roma do still look a threat on the counter-attack though, particularly with the pace of Salah.

Lacazette turns Fazio brilliantly inside the right-hand edge of the penalty box, but the Roma centre-back does superbly well to stick with him and make a good sliding block as he looks to test Alisson with a low shot from a tight angle.
Ghezzal skips past a couple of Roma defenders with ease inside the penalty box, but Fazio stands up tall and makes a good tackle on the winger, who has certainly impressed so far today.
This game is being played at an extraordinary speed and tempo now, with Lyon enjoying a good spell of possession as their fans get louder and louder.

Gonalons gives the ball away cheaply deep inside his own half and Dzeko appears to have space to shoot left-footed from just inside the Lyon penalty box, but Mammana does well to get across and block the effort, bailing his captain out in the process.

That goal really has brought the home fans to life at the start of the second half, first cheering their side on before greeting De Rossi with a loud chorus of boos as he lines up a free-kick from close to half way.

Ghezzal whips in a dangerous cross from the right which is superbly cleared by a recovering Manolas, before Roma break forward at pace through Dzeko and Salah, before Strootman forces Lopez into a smart save low to his right to keep the scores level. It really is end-to-end stuff at the start of the second half.
It was lovely one-touch build up play between Lacazette and Tolisso that created the space for the shot.

GOOOAAAAALLLLLL!!! Wonderful goal from Corentin Tolisso!! The midfielder exchanges a lovely one-two with Lacazette just outside the Roma penalty box before firing a fierce effort past Alisson into the left-hand corner from 20 yards out to bring Lyon level.
Kick-off! Referee Anthony Taylor blows his whistle and Lyon get the second half underway.
Lyon are making a change at the break with Christophe Jallet replacing Rafael, who picked up a knock in the first half.

Lyon manager Bruno Genesio will certainly not want to take a deficit into the second leg at the Stadio Olimpico, and may well turn to Nabil Fekir early on in the second half in attempt to get back on level terms, while his opposite number Luciano Spalletti will be hoping his side can get another away goal to take back to Rome.

Roma lead at the Parc Olympique Lyonnais thanks to goals from Salah and Fazio after Diakhaby had given Lyon an early lead. Both sides have had further opportunities to score in a half which has been played at a pretty high intensity, although Roma have created the better chances and deservedly go into the break ahead.
Half-time: Lyon 1-2 Roma
We’re into two minutes of stoppage time at the end of the first half.

Jesus brings down Ghezzal with another clumsy challenge just outside the Roma penalty box and Valbuena once again stands over the free-kick. This time though he goes for goal but Alisson reads it well and gets across towards his near post to catch it comfortably.

Ghezzal plays a lovely Crossfield ball towards Valbuena who brings it down on his chest before laying the ball off to Lacazette on the edge of the box, but the striker has very few options and ends up rolling the ball back towards Maxime Gonalons who hits a tame effort straight at Alisson.

Emerson becomes the first player to go into the book for a foul on Rafael close to the corner flag on the right-hand side. Valbuena whips in the resultant free-kick but Fazio gets up well at the near post to head the ball clear.

Valbuena and Lacazette link up well down the left-hand side before the latter is tackled by Manolas as he looks to get down the outside of him. Lyon have responded well to falling behind but are struggling to create any real threat on Alisson’s goal.

Salah breaks forward at pace and plays an early cross towards Nainggolan on the edge of the box, but the ball is just taken away from the Belgian as he looks to hit an ambitious first-time volley towards goal.
Roma have certainly looked the more likely to score since drawing level earlier in the half, and Luciano Spalletti will be delighted with the way his side have played in the last 20 minutes.
De Rossi had stayed wide having taken the corner, and put in a wonderful dipping cross for Fazio to head home.

GOOOOAAAALLLLL!!! Fazio heads Roma ahead!! De Rossi swings in a deep cross from the right-hand side and Fazio, who had stayed forward following a corner moments earlier, arrives late at the back post to head powerfully past Lopez from six yards out.

Chance for Roma! Salah plays Strootman in down the right-hand edge of the penalty box and the midfielder appears to only have Lopez to beat, but Lyon get back in numbers to get a block in and prevent their goalkeeper being called into action.

Ghezzal brings down Emerson Palmieri 30 yards out from goal and it appears as though Rafael landed awkwardly as he jumped to avoid the Roma midfielder. The right-back is down receiving some treatment but it looks as though he’s going to be able to continue.
This game is certainly not lacking intensity with both side committing plenty of numbers forward whenever they have possession, and both sides look equally dangerous in the final third.

Strootman brings down Ghezzal just outside the Roma penalty box handing Lyon a free-kick in a dangerous area, but Ghezzal can only strike it straight into the wall, before Lucas Tousart is flagged offside as he attempts an acrobatic effort from eight yards out on the rebound.
Lopez reacts quickly to come off his line and smother Dzeko’s close-range effort from a tight angle on the left-hand side, but the flag goes up so the goal wouldn’t have stood anyway.
Roma will be delighted with the way they have bounced back from conceding that opening goal, but the equaliser doesn’t seem to have dampened the spirits of the home fans, who are still pretty vocal.
Federico Fazio has been credited with the assist, but it was more of a clearing header forward which led to Diakhaby slipping over.

GOOOAAAAALLLLLL!!! Salah brings Roma level!! Having given Lyon the lead, Diakhaby gifts Roma an equaliser as he loses his balance, handing possession straight to Salah 35 yards out from goal, and the Egyptian winger runs clean through on goal unopposed before slotting the ball past Lopez.
Roma haven’t quite got going yet but they’ve responded well to going a goal behind and they certainly look the more dangerous side now.

Chance for Dzeko! Salah gets in behind the Lyon defence down the right-hand side and stands up a cross towards Dzeko who is completely unmarked on the edge of the six yard box, but the ball is fractionally too high and he can only head the ball onto the roof of the net.

Roma look to hit back though as Dzeko holds the ball up well before laying it off to Kevin Strootman on the edge of the box. The midfielder though chooses not to shoot and finds Peres in space on the right-hand edge of the penalty box and the right-back does shoot, but the effort is straight at Lopez who hangs on at the second attempt.
Lyon flood forwards in numbers again and Lacazette lays the ball off to Valbuena who has space to shoot 12 yards out from goal, but Juan Jesus does well to get across and block the first-time effort.
That goal has certainly lifted the home crowd who were pretty quiet for the opening few minutes, but they’re making themselves heard now.
The initial delivery from Valbuena wasn’t the best but Rafael did superbly well to get his head to it and flick it into Diakhaby’s path.

GOOOOAAAALLLL!!! Mouctar Diakhaby gives Lyon the lead!! Mathieu Valbuena swings in a free-kick from the right-hand side after a foul on Lacazette, and Rafael flicks a header across the face of goal towards the far post, where the centre-back knocks the ball in from six yards out.
Dzeko gets into space down the left-hand edge of the Lyon penalty box and picks out Salah who is unmarked 12 yards out from goal, but he rushes his first-time shot and blasts it high over the bar.

Save! Nainggolan strikes a fierce effort towards goal from just outside the Lyon penalty box and Anthony Lopez has to spring to his right to keep it out before Mohamed Salah is penalised for handball as he slips looking to get to the rebound.

Alexandre Lacazette is well tackled by Nainggolan after a neat piece of link-up play with Rafael down the right. Lyon will certainly want to get their centre forward into the game as much as possible.

Radja Nainggolan looks to play a first-time ball over the top of the Lyon defence for Dzeko to chase after a good run infield from Bruno Peres, but the striker fails to bring the ball under control. It looks as though Nainggolan is playing just in behind Dzeko early on though.
Kick-off! Edin Dzeko gets the game underway for Roma.
The players are making their way out onto the pitch, kick-off is not far away now.
The two sides last met in the 2006/07 Champions League last 16, when Francesco Totti, who is included on the Roma bench today, scored as Roma secured a 2-0 aggregate win across the two legs.

Roma meanwhile make four changes to their side that was beaten by Napoli, with Bruno Peres, Emerson Palmieri and Mohamed Salah replacing Antonio Rudiger, Diego Perotti and Stephan El Shaarawy outfield, while Alisson Becker replaces Wojciech Szczesny in goal.
Lyon make just two changes from their 1-1 draw with Bordeaux last time out, with Rachid Ghezzal and Mathieu Valbuena coming in on either wing for Nabil Fekir and Memphis Depay.
Subs: Szczesny, Vermaelen, Mario Rui, Paredes, Perotti, Totti, El Shaarawy
Roma (3-4-3): Alisson; Manolas, Fazio, Juan Jesus; Bruno, De Rossi, Strootman, Emerson; Nainggolan, Dzeko, Salah
Subs: Gorgelin, Jallet, Yanga-Mbiwa, Sergi Darder, Ferri, Fekir, Cornet
Team news: Lyon (4-3-3): Lopes; Rafael, Mammana, Diakhaby, Morel; Tolisso, Gonalons, Tousart; Ghezzal, Lacazette, Valbuena

They do though come into the game on the back of a disappointing 2-1 home defeat to Napoli in Serie A, a result that left them 12 points behind leaders Juventus, putting a huge dent in their title ambitions.

Roma meanwhile have lost just once in Europe this season, a 1-0 home defeat to Villarreal in the second leg of the last 32, but the narrow margin of the defeat was enough to see them into the last 16 after a 4-0 first-leg win in Spain.
Their domestic form is equally as impressive with just one defeat in their last five Ligue 1 matches, leaving them fourth in the table, although they are fifteen points adrift of third place Nice.
Lyon progressed to this stage of the competition with an emphatic 11-2 aggregate win over AZ Alkmaar in the last 32, having finished third in Champions League Group H behind Juventus and Sevilla.
Hello and welcome to live coverage of the Europa League last 16 first-leg tie between Lyon and Roma at the Parc Olympique Lyonnais.
news: Substitute Nabil Fekir and top scorer Alexandre Lacazette netted second-half strikes to earn Lyon an enthralling 4-2 win over Roma in the first leg of their round-of-16 tie in France.

Fekir struck less than four minutes after coming off the bench, dancing past two opponents before beating goalkeeper Alisson, while Lacazette grabbed a fourth with a stunning long-range strike deep into stoppage time.

Lyon went a goal up early on when Mouctar Diakhaby found the net after Mathieu Valbuena's free-kick from the right, but his error contributed to Mohamed Salah and Federico Fazio turning things around before half-time.
Corentin Tolisso then struck early in the second half to begin the hosts' revival, before Fekir and Lacazette sealed the win late on in a hugely entertaining encounter.

The Ligue 1 giants will have fancied their chances heading into Thursday's encounter following their excellent form at the Parc Olympique Lyonnais in recent weeks, with Bruno Genesio's men netting an impressive 24 goals in their last five home games.
Roma, meanwhile, were relatively low on confidence after winning just one out of their last four matches in all competitions, losing the other three.
Alisson came to the fore to keep out Maxime Gonalons' deflected long-range effort, before pulling off another smart stop to keep out a powerful strike from Lacazette.

commentary: Well, that’s all from me for now. Until next time. goodbye!

With Manchester United having been held to a goalless draw by Hull City, however, Everton have lost no ground as they aim to hunt down the top six. They remain planted in seventh place, while Stoke move up to ninth.

And deservedly so, with neither side truly having the quality to outmatch the other, though Lee Grant pulled off an outstanding save to deny Tom Davies late on, after Saido Berahino had been denied a debut goal by Ramiro Funes Mori at the other end.
FULL TIME! It’s all over at the Bet365 stadium, where it has finished all square between Stoke and Everton, who have to settle for a share of the spoils.
Adam’s free-kick is directed straight into the wall, however. There will be three minutes of added time in total...
Reckless play from Everton, who concede possession high upfield before Schneiderlin, rather unfortunately, is deemed to have felled Barahino 30 yards out from goal...
Another change for Stoke. Off comes Arnautovic, and on comes Julien Ngoy.
Really composed play from Lookman, who gets clear of his marker before slipping a pass into McCarthy, but the Ireland midfielder cannot find Davies.
Another fantastic stop by Grant, who keeps out Funes Mori’s effort. It wouldn’t have counted, though, as the Argentine had strayed offside.

SO CLOSE! What a save from Grant! That was outstanding from Stoke’s goalkeeper, who somehow tipped Davies’ header away. Lookman latched onto the rebound, but his effort flashes across the face of goal.
CHANCE! Funes Mori loses the run of Berahino, but atones for his error, making sure that the Stoke forward can’t get his debut goal by clearing the ball off the line.
A wicked deflection off McCarthy makes life difficult for Everton from another Adam cross, and Williams is forced into evasive action, unceremoniously heading the ball out of play.
That’s a booking for Bardsley, and it is merely for an accumulation of fouls committed by the former Sunderland man, who on this occasion dragged down Lookman.

For all Stoke’s flair players, it has to be said that the hosts’ best chances have come courtesy of the Adam and Crouch combination, and the two veterans almost link up again as the former puts a dangerous delivery into the box, but Crouch is just unable to stretch fair enough.
CLOSE! A difficult header for Schneiderlin, but the ex-Southampton captain manages to direct it goalwards, though it lacks the power to beat Grant.

End-to-end play here. First, Funes Mori does well to intercept Arnautovic’s pass, and in turn clears the ball into the path of Coleman who, after combining with Lukaku and Barkley, gets free down the right and wins a free-kick...
Something of a nasty tackle from Adam, who goes in late on Barkley, catching the midfielder’s knee with a stray boot. Barkley looks okay to carry on, though...

SAVE! Well, what an introduction that would have been for Lookman! With his first touch, the former Charlton youngtser went for goal from an acute angle, and only an instinctive stop from Grant low to his right prevented Everton taking the lead.
Koeman responds to Berahino’s introduction by making a change of his own, with Ademloa Lookman replacing Kevin Mirallas.

Pinball in the Everton area, as Adam’s free-kick causes havoc. Funes Mori appeared to have been dragged back by Crouch, but there was nothing doing for the official. However, Everton eventually manage to escape unscathed.
Here is the new boy then, as Saido Berahino comes on to make his Stoke debut. Joe Allen is the player making way…
A quick counter from Everton almost results in a chance. Davies drives forward, his cross aimed in to Lukaku, but Bardsley recovers to make a timely intervention.
Two chances in quick-succession for Crouch. First, he heads over from Afellay’s corner before, moments later, he cannot direct his effort on target from Arnautovic’s cross.
Reckless from Davies, who concedes possession before barging Adam over. Stoke’s midfielder powers i a swerving free-kick, and Robles has no choice but to tip it over.
Fine skill from Arnautovic, as he gets the better of Williams down the left. His cross deflects towards the touchline, but Schneiderlin manages to get back and hook it clear.

AUDACIOUS! A classic Adam effort. The Scot, like he did against Chelsea in the past, met the ball at the half-way line, and wasted no time in hammering a first-time strike goalwards. Fortunately for Everton, Robles had predicted it, and got back in time to make a save, albeit a far from convincing one.

Well, moments after being caught by Adam, McCarthy shows he is not shy to put a tackle in. Arnautovic is on the receiving end, and manages to get out of the way before McCarthy’s sliding tackle takes the ball cleanly out of play.
Everton’s new system seems to have halted Stoke somewhat, with Crouch starved of service so far. Saido Berahino is warming up, and we may well see him introduced sooner rather than later...
That’s a crunching challenge from Adam, who dives in from behind on McCarthy. The Scot appeared to win the ball, though did take the man in the process, and Pawson rightly awards a free-kick.

Classy play from Schneiderlin, who has started to grow into this game. He picks out Barkley with a clever pass, and the England midfielder proceeds to burst forward. He has Mirallas to his left, but elects to shoot, but his tame effort is easily handled by Grant.
Good work from Schneiderlin, who tracks the run of Allen and puts in a strong challenge, resulting in an Everton goal kick.
That change suggests a change in shape for the visitors, who appear to have switched to a diamond formation of sorts now.

Welcome back! We’ve had a change from Everton at the interval, with Koeman having replaced Mason Holgate - who had struggled to cope with the pace and movement of Arnautovic. James McCarthy has come on in his place.
It has left the game perfectly poised heading into the second-half, and both sides will be confident of going on to claim the points.

Stoke deservedly took the lead through Peter Crouch’s 100th Premier League goal, and could well have extended their advantage if not for a fine stop from Joel Robles. However, Everton penned them back, with Ryan Shawcross turning the ball into his own net under pressure from Romelu Lukaku.
HALF-TIME! A really entertaining first half at Stoke, where the scores are level at 1-1. There’s been plenty of talking points, though...

WHAT A SAVE! An error from Barkley almost costs Everton dear, as it allows Crouch to feed Arnautovic with a sublime flick-on. The Austrian looks all-set to put Stoke back into the lead with the final kick of the half, but Robles comes out brilliantly to once again deny the hosts’ No.10.
Crouch is furious now, though it is difficult to imagine why. He blatantly tugged the shirt of Coleman, and Pawson had no choice but to award the free-kick Everton’s way.
Nothing comes of it, though, and Stoke regain possession courtesy of a strong challenge from Whelan on his compatriot Coleman. Two minutes of stoppage time to go...
Stoke are just having to sit deep and contain Everton at the moment, as we rapidly approach half-time. Funes Mori blasts an effort goalwards, and it is deflected wide for a corner...
CLOSE! Everton are pressing now, and very nearly have a second when Barkley’s cross is parried up into the air by Grant. Davies latches onto the loose ball, but cannot direct his effort goalwards.

It was, in fairness to the officials, a confusing moment - though clearly the goal should have stood. Coleman got free down the right, and cut onto his left foot before drifting in a cross. Lukaku may well have been in an offside position, but it mattered little, as it was Shawcross who turned the ball into the net.

GOOOOOAALLLL!!! Drama here! Everton had the ball in the back of the net, and Pawson seemed to allow the goal to stand. The linesman had ruled out the goal for offside, but - after a brief discussion - Pawson comes to the correct decision, and the goal will stand.

Very nearly an opening for Everton, as Bardsley gets back just in time to prevent Mirallas’ pass getting into Lukaku. From the next move, Mirallas again drives forward, this time winning a free-kick… though that comes to nothing.
Pieters appears to have picked up a knock, though the full-back is carrying on for now. Muniesia is, however, warming up on the touchline.
Lukaku has scored four goals in his six previous appearances for Everton against Stoke in the league. However, he has had to feed off scraps so far this evening...

SAVE! That’s a great stop from Robles, who rushes out to deny Arnautovic what would have been a certain goal. Adam did well to find some space and pick the pass, with Holgate again dragged in. Fortunately for Everton, their goalkeeper comes to the rescue.

CLOSE! A really well-worked move from Everton sees Coleman, at the culmination of some fine inter-play between Schneiderlin and Mirallas, get in down the right. However, Martins Indi’s covering challenge just puts the Republic of Ireland captain off, and the effort soars over.
Everton counter swiftly - Davies picking out Baines with a pinpoint cross-field pass. The full-back crosses in to Mirallas, but the Belgian cannot take the ball under his spell.

CHANCE! A reckless decision by Funes Mori, who concedes a needless free-kick on the half-way line. Stoke work the ball back into the area after it is initially cleared, with Crocj trying his luck with a powerful volley that inches just wide.

Crouch has now scored in three successive Premier League months for the first time since March 2014. And he is looking for another, as he wins a header at the back post, but it is a simple save for Robles.

Wasteful from Lukaku! A neat passage of play from the visitors, as they thread the ball into their striker. However, despite having plenty of space to run into, he decides to go for goal from 30 yards out, and Grant just allows the ball to trickle wide.

A strange bit of officiating from Pawson, who ignores a blatant handball from Whelan, allowing Stoke to race forward. Barnsley than challenges - seemingly fairly so - with Baines, but the referee blows his whistle on this occasion.
Clever from Barkley, who prods a threatening pass through Stoke’s ranks. It just evades Mirallas, though, and Grant manages to claim the loose ball before Lukaku could react.

Well wide! Everton have improved in recent minutes, but won’t go close with efforts like that! Mirallas’ corner was cleared, but only as far as Coleman who, on his 200th appearance for the club, elected to try his luck from range, only to get his strike horridly wrong.
Another clever passage of play from the visitors, with Mirallas finding space down the right. His cross picks out Barkley, but Lukaku is unable to turn the midfielder’s header goalwards.
Brilliant from Davies, who weaves his way into Stoke’s area with a fantastic bit of footwork. He tees up the onrushing Coleman, but Everton’s full-back cannot take the ball in his stride.

That goal has really lifted Stoke, and Everton just cannot get out of their own half at the moment. Holgate concedes a corner, which Adam whips in, but the youngster is on hand to clear with a powerful header.
It was clever movement from Arnautovic, though it was poor defending from Holgate, who was caught sleeping at the back, and the Austria winger duly made Everton pay.

GOOOOAAAAAALLLLLL!!! CROUCH HAS HIS GOAL! Well, it just had to be him. An iffy moment for Grant, as he appeared to handle outside of his area. He gets away with it, though, and proceeds to hook a ball upfield. Holgate is caught out by Arnautovic, who in turn feeds the ball into the area, where Crouch is on hand to tuck home.

Crouch, of course, is currently on 99 Premier League goals and will be looking to reach 100 in this match. He’s scored five goals in the competition against Everton, but none have come in his last 13 appearances versus them. Stoke will be looking to use the former Liverpool man as a focal point this evening.
An early chance to get the ball into the area for Stoke, as Schneiderlin deflects Crouch’s header wide. However, Adam’s resulting set-piece is a poor one, and the ball sails harmlessly out of play.

Neither side played at the weekend, courtesy of their early FA Cup exits. However, they are both in fine fettle in the league. Stoke are searching for their fourth straight victory this evening, after they were denied a win by Wayne Rooney’s record-breaking goal last time out. Everton, on the other hand, have scored eight goals without conceding in their last three Premier League fixtures.

KICK-OFF! We are up and running, with the hosts getting proceedings underway at the sound of Craig Pawson's whistle. The last time this referee featured at this ground, he controversially sent Leicester City's Jamie Vardy off.

While Schneiderlin has been handed his first start for Everton, there is also a new face in Stoke's squad, with former West Brom forward Berahino available on the bench, having finally secured his long-mooted move away from The Hawthorns.

It was a rather low-key ending to the transfer window for both Stoke and Everton, who focused mainly on letting players leave rather than adding to their squads as January wore on. Stoke have allowed Bojan to join Bundesliga side Mainz on loan, while Everton allowed a host of their fringe players attempt to find first-team football at pastures new...

The teams are in from the Bet365 Stadium. There are two changes in total for the hosts, as Hughes drafts in Phil Bardsley and Ibrahim Afellay in place of the injured Glen Johnson and Xherdan Shaqiri, while new boy Saido Berahino is on the bench. Meanwhile, Morgan Schneiderlin makes his full Everton debut, replacing Gareth Barry.
TEAM NEWS - Everton substitutes: Stekelenburg, Jagielka, Lennon, McCarthy, Barry, Valencia, Lookman.
TEAM NEWS - Everton (3-5-2): Robles; Holgate, Williams, Funes Mori; Coleman, Davies, Schneiderlin, Barkley, Baines; Mirallas, Lukaku.
TEAM NEWS - Stoke substitutes: Muniesa, Berahino, Bony, Imbula, Given, Ngoy, Edwards.
TEAM NEWS - Stoke (4-2-3-1): Grant; Bardsley, Shawcross, Martins Indi, Pieters; Whelan, Adam; Afellay, Allen, Arnautovic; Crouch.

After a difficult start to the campaign, Mark Hughes side will feel they are back where they belong following fine runs of form either side of the festive period. Stoke sit in 10th place, eight points behind Ronald Koeman's Everton, who are aiming to claim a fourth-successive Premier League victory.
It's a typical winters night in the Potteries, but we should be in for an enthralling encounter nevertheless at the Bet365 Stadium, in what could prove to be a vital game for both these sides.
Hello and welcome, football fans around the globe! Stay tuned, as we bring you LIVE coverage of one of the three Premier League fixtures taking place today, with Stoke City taking on Everton!
news: Peter Crouch's 100th Premier League goal was not enough for Stoke City to overcome Everton as the two in-form sides drew 1-1 at the Britannia Stadium.
The 36-year-old striker reached his century early in the game from close range, and celebrated in nostalgic fashion with his trademark robot celebration.

Crouch was impressive throughout the game, but he and Marko Arnautovic spurned chances to extend the hosts' lead in a dominant first-half performance before a Ryan Shawcross own-goal salvaged a point for Everton.

It was initially chalked off for offside, only for the decision to be reversed after referee Craig Pawson correctly ruled that Seamus Coleman's strike had struck the Stoke skipper and not Romelu Lukaku on its way into the net.
Stoke are now four league games unbeaten while Everton are six in the top flight without defeat.
The hosts were fastest out of the traps and Crouch reached his ton after just seven minutes when he slid home at close range from a pinpoint Arnautovic pass.
Everton's defence, watertight in their last three league games, were caught napping by a hopeful long ball that freed the Austria international on the left-hand side of the penalty area.
The veteran striker went agonisingly close to making it 2-0 after 25 minutes, catching Arnautovic's cushioned header sweetly on the volley, only to see his strike whistle past the post.
Joel Robles then charged down an Arnautovic effort as Stoke continued to dominate.
Everton struggled to match Stoke's intensity and were fortunate to draw level five minutes before the interval thanks to Pawson's change of heart.
Ronald Koeman introduced James McCarthy for Mason Holgate at half-time, abandoning his side's 3-5-2 shape, making Everton much more effective in inhibiting Stoke's attacking play.
Stoke were limited to two audacious Charlie Adam attempts from long-range to catch out Robles, and Crouch headed over just after the hour.

Mark Hughes brought on Saido Berahino for his Stoke debut in the 66th minute, though it was Everton's January signing Ademola Lookman who made an immediate impact from the bench, forcing Lee Grant into a smart save at his near post.
Both teams had chances to win it inside the final five minutes.
Berahino almost marked his debut with the decisive goal, lifting the ball over an onrushing Robles only for Ramiro Funes Mori to head to safety from below his bar.
His team-mates then owed thanks to Grant for safeguarding the point, improbably clawing away a goalbound Tom Davies header in the final stages as both sides had to settle for the a draw.

commentary: FULL-TIME! Leicester leave Seville with a valuable away goal, despite losing 2-1 against Sampaoli's Sevilla. The hosts were dominant in the first half but failed to fully capitalise on their situation, and a second-half Vardy strike has left the door open for a second-leg comeback in England. Not the best of nights for Los Nervionenses, but the travelling fans are overjoyed. That's all that we have time for, we hope to see you again next time.
Carrico is the latest man to go into the referee's book, as the substitute drags back Mahrez cynically as the Leicester wide man tried to counter at pace.

Sevilla are desperately pushing on and looking to try and claw their way back to two goals in front, but Leicester are sat very deep indeed at this point. There will be three minutes of stoppage time at Ramon Sanchez Pizjuan.

OFF THE BAR! Rami rises highest to meet a corner delivery from the left-hand side, but the France international can only rattle a close-range header onto the woodwork. Half of the ground thought that was in.
Albrighton takes his time while walking off the pitch, much to the annoyance of the home players, with Amartey coming into the game for its dying embers.
Jovetic tries his luck from the edge of the penalty area, but a deflection sends the ball curling shy of the left-hand post. That almost crept in.

Over the top from Sarabia! The Spanish goalscorer checks in from the right and shoots, but a deflection sends his effort ballooning over the crossbar. Once again, however, Sevilla's corner comes to absolutely nothing. Another goal would do the home side the world of good heading into the return leg.

Good stop from Schmeichel! Sarabia lifts a diagonal ball to the left-hand side of the Leicester penalty area, but Vitolo can only force a save out of the opposition goalkeeper with a tame header. The hosts get themselves a corner as a result, which is cleared, but Gray is denied a chance to counter by some good strength from Mariano.

Sevilla are now the team to be launching dangerous counter-attacks, as Leicester are growing in confidence and pushing more players forward. Mariano is fed to the right byline and cuts a good cross back into the box, but nobody can get on the end of it!

Jovetic is picked out in the penalty box by a cut-back from the left-hand side, after a neat dummy from Iborra, but the Montenegrin striker drags his shot a long way wide of the post. He goes down immediately afterwards and claims for a penalty, but it would have been harsh had it been given. This contest could swing either way in these dying stages.

Drinkwater shoots from long-range, but his effort is easily blocked. Leicester suddenly have their tails up as a result of that goal from Vardy. Suddenly, Sevilla are the team on the back foot and there could be more goals in this for the away side somewhere.
Mahrez leads the counter-attack for Leicester, but Escudero hacks the Algerian winger down unceremoniously. That is the easiest yellow card this referee will ever have to give.

Leicester try to threaten by using the same blueprint as with their goal, but this time a cross from Drinkwater is gobbled up easily by Sergio Rico. This contest is at a very precarious point for Sevilla now, as rather than closing out a comfortable win, they have afforded their opponents some hope heading into the second leg.

GOOOOOOOOOAL! VARDY SCORES FROM CLOSE-RANGE! Sampaoli will be livid. Drinkwater is allowed to burst down the left channel and square a brilliant cross, which Vardy simply can't miss at the back post. Sevilla fall asleep for a second and Leicester have their away goal.
Drinkwater provides some drive from midfield and angles a great delivery into the six-yard box for Vardy to prey on.

We're into the last 20 minutes in Seville, and Leicester look as though they are already thinking about the journey home. Gray scampers down the left and tries to get into the box, but Rami steps out and makes a vital challenge. In short, the away side just don't look like a team, but rather like a group of strangers.

Despite going two goals behind, Leicester are still not pushing on and pressing intensely. Everything is a little bit too easy for Los Nervionenses. Jovetic gets into the penalty area once again and tries to slot home a close-range finish, but Schmeichel does just enough to deny him.

Sampaoli will be furious if Sevilla step off the gas now, as Leicester are on the ropes. It is perceivable that the home side could kill this knock-out tie off tonight. Jovetic tries to wriggle down the left and get a ball into the area, but Simpson stands up to the Montenegro international well.

Less than half an hour remains for Leicester to try and get an away goal to take back to the King Power with them, but it isn't looking likely. Albrighton curls in a cross from the left-hand side, but Sarabia makes a good interception. Ranieri has made one change, but he might have to twist again to get some change out of the hosts' back four.
Correa is withdrawn, with Iborra getting a chance to slot into the Sevilla midfield. After missing the weekend due to suspension, he needs some minutes.
Jovetic brings the ball down expertly under pressure, before flicking a cute pass out to find Correa unmarked.

GOOOOOOOAL! CORREA MAKES IT 2-0! He makes up for his penalty miss. Jovetic holds the ball up wonderfully in the Leicester penalty area, before flicking an intelligent pass into his overlapping teammate. The Argentine midfielder makes no mistake and smashes home a close-range finish to send Ramon Sanchez Pizjuan crazy.

Vardy tries to battle his way into the Sevilla penalty box, but the England international striker is promptly mobbed by a few red and white shirts. Mariano then gives possession away in the middle of the park, with Leicester's break resulting in a shot from Drinkwater being deflected wide of the target. Their corner is taken short, but a clipped ball from Albrighton comes to nothing.

Sevilla haven't had the same relentless dominance in this second half, so Leicester may be already thinking that they have weathered the worst that the hosts have to offer. Schmeichel tries to lift a long kick forward to Albrighton, but the ball bounces once before looping into Sergio Rico's grasp.
Musa takes his leave after a quiet evening, with Gray being deployed out on the right-hand side.

Wide from Sarabia! The Sevilla goalscorer is picked out at the back post brilliantly by Vitolo, but can only jink side to side to open up some space before shooting beyond the near post. Schmeichel was worried there, as he seemed to be a little bit unsighted by Fuchs.
Lenglet is taken off with a muscle problem, forcing Sampaoli to introduce Carrico at the heart of the defence. Leicester could look to exploit the substitute.

Vardy feeds Musa to the left byline, but the former CSKA Moscow striker gets his feet muddled up and runs the ball straight out of play for a goal-kick. There is a quick break in play, as Lenglet goes down with an injury problem. Daniel Carrico might have to be thrown in at the deep end here, after not playing in any big games for a while.

Nasri carries the ball with confidence, before slotting a pass straight out of play due to some miscommunication between himself and Mariano. Moments later, Jovetic is picked out in space on the edge of the box, before a fierce shot from Escudero cannons into a ruck of defenders and away to safety. The Sevilla left-back is a real menace.

Mahrez tries to flight in a cross from the right-hand side, but it is easy for Sergio Rico to deal with. Ranieri's men are trying to push a little high upfield to cause Sevilla some problems in their build-up play. A ball sits up nicely for Ndidi some 30 yards out from goal, but the Nigerian midfielder can only send a shot rasping straight down Rico's throat. Moments later, Vitolo shoots narrowly beyond the far post from a tight angle on the left with the aid of the near upright.

Jovetic whips in a cross, but Fuchs half-clears, before a shot from Mariano is flicked goalwards in improvised fashion by Correa! The Sevilla midfielder almost accidentally deflects the ball towards the bottom-left corner, forcing Schmeichel to get down smartly and made a solid save.

We are back underway in the second half in Spain! Sevilla played Leicester off the park before the interval, but couldn't open up a telling gap. Ranieri and company might just be able to punish their profligacy.

HALF-TIME! Sevilla dominate the first half at Ramon Sanchez Pizjuan entirely, but Sampaoli's men only have a 1-0 lead for their troubles. Schmeichel has been incredibly busy and even saved a penalty to deny Correa, but Sarabia's excellent header eventually broke the deadlock. The hosts will need to make their pressure count, otherwise Leicester could crawl back into this one.

Vitolo can't hit the target! Mariano whips in a devilish cross from the right-hand side, which makes its way towards the far post. The Spaniard gets up well, but plants his looping header a long way over the crossbar. Disappointing.

Sevilla's pressure has subsided a little in the last five minutes, with the hosts perhaps wary of the fact that conceding now would give Leicester a real psychological boost. Mahrez is fed possession in between the lines, but N'Zonzi is immediately upon him and robs the Algeria international of the ball.

Leicester win themselves a free-kick in a dangerous area, but a cross from Mahrez is headed away from the danger zone easily by Escudero. What a waste that was. The visitors need to make the most of set-pieces, given how little possession they have had.

Ranieri uses the break in play to relay some instructions on the field, but he will be keen to get his players into the dressing room for a tactical re-think at the interval. Albrighton bursts down the left, but the Englishman is quickly silenced by Mariano. Leicester are running out of steam before they even reach the final third.

Sevilla whip a free-kick into the box from deep on the left-hand side, but Schmeichel is again alert and punches a long way clear of the danger zone. Some treatment is needed for Musa in the aftermath, as the Nigeria international clashed heads with Escudero nastily. Both sets of physios are called on.

Good save from Schmeichel! Correa is teed up on the edge of the Leicester box, and fires a low drive at goal, forcing the visiting goalkeeper to get down smartly and push the ball behind for a corner. The resulting set-piece is hacked clear at the near post by Drinkwater.

Leicester are being forced to regularly give the ball away, which is leading to just relentless pressure from Sevilla. It is almost as if the home side are playing downhill, such is their dominance. N'Zonzi is linking everything together in the middle of the park for Los Nervionenses completely unchecked.

Sergio Rico hasn't had anything to do so far, with Ranieri hoping for his players to get into the half-time break without further damage. At 1-0, they can mount some kind of comeback. Nasri looks for Jovetic over the top, but the ball skips off the turf and straight through to Schmeichel.

Schmeichel is forced to palm a dangerous cross away from the danger zone, as his penalty area is besieged. N'Zonzi drives forward powerfully, before opening play out to the right-hand side. This time, Fuchs makes an interception, before a long ball that looks for Vardy is mopped up by Rami.

Jovetic is picked out by a cross from the left-hand side, but the Montenegro international is unable to bring the ball down and shoot - he loses his balance after the first part. With 15 minutes left until the break, Sevilla are monopolising possession and calling all of the shots.

The home fans continue to make this atmosphere quite unbearable for the away side, with Leicester continuing to chase this game without much luck. The Foxes are pressing high, but not with any conviction, while their teammates don't get up in close support to help show a united front. Sevilla are just playing their way out.

OFF THE BAR! Jovetic spots Schmeichel off his line and tries his luck outrageously from 40 yards out, with the Leicester goalkeeper forced to push the ball over the crossbar. The Sevilla striker goes berserk at the fans, asking for more noise, and they respond. The Foxes must have wondered what they have walked into here.

GOOOOOOOOOAL! SEVILLA OPEN THE SCORING! Sarabia comes up big for the home side yet again. The hosts break down the left-hand side, with Escudero curling in a beautiful cross. The ex-Getafe winger is there at the back post to thump a great header across Schmeichel and off the inside of the post.
Escudero whips in a lovely ball from wide on the left, which Sarabia nods home with aplomb.

Sampaoli's men are continuing to see more the ball and ask questions of Schmeichel, but until they open the scoring Sevilla will be living in fear of Leicester's counter-attacking potential. Drinkwater dribbles forward and goes on a mazy run, but an eventual pass forward that searches for Musa is cut out. The home side respond through Vitolo, but the Spaniard sees a shot blocked from a tight angle.

Jovetic flicks a lovely ball from Lenglet out to the right-hand side, with a ball then cut back to Escudero on the edge of the Leicester box. The Sevilla left-back unleashes a wicked left-footed effort at goal, with the aid of a minor deflection, and Schmeichel has to be at his very best to get down quickly to make a top save.

Correa is fed a pass into the penalty area, but Drinkwater tracks his man well to get goalside and then angle a clearance out of play for a throw-in. Moments later, Mariano picks out a teammate on the edge of the box, but a first-touch pass into Correa is shepherded behind for a goal-kick.

Albrighton flights in a good cross from the left-hand side, but Morgan can't stretch enough to guide a glancing header inside the far post. Leicester are trying to give as good as they are getting, but it is turning this contest into an open one. This will suit Sevilla down to the ground.

What drama early on! That save from Schmeichel has really got Leicester out of jail, as going 1-0 so early on could have easily turned this scoreline into one that belongs in cricket. The away side respond with a jaunt forward, but a cross into the Sevilla box is cleared with ease.
CORREA MISSES! Schmeichel guesses the right way and easily smothers the low drive from the Sevilla midfielder. He might have won the spot-kick, but that finish was awful.
PENALTY TO SEVILLA! Correa dances across the penalty area and takes a touch beyond Morgan, who promptly scythes down the hosts' midfielder. As clear as they come.
Penalty Miss Carlos Joaquín Correa

The hosts are dominating possession and probing for gaps, with their full-backs racing right on. Sarabia slides a pass to the byline for Mariano to meet, but the Brazilian's cut-back is easily blocked. Leicester are struggling to get out of their own final third.

Sevilla open the ball out to Mariano on the right-hand side, with Jovetic picked out by a smart cross from the Brazilian. The ex-Manchester City striker gets to the ball first, but his shot bounces into the turf and over the target. Despite the Montenegro international claiming for a corner, the referee isn't interested.

Schmeichel is able to claim a cross from the right-hand side, with the visitors then trying to break at pace. Their goalkeeper kicks long, very long, but Vardy is watched carefully by Rami. Everything about Leicester's play is an attempt to be vertical and quick on the break.

Leicester have managed to mount a couple of surges forward, but Sergio Rico remains a spectator. Already, Sampaoli is losing his mind while watching the game from the stands. He clearly isn't happy with how Sevilla have started this match. The Foxes are settling in a little bit.

Almost an error from Fuchs! The Austria international tries to flick a dangerous cross back to his goalkeeper with his head, with Sarabia breathing down his neck. Schmeichel, however, was already on his way out and is forced into a save to deny his own teammate! The Dane screams at his defender, his initial call must have been lost in the noise of the atmosphere.

Sarabia takes aim from wide on the right-hand side, but a left-footed strike from the Spaniard sails over Schmeichel's crossbar and behind for a goal-kick. The hosts are enjoying all of the possession, with Sampaoli clearly wanting immediate control in this tie. Sevilla are very wary of Leicester's attacking capabilities.

Sevilla enjoy all of the ball in the early stages, with Leicester set up in a deep system as expected. Musa is playing on the right-hand side, however, with Mahrez playing in behind Vardy. An interesting tactical decision from Ranieri, who must be wanting to keep tabs on the marauding Escudero.

We are underway in the first half at Ramon Sanchez Pizjuan! Sevilla have gone with a slightly different set-up to usual, but Leicester will be approaching this one with their usual solid two banks of four and pace up top.
Leicester substitutes: Zieler, Chilwell, King, Amartey, Okazaki, Gray, Benalouane.
Sevilla substitutes: Soria, Kranevitter, Carrico, Iborra, Vietto, Ben Yedder, Vazquez.
Leicester starting line-up (4-4-2): Schmeichel; Simpson, Huth, Morgan, Fuchs; Mahrez, Ndidi, Drinkwater, Albrighton; Vardy, Musa.
Sevilla starting line-up (4-2-3-1): Sergio Rico; Mariano, Lenglet, Rami, Escudero; N'Zonzi, Nasri; Sarabia, Correa, Vitolo; Jovetic.

TEAM NEWS: Ahmed Musa partners Jamie Vardy up top for Leicester, with Ranieri clearly hoping to use some pace on the break on their Champions League travels. Wilfred Ndidi features in central midfield alongside Danny Drinkwater, with the visitors not providing any selection surprises at all. Much of a muchness for the Foxes. Marc Albrighton and Riyad Mahrez are the wide options employed.

TEAM NEWS: Clement Lenglet has a big test ahead of his at centre-back for Sevilla, with no other surprises within Sevilla's back four. Pablo Sarabia, Joaquin Correa and Vitolo are the trio asked to support lone striker Stevan Jovetic. Wissam Ben Yedder takes a seat on the bench, as does Franco Vazquez. A reserved starting line-up from Jorge Sampaoli.

The Foxes, meanwhile, have only had smiles on their faces in this competition. Domestically, Leicester are hovering just one point above the relegation zone, despite winning the title last year. After finishing top of their group, confidence should be high, but a dismal one win in their last eight competitive games has had the opposite effect - and that sole victory came in an extra-time FA Cup result against second-tier Derby County. This game is make-or-break.

Hello and welcome to live coverage of Sevilla's home clash against Leicester in the Champions League, as Claudio Ranieri's men attempt to forget their Premier League woes with a fairytale European run. The hosts are in fantastic form, finding themselves in third place in LaLiga at present, and haven't lost at the Ramon Sanchez Pizjuan since a European group match against Juventus back in late November.
news: There was no awakening from Leicester City's nightmare season as they went down 2-1 at Sevilla in their Champions League last-16 first-leg meeting, but Jamie Vardy's away goal stirred old senses again for the Foxes.
This continental trip offered the Foxes distraction from domestic dismay that lurched from slipping into a Premier League relegation fight to FA Cup elimination at the hands of Millwall on Saturday.

Given their woeful form, a trip to the Ramon Sanchez Pizjuan was the last thing Claudio Ranieri needed and Sevilla - without the suspended Jorge Sampaoli on the touchline - routinely found gaps in a porous and passive defence.

Kasper Schmeichel was the only visiting player to provide resistance, saving Joaquin Correa's early penalty and numerous other efforts, but Pablo Sarabia's firm header had Sevilla ahead at half-time and Correa atoned for his miss with a goal after the break.

Schmeichel's saves largely looked to be in vain, but a Sevilla lapse opened up space for Danny Drinkwater to tee up Vardy's first Champions League goal and send a Leicester following that has become increasingly browbeaten to dream again.
The Foxes won all three of their group games at the King Power Stadium, twice by the 1-0 scoreline that would take them through in three weeks' time.

Ranieri had spoken of this fixture having a transformative effect on Leicester's campaign, but it was more of the same from the off, Christian Fuchs almost nodding past Schmeichel, who reacted sharply for the first of many times to save the Austrian.

The air of calamity would not clear, though, as Correa weaved past a static Robert Huth before he was felled by a clumsy, lunging Wes Morgan in the penalty area. Though Schmeichel saved his captain's blushes by holding Correa's weak effort, the Sevilla tide was unrelenting.
Sergio Escudero was a persistent menace on Sevilla's left, and he forced Schmeichel into a smart stop before setting up a magnificent opener.

The full-back beat Ahmed Musa to the ball before coming back into possession and whipping an inch-perfect cross over Fuchs for Sarabia to race onto and plant a firm header beyond the helpless Schmeichel.

The increasingly desperate Dane had to fist a looping, deflected Stevan Jovetic shot over and tip away a fizzing Correa shot as Leicester's lifeless approach of sitting deep in their own half did nothing to stem Sevilla's roaming through the pitch.

Wilfred Ndidi blasted the visitors' first shot on target straight at Sergio Rico, but it did not immediately signal the coming fightback as Vitolo hit the post from an impossible angle before the dithering Morgan and Huth converged on Jovetic, allowing Correa the time and space to finish after the Montenegrin offloaded the ball.

Sevilla were in control, but they were guilty of allowing Leicester a scent of progression when Drinkwater wandered into open space before picking out Vardy for his first strike since a hat-trick against Manchester City in December.
380 - Jamie Vardy has scored with his first shot on target in 380 minutes for Leicester. Lifeline.

Victory remained Sevilla's, while Real Madrid's defeat at Valencia also vitalised a potential title tilt in LaLiga, and Sampaoli's return to the touchline for the second leg could prove crucial in the Spanish side making the Champions League quarter-finals for the first time.

commentary: Thanks for joining our commentary this afternoon. Until next time, goodbye.

The Gunners suffer back-to-back defeats for the second time in the campaign and are now locked in a battle to secure their place in the top four, while Antonio Conte's men need only to remain on the path to secure the crown.

Chelsea take a huge stride towards the Premier League title as they go 12 points clear at the top of the table. Goals from Marcos Alonso, Eden Hazard and Cesc Fabregas secure a comfortable win over Arsenal, who did not seem up for the fight this afternoon.
FULL-TIME: CHELSEA 3-1 ARSENAL
The referee ends the contest.
Monreal has been Arsenal's best player today and gets an assist for his troubles.
GOALL!!! CONSOLATION FOR THE GUNNERS! Giroud stoops at the near post to head Monreal's cross at goal and his effort creeps through the hands of Courtois to find the net.
There will be three minutes of added time.
OVER! Costa takes possession on the left flank and drives forward in an attempt to get on the scoresheet himsef. He has support but takes the shot on from a tight angle, blazing his effort over.
CHANCE! Alonso latches on to Fabregas' cross in an attempt to notch his second of the game, but Cech jumps to catch his looping header.
Moses is withdrawn late in the game for Zouma.

GOALLL!!!! IT'S THREE FOR CHELSEA! A disaster for Cech as he miscues his clearance straight to Fabregas. To rub salt into the wound the former Arsenal captain scores against his old club by simply lofting the ball over the keeper and into the net. Game over!
Pedro has put in a good shift and now makes way for Willian.
Hazard makes way for Fabregas.
Arsenal are running out of ideas in the final third. They've had their chances to get back into the game, but have been unable to convert in front of goal.
Costa carries the ball downfield and has Hazard to hit in the middle of the box, but takes his time and can only win a corner on the left flank.
WIDE! Sanchez lifts the ball itno the box from the resulting corner and Mustafi gets a march on his marker and guides a header towards goal, only to miss the target.

SAVE! Welbeck guides a header from Sanchez's cross from the right towards the bottom corner. It looks goalbound, but Courtois gets down low to his right to palm the ball past the post. A great stop from the Belgian.
Chelsea may just have to be careful here as they've taken their foot off the gas a little bit. A third goal may be needed to kill of the contest.
Oxlade-Chamberlain slides the ball into the feet of Welbeck in the box and the striker lays the ball back, but there's no red shirt behind him to collect.
Gabriel catches Hazard with a stray arm and sends the Belgian tumbling to the deck. That was not a good look for the Arsenal defender.
Sanchez is brought down and the Gunners win a free-kick, but it's wasted as the flag goes up against Giroud in the box.
Matic brings down Oxlade-Chamberlain and goes into the book.
Welbeck comes on for the final 20 minutes as Wenger goes all out.
Luiz almost has the freedom of the Arsenal box to shoot, but there's a reason for that as he is flagged offside.
Gabriel does well covering at the back for the Gunners as he sweeps Pedro's threatening cross out for a corner. It has been a tide of pressure from Chelsea in the second half.
Coquelin makes way for Giroud as Wenger sets his stall out to attack for the final 25 minutes.
Alonso takes a whack in the back of the head from his own team-mate as Luiz wipes him out on the edge of the box.
Arsenal are throwing caution to the wind here and committing a lot of men forward, but it has left them very exposed at the back. Hazard almost releases Pedro, but Koscielny cuts out his pass.
Moses breaks again down the right and attempts to lift the ball to the left edge of the box for Costa to attack, but Mustafi clears it away under huge pressure.
Cahill has to be alert to stop Walcott bursting in behind him and the defender does just enough to block his strike behind for a corner.
Moses takes the ball down the right wing on a forward surge before he attempts to pick out Costa in the box. However, the ball just doesn't fall for the forward as he attempts to volley at goal.
Arsenal press back and force a corner on the left flank, but the home side clear the danger with ease.

GOALLL!!! HAZARD SCORES A STUNNER! The Belgian collects the ball in the centre circle and weaves his way past one challenge before speeding past Coquelin. He drives into the box and bamboozles Koscielny with his skill before firing his strike past Cech. An outstanding finish to double Chelsea's lead.
What a start to the half from Kante as he steals the ball again and this time does play in Costa, only for the striker to be flagged offside.
Kante wins the ball back again for the home side and tees up Hazard 25 yards from goal. The forward twists and turns to fire at goal, but can only blast his effort over the bar.

Kante whips the ball away in the middle of the park and drives forward following a misplaced pass from Koscielny. He tries to release Costa, but has second thoughts at the last moment, although the Frenchman retains possession.
Hazard almost latches on to Costa's throughball, but Koscielny comes across at the last moment with a sliding challenge to take the ball away from the Belgian.
We're back underway at Stamford Bridge.
The players are back out on the pitch, so we should be underway shortly.

Chelsea take a 1-0 lead into the break thanks to Marcos Alonso's header in the 13th minute. The game has been fairly even as Arsenal have had their chances to draw level, with Gabriel and Mesut Ozil missing late chances, but Antonio Conte's men remain in control.
HALF-TIME: CHELSEA 1-0 ARSENAL
The referee brings the first half to an end.
No they can't as Pedro slips and knocks the ball out for a goal-kick.
Chelsea earn a corner left with seconds remaining int he half. Can they get the second goal before the break?
CHANCE! Coquelin finds Ozil in all sorts of space in the right inside channel. The German cuts back on to his left foot to shoot, but his eventual strike is tame and saved by Courtois.
There will be four minutes of added time.
Mustafi does well under pressure to prevent a corner after Pedro almost broke through the Arsenal backline. The Gunners need to see out the half without conceding again.
Pedro misses a golden opportunity to release Costa's run in behind the Arsenal defence, but Koscielny makes the interception to stop the attack.
Hazard and Pedro almost link-up in the final third as the Belgian dummies the ball to allow the winger to take possession. However, his attempted throughball for Hazard goes straight to Cech.
The Gunners keep the pressure on from the resulting corner, but Coquelin's strike from the edge of the box is deflected straight into the hands of Courtois.

CHANCE! Arsenal should be level as Gabriel has a free header at goal from Oxlade-Chamberlain's cross, but he heads straight at Courtois, who makes a decent stop. However, the Gunners defender had space and time to pick his spot.
Wenger's men battle back with a spell of pressure of their own, but they still haven't forced a save from Courtois thus far into the contest.

The pressure is well and truly on the Arsenal defence here and even Sanchez is forced to get back to help out his team-mates. Chelsea are sending cross after cross into the box to test the Gunners' resolve.

SHOT! Alonso collects on the left flank and plays the ball back across the box to Pedro. The Spaniard shoots first time, and although his effort lacks power Cech is still forced to turn the ball behind for a corner.

CHANCE! Chelsea break on the counter and Hazard releases Costa inside. The striker has support from Pedro, who is free on the right flank, but he opts to go alone and loses possession on the edge of the box.
The Gunners have a chance to threaten from a free-kick on the left as Monreal is brought down by Moses.
Hazard leaves Walcott for dead on the left flank and plays the ball to Matic to send the ball into the box, but there are enough Arsenal shirts at the back post to clear the danger.
Arsenal clear the danger from the free-kick, but Chelsea retain possession in the final third and are probing as Hazard returns to the pitch.
A sore one for Hazard as he gets hit right on the knee. That could be a dead leg that may take a little while to run off.
Hazard beats Mustafi for pace down the left flank and the German is forced to bring down the Chelsea forward. Referee Atkinson has no choice but to book the Arsenal man.
Matic plays a neat inside pass for Costa's run, but on this occasion the striker is fractionally offside.

CHANCE! Costa weaves his way through one challenge to burst into the right inside channel. The striker goes for the shot from a tight angle, but can only blast his effort into the side-netting. Cech appeared to have his angles covered anyway at the near post.
Arsenal win a succession of corners and the second falls to Coquelin on the edge of the box. He goes for a strike with the outside of his boot, but sends his effort narrowly over the bar.
Gabriel replaces Bellerin following the nasty collision with Alonso.
Walcott makes a surge down the right flank and wins a corner off the legs of Cahill. The Gunners need a response here.
Bellerin hit the deck hard after losing his header against Alonso and has required treatment on the pitch. He may have to go off here as Gabriel goes through his warm-up.

GOALLL!!!! CHELSEA TAKE THE LEAD! Alonso heads home from close range as he outbattles Bellerin in the box to power his effort past Cech. Costa caused the damage as his powerful header from Pedro's cross left Cech stranded, allowing his team-mate to capitalise.
Moses makes an error from a clearance and it puts Luiz under huge pressure from Iwobi and Sanchez, but he goes just enough to get it away from the box.
