commentary: Thanks for joining our commentary this evening. Until next time, goodbye.

Thomas Tuchel will be furious with his side who now have to overcome a deficit to reach the quarter-finals of the competition. Rui Vitoria's men will have to display the same level of resilience when they travel to Germany for the second leg in three weeks time.

Benfica will take a 1-0 lead into the second leg at Signal-Iduna Park thanks to Kostas Mitroglou's goal in the 48th minute. How they have the advantage is anyone's guess as Borussia Dortmund spurned numerous chances, including a second-half penalty from Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang.
FULL-TIME: BENFICA 1-0 BORUSSIA DORTMUND
The referee ends the contest.
Benfica have taken the sting out of the Dortmund attack in their desperate attempt to snatch a late away goal.
All hands on deck for the home side at the back as Semedo is forced into a block to stop Schmelzer's cross on the left flank.
There will be four minutes of added time.
Bartra goes into the book for a foul on Jimenez.
OVER! Pulisic collects another loose ball on the edge of the box and shows great technique to bring the ball down and volley at goal. However, he puts his strike narrowly over the bar.
Dembele sends the ball into the box from the flank and there are a few swipes from the Benfica defence before Semedo clears.
Pulisic brings down Pizzi on the edge of the Benfica box and he goes into the book.

SAVE! Ederson makes a brilliant save to rub salt into the Dortmund wounds. Pulisic lets fly with a strike from the edge of the box and it takes a huge deflection off Jimenez, but the keeper makes a reaction stop to keep the ball out.
Pulisic replaces Guerreiro for the visitors.
Reus makes way for Castro.
The visitors are still dominating possession, but their lack of success in front of goal has dented their confidence in and around the box.

Definitely not Dortmund's night as Schurrle makes a neat turn on the edge of the box, but he just cannot pull the trigger in time before Semedo and Luisao close him down. The full-back had a chunk of the German's shirt, but the referee did not see that!
Jimenez replaces the goalscorer Mitroglou for the home side.
Schmelzer goes into the book for a foul on Salvio.
The home side are encamped on the edge of the box, but you get the feeling we could play until tomorrow and Dortmund would not score.
Benfica have the lead in this game, but have had one opening in front of goal. If a scoreline ever did not tell the story of a match - it's this game!
WIDE! Piszczek rises highest in the box to head Dembele's corner at goal, but he can only guide his effort past the post.
Dortmund are keeping the pressure on the home side, despite their poor form in front of goal this evening. There's no lack of effort.
Rafa Silva makes way for Cervi.

WIDE! Dembele runs at the Benfica defence and slides the ball out wide to Guerreiro, who sends the ball into the box. Reus meets the cross with his left foot, but can only guide his effort past the post.
Fejsa brings down Guerreiro and heads into the book.

CHANCE! Sokratis fails to read the flight of the ball from Guerreiro's free-kick and can only watch as he is a yard away from the ball as it drifts past the post. Tuchel is furious on the touchline and who can blame him.
Aubameyang's awful evening is over as Schurrle replaces him.
It's looking like it's going to be one of those nights for Dortmund. They've done everything but score, and Aubameyang has played a huge role in that.
Ederson makes a routine save from the spot, keeping the Gabonese's effort out.

SHOCKING PENALTY! Aubameyang is having a nightmare this evening. He continues his awful performance with one of the worst penalties you will see as he simply strikes the ball straight at Ederson, who makes the save.
PENALTY TO DORTMUND! It has been coming and the pressure tells as Fejsa handles in the box, forcing the referee to point to the spot.
SAVE! Dortmund are really coming at the home side now and only an excellent diving save from Ederson stops Piszczek from finding the net as his curling effort is tipped wide by the Benfica keeper.
CHANCE! Reus sneaks off the back of Semedo on the left flank to latch on to Durm's cross and gets an effort away at goal, but Ederson makes a fine stop at his near post.

WHAT A MISS! Aubameyang fails for the second time of the match to find the net from close range. Sokratis' pass was deflected into his path 12 yards from goal and with only Ederson to beat he scuffed his effort over the bar.

CHANCE! Dortmund should be level as Dembele latches on to a flick-on from Reus in the box, but in a crowded area he fails to lift the ball over Ederson, who gets enough on the shot to deny the Frenchman.
Luisao won the first header from the corner to tee up Mitroglou to find the net.

GOALLLLL!!! BENFICA TAKE THE LEAD! After doing nothing for the opening 45 minutes the home side have come to life to forge ahead in the contest. Luisao won the first header from Pizzi's corner and Mitroglou controlled the ball two yards from goal before placing his strike past Burki.
Salvio has a dart down the right flank and wins a second corner of the half for the home side as Schmelzer covers.
We're back underway at the Estadio da Luz.
Carrillo makes way at the break for Filipe.
The players are making their way out for the second half and a change is coming for the home side.
Benfica have not got going at all in the first period and are fortunate to be level at the break. Rui Vitoria will want to see a lot more from his team in the second half.

Borussia Dortmund will be frustrated heading into the interval as they've dominated the first half, but have not been able to find the back of the net. Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang should have put the visitors ahead, only to blaze his effort over the bar from close range.
HALF-TIME: BENFICA 0-0 BORUSSIA DORTMUND
The referee brings the first half to an end.
Salvio makes a rare foray down the right flank and crosses to the near post, but Burki claims the ball with ease.
There will be three minutes of added time.
Schmelzer sends a deep cross to the back post, and with Durm lurking behind him Eliseu heads the ball behind for a corner.
Dembele attempts to pick out Aubameyang with his forward run, but he tries to squeeze the ball into too tight a space and it allows the home side to clear.
Reus and Guerreiro combine in the final third, with the forward releasing the Portuguese in behind. However, Guerreiro moved a second too soon and was caught offside.

Dembele attempts to latch on to a ball behind the Benfica defence and beats Ederson to it, only for the keeper to wipe him out in the process. The referee is unmoved as the ball trickles out for a goal-kick, much to the bemusement of every Dortmund player. That should have been a free-kick on the edge of the box.

CLOSE! Fejsa allows Guerreiro to break in behind him and although he covers his mistake, he then lazily stops his work and the Portuguese swings his foot at the ball to send it across the face of goal. Unfortunately for Dortmund there's no player on hand to capitalise.
Dortmund have completed 214 passes so far compared to Benfica's 86. The German outfit have dominated possession, holding 62% of the ball.
Frustrating times at the moment for Benfica as they cannot get close to the German outfit with the ball. It's the travelling supporters who are making the noise inside the stadium.
Dortmund are still controlling this match, with the home side sitting in their defensive shape to keep them at bay. Vitoria will want to see an improvement from his team going forward.
Fejsa almost sells Ederson short on a backpass with Aubameyang pressing, but the Benfica keeper races out of his box to clear the danger.
Dortmund keep the ball on the ground and lose possession. For all of their good work this evening, Tuchel's men have not been clinical enough in the final third.
Schmelzer gets caught by Fejsa in an advanced position and goes down. Another chance for the German outfit to send a cross into the box.
Dortmund have dominated this contest thus far, but have nothing to show for it. They've quietened the crowd in the Estadio da Luz, but Tuchel remains a frustrated figure on the sideline.
WIDE! Ederson punches the resulting cross clear to the edge of the box where Schmelzer waits. The skipper strikes the ball first time, but he scuffs his attempt well wide of the post.
Ederson requires treatment for a knock to the mouth he took in the aftermath of the strike before the Dortmund corner can occur.

SAVE! Ederson comes to the rescue for the home side as he makes a fine block to deny Dembele from close range. Dortmund played through the Benfica backline down the left and the Frenchman collected and fired first time at goal on the turn, but the keeper was there to make the save.
Weigl sends an inviting ball over the top of the Benfica defence for Durm's run, but once again a lack of control lets a Dortmund player down as the ball trickles out for a goal-kick.
Tuchel is shaking his head on the sideline after that piece of control from Guerreiro. His side have been in control thus far, but have not been clinical enough in the final third.
Schmelzer and Bartra play sublime football down the flank, with the former knocking the ball to the edge of the box for Guerreiro's run, but the midfielder cannot take the ball in stride.
Pizzi swings the ball into the box, but he gets his delivery all wrong and the visitors are able to clear with ease.
Salvio goes down under pressure from Schmelzer and wins a free-kick on the right flank. An opportunity for the home side to test the fragile Dortmund defence.
Guerreiro and Durm combine and the former almost releases Aubameyang behind the Benfica defence, only for Lindelof to make a vital interception.
Dortmund are controlling the pace of the game in the early stages of the contest. Durm and Weigl are seeing a lot of the ball in possession on the right flank and centre of the park respectively.
Reus wins a free-kick and has the opportunity to swing the ball in from the left flank, but his delivery misses everyone in the box and goes straight through to Ederson.

CHANCE! Aubameyang misses a sitter as he blazes the ball over the bar from 12 yards with only Ederson to beat. Dembele won the ball back deep in the Benfica half and sent his team-mate through on goal, but the Gabonese failed to hit the target.
Aubameyang attempts to latch onto Piszczek's ball over the top, but the offside flag goes up to stop the Gabonese's run.
A frenetic start to the contest from both sides, displaying their attacking pedigree and defensive frailties.

CHANCE! Salvio collects the ball in acres of space on the right flank and he beats Sokratis for pace with ease. He lines up a strike, but gets his effort all wrong, sending the ball over the bar. A wasted opportunity.
Luisao makes an important block to deny Dembele in the box as the Frenchman collected a low pass from Durm and went for the strike, but the veteran defender blocked his path.
Schmelzer covers Rafa Silva's run to the near post, heading a cross from Semedo behind for a corner.
Dembele takes possession twice in the final third in the space of a minute for the visitors, but loses it very easily. Not the best start for the Frenchman.
Salvio makes an early raid down the right and he races to the byline to cut the ball back into the box, but Sokratis is on hand to clear the danger.
We're underway at the Estadio da Luz.
The players are making their way out on to the pitch, so we should be underway shortly.
STAT ATTACK! Dortmund have lost six of their last eight matches in the Champions League knockout stages.

Dortmund have made four changes from their defeat to Darmstadt 98. Lukasz Piszczek, Marcel Schmelzer, Ousmane Dembele and Marc Bartra are all recalled into the team to face the Portuguese outfit this evening.
Benfica have made two changes from their win over Arouca last week. Eduardo Salvio and Rafa Silva come back into the side to replace Andrija Zivkovic and Jonas in the starting line-up.
Dortmund subs: Weidenfeller, Schurrle, Pulisic, Kagawa, Ginter, Passlack.
DORTMUND (5-3-2): Burki; Piszczek, Papastathopoulos, Bartra, Schmelzer, Durm; Dembele, Weigl, Guerreiro; Reus, Aubameyang.
Benfica subs: Filipe, Samaris, Jimenez, Cesar, Cervi, Jardel, Almeida.
BENFICA (4-4-2): Ederson; Semedo, Luisao, Lindelof, Eliseu; Salvio, Fejsa, Pizzi, Carrillo; Silva, Mitroglou.
The team news has been announced and we'll start with the home side.
Tuchel's men have not progressed beyond the round-of-16 since the 2013-14 season and will need to put in a stout display this evening in a raucous atmosphere in the Estadio da Luz.

Dortmund enjoyed an excellent campaign in the group stage, finishing above Real Madrid in Group F. Thomas Tuchel's men claimed four wins out of six, drawing twice with the Spanish giants on their way to the knockout phase.

Rui Vitoria's men were made to scrap for their place the first knockout round - just edging in front of Besiktas to secure their spot. The Portuguese outfit reached the quarter-finals of the competition last term and will be determined to overcome Dortmund starting with a strong display tonight.
Good evening and welcome to the live commentary of the Champions League clash between Benfica and Borussia Dortmund.
news: Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang missed a penalty in a nightmare outing as Kostas Mitroglou's opportunistic strike gave Benfica a 1-0 victory over Borussia Dortmund in the first leg of their Champions League last-16 tie.

The usually dependable Aubameyang spurned three excellent chances to get Dortmund an away goal at the Estadio da Luz and was withdrawn by coach Thomas Tuchel after 62 minutes, with Benfica holding on to gain the upper hand.
Dortmund started positively but Aubameyang was unable to finish a one-on-one chance in the early exchanges, to set the tone for his dismal game.
Rui Vitoria's side took the lead when Mitroglou converted off a header from Luisao - the 36-year-old captain marking his 500th Benfica appearance with an assist.
After missing a great chance to draw level, Aubameyang looked certain to score when referee Nicola Rizzoli awarded Dortmund a penalty for handball by Ljubomir Fejsa.

However, the striker's weak penalty was kept out by the brilliant Ederson, and Benfica withstood late pressure following Aubameyang's withdrawal to ensure they take an advantage to Signal Iduna Park on March 8.
Dortmund scored a Champions League record 21 goals in the group stage and they first bared their teeth in the 10th minute.
Ousmane Dembele won possession in the opposition half and slid an excellent pass to put Aubameyang one-on-one with Ederson, but he could only fire over from 12 yards.

Dortmund used their control of the ball to slow the tempo after a frantic start and their high pressing continued to cause Benfica problems, Victor Lindelof colliding with Ederson when blocking another Dembele effort.

The hosts had to soak up plenty of pressure but Fejsa almost undid their good work when he failed to shepherd the ball out under pressure from Raphael Guerreiro, who stole in to roll a pass across the face of a vacant goal and agonisingly out of Aubameyang's reach.
Tuchel was furious his side were not awarded at least a free-kick when Dembele was clattered by Ederson on the edge of the area and Rizzoli saw no foul.
The hosts went ahead three minutes after the restart when Mitroglou stuck out a leg to stop Luisao's header from reaching the diving Roman Burki, before slotting into the gaping net.

Aubameyang wasted another glorious opening when he swiped over five minutes later, while Ederson produced great stops from Marco Reus and Lukasz Piszczek before the Gabon captain's outing took another turn for the worse.

Fejsa handled inside the area to concede a penalty, but Aubameyang was unable to take advantage as his poor effort straight down the middle was batted away by a squatting Ederson and Tuchel quickly hooked him for Andre Schurrle.

Dortmund pressed for an equaliser but saw Piszczek head wide before Ederson capped a sensational display by clawing Christian Pulisic's deflected volley out of the top corner, leaving Benfica fans dreaming of a Champions League quarter-final at the Estadio da Luz for the second successive season.

commentary: That's all for our live coverage, thanks for following along. Goodbye!

Goals from Diego Costa and Gary Cahill late in each half see the Blues extend their lead atop the Premier League table to a seemingly impregnable eight points. It was far from comfortable, but it's job done in the end for Antonio Conte's side.
FULL-TIME: CHELSEA 2-0 HULL.
Both teams have switched off, accepting the inevitable result here. The tempo has gone as Chelsea pass it around patiently, waiting for the clock to run out.
There will be four minutes added on for injuries and stoppages.

This is a crucial result for Chelsea when you look ahead at their next two league fixtures, away to Liverpool and home to Arsenal. A slip up here today and their lead at the top would all of a sudden have started looking a bit more penetrable.
Costa goes off to a stirring ovation from the home fans, replaced by Michy Batshuayi for the final minutes.

It should be signed, sealed and delivered now for Chelsea, who are playing looser once again. It's going to appear a routine victory for them on the scoresheet, but it's really been anything but this evening against a plucky Hull side.
STAT: Chelsea are unbeaten in their nine Premier League meetings with Hull (W7 D2), keeping six clean sheets in the process.
Fabregas is off the bench and into the scoresheet with an assist.

THAT SHOULD SEAL IT! Cahill's header is tucked in at the far post, but that was all in the quality of the delivery from Fabregas, following a good bit of skill from Willian to win the free-kick. What an impact from the two Chelsea substitutes!

This has the feel of a game where Chelsea might just need a second goal. They certainly could use the breathing room for their own peace of mind, because it's shaping up to be a tense finish at Stamford Bridge, on what could be the perfect weekend for the Blues - otherwise it will be an opportunity missed.

At the risk of patronising Hull, this has been a very intrepid and unflinching display from them. They've come up against the league leaders, on their turf, and are really taking it to them in this second half. You almost feel like they deserve a reward at this point.
Hull's third and final change sees Adama Diomande come on to replace Hernandez.
STAT: Hull's only previous Premier League goal at Stamford Bridge was in August 2009, Stephen Hunt giving the Tigers the lead before eventually losing 1-2.
Willian also enters the fray, at the expense of Pedro.
A double switch here from Chelsea, the first of which sees Cesc Fabregas replace Hazard.

Moses flings his arms up in the air rather recklessly to block Robertson's cross from coming through, which gifts Hull a free-kick out wide. The ensuing delivery is too deep, however, before Niasse's ambitious effort from a difficult angle sails miles over the bar.

The Tigers are playing with a real discernable sense of belief here. This has been by far their best spell of the match, spurred on by the Davies substitution, which prompted a switch to a more standard back four. Niasse is also proving a good outlet on the right.

Hull are continuing in the ascendency, as these Chelsea supporters begin to grow a bit restless. The league leaders are ahead, but it's all been rather pedestrian, if not uninspiring, from them this evening.

This second half has been devoid of any real attacking quality. In fact, it's Hull who have produced the two best moments on the front foot since the restart, with Meyler's shot and Hernandez's penalty shout - maybe just a reason for them to believe here.
STAT: Victor Moses is the seventh different player to assist Diego Costa in the Premier League this season. It was his first Premier League assist at Stamford Bridge since May 2013.
Oumar Niasse, who made his home debut last weekend against Bournemouth, comes on to replace the injured Davies.

Play resumes without Davies, as Hull don't have a substitute prepared yet. This is proving a bit of a nightmare for Marco Silva, who's being forced into a second change of the match as a result of injury.
Davies has a problem now for Hull, as he goes down with what appears to be a hamstring injury, before signaling over to the touchline as if to indicate he needs to come off.
Courtois called into action for a second time this evening! He hasn't been the busiest of keepers, but that's two important saves now, this one to deny Meyler's effort from just outside the area.

Robertson, who has a horrid time trying to track Moses on the flank, puts in a late challenge to take the wing-back to ground, earning a yellow card and conceding a free-kick in a decent area for Chelsea to whip in a cross here.
STAT: At 51 minutes and 35 seconds, Diego Costa's is the latest 1st half goal since Opta started recording exact times (2006-07).

Decent penalty shout! Alonso puts in a really needless intervention on Hernandez inside the area after the ball had gone. It had no effect on the play, but it was a foul and it came inside the area, so he's very lucky not to have conceded a penalty there.
Here we go again...

Stern resistance and sound organisation from Hull at the back is broken deep in stoppage-time by Diego Costa, as Chelsea's persistence pays off. Hull will feel hard done by, as there appeared to be a foul on Abel Hernandez by Gary Cahill in the build-up, but they only have themselves to blame as they had a more than a few chances to snuff out the move between the non-call and the goal.
HALF-TIME: CHELSEA 1-0 HULL CITY.
Moses provides the assist.

DEEP IN ADDED TIME, CHELSEA LEAD! Moses makes a delightful run down the right flank and somehow manages to thread a low cross through a crowd of bodies, straight to the feet of Costa in the centre, and he's never going to miss from there!

NEARLY THERE! Alonso finds space out wide and flashes in a delightful low cross, which only needed a touch from Kante! The midfielder can't meet it, however, as it arrives safely into the hands of Jakupovic.
That's a wasted opportunity by the Blues, as Pedro's delivery from the free-kick doesn't have the pace needed behind it to really test the Hull defence.

Davies is a lucky boy! He lunges into a challenge on the very edge of the box, clearly taking out Pedro and none of the ball. It's a free-kick for the Blues, and a stern talking to for the Hull centre-half, who is already on a yellow. That was likely his final warning.
The board goes up to indicate nine minutes of stoppage-time at the end of this first half. No real surprise there.

FINE SAVE! It's Hull who negotiate the best chance of the match thus far, with Maguire stinging the palms of Courtois from just over 20 yards! He got all of that strike, did the Tigers centre-half, and what a shock lead that would have been.
A hard foul on the halfway line sees Kante into the book. Three yellow cards handed out here so far in the first half.

While we're nearing the 45th minute, there should be a lot more time added on at the end of the half, considering the lengthy stoppage following the Mason injury. The game was brought to a halt for nearly eight minutes before play restarted, so it will be interesting to see if they're all accounted for.

Hull are in no hurry whatsoever to get the ball forward when they win it back, and Chelsea aren't looking particularly keen to get at them, either. There's just no real flow to this match in the first half, which has proved tedious viewing from a neutral standpoint.

It remains tough sledding for Chelsea in attack. There's simply not been enough movement off the ball to open up lanes for passes to come through. The bulk of their possession has been away from the danger areas.

Well for all of Chelsea's dominance in possession, they've been limited to just the one shot on target thus far. It's been a virtual walk in the park for Jakupovic, though the same can't be said for his defence, who have worked fervently to protect him.
STAT: Pedro has been directly involved in more Premier League goals this season (10, 5 goals, 5 assists) than the whole of last season (9 - 7 goals, 2 assists).

Appeals for a penalty as Pedro goes down in the area, but he doesn't win the decision from Swarbrick, who has a good look before pointing towards the corner flag. Luiz was up there as well, and his unexpected presence really seemed to throw off the Hull defence.

Pressure is starting to build again on the Hull defence. They're being pegged back here, unable to win it back, and sloppy with their passing when they do get the chance to break. The noise level is starting to increase again, after an extended period of quiet in the stands.
Mason's injury has, understandably, sucked the life out of this match. It's really struggled to get going again, with Chelsea doing their best to increase the tempo, but to no real avail as of yet.
This isn't shaping up all to well for Hull, who now have two of their three centre-backs on a booking as Davies is shown a yellow card.

It's always a tough thing for these players, especially from a Hull perspective, to carry on after that sort of scene. Mason is in the best hands possible, so all they can do at this point is try and maintain their focus and get a result for their team-mate, which, of course, is easier said than done.
STAT: Eden Hazard needs one more goal to reach double figures in the Premier League this season, something he's done twice before (14 goals in 2013/14 and 2014/15).
A rousing, if not slightly poignant applause echoes throughout the ground as Mason is carried off the pitch. David Meyler comes on to replace him, and the match is set to resume.

Still Mason is on the ground, being prepped. He has the oxygen mask taped to his face, neck secured in a brace, and his legs strapped together. Hopefully all this is simply a precaution, and Mason is healthy going forward.

Good work from the medical staff here, who take all the proper precautions as they secure Mason in preparation for lifting him onto the stretcher. It's a lengthy process and one which should by no means be rushed.

Cahill is back on his feet, walking off the knock, but Mason remains down in rather ominous fashion. The stretcher is out for him, with an oxygen mask strapped to his face. Somber moments at Stamford Bridge, and you could hear a pin drop at the moment.

Scary moments here as Cahill runs on to meet a cross, but winds up clashing heads with Mason. Both players go to ground in a heap, with referee Neil Swarbrick immediately calling towards the touchline for the training staffs to come out.

Hull are doing well to keep organised under consistent pressure, at least keeping the hosts to the periphery. The deliveries in from the wide areas have been dealt with accordingly, and they're starting to play with a bit more confidence as a result.
STAT: Hull's last league win against Chelsea came in the old second division, winning 3-0 at Boothferry Park in October 1988.
Dawson is booked for a bad foul on Pedro - an early and unwelcomed booking for the centre-half, who will be walking a tight line the rest of the way.
Chelsea seem keen to build down that right-hand side, with Moses and Pedro particularly lively in the early stages here. It's been one-way traffic, as many would have expected, straight from the off.

Expectedly controlled start here from Chelsea, who are playing with the utmost confidence at the moment. They're knocking the ball around at will, playing keep-away from Hull, who are already scrambling a bit off the ball.

INCHES WIDE! It takes just 10 seconds for Chelsea to issue a statement of intent, as a long ball over the top from Luiz presents Costa with a chance on the volley, which he flashes fractions wide of the near post!
AND THEY'RE OFF! Chelsea get us underway, attacking right to left.
The teams are out on the pitch at Stamford Bridge, with kick-off rapidly approaching!
STAT: Costa has scored in all three of his previous Premier League appearances against Hull, assisting twice.
Hull substitutes: Marshall, Meyler, Maloney, Diomande, Niasse, Tymon, Bowen.
Hull (3-5-2): Jakupovic; Maguire, Dawson, Davies; Elabdellaoui, Mason, Huddlestone, Clucas, Roberston; Evandro, Hernandez.
Chelsea substitutes: Begovic, Ake, Zouma, Chalobah, Fabregas, Willian, Batshuayi.
Chelsea (3-4-3): Courtois; Azpilicueta, David Luiz, Cahill; Moses, Kante, Matic, Alonso; Pedro, Costa, Hazard.

The big pre-match news, however, is that Diego Costa is back in the starting line-up for Chelsea. The striker was dropped for last weekend's 3-0 win over Leicester City amid reports of a bust-up with Antonio Conte and interest from the Chinese Super League. He returns to make his 100th appearance for the club today, and the full line-ups are coming now.

The Tigers sit just one point off the bottom, but a shock-victory today, which would be a first for them against the Blues in the Premier League, could pull them ahead of Swansea and out of the bottom-three.

Hull City got the win they so desperately craved last weekend against Bournemouth, just their second since the end of August, but they’re in tough to keep that momentum going today against a Chelsea side firing on all cylinders.

Liverpool, Tottenham, Manchester City and Manchester United all dropped points yesterday, meaning the Blues can go eight-points clear atop the table in what, at least on paper, appears a very winnable fixture for them.
Chelsea were idle on Saturday but the stars aligned for Antonio Conte and company as results elsewhere have the runaway top-flight leaders poised to increase the gap at the Premier League summit.
Hello and welcome to Stamford Bridge as Chelsea aim to widen their lead atop the Premier League table when they play host to relegation-threatened Hull City!
news: Diego Costa returned to the Chelsea fold with a bang as his 15th Premier League goal of the season and a late header from Gary Cahill saw off a feisty Hull City 2-0.

Costa missed last weekend's 3-0 win at Leicester City with a back injury amid intense speculation of a falling-out with head coach Antonio Conte, but the Italian clearly held no grudge, with his star striker immediately back in the team to make his 100th Chelsea appearance.

And the Spain international proved pivotal, scoring in the seventh minute of first-half injury time - brought on by a nasty-looking head injury to Ryan Mason - prompting a typically fiery celebration in which he intimated that much of the talk doubting his future at Stamford Bridge was just that.
Cahill wrapped up the victory nine minutes from time to send Chelsea eight points clear at the top of the table, with Arsenal the only other team in the top six to pick up a win this weekend.

The Blues' 13-game winning run at the back end of 2016 had been kick-started at the KCOM Stadium in October, but they were not at their best this time around in the face of stern resistance from Marco Silva's men.
Harry Maguire was influential at both ends of the pitch, Thibaut Courtois was called into regular action and Hull were unlucky to not be awarded a second-half penalty.

Silva's start to life at the club has been positive but a pre-match claim that it was proving "impossible" to keep in-demand top scorer Robert Snodgrass - injured for this match - in East Yorkshire could spell trouble.
This was another composed performance for Hull, although Costa immediately looked in the mood, drilling wide with just 10 seconds on the clock.
But the Blues could not keep their foot down early on, with Hull frustrating them until the game was punctuated by an eight-minute period of treatment for Mason after a clash of heads with Cahill.
Hull came out of that break strongly, Maguire marauding out of the back three to force a corner, from which he headed unchallenged at Courtois.
That scare sharpened the hosts.

Marcos Alonso's deflected shot had Eldin Jakupovic scrambling to keep the ball out of the top corner before Eden Hazard began to exert more influence over the game, hitting the byline to cause panic in the Tigers' backline which saw debutant Omar Elabdellaoui stumble into Pedro - referee Neil Swarbrick waved away the penalty appeals.
Again Silva's side hunkered down to stem Chelsea's momentum and Maguire once more tested Courtois, this time with a thunderous 25-yard shot.

But the swollen amount of first-half stoppage time helped the Blues move ahead, Costa slamming home after Victor Moses had burst past Andy Robertson and immediately making his feelings on his situation known.

City were furious to see a clear foul on Abel Hernandez by Alonso in the area go unpunished five minutes into the second half before Courtois saved an effort from Mason's replacement David Meyler and Costa had three shots in quick succession repelled with space opening up.

Curtis Davies limped off to further stretch Silva's thinning resources and the visitors eventually ran out of steam, Cahill heading home unmarked to cap another Chelsea win that restores a healthy cushion at the top.

commentary: In the end, it was a comfortable evening for United, who were easily able to weather a minor Etienne storm in the first half and deservedly leave with a three-goal lead that should mean that they are safely into the next round of the competition. They were comfortably the better of the two sides during the second period and made Etienne pay for some sloppy defending, leaving them with what should be an easy job to complete next week.
FULL-TIME: MANCHESTER UNITED 3-0 SAINT ETIENNE

Ibrahimovic picks up the ball just outside of the Etienne box and is immediately clattered into from behind, resulting in a late free-kick for the osts. Paul Pogba steps up and unleashes a great shot, but it swings just a few inches wide of the post after leaving Ruffier rooted to the spot.

Etienne keep trying to push forward as they attempt to find an away goal to take home with them ahead of next week's second leg. They're unable to do so, however, as more good defending from Bailly stops a curling cross from finding a green shirt in front of goal.
The fourth official has indicated that there will be four minutes of added time.
GOAL! Ibrahimovic steps up and easily wraps up his hat-trick as he sends Ruffier the wrong way and fires a lovely low shot into the bottom left-hand corner of the net.

PENALTY! Ibrahimovic, who has been in great form this evening, muscles his way into the Etienne penalty area before being clumsily caught from behind by Theophile-Catherine, leaving the referee with no choice but to point to the spot.
United have made a late change, with Ashley Young coming on to replace Martial, who receives a rousing round of applause from the home fans as he makes way.

Saivet steps up and unleashes a curling shot from the set-piece, but his shot flies into a flailing arm and results in another free-kick. Once again he decides to shoot, but another poor strike fails to test Romero.

Veretout breaks forward on a rare Etienne attack as the visitors desperately try to get back into the game at this late stage, but he's bundled over by Bailly and wins his side a free-kick in a very dangerous position just outside of the penalty area.

Ball after ball is fired into the Etienne penalty area, but, somehow, the French side are able to hold on. The last of the crosses is arguably the best, as Ibrahimovic fizzed pass across the face of goal narrowly misses two team-mates before being blasted away.
Etienne are forced into making their final substitution of the game after Florentin Pogba goes down off the ball, resulting in him having to make way for Robert Beric.

Lingard almost makes it 3-0! This time it's Martial who embarks on a fantastic run towards the Etienne box before teeing up Lingard, but the winger's shot from 20 yards out ends up curling just wide of the near post after beating Ruffier.

GOAL! Ibrahimovic has doubled United's lead! Rashford makes a great run forward as he skips into the Etienne penalty area and towards the near post. He then fires a low pass across the face of goal that Ruffier can only palm out to Ibrahimovic, who is then easily able to tap the ball into the back of the net from a few yards out.

What a chance for Roux to equalise for Etienne! Selnaes is immediately called into action as he pokes a great pass into the path of Roux, but the forward is unable to chip the ball into the back of the net after beating Romero with his close-range strike.
Etienne have made a further alteration, with Pajot making way for Ole Selnaes.
Paul Pogba backs into Veretout and ends up catching the Etienne midfielder with a flailing arm, and he's the latest player to receive a yellow card as a result.
United have made their second change, with Marcus Rashford coming on to take the place of Mata.

Paul Pogba hits the crossbar! Martial is fouled as he tries to fly forward, resulting in a free-kick for United in a dangerous position. It's curled into the penalty area and finds Pogba at the far post, but his bullet header smashes off the crossbar after beating the outstretched hand of Ruffier.

Perrin has been in the wars this evening, as, after being clattered in the head by Smalling, this time he receives a high boot from Lingard that catches him on the ankle and results in a yellow card for the United winger.
Etienne have made their first alteration of the night, with Jorginho making way for Nolan Roux.
Pajot dives into the back of Herrera and catches the Spaniard with a poorly-timed challenge, resulting in the referee adding his name to his notebook.

Chance for Paul Pogba! The midfielder beautifully spins round Veretout just outside of the Etienne penalty area before trying to beat Ruffier with a curling strike, but the goalkeeper dives well to his right to deny the United man with a fine save.

Herrera is caught on the ball in the middle of the pitch by Saivet, who then flies forward. He works the ball out to Monnet-Paquet and a low cross is then fired into the heart of the box, but it fails to pick out a green shirt and is easily cleared by Smalling.

Valencia is put under pressure deep down the right wing as Etienne try to put pressure on a United back line that have barely been tested since the break, but the Ecuadorian does well to keep three players at bay before earning the hosts a goal-kick.

The set-piece is curled into the heart of the penalty area and finds Paul Pogba, but his downward header is cut out by his brother and results in an Etienne counter-attack. Jorginho charges down the right wing before taking on Ander Herrera, but the Spaniard brings the Portuguese crashing to the ground with a mistimed challenge that earns him a yellow card that rules him out for the second leg.

Valencia goes close! Ibrahimovic out-muscles his marker on the edge of the box before teeing up Valencia to his right, but the full-back's thumping strike is deflected just wide of the far post and out for a corner.

Martial pushes forward on another marauding run before trying to tee up Paul Pogba inside the penalty area, but the midfielder doesn't react to the pass from his fellow Frenchman and Etienne are just about able to deal with the danger.

Almost a lovely goal for Martial! The Frenchman embarks on a wonderful run as he skips into the Etienne box. He easily beats Malcuit before taking on Ruffier, but the goalkeeper pulls off a strong save to deny the winger at the near post.

A deflected Blind cross bounces out of the Etienne penalty area and towards Paul Pogba, but the midfielder's thumping effort fails to hit the target and instead sails several yards over the top of the crossbar.

Ouch! United win themselves a free-kick over on the right flank after Valencia is caught by Veretout. The set-piece is curled into the box but is cut out by Perrin, who then receives a heavy blow to the head from Smalling as the two battle for the ball. The Etienne captain is left in serious discomfort in a heap on the floor.

Ibrahimovic scores, but it's ruled out for offside! Mata cuts inside from the right wing and fires a great cross into the middle of the Etienne penalty area. It swings into the box and picks out Ibrahimovic, who then beats Ruffier with a bullet header, but the striker is slightly offside and the linesman's flag is quickly raised.

Lingard makes an immediate impact as he ploughs through the middle of the pitch on a speedy run. He tees up Ibrahimovic, who takes on Theophile-Catherine before linking up with Martial, but the Frenchman is quickly penalised for a flailing arm that catches Malcuit in the face.
United have made one substitution during the break, with Jesse Lingard coming on to replace Fellaini.
We're underway once again!
The two teams are making their way back out on to the pitch ahead of the start of the second half.

It hasn't been the best of first-half performances from United, but they nonetheless find themselves with a one-goal lead heading into the half-time break. They've arguably been the better of the two sides despite dropping off late on, and the half-time break certainly came at a good time for them as Etienne started to find more joy pushing forward. Hamouma and Monnet-Paquet have impressed in front of goal, whilst Malcuit has started finding some space deep down the right wing.
HALF-TIME: MANCHESTER UNITED 1-0 SAINT ETIENNE

Malcuit sprints down the right wing on an impressive run before cutting a low pass back into the United box. It flies past three red shirts before falling nicely for Pajot, but the midfielder's first touch is poor and allows the ball run under his boot. It's picked up by Monnet-Paquet, but the winger can't swing his curling shot anywhere near the goal.

Etienne keep putting pressure on United as they try to find a way back into the game before the half-time break. This time it's Veretout who attempts to start something for the visitors, but his cross-cum-shot from 30 yards out fails to find either a team-mate or the back of the net.

United are caught out in the middle of the pitch, allowing Hamouma to fly through on goal. He's easily able to skip past Bailly as he sprints into the penalty area, but the striker's eventual shot is poor and sails comfortably wide of the near post.

It's Etienne who are on top at the moment, and they're doing well to put United under a good amount of pressure as we near the half-time break. Hamouma drifts out to the left and picks up the ball on the side of the penalty area before poking it back to Monnet-Paquet, but the winger can't direct his shot on target and instead sends it trickling into the hands of Romero via the outstretched foot of Chris Smalling.

Another important block by Bailly! A looping cross flies into the United penalty area and finds Hamouma in a promising position in front of goal. The striker immediately unleashes a well-timed half-volley, but Bailly is there to close down the danger once again.

Etienne continue enjoying good spells of possession as they patiently push forward. They get themselves into a promising position before Pajot decides to try and test Romero from 30 yards out, but the midfielder's long-range effort isn't hit well enough to trouble the Argentine.

Mata flies through the Etienne defence as he tries to latch on to a thumping pass forward from Valencia, but his run into the penalty area is slightly mistimed and, as a result, he's flagged offside just as he's about to unleash a shot on goal.

Ibrahimovic receives a low pass 25 yards away from the Etienne goal and quickly chips a pass into the French side's penalty area. It looks set to bounce into the path of Mata in front of goal, but the Spaniard is beaten to the ball by Kevin Theophile-Catherine and loses out to the centre-back at the near post.

And then Martial and Ibrahimovic both almost score! United hit Etienne on a counter-attack of their own, and it's one that narrowly avoids doubling their lead. Martial dances his way into the penalty area before unleashing a shot, but it's saved by Ruffier and takes Ibrahimovic by surprise, resulting in the striker poking his follow-up effort just over the top of the crossbar.

Saivet goes close to equalising! A pass from Paul Pogba can only find his brother, and the full-back quickly kick-starts a swift counter-attack. Hamouma darts down the left wing on a great run before cutting inside and finding Saivet, but the on-loan forward can't find the bottom left-hand corner of the net with his toe-poked shot.

Jorginho is caught by a late challenge from Ibrahimovic, resulting in a free-kick for Etienne just inside the United half of the pitch. It's quickly fired over the top of the hosts' back line and towards Hamouma, but, despite his best efforts, the striker is unable to make contact with the ball inside the box.

Valencia is caught sleeping on the ball by Monnet-Paquet and allows the winger to dart his way into the United penalty area. He does well to reach the byline before trying to tee up a team-mate with a cross, but Bailly dives in front of the ball to stop it from finding a green shirt.

What a chance for Mata! A lovely chipped pass from Pogba flies through the Etienne back line and finds Mata unmarked in front of goal. The Spaniard meets the ball well and immediately fires a volleyed strike towards goal, but Ruffier pulls off a great diving save to deny him the second goal of the game.

Fellaini battles his way into the Etienne penalty area before winning United a corner over on the right wing. It's swung towards the near post by Mata and almost finds a red shirt, but the visitors have plenty of bodies in front of goal to easily deal with the danger.

Etienne are able to string together a good series of passes before Malcuit cuts inside from the right flank and tries to take on Paul Pogba. He's unable to beat the United man, however, and the midfielder easily wins the ball back for the home side.

Veretout dispossesses Martial just outside of the Etienne penalty area and kick-starts a quick counter-attack for the French side. It's worked over to Hamouma, who cuts inside and tees up Jorginho, but the Portuguese winger loses his footing under pressure from Blind and is unable to get a shot away from inside the United box.

Despite starting the better of the two sides, Etienne have struggled over the last quarter of an hour and have seen very little of the ball. United are looking confident in possession and are doing well to continually put their opponents under plenty of pressure.

GOAL! It's 1-0 to United! Ibrahimovic steps up and unleashes a low shot from the set-piece that flies into the wall in front of him. It deflects off the ankle of Vincent Pajot and towards goal, and, somehow, the ball rolls slowly past both Loic Perrin and Ruffier and into the back of the net.

United have taken the lead! Daley Blind gets himself into a good position deep down the left flank and quickly sets up Ibrahimovic on the edge of the penalty area, but the Swede is bundled over by Jordan Veretout as soon as he makes contact with the ball. The referee awards a free-kick just outside of the box, and it's certainly in a great position for the home side.

Henri Saivet is caught sleeping on the ball in the middle of the pitch, allowing Ibrahimovic to charge forward. The striker darts towards the penalty area before trying to penetrate the box, but Kevin Malcuit is there to help out his team-mate with an important interception.

Ibrahimovic battles his way towards the Etienne penalty area once again before winning his side a throw-in over on the right flank. It's taken quickly and sent to Mata, who then swings a cross into the middle of the box, but Fellaini is unable to flick the ball on to Martial and the Etienne defence are easily able to deal with the danger.

Chance for Anthony Martial! An Etienne attack breaks down, allowing United to counter quickly. They do so through Ibrahimovic, who charges down the left wing before teeing up Martial, but the Frenchman is unable to beat Stephane Ruffier with his curling shot from 25 yards out.

The home side patiently pass the ball around inside the Etienne half of the pitch before Paul Pogba picks out Antonio Valencia with an excellent cross-field pass. The full-back brings it down beautifully and skips past Florentin Pogba before teeing up Juan Mata, who quickly links up with Marouane Fellaini, but the linesman's flag is raised a few seconds before the Belgian rifles a low strike into the bottom left-hand corner of the net.

United do well to break out of their own half of the pitch and work the ball up to Paul Pogba, who then tries to curl a cross into the Etienne penalty area and towards Zlatan Ibrahimovic. He's unable to pick out the Swedish striker, however, and the ball sails out of play.

Almost another costly mistake! United are caught out at the back once again as they fall asleep on the ball inside their own box. It allows Romain Hamouma to round Sergio Romero before looking to shoot, but he's unable to do so from a tight angle and is eventually dispossessed, much to the hosts' relief.

United embark on a good start to the game as they put Etienne under plenty of early pressure. A poor pass from Eric Bailly seems the lose the ball, however, but Kevin Monnet-Paquet's low cross from the left-hand side of the hosts' penalty area is well cleared by the Ivorian centre-back.
We're off! United get us underway, attacking from left to right.
The two sides are making their way out onto the pitch, with just a few minutes to go until kick-off.

Meanwhile, Etienne boss Christophe Galtier has named an unchanged side to the one that featured in their last outing, with Florentin Pogba once again featuring at left-back as he takes on his younger brother Paul for the first time.

Jose Mourinho has decided to make two changes to the United side that started the 2-0 victory at home to Watford on the weekend, with Sergio Romero and Marouane Fellaini coming into the starting line-up to replace David De Gea and Henrikh Mkhitaryan, respectively.
Saint Etienne substitutes: Moulin, Pierre-Gabriel, Lacroix, Selnaes, Lemoine, Beric, Roux.
Saint Etienne XI (4-2-3-1): Ruffier; Malcuit, Theophile-Catherine, Perrin, Florentin Pogba; Veretout, Pajot; Jorginho, Saivet, Monnet-Paquet; Hamouma.
Manchester United substitutes: De Gea, Darmian, Rojo, Young, Schweinsteiger, Lingard, Rashford.
Manchester United XI (4-3-3): Romero; Valencia, Bailly, Smalling, Blind; Herrera, Fellaini, Paul Pogba; Mata, Ibrahimovic, Martial.
There’s just over 15 minutes left to go until kick-off, so let’s have a look at how the two teams will be lining up this evening…

The two sides have only met one another in a European competition on two previous occasions way back in 1977, with United winning 2-0 on home soil after drawing 1-1 in France. Crowd trouble in the first leg meant that the return fixture was played in Plymouth rather than Manchester, meaning that tonight’s game will be the first ever meeting between the two at Old Trafford.

Etienne will be far from easy opponents, however, as they have lost just one of their previous 16 Europa League games. They enjoyed an unbeaten group stage campaign to finish top of Group C, one point clear of Anderlecht thanks to a final day win against the Belgian side, sending them through to the knockout stage of the competition for the second consecutive campaign.

After suffering a disappointing start to the group stage with a 1-0 defeat away to Feyenoord, United went on to win four of their next five clashes to finish in second place in Group A. Their final two encounters saw them hit their stride with easy victories against both Feyenoord and Zorya, and, coupled with the impressive domestic run that they currently find themselves on, they will no doubt be feeling confident about their chances of winning here this evening.

With Premier League, FA Cup, EFL Cup and Europa League games all to take part in over the next few weeks, United’s current schedule is proving to be a rather hectic one. Their main focus is undoubtedly to secure a place in next season’s Champions League, and Jose Mourinho has been quick to reassure fans that his side will give it their all in the Europa League, mainly due to the guaranteed Champions League place reserved for the winners of the competition.
Good evening and welcome to our live text commentary of today’s Europa League last-32 first leg tie between Manchester United and Saint Etienne at Old Trafford.
news: Manchester United claimed a 3-0 win over Saint-Etienne in the first leg of their Europa League last-32 tie thanks to a first hat-trick for the club from Zlatan Ibrahimovic.
The striker's deflected free-kick after quarter of an hour and a second-half double were enough to give the home side an important if not wholly convincing victory at Old Trafford.

The match - which saw brothers Paul and Florentin Pogba face one another for the first time competitively - was United's first of four in only 10 days, but manager Jose Mourinho nonetheless named a strong side in an effort to take control of the tie.

Ibrahimovic duly obliged with the opening goal after 15 minutes - his 21st of the season in all competitions - but Saint-Etienne looked a real threat for much of the first half against a United side that seemed strangely imbalanced and out-of-sorts.

Mourinho responded with a tactical tweak after the break and the home side soon began to assume control of proceedings, although Ibrahimovic saw a second goal disallowed and Anthony Martial missed a good chance of his own to double the lead.

Paul Pogba hit the crossbar before Nolan Roux wasted a glorious opportunity for a vital away goal, but Ibrahimovic added a second from close range before adding a late third from the penalty spot to make certain of the win and give United a strong chance of progressing to the last 16.

Mata blasted a volley straight at Ruffier as United pushed for a second, and Ibrahimovic contrived to turn a loose ball over the bar from less than six yards out after Martial's mazy run and shot saw the ball blocked into his path.

The visitors - roared on by their boisterous following - were certainly not daunted by their deficit, though, and Henri Saivet missed the best of a number of half-chances as they began to stroll through United's midfield to attack the back four almost at will.

Ibrahimovic had a header correctly ruled out for offside and Martial saw another strong run and strike blocked by Ruffier, as United began to look a little more settled in their pursuit of a second goal.

Paul Pogba spun superbly before curling a shot narrowly wide, but the France star should have done better when he headed Daley Blind's fine delivery against the crossbar when unmarked at the far post soon after.

Substitute Roux lifted the ball over Romero and onto the roof of the net when played clean through on the break following Saint-Etienne's best move of the match, and that miss was punished scarcely two minutes later - much to the relief of the home fans inside Old Trafford.

commentary: FULL TIME: West Ham 2 West Brom 2. Late second half drama sees West Ham come away with one point when they should have hung on for three after Lanzini's 86th minute strike. Bilic sent to the stands after West Brom's equaliser deep into second half injury time.
Yellow card Mark Noble
GOAL!! LATE DRAMA! West Brom have drawn level to the disgust of Slaven Bilic. McAuley rises highest to head home a long throw in. Randolph nowhere near the ball. It's a simple header. 2-2.
Substitution: Feghouli leaves and Bilic throws on James Collins to try and preserve their lead.
Five added minutes for West Ham to cling to onto three points.
BOOKING: Chris Brunt is shown yellow in the closing stages. Frustration boiling over perhaps.
Substitution: Robert Snodgrass leaves the action for West Ham after a lively game. Edimilson Fernandes on in his place.

WHAT A GOAL!! West Ham lead! West Brom invited Lanzini to run at them and boy did he. He picks up a pass from Feghouli and fires a vicious left foot shot from 25 yards past a hapless Foster. 2-1 The Hammers lead.
YELLOW CARD: Winston Reid the second West Ham player in the book.
West Brom look content with a point at this stage. West Ham greeted with a sea of white and blue shirts once they get anywhere near the West Brom penalty area.
Substitution: Third and final change for Tony Pulis. James Morrison is brought off and Claudio Yacob enters. All hands on deck now for the visitors.
Rondon blazes his effort high and wide after Albion mount a rare assault on the Hammers' goal.
Foster almost went from hero to zero after his awful clearance attempt falls to Calleri. His effort from 25-yards is blocked sparing the former England goalkeeper's blushes.

Brilliant ball from Obiang who plays in Calleri. This time the second half sub brings out the best of Foster and the Albion shot stopper is at full stretch to keep it out and Dawson beats Lanzini to the second ball. West Ham corner. 1-1.
YELLOW CARD: Salomon Rondón goes in the book after a poor challenge on Obiang.
CHANCE: Feghouli is giving West Brom all sorts of problems. He scampers away down the right and sends in a brilliant cross for Calleri to attack. The little Argentine has his effort blocked. 1-1.
Another penalty shout for West Ham as Calleri takes a tumble under pressure from Dawson as he tries to bring in Antonio's little clip over the top. Michael Oliver again waves the shout away.
Substitution: Matt Phillips is brought off and in his place is Hal Robson-Kanu. The visitors looking for more impetus up front.
Hammers fans making all the noise now. West Brom under serious pressure.

GOAL!! Sofiane Feghouli pulls West Ham level. He reacts quickest to tap in after Foster excellently tips Lanzini's shot onto the bar. Snodgrass casues chaos with his cross that the West Brom defence don't properly clear. Bilic a happy man on the touchline.
Yellow card: Pedro Obiang is the first player in the book today for a mistimed challenge.
West Ham want a penalty for handball as Snodgrass' cross strikes Darren Fletcher. Not much of a protest from the players or the fans, shouting in more hope than expectation.
West Brom almost catch the home side out earning a corner for their efforts. Rondon forces Fonte to clear it behind. Their first attack of the second half.
Pulis takes action to stabilise his side. The goal-scorer Nacer Chadli reluctantly leaves to be replaced by Jonny Evans who has missed the last 4 games with a calf problem.
The visitors are on the ropes early in the second half. Feghouli puts in a low cross but no West Ham player attacks it and it is eventually cleared. Pulis looks on in discomfort.
Pinball in Ben Foster's box as Feghouli's attempt ricochets off a West Brom defender and left for Foster to smash the ball clear.
West Ham picking up where they left off in the first half, they are camped in the West Brom half of the field at the start of this second period.
West Ham have made a change during the break: Aaron Cresswell departs from the action with Jonathan Calleri entering in his place.
KICK OFF: West Brom get the ball rolling for the start of the second half.

HALF TIME: West Brom take a slim 1-0 lead into the dressing room. Boos ring around the Olympic Stadium, perhaps aimed at referee Michael Oliver. West Ham have worked themselves into decent positions but lack a clinical edge in the final third.
PENALTY SHOUT from West Ham. Feghouli feeds Snodgrass in the box and the Scotland international goes down under pressure from Dawson. Nothing doing for Oliver.
Three minutes of first half stoppage time added on by Michael Oliver.
CHANCE: Antonio heads over after a delicious outside foot cross from Snodgrass. West Ham have had plenty of half chances in the first 45 minutes but nothing clear cut.
Snodgrass' free kick from 25-yards out hits the wall. Mark Noble has a second bite at the cherry with a wicked effort that hits McAuley in the face.
All of The Hammers' big moments are coming down the right. Antonio finds Feghouli but the Algerian can't pick out the 5"5 Lanzini with his cross and it goes out for a corner.

Chances at both ends. Phillips' corner is not cleared and Brunt's stinging shot is blocked. Straight up the other end West Ham go with Antonio but his pass is too heavy for Feghouli and it is dealt with by Foster.
Andy Carroll clearly a big miss for the home side as Kouyate again finds space on the right flank but has very little to aim at with his cross.
West Ham shirts are swarming in and around the West Brom final third with Manuel Lanzini, Feghouli and Snodgrass all trying to unlock the firmly closed Albion door.
OFF THE LINE: Foster flaps at Snodgrass' corner, Michail Antonio heads the ball towards goal and it's desperatly hacked away by the visitors for another corner.
West Ham caught sleeping again as Rondon slips in Chadli. Once again the winger wrong foots Kouyate but this time his shot is straight into the waiting arms of Randolph.
CHANCE: Matt Phillips whips in a corner and Gareth McAuley attacks the ball with great intent. His effort forces another corner.
The claret and blue having much more of the ball in the last 15 minutes but unable to create any clear cut chances. West Brom typically disciplined.
A close shave for West Ham as a stray backpass from Winston Reid has Randolph sprinting out of his area to clear his lines with Rondon closing in.
Feghouli zips a shot from 20 yards out which whistles just wide of Foster's goal.
Slaven Bilic is less than pleased that his side have had a goal chalked off. However, his team are showing much more attacking intent.

NO GOAL: Short lived jubilation for the home fans as Sofiane Feghouli finds the net with a scruffy effort, after another brilliant free-kick delivery from Snodgrass, but Michael Oliver rules it out for a foul on Craig Dawson. Still the visitors lead 1-0.
WOODWORK: Salomon Rondon clips the bar with a fantastic dipping volley effort. Randolph was beaten, a let off for the home side. 0-1.
CLOSE: Snodgrass with a free-kick from the right of the West Brom box. His whipped ball evades everybody and forces Ben Foster into a smart save. West Ham earn a corner. 0-1.
West Ham are searching for the equaliser but finding it tough to break down the organised West Brom defence.

GOAL!! Perfect start for the visitors. James Morrison plays a pass to Nacer Chadli. The Belgian with a delightful nutmeg on Kouyate and then beats Darren Randolph with the same trick in the West Ham goal. West Ham 0 West Brom 1.
Early chance for the home side as Kouyate muscles his way into the box. His cross is just too awkward for Robert Snodgrass whose acrobatic attempt doesn't fluster West Brom. 0-0.
KICK OFF: West Ham get us underway. Michael Oliver is our referee today.
A loss could see West Ham potentially slide down the table into 12th.
West Brom are searching for their first away Premier League victory over The Hammers since 2002.
Heading into the game both sides have scored an identical number of goals in the Premier League with 32, but West Ham have shipped 12 more than today's opponents.

TEAM NEWS: West Brom starting XI: Foster; Nyom, Dawson, McAuley, Brunt; Livermore, Fletcher(c); Chadli, Morrison, Phillips; Rondon. Substitutes: McClean, Evans, Yacob, Olsson, Wilson, Robson-Kanu, Myhill. A 4-2-3-1 formation being deployed by Tony Pulis.

TEAM NEWS: West Ham starting XI: Randolph, Kouyate, Reid, Fonte, Cresswell, Obiang, Noble(c), Feghouli, Lanzini, Snodgrass, Antonio. Substitutes: Adrian, Collins, Byram, Nordtveit, Fernandes, Calleri, Fletcher. A tradition 4-4-2 formation for The Hammers.
news: An injury-time header from substitute Jonny Evans saw West Brom deny West Ham in the trademark style of manager Tony Pulis, as the Baggies pounced to snatch a dramatic 2-2 draw at London Stadium on Saturday.

The Hammers, missing injured striker Andy Carroll, may consider themselves hard done by not to take all three points in front of their fans, having had one goal disallowed and a penalty claim dismissed, while there was also a contentious element to Nacer Chadli's early opener for the Baggies.
West Ham overcame the disappointment of what must have appeared to be repeated misfortune to equalise soon after the hour-mark through Sofiane Feghouli.

After a sustained period of pressure, Manuel Lanzini struck to make it 2-1 in fine style with four minutes of regulation time to go, running at the West Brom defence before unleashing a long-range strike that Ben Foster was powerless to keep out.

But West Brom were not to be denied, Evans climbing highest at the back post to head a corner beyond Darren Randolph and snatch a point, prompting a furious reaction from Slaven Bilic that saw the West Ham manager follow his assistant in being sent off by referee Michael Oliver.
pic.twitter.com/lGg3eMAPDj
The result means West Brom remain eighth in the table, five points ahead of West Ham, who drop to 10th spot.

In a sign of things to come, there was controversy in the air as early as the sixth minute in east London, when West Brom took the lead. Feghouli expected to be awarded a foul as he was bundled over by Chris Brunt, but Oliver ignored those appeals.

James Morrison seized on a subsequent moment of hesitation from the Hammers backline to slip in Chadli, who beat Cheikhou Kouyate with a nutmeg before also stroking the ball between the legs of goalkeeper Randolph.
5 - Nacer Chadli has had a hand in five goals in his two Premier League games v West Ham this season (3 goals, 2 assists). Hammered.

West Ham thought they had equalised in the 16th minute, Feghouli steering home Lanzini's shot after Foster had felled his own defender Craig Dawson in the process of spilling a Robert Snodgrass free-kick.

It was unclear if Oliver disallowed the goal for offside or a foul, Michail Antonio clattering the keeper from behind, but regardless of the reasons for the decision, incensed Hammers assistant coach Nikola Jurcevic was sent to the stands after venturing the length of the touchline to remonstrate with the linesman.

Perhaps seeking to vent their frustration, West Ham created good chances for Feghouli and Antonio, although the visitors had earlier hit the bar through Salomon Rondon and continued to carry plenty of threat.

Snodgrass went down looking for a penalty under pressure from Jake Livermore in first-half injury time but yet again Oliver ignored his protests, an enraged Bilic waiting in the mouth of the tunnel to confront the referee after experiencing 45 minutes of intense frustration, much to the delight of his opposite number Pulis.

After replacing Aaron Cresswell with Jonathan Calleri at half-time and switching to three at the back, Bilic saw his players continue to dominate early in the second half and they were rewarded in the 63rd minute.
Lanzini's fierce strike was tipped onto the bar by Foster, but Feghouli got to the rebound first to guide home the equaliser.
West Ham pushed hard in search of a winner, Dawson called on to deny Lanzini and McAuley blocking a Calleri attempt.

They celebrated Lanzini's spectacular strike as if it would prove decisive, but Evans and Pulis had other ideas, the former Manchester United defender crashing home an uncompromising leveller in the 94th minute.

commentary: Well, that’s all from me for now. Until next time, goodbye!

It was all a case of too little, too late from Everton this afternoon, however. Koeman’s changes were effective, but were made too late to have a real impact, as Kane stole the show to claim the points, condemning the Toffees to their first league defeat of 2017 in the process.
It was a deserved victory for Spurs, but it is only Alli’s late strike - that seemed a mere gloss on the win initially - that has won it, with Valencia having swept home a minute later.
FULL TIME! It’s all over at White Hart Lane, where Spurs have sealed a ninth-successive league home win, despite late drama.
A late booking for Ashley Williams for a foul on Alli.
It was a fantastic cross from Barkley, who has played well today.
GOOOOOOAAAALLLLLL!!! VALENCIA NETS! Madness at White Hart Lane, as awful defending from Spurs allowed Valencia to sweep home Barkley’s free-kick. But, it is certain to be too little, too late.
It was a clever pass form Harry Winks, who exposed Everton's lacklustre defence.
GOOOOOAAAAAALLLLL!! ALLI SEALS IT! That’s, finally, game over, as awful Everton defending allows Winks to play in Alli, who duly prods home.
A final Spurs substitute. Harry Kane, having won the battle of the strikers today, receives a standing ovation, as Vincent Janssen comes on.
A nervy moment for Lloris, who very nearly allows Valencia to nip possession from him on the edge of Spurs’ area.
Lukaku has now scored 18 PL goals in 26 games this season, equalling his tally for last season (18 goals in 37 apps in 2015/16).
A Tottenham change now, as Moussa Sissoko - who turned down Everton to join Spurs in August - replaces Christian Eriksen.
A weaving run from Barkley gets him free down the left, and his ross forces Vertonghen to concede a corner... But Lloris punches it clear and Spurs counter...
Lukaku has now scored more goals than any other Everton player in Premier League history (61).
A mistake from Robles again costs Everton, but this time, the keeper atones for his error by denying Kane from close-range.
A third and final substitution for Everton. Idrissa Gueye makes way for Enner Valencia.
It was nothing more than a hopeful pass into the feet of Lukaku from Mirallas, and Vertonghen's mistake has allowed Everton right back into this!
GOOOOOAAAAALLLL!!! LUKAKU HAULS EVERTON BACK INTO IT! A dreadful mistake from Vertonghen, who slips in a one-on-one with Lukaku, who makes no mistake with a venomous finish past Lloris. Game on!?
It’s all too easy for Spurs, as they look to well-and-truly put this game to bed. Eriksen drives in a cross-cum-shot that Robles does well to clear.
A regular occurrence now, as Harry Winks comes on. This time, the youngster replaces Dembele.
Barkley pings a pass into the feet of Mirallas from the free-kick, but it is not accurate enough, meaning the Belgian winger has to adjust his feet before unleashing a shot, which is easily blocked.
The introduction of McCarthy has helped up the tempo though, and he combines well with Schneiderlin to tee up Coleman, who wins a free-kick right on the edge of the area, drawing a foul from Dembele.

Everton look well-beaten here, and in all truth have looked so since the 20th minute, when Spurs blasted in Spurs’ opener. There is certainly a gulf in quality, though the visitors tactics’ were rather negative from the start...

CLOSE! Walker ghosted in behind Everton’s defence, nudging a simple cross back into the feet of Kane, whose shot is saved by Robles. Eriksen rifles in the rebound, but the move is called back for offside.
Neat inter-play from Mirallas and Barkley on the edge of the area, with the latter eventually looping a strike into the arms of Lloris, who makes an easy stop.
Spurs are simply managing this game now, setting the tempo and making Everton play at their pace. It has been a brilliant, imperious display from Pochettino’s men so far.
Immediately, Everton look to get on the front foot, with the energy of McCarthy enabling Coleman to press higher upfield. Still, the passes into Lukaku are poor, though.
The second change sees Tom Davies make way, with Kevin Mirallas his replacement.
The first substitution sees James McCarthy replace Gareth Barry, who has struggled this afternoon.
Finally, Everton manage to get on the ball, but the service into Lukaku is poor. Changes are being prepared, but it may already be too late...
Harry Kane has scored 14 home league goals this season, the highest number ever recorded by a Spurs player in a single PL season.

Koeman’s refusal to switch his tactics may have led to Everton’s downfall, though individual errors have not helped the Dutchman’s cause. It was poor play from Robles, while Schneiderlin and Williams also failed to cover themselves in glory for that second goal.
It was smart play from Alli, who was on his toes to rob Schnedierlin of the ball and prod a pass into Kane’s feet, who never looked in danger of missing.
GOOOOOOOAAAALLLL!! Well, it was coming! A calamitous error from Robles, who rolls out a poor pass to Schneiderlin, and Spurs take full advantage as Kane slots home his second of the game.
A huge cheer of appreciation from the home faithful, as Vertonghen dispossesses Barkely with a deft tackle and turn. Koeman must be looking to change things sooner rather than later...
What a run! A brilliant charge from Vertonghen carves Everton open, and only an instinctive Robles save denies the Belgian thumping in a second for the hosts.
CHANCE! Spurs work a short corner into Davies, who delivers a precise cross onto the head of Alli, but the youngster can’t generate the power to beat Robles.
A pause in play now, as Wanyama - who rattled the woodwork with a venomous strike in the first-half - receives treatment for what appears to be a knee injury. He looks set to continue though.
Everton have failed to win all 11 previous Premier League games against Spurs in which they’ve trailed at half-time (D2 L9).
A clattering collision between Davies and Coleman, as both rush in with full-blooded challenges. Fortunately, neither is hurt.
Welcome back! Surprisingly, there have been no changes for Everton at the break, as the Toffees get the second-half underway.

Everton have rarely threatened, and Koeman must surely look to switch systems now, with Barry looking particularly sluggish in midfield, and Lukaku isolated. Spurs could have added more, but Kane, Eriksen and Wanyama all failed to apply the finishes.

We’ve reached the interval here, and despite a workmanlike display in which they restricted Spurs for 20 minutes, Everton are fortunate to only be 1-0 down. The game was lit up by a moment of magic from Kane, who moves to the top of the Premier League scoring charts in the process.
HALF-TIME: Tottenham 1-0 Everton.
Tom Davies makes a brilliant run from deep to take in Coleman’s cross-field pass, but he is wrongly flagged offside.

Spurs are unbeaten in eight Premier League games against Everton (W3 D5) since a 2-1 defeat at Goodison Park in December 2012. The Toffees have grown back into this game in recent moments, though it is the hosts who are in pole position...
CHANCE! Davies gets into Everton’s box courtesy of a fortunate bounce, swiftly proceeding to lob in a cross. Eriksen meets it, directing his header back across goal, but the ball inches wide.
Good work from Barkley, who pressurises Walker and Dier, winning a corner for his efforts… The playmaker delivers a decent cross, but both Mori and Lukaku fail to apply the finishing touch.
CLOSE! Barry finds space in the final third and dinks an inviting lob into the path of Lukaku, who had drifted clear of his marker. The Belgian stretches out a leg, but can’t make contact.

It is all a bit too congested for Everton now, and while that aided them in the openings stages, it is proving difficult for their more influential attacking players to gain a foothold on proceedings.

Fantastic goalkeeping from Lloris prevents what may have been - against the run of play - an Everton leveller. Barkley seemed down the right, powering in a superb cross that seemed destined for Lukaku, but the France goalkeeper was on hand to tip it away.
The rain is teeming down at White Hart Lane now, and at the moment Everton are caught in the eye of a Tottenham storm. Gueye picks up the first booking of the game for a late lunge on Davies...

POST! Everton have completely lost their composure now, and Wanyama very nearly added a second with a thunderous strike that rattled the woodwork. Kane latched onto the rebound, firing wide, though he was offside anyway.

A reckless challenge from Funes Mori puts Everton on the back foot, with Spurs now having the opportunity to test Everton’s defence from another set-piece… Eriksen whips in an immaculate delivery, but Kane just fails to connect.
CLOSE! A sloppy pass from Lukaku allows Kane to thread Eriksen through, but the former Ajax man can only slide his effort wide. Everton are living dangerously at the moment...
Kane has now scored 11 times in 10 competitive appearances in 2017 for Spurs. He almost had another one there, having read Walker’s cross, but Robles managed to get there first.

CHANCE! Suddenly, Everton’s defence looks all at sea. Kane finds himself in space in the area, taking the ball around Williams before unleashing a powerful strike, but Robles is out quickly to make the save. Eriksen collects the loose ball, only to blast his effort over.
Davies will be credited with the assist, but that goal was all Kane, though questions can be asked of Everton’s defending.

GOOOOOAAAAALLLL!! Talk about the curse of the commentator! It’s that man Kane, who produces a moment of quality from absolutely nothing! The England striker took the ball out on the left, drifting in from the flank, breezing off four defenders before thumping a dipping strike into the bottom-left corner.

Koeman will be pleased with his side’s effort in the opening 20 minutes, with Spurs restricted to rather little despite dominating possession, but he will be now looking for Everton to step-up their attacking impetus.

Everton are really starting to pressures Spurs in midfield, but at the moment have not been able to find the final ball into Lukaku. Spurs manage to get up the other end, though, with Alli winning a soft free-kick after colliding with Schneiderlin... Again, however, Eriksen's delivery is cleared.
A mix-up between Spurs’ defence allows Davies to nip in on the edge of the area, having made a fantastic run from deep. However, at the vital moment, Dier recovers to make an excellent tackle.
Pochettino is hunting his 100th win in English football, if you include his time at Southampton. But Spurs are being held at arms length by Everton at the moment.

With Everton having set-up to congest the midfield, it is making life very difficult for both sides to get the ball down on the deck. However, it is Spurs who have had the majority of the ball so far...

A big call from the referee Michael Oliver, and he gets it spot on! Waker isolated Baines down the right, but the Everton full-back managed to nip in with a fantastic tackle. Spurs wanted a penalty, but there was nothing doing for the official.

Superb defending from Vertonghen! Everton countered, with Barkley picking out Lukaku with a sublime pass. The Belgium striker drove into the area, but his compatriot did brilliantly to time his challenge.
Eriksen’s free-kick is a poor one, though, and the wall blocks it. The Danish playmaker regains possession, but a combination of Baines and Schnedierlin copes with the resulting cross.
A chance now for Spurs from a free-kick, as Alli draws a clumsy foul from Barry around 25 yards out from goal...
STAT - Spurs are the only unbeaten side at home in the Premier League this season, winning 11 of 13 fixtures (W11 D2 L0), having conceded just five goals at White Hart Lane.
Neat play from Coleman and Gueye down the right results in the latter whipping in a dangerous cross. Davies attempts to connect, but the youngster just times his header wrong.
KICK-OFF! Spurs, donning their usual black and white away strip, get proceedings underway...

We’re just moments away from kick-off at White Hart Lane. Spurs are chasing a ninth straight home victory in the league - which would represent a new club record. Koeman, however, is the last visiting manager to claim a top-flight win here.
