Saint Etienne push forward on another impressive attacking move before winning themselves a corner off a beautiful Veretout cross. The set-piece is poorly struck, however, and is easily cleared by Young at the near post before the referee brings an end to the first half.
The fourth official has indicated that there will be just one minute of added time.

Mata shows good footwork just outside of the Saint Etienne penalty area as he tries to link up with Ibrahimovic. He initially does well to beat one defender before looking to tee up the striker, but he's quickly dispossessed before he's able to do so.

Vital interception by Romero! Saint Etienne fly forward on a blisteringly quick counter-attack before Monnet-Paquet darts into the left-hand side of the United penalty area and towards a through-ball, but the Argentine goalkeeper is just about able to get a foot on the ball to poke it away from the forward just as he's about to round him and shoot.

Thumping strike by Ibrahimovic! Rashford out-muscles Malcuit over on the left flank before bursting down the wing. He then cuts inside and picks out the Swedish striker in acres of space, and unleashes a rocket of a long-range shot that flies just a few yards over the top of the crossbar.

Great chance for Perrin! Saint Etienne win themselves a free-kick over on the left wing, which Veretout curls into an excellent position inside the United penalty area. Perrin rises high and easily meets the ball completely unmarked, but he sends his headed effort straight into the hands of Romero.

Ibrahimovic picks up a loose ball 25 yards away from the Saint Etienne goal and quickly chips a pass over the hosts' back line and towards Paul Pogba. The Frenchman is able to meet and control the ball inside the box, but his run forward was slightly mistimed and the linesman's flag is raised as a result.

After regaining possession, Florentin Pogba flies down the left wing on a marauding run. He gets himself into a good position and then swings a dangerous cross towards Robert Beric, but the striker, who has seen little of the ball thus far, is unable to reach the ball and it flies a yard or so over his head.

Another attempted Saint Etienne attack comes to an end and United are able to win back possession once again. They work the ball around patiently before Rashford is brought into the move, but his first touch is poor and he's unable to continue it over on the left flank.

Saint Etienne enjoy a good spell of possession as they try to find a way back into the game. A low cross from the right wing finds Henri Saivet in the heart of the penalty area, but the forward's first touch is poor and the ball is deflected out to Veretout. The midfielder immediately unleashes a rocket of a shot from 25 yards out, but it deflects off a white shirt and bounces behind for a corner.

United almost make it 2-0! Space opens up in the middle of the pitch, allowing the visitors to fly forward on another dangerous counter-attack. Ibrahimovic and Young link up well deep down the right flank before the latter fires a low cross over to the far post, but it misses both Rashford and Mata before rolling out for a goal-kick.

Rashford holds up the ball deep down the left wing as he tries to find a way past Theophile-Catherine. He's unable to do so and decides instead to tee up Mata, but Malcuit is there to stop the pass from finding the Spaniard with a vital interception.

Almost a costly mistake by Paul Pogba! The midfielder is caught in possession midway inside the United half of the pitch and clumsily has the ball stolen off him from under his nose. Saint Etienne then break forward swiftly through Romain Hamouma, but he's unable to do anything with the opportunity and chips a cross out of play.
Mkhitaryan looks to have picked up a slight injury after stretching to put United in front, and he gingerly makes his way off the pitch to be replaced by Marcus Rashford.

Once again, an attack-minded home side lose out on the halfway line and are caught on the break. This time it's Mkhitaryan who sprints towards the penalty area, but he's unable to deal with the pace of Malcuit and is beaten by the defender before fouling him from behind.

Saint Etienne lose possession in the centre of the pitch and present United with a chance to counter swiftly, but Ibrahimovic's run through the hosts' disjointed back line is slightly mistimed and the linesman's flag is raised as soon as he meets Paul Pogba's through-ball.

Fantastic save by Ruffier! Ibrahimovic charges through the middle of the pitch on a great run before teeing up Mata to his left. The Spaniard takes a quick touch and then fires a dangerous cross into the Saint Etienne penalty area, where it pinballs off both Perrin and Pajot before Ruffier scoops the ball away with a great diving stop at the near post.

Malcuit twists and turns as he weaves his way down the right flank and towards the byline. Blind sticks to the full-back like glue as he tries to stop him from whipping a cross into the box, and he's able to do so before shepherding the ball out for a goal-kick.

Another attempted Saint Etienne attack comes to an end and United take the opportunity to counter quickly. Carrick fires a great cross-field pass over to the left wing and picks out Blind perfectly, but the Dutchman is unable to control the ball with his head and ends up losing out.

Saint Etienne immediately push forward from the restart and are almost able to carve out a chance on goal thanks to a dangerous cross from the right wing, but Young does well to rise high and meet the ball before Monnet-Paquet can.

GOAL! United have taken the lead! Juan Mata cuts inside from the left flank and immediately fires a wonderful bouncing cross into the middle of the Saint Etienne box. Neither Kevin Theophile-Catherine nor Perrin are quick enough to deal with the danger, allowing Mkhitaryan to skip between the two of them before sending a deft flick past Ruffier.

Mata's low cross into the box was a great one, but the hosts' defending left a lot to be desired. Nobody picked up Mkhitaryan's run and the two centre-backs were far too slow in trying to cut out the danger.

It's been a tough opening 15 minutes for Saint Etienne, who have seen little of the ball inside the United half of the pitch. The visitors are comfortably bossing possession, and whenever the hosts are able to pick up the ball they seem to be in a rush to launch it over the sea of white shirts camped in front of them.

Ashley Young is closed down quickly by both Florentin Pogba and Kevin Monnet-Paquet, but he nonetheless does well to whip a cross into a dangerous position inside the box. It curls towards the far post and looks set to find Ibrahimovic, but the striker seems to duck out of the way of the ball instead of rising high to meet it.

United keep dominating possession as they look to carve out their first chance on goal. They're unable to do so, however, as a poor pass from Chris Smalling flies over the top of the Saint Etienne defence before rolling harmlessly out of play for a goal-kick.

Paul Pogba cuts inside from the left wing and easily skips past two defenders before chipping a deft cross into the middle of the Saint Etienne box. Mkhitaryan makes a good run towards goal as he tries to reach the pass, but he's unable to and Stephane Ruffier is comfortably able to cut out the danger as a result.

Michael Carrick is caught by a late challenge from Vincent Pajot, resulting in a free-kick for United just inside the Saint Etienne half of the pitch. It's sent short and worked up to Mkhitaryan, but he's unable to beat Loic Perrin and is dispossessed by an outstretched foot from the centre-back.

Ibrahimovic chases a loose ball down the right flank and does well to stop it from bouncing out of play. He then spins and launches a volleyed cross over to Paul Pogba, who quickly nods the ball down to Henrikh Mkhitaryan, but the Armenian is unable to bring it under his control and loses out to Veretout.

Daley Blind sends a clever pass down the left wing and into the path of Zlatan Ibrahimovic, who cuts inside quickly and then tees up Paul Pogba. The midfielder is in a good position just outside of the penalty area and looks set to shoot, but he's too slow in doing so and is eventually dispossessed by a great tackle from Jordan Veretout.

Saint Etienne quickly pick up possession for the first time and plough forward. Kevin Malcuit does well to dart towards the right-hand side of the United penalty area before curling a low cross into the box, but it's sent too near to Sergio Romero and is easily collected by the goalkeeper.
We're off! United get us underway, attacking from right to left.
The two sides are making their way out onto the pitch, with just a few minutes to go until kick-off.

Meanwhile, United boss Jose Mourinho has made three alterations to the team that featured six days ago, with Antonio Valencia, Anthony Martial and Ander Herrera - the latter of whom is suspended - making way for Ashley Young, Henrikh Mkhitaryan and Michael Carrick, respectively.

Christophe Galtier has decided to make just one change to the Saint Etienne side that started last week’s first leg, with Robert Beric coming into the starting line-up to replace Jorginho, who drops to the substitutes’ bench.
Manchester United substitutes: De Gea, Valencia, Rojo, Schweinsteiger, Lingard, Martial, Rashford.
Manchester United XI (4-3-3): Romero; Young, Bailly, Smalling, Blind; Fellaini, Carrick, Paul Pogba; Mata, Ibrahimovic, Mkhitaryan.
Saint Etienne substitutes: Moulin, Pierre-Gabriel, Lacroix, Selnaes, Jorginho, Roux.
Saint Etienne XI (4-2-3-1): Ruffier; Malcuit, Theophile-Catherine, Perrin, Florentin Pogba; Veretout, Pajot; Hamouma, Saivet, Monnet-Paquet; Beric.
There’s just over 15 minutes left to go until kick-off, so let’s have a look at how the two teams will be lining up this afternoon…

Despite being three goals up and with the EFL Cup final taking place on Sunday, Jose Mourinho has decided against leaving some of United’s more important players at home. Instead, they will start the game with the likes of Ibrahimovic, Paul Pogba and Juan Mata on the pitch, clearly showing how seriously the Portuguese is taking each and every competition in which his team are still taking part.

It’s been a difficult few weeks for Saint Etienne, who are once again chasing Europa League qualification in Ligue 1 but lost out to Montpellier in their last outing, leaving them four points away from a qualifying spot. The Greens have tasted victory in just one of their previous six games, whilst away from home they have failed to avoid defeat in any of their last four encounters.

Nothing can be taken for granted, however, so United’s Portuguese boss has decided to field a similarly strong side to the one that featured in the first leg. A 2-1 win against Blackburn Rovers in the FA Cup on the weekend means that the Red Devils have lost just one of their previous 24 games, with none of their last 20 home clashes ending in defeat. As such, they head into tonight’s encounter as firm favourites to get the job done.

Thanks to a comfortable outing six days ago, United head to France with a place in the next round of the Europa League all but confirmed. Zlatan Ibrahimovic, often his side’s saviour, bagged himself the first hat-trick of his United career to hand Jose Mourinho’s men a well-deserved 3-0 lead on aggregate, and it’s one that is unlikely to be seriously challenged by a Saint Etienne side that looked off the pace at Old Trafford.
Good afternoon and welcome to our live text commentary of today’s Europa League last-32 second leg game between Saint Etienne and Manchester United at the Stade Geoffroy-Guichard.
news: Manchester United cruised into the last 16 of the Europa League as a 1-0 victory at Saint-Etienne crowned a dominant 4-0 aggregate triumph, but match-winner Henrikh Mkhitaryan left boss Jose Mourinho with an injury worry.

The sight of the Armenia captain - who continued his recent fine form with a smartly taken goal from Juan Mata's cross - departing before the half hour with an apparent hamstring problem was far from welcome with Sunday's EFL Cup final against Southampton on the horizon.

Mourinho's scope for tactical substitutions with an eye on that Wembley date was further limited when centre-back Eric Bailly was booked for two fouls on Romain Hamouma in the space of three needlessly rash minutes in the second-half.

It means the Ivory Coast international will be suspended when United begin their last-16 tie and his manager will have been pleased to see the remaining action at a buoyant Stade Geoffroy-Guichard pass without incident.
In contrast to the raucous din made by the home support, United played with an easy control that meant there was little to report until they opened the scoring in the 16th minute.
The former Borussia Dortmund star's joy was short-lived however, as he made way for Marcus Rashford and headed straight down the tunnel within 10 minutes of his sixth goal this season.
Rashford and Mata saw a low cross from Ashley Young flash agonisingly beyond them as Saint-Etienne appeared ripe to be cut open whenever it suited Mourinho's men to do so.
An ungainly challenge from United goalkeeper Sergio Romero to thwart Kevin Monnet-Paquet gave the hosts a little encouragement before the interval, with pride their only remaining concern.
Daley Blind cut infield for United in the 58th minute, slipping a pass through for Marouane Fellaini to slam into the side-netting – an unmarked Zlatan Ibrahimovic inside was unimpressed.
Paul Pogba then drove into the arms of Saint-Etienne goalkeeper Stephane Ruffier and Mourinho's star names remained in play as the hour passed, in spite of Mkhitaryan's cautionary tale.
The likes of Ibrahimovic and Paul Pogba had to remain for the duration after Bailly's indiscipline forced Mourinho to introduce Marcos Rojo in place of Mata.

Florentin Pogba stoked the dying embers of this battle for sibling supremacy when the Saint-Etienne left-back thudded an optimistic long-range shot wide, while his younger brother saw the ball run away from him when Rashford's 75th-minute effort trickled across the six-yard box.
Family bragging rights had not been in doubt for some time by that stage.

commentary: Well, that was good fun! In the end, a draw is certainly a fair result, as both teams battled hard and would feel hard done by if they had to leave empty-handed. Liverpool were the better of the two in the first half before sitting slightly too deep after the break, allowing United to constantly hammer away at them before they finally broke their opponents down. The home side then pushed hard for a late winner, but by that point it was slightly too late.
FULL-TIME: MANCHESTER UNITED 1-1 LIVERPOOL

It's all United as they push every available body forward in search of a late, late winning goal, but they're unable to break down a formidable Liverpool defence before Fellaini gives away a free-kick by dragging Klavan to the ground. That should be that.

What an opportunity for Wijnaldum! Can breaks towards the edge of the United penalty area before teeing up Wijnaldum with a great knock to his left, but the Dutchman's side-footed shot is far too weak and ends up rolling straight into the hands of De Gea in the middle of the goal.
Firmino reacts angrily and pushes Herrera to the floor in retaliation, and he too is booked.

Another United attack fails to result in a chance on goal and Liverpool counter quickly, but Firmino is unable to get past the halfway line after being dragged back by Herrera, who receives a yellow card for his cynical challenge.
The fourth official has indicated that there will be four minutes of added time.

It's all United at the moment as they desperately try to find a late winner, but Liverpool have plenty of bodies behind the ball and do well to bring another attempted attacking move to an end over on the left flank.

The corner initially fails to result in a chance on goal for Liverpool before Lallana charges into the box on a lovely run. He beats one player before taking on Fellaini, but the midfielder comes out on top and does well to poke the ball back to De Gea.

Can flies down the right flank before curling a cross into the middle of the United penalty area that is nodded on to Wijnaldum. The Dutchman takes a quick touch and then unleashes a shot, but it's closed down by Jones and deflects out for a corner.

Valencia did well to set up Ibrahimovic, but United deserve full credit for their fight-back this half. They've put Liverpool under an incredible amount of pressure and it was only a matter of time until they were going to crack.

GOAL! United have equalised! The home side throw everything they've got at Liverpool as ball after ball is flung into the box. Rooney does well to get away from Alexander-Arnold before chipping a cross over to the far post, where Valencia knocks the ball into the path of Ibrahimovic and sets up the Swedish striker to beat Mignolet with a header on the edge of the six-yard box.

What a save by Mignolet! A looping cross from Herrera flies into the Liverpool box and finds Mata. The Spaniard rises high and nods the ball down to Rooney, who immediately unleashes a thumping strike that is pushed away by the feet of Mignolet at the near post.

Coutinho picks up two free-kicks in quick succession after being clumsily tripped over inside the United half of the pitch. The second set-piece is curled into the penalty area in search of Lovren, but it fails to find the big Croatian and the home side do well to hold on.

Herrera gets himself into a pocket of space just outside of the Liverpool penalty area and quickly tries to tee up Rooney with a chipped pass into the box, but it's totally mishit by the Spaniard and sails harmlessly out of play for a goal-kick. The United captain doesn't look at all happy with that!
Mourinho has made his final roll of the dice, with Darmian making way for Marouane Fellaini. It looks as if Mkhitaryan is going to take the Italian's place at left-back.

Great chance for Wijnaldum! Pogba is caught in possession inside the Liverpool half of the pitch and gifts the visitors with an opportunity to fly forward. Can flies down the right flank on a great run before setting up Wijnaldum, but the Dutchman's diving header ends up looping a few yards over the top of the crossbar.

Liverpool continue to enjoy a good spell of possession inside the hosts' half of the pitch before Firmino is set up over on the left flank, but the Brazilian's dart down the wing is slightly mistimed and he's flagged offside just as he's about to cut towards the penalty area.

Milner is able to get back to his feet after a couple of minutes and the game gets underway once again. Liverpool immediately push forward and wins themselves a throw-in, which is quickly sent over to Wijnaldum, but the Dutchman is unable to reach the ball inside the penalty area and loses out to Jones.

Ouch! Rooney and Milner battle for the ball as they both try to latch on to a loose pass, but the challenge from the United captain is a high one and catches the latter on the ankle, leaving him in serious discomfort on the floor.

United patiently pass the ball around inside the Liverpool half of the pitch as they desperately try to find a way through the sea of defenders camped in front of them, but they're unable to do so before a looping cross from Mata is easily collected by Mignolet.

Lallana goes close! Coutinho wriggles his way through a sea of red shirts as he somehow makes it into the United penalty area. The Brazilian then spins and finds Lallana, but the midfielder's low shot fails to beat De Gea at the near post.
United have made their second alteration, with Martial making way for Juan Mata.

Rooney peels away from his marker on the edge of the Liverpool penalty area before trying to test Mignolet with a 20-yard strike, but he's unable to make decent contact with the ball and ends up sending it bouncing well wide of the far post.

Darmian cuts inside from the left wing and fires a dangerous cross into the middle of the Liverpool penalty area that Klavan does well to head away from Rooney. Ibrahimovic decides to keep the ball in play before fizzing it across the face of goal, but there's nobody there to get a touch on the pass.

Chance for Firmino! Coutinho makes an immediate impact as Liverpool go on the offensive for one of the first times since the break, but Firmino's low shot towards the near post is well pushed away by De Gea.
Wijnaldum is shown a yellow card, presumably for dissent after having a few words with the referee.
Liverpool have made their first change of the game, with Philippe Coutinho coming on to replace Origi.

United keep pushing forward as they continue to put their visitors under plenty of pressure, but a promising attacking move comes to a disappointing end after Pogba fires an audacious long-range strike well wide of its intended target.

Mkhitaryan spins round his marker on the right wing before flying towards the Liverpool penalty area. The Armenian then plays a quick one-two with Rooney before looking to shoot, but he's out-muscled by Lallana just as he's about to do so.

Herrera picks up the ball in a good position over on the right flank and quickly fires a long pass down the wing and into the path of Rooney, but the captain is unable to pick out a team-mate after spinning on the edge of the penalty area and sends the ball straight to Mignolet at the near post.
This time it's Mkhitaryan who curls the set-piece into the Liverpool box and towards a team-mate, but Mignolet rushes out to punch the ball away from danger and over to the left wing.

What a chance for Mkhitaryan! Alexander-Arnold loses out over on the right wing and gifts United with a great chance to fly forward on a counter-attack. They do so brilliantly through Martial before Ibrahimovic spins and finds Mkhitaryan, but the Armenian's low cross-cum-shot fails to find the back of the net and is deflected out for another corner.

The ball pinballs around the edge of the Liverpool penalty area before Rooney tries to poke a pass into the path of Ibrahimovic, but the Swedish striker is unable to muscle his way through a sea of defenders and loses out to Mignolet.

Rooney battles his way down the left wing and does well to win United a corner. He then whips the ball towards Rojo at the near post, but it's poorly hit by the captain and is easily headed away by Lallana.
Milner steps up and curls a deep cross into the penalty area that is then nodded over to Can, but the midfielder pushes Herrera to the ground as they battle for the ball and gives away a free-kick.

Origi goes close! United lose the ball in the Liverpool half of the pitch and allow the visitors to break forward on a quick counter-attack. Firmino flies through the middle of the field before teeing up Origi to his left, but the Belgian's curling strike is deflected just wide of the far post and out for a corner.
United have made one substitution during the half-time break, with Carrick making way for Wayne Rooney in an attack-minded alteration.
And we're underway once again!
The two teams are making their way back out on to the pitch ahead of the start of the second half.

So far, so good for Liverpool, who have done well to nullify a United side that haven't quite got going yet. The visitors haven't been presented with too many chances to test De Gea, but Milner was easily able to beat the Spaniard with a thumping strike from the spot that left him with no chance. At the other end, Liverpool have looked surprisingly solid, making life difficult for Ibrahimovic in front of goal.
HALF-TIME: MANCHESTER UNITED 0-1 LIVERPOOL

Alexander-Arnold flies into Martial but completely misses the Frenchman, gifting him with an opportunity to set up Pogba. It's one he's unable to take, however, as his attempted through-ball into the penalty area is poor and easily cut out by Lovren.
The fourth official has indicated that there will be just one minute of added time.

Milner sends another dangerous cross into the United box and towards a team-mate, but, luckily for the Frenchman, Pogba ends up winning his side a free-kick after being pushed over by Klavan as the two battled for the ball.

Origi breaks down the left flank before cutting inside and being barged to the ground by Valencia, resulting in a free-kick for Liverpool in a dangerous position. A deep cross is fired in by Milner and finds Lovren at the far post, but the defender's volleyed cross-cum-shot deflects off an outstretched leg and out for a corner.

Golden opportunity for Mkhitaryan! The Armenian flies through the Liverpool back line and into the visitors' penalty area before latching on to a wonderful pass forward from Herrera, but he's unable to beat Mignolet and instead fires his shot straight at the Belgian.

Almost a chance for Origi! Rojo is caught out at the back and is unable to deal with Origi, who does wonderfully well to muscle his way past the defender. He then tries to break into the penalty area to take on De Gea, but Matteo Darmian darts across the box to deal with the striker at the vital moment.

Milner barges into Mkhitaryan from behind and gives away a free-kick midway inside the Liverpool half of the pitch. It's taken quickly and worked over to Pogba, but the Frenchman loses out to Wijnaldum before conceding a free-kick himself.

Martial sets up Valencia, who had flown down the right wing on a dangerous run, but Liverpool have enough bodies back to deal with the danger and concede a corner. Mkhitaryan's cross is fired towards Ibrahimovic, but Lovren rises high above the Swedish striker to beat him in the air.

Origi charges down the left wing before forcing Jones into poking the ball out for a Liverpool corner. Milner steps up and curls a cross into the six-yard box, but it's easily collected by De Gea after being fired straight into the hands of the Spaniard.

Fantastic save by Mignolet! Ibrahimovic steps up and fires a rocket of a shot towards the bottom right-hand corner of the net, but Mignolet gets down superbly well to push the strike round the post and out for another corner.

The resulting free-kick is flung into the middle of the Liverpool box but is easily nodded out of play for a corner by Can. It's whipped into the penalty area and cleared only as far as Herrera, who is then bundled over by a clumsy challenge from Origi just a yard or so outside of the box. Can Ibrahimovic fire his side back into the game?

Alexander-Arnold carelessly concedes possession over on the right flank and allows Liverpool to fly forward on a quick counter-attack, but Lovren is there to stop Ibrahimovic in his tracks. The Croatian then tries to close down Martial to stop him from reaching the loose ball, but he's slightly late with his sliding challenge and is shown a yellow card as a result.

Pogba tries to make amends for his mistake by thumping a chipped cross into the Liverpool box and towards Ibrahimovic, but it's slightly underhit by the Frenchman and fails to find the striker in front of goal, allowing the visitors to easily deal with the danger.

GOAL! Milner steps up and calmly fires a wonderful strike past the outstretched limbs of De Gea and into the right-hand corner of the net. Jose Mourinho looks absolutely furious, and it's no wonder why.

PENALTY! A Liverpool corner is swung into the heart of the United penalty area and flies towards Lovren, but just as the defender is about to reach the ball, it's smashed away by the outstretched hand of Pogba and leaves the referee with no choice but to point to the penalty spot.

Almost an opportunity for Lallana! Jones is caught out by Firmino on the edge of the United penalty area after falling asleep on the ball, but Rojo does well to rush back and deal with the Brazilian before he can poke a pass into the feet of Lallana.

Alexander-Arnold gets himself into a good position on the right-hand side of the United penalty area after doing well to fly past Martial. He then brings down a lofted Can pass with a wonderful first touch, but he's unable to beat Martial with his thumping strike that deflects away from danger.

Milner takes his time with the set-piece before whipping a cross into the penalty area, where it finds Lovren. The defender does well to rise high above Pogba before nodding the ball down to Origi, but the striker is unable to make decent contact with the ball and sends it spinning into the hands of De Gea.

A misplaced pass from Michael Carrick flies out of play and results in a throw-in for Liverpool. It's taken quickly and sent over to Origi, who bursts down the right flank before winning his side a free-kick after being bundled over by Pogba.

What a chance for Pogba! The Frenchman darts through the middle of the Liverpool defence and links up brilliantly with Henrikh Mkhitaryan, but the Frenchman scuffs his shot from the edge of the box and ends up sending it bobbling just wide of the far post. He really should have buried that!

Almost a costly mistake by Lovren! The defender is far too lax with his attempted pass back to Simon Mignolet and puts his goalkeeper under unnecessary pressure, resulting in him firing his clearance off the outstretched foot of the on-rushing Ibrahimovic and on to the roof of the net.

Pogba is caught out in the middle of the pitch, allowing Liverpool to break forward quickly. Can darts towards the penalty area before teeing up Adam Lallana, but the midfielder is unable to beat Marcos Rojo before Trent Alexander-Arnold fires a looping cross several yards over the top of the crossbar.

A lofted pass forward finds Ibrahimovic, who beats Klavan in the air before nodding the ball back to Paul Pogba. The midfielder is in a pocket of space midway inside the Liverpool half of the pitch and tries to tee up Martial, but the winger lets the ball run under his boot and out for a throw-in.

Almost a chance for Ibrahimovic! Martial, who has started well, cuts inside from the left flank on another good run before firing a deep cross over to the far post, but, despite his best efforts, Ibrahimovic is unable to make decent contact with the ball and ends up bouncing his attempted acrobatic volley out for a goal-kick.

Martial goes down inside the penalty area, but nothing is given! The Frenchman showcases some great footwork on the edge of the Liverpool box before ploughing into the penalty area and going down after tangling with Lovren. There wasn't any contact between the two, however, and the referee ignores the half-hearted penalty pleas from the home fans.

United give away another free-kick, this time for a challenge on Firmino by Ander Herrera. The set-piece is sent short and worked over to Ragnar Klavan, but the centre-back's attempted pass over to the left wing fails to find Milner and instead bounces harmlessly out of play for a throw-in.

Georginio Wijnaldum is tripped from behind and wins a free-kick for Liverpool just inside the United half of the pitch, but Roberto Firmino's run forward in an attempt to reach Milner's lofted pass is mistimed and he's quickly flagged offside as a result.

Anthony Martial twists and turns as he weaves his way down the left wing, but he loses out to Lovren and concedes a throw-in. It's taken quickly and sent to Lovren, who then fires a strange cross-field pass straight out of play for a United throw-in over on the opposite flank.

United patiently pass the ball around inside the Liverpool half of the pitch before Valencia swings a cross into the penalty area and over to Zlatan Ibrahimovic at the far post, but the Swedish striker loses out in the air and is unable to get the better of Dejan Lovren in the air.

Milner decides to send the second corner slightly deeper in search of a team-mate at the far post, but it's fired slightly too near to David De Gea and is easily cut out by the goalkeeper on the edge of the six-yard box.

Antonio Valencia is caught in possession over on the left wing, allowing Divock Origi to plough into the United penalty area before winning his side an early corner. It's whipped in by James Milner and finds Emre Can at the near post, but the midfielder's header deflects off Phil Jones and out for another corner.
And we're off! Liverpool get us underway, attacking from right to left.
The two sides are making their way out onto the pitch, with just a few minutes to go until kick-off.

Meanwhile, Liverpool boss Jurgen Klopp has also made four alterations to the team that featured in their last outing, with Loris Karius, Nathaniel Clyne, Lucas Leiva and Daniel Sturridge making way for Simon Mignolet, Trent Alexander-Arnold, Jordan Henderson and Divock Origi.

Jose Mourinho has decided to make four changes to the United side that started the EFL Cup victory against Hull, with Marcos Rojo, Michael Carrick, Anthony Martial and Zlatan Ibrahimovic returning to the starting line-up to replace Chris Smalling, Juan Mata, Wayne Rooney and Marcus Rashford, respectively
Liverpool substitutes: Karius, Moreno, Ejaria, Stewart, Gomez, Coutinho, Sturridge.
Liverpool XI (4-3-3): Mignolet; Alexander-Arnold, Lovren, Klavan, Milner; Wijnaldum, Henderson, Can; Firmino, Origi, Lallana.
Manchester United substitutes: Romero, Blind, Smalling, Fellaini, Mata, Rashford, Rooney.
Manchester United XI (4-3-3): De Gea; Valencia, Jones, Rojo, Darmian; Herrera, Carrick, Pogba; Mkhitaryan, Ibrahimovic, Martial.
There’s just over 15 minutes left to go until kick-off, so let’s have a look at how the two teams will be lining up this afternoon…

A usually free-flowing, attack-minded Liverpool side failed to find the back of the net in each of their previous two games, which was the first time they were unable to do so since last February. The absence of Sadio Mane, who is currently away at the Africa Cup of Nations, seemed to blunt their attack in Wednesday’s League Cup defeat against Southampton, and he could end up being missed again this afternoon as they try to break down the league’s third-best defence.

As for Liverpool, they were left frustrated by Sunderland in their last league outing, as the struggling side came from behind twice to hold Klopp’s men to a 2-2 draw at the Stadium of Light. The draw has resulted in them surrendering their second-place spot, but they will move back above both Arsenal and Tottenham Hotspur if they’re victorious here today.

In the build-up to the game, Liverpool boss Jurgen Klopp insisted that United are a better team than when the two sides last met in an eventless stalemate at Anfield, and that certainly seems to be the case. All of their previous six Premier League games have ended in victories, with the Red Devils scoring nine times in their last four clashes. Zlatan Ibrahimovic has scored four of those, and the Swedish striker is back in the squad after missing the game against Hull during the week.

United’s early season struggles seem a thing of the past thanks to an excellent run of form that has seen them embark on a nine-game winning run across all competitions. Reading and Hull City were both easily dispatched in the FA Cup and League Cup, respectively, whilst the 2-0 win against West Ham United helped to move them to within five points of today’s opponents.
Good afternoon and welcome to our live text commentary of today’s Premier League game between Manchester United and Liverpool at Old Trafford.
news: Zlatan Ibrahimovic scored a dramatic equaliser with six minutes remaining as Manchester United grabbed a 1-1 Premier League draw at home to Liverpool.
Paul Pogba had looked like being the villain of the piece for United, but Ibrahimovic's header – his 10th goal in 10 top-flight games – prevented a damaging defeat.
James Milner's 27th-minute penalty and sixth league goal of the season – awarded after a handball from Pogba – had looked like it would prove to be the winner at Old Trafford.

Pogba missed a brilliant opportunity to put United ahead prior to Milner's strike, while Simon Mignolet had made key saves from Ibrahimovic and Henrikh Mkhitaryan in the first half, but had barely been troubled prior to the veteran Swede's intervention.
United's nine-match winning streak in all competitions is now over, but they still sit within five points of second place after salvaging a draw.
Liverpool, meanwhile, are winless in four matches and trail leaders Chelsea by seven having dropped from second to third over the course of the weekend.

The hosts had threatened first when Ibrahimovic – one of four players brought into Jose Mourinho's team - charged down Mignolet after a weak back-pass from Dejan Lovren and watched the ball deflect agonisingly onto the roof of the net.
United then squandered a golden chance to take the lead when Mkhitaryan produced a superb throughball to release Pogba, but the midfielder could only drag his left-footed shot wide.
Pogba's first half got worse when Milner swept in a corner from the right and the France international's raised arm inside the area prevented Lovren from attempting a header.
Milner took the penalty himself and confidently beat David de Gea despite the goalkeeper correctly diving to his left.

Mignolet made a brilliant stop from Ibrahimovic's powerful 20-yard free-kick at the other end, saving the visitors after Divock Origi – starting as one of four Liverpool changes - had brought down Ander Herrera in a dangerous position.
The Liverpool keeper was alert again to keep out Mkhitaryan's left-footed strike after the playmaker had been fed by Herrera, ensuring Jurgen Klopp's men had a half-time lead.
Mourinho brought on Wayne Rooney for Michael Carrick at the break, the United captain's 450th Premier League appearance.

Origi saw an effort deflect narrowly wide, but the hosts were soon in the ascendancy when a fast counterattack – prompted by Anthony Martial dispossessing Trent Alexander-Arnold on his Premier League debut - led to Mkhitaryan's cut-back just evading the France forward.

Klopp then introduced Philippe Coutinho from the substitutes' bench and his change almost had an instant impact with the playmaker setting up compatriot Roberto Firmino, only for De Gea to make a two-handed stop.

Juan Mata, who had scored three goals in his last four league games against Liverpool, replaced Martial, but United were finding it more difficult to create openings, Rooney shooting wide from one rare chance.
If anything, the visitors were looking more likely to put the game beyond United, Adam Lallana denied by De Gea and Georginio WIjnaldum just off-target with a header.

But Ibrahimovic struck in dramatic fashion, his looping header from Antonio Valencia's cross beating Mignolet and a despairing clearance from Lovren, the move kept alive after substitute Marouane Fellaini had headed Rooney's delivery against the post.

commentary: FULL-TIME! WHAT A GAME! BARCELONA GO THROUGH 6-5 ON AGGREGATE! Sergi Roberto hasn't scored all season and what a time to get it. The hosts have turned around a four-goal first leg defeat to win and progress inside a cauldron of noise at Camp Nou. Three goals in less than eight minutes seal a historic comeback that will never be matched again. That's all that we have time for, we hope to see you again next time.
GOOOOOOOOOOAL! WOULD YOU BELIEVE IT! THEY'VE DONE IT! A long ball is clipped into the penalty area invitingly, and Sergi Roberto slides in to lift a close-range finish over Trapp! What a game.
Neymar lifts a brilliant ball into the box and Sergi Roberto does the rest.
Verratti gets a yellow card for cynically hacking down Messi.
Krychowiak comes into the game at the expense of Meunier. Emery is desperately shutting up shop. There are five minutes of stoppage time.

Pique is picked out by a long ball into the PSG penalty area, but the Barcelona defender can only nod a header down into Trapp's gloves. The home crowd are making a lot of noise yet again and the visitors are hanging on.
GOOOOOOOOOAL! NEYMAR CONVERTS! It is 5-1 and they just need one more to take this contest to extra time!
Marquinhos gets a yellow for his part in the penalty, even though it appeared that Suarez dived.
PENALTY TO BARCELONA! The referee has pointed to the spot again. Could this go down to the wire?
GOOOOOOOOAL! NEYMAR MAKES IT 4-1! It won't matter, but the Brazil international curls a lovely free-kick into the back of the net from 20 yards out. Trapp didn't even move.

Neymar manages to force a corner for the home side, with the resulting corner dealt with easily by Thiago Silva. Busquets earns Barcelona a free-kick on the right, but Trapp punches half-clear, before the hosts get a chance to threaten from a dead ball on the edge of the box.

Di Maria shoots wide! The Argentine substitute manages to break in behind the Barcelona defence, before bearing down on goal. He has a go, with Ter Stegen exposed, but a recovering defender puts enough pressure on him to affect his composure.
Rakitic is replaced by Andre Gomes in the dying stages.

PSG try and run down the clock a little more with some patient possession, but this game has died as a contest really. The atmosphere has almost completely gone along with it. Barcelona probably want the final whistle to come already.

We're into the last 10 minutes, with Barcelona pushing without any real belief that scoring a goal or two more would change the face of this contest. Arda Turan gets into the area, but then sees an attempted cross well blocked.

Neymar slips a pass forward for Sergi Roberto to chase, with the Spaniard's fresh legs helping him burst into the penalty area. The substitute wins his side a corner, but neither the first nor second ball can be turned goalwards. PSG are defending for their lives.

Trapp makes a meal of yet another free-kick delivery into the PSG penalty area, but the rebound can only be looped onto the roof of the net by Arda Turan. Pique was penalised for being offside in the build up anyway.
Rafinha is replaced by Sergi Roberto for the last quarter of an hour or so.
Draxler is replaced by Aurier, which leads to Meunier taking his position higher on the right-hand side for PSG.

Rafinha tries to flight in a cross from the right-hand side, but Rabiot clears PSG's lines for a brief moment. Messi then comes driving forward from deep, but the Argentina international can only drag a shot some way wide of the right-hand post!

Neymar tries his luck from 25 yards out, but a slip upon contact with the ball results in his effort going straight down Ter Stegen's throat. Moments later, Luis Suarez is fed into the penalty area, but the Uruguayan is penalised for shoving Marquinhos in the back.

Pique launches a long ball straight out of play for a goal-kick, with Barcelona appearing to look a little low on ideas now. The belief isn't quite there for the hosts any more, given the enormity of the task at hand. How vital that snapshot of brilliance from Cavani has been.

The referee isn't buying any of these attempts from Barcelona to earn themselves penalties, with his yellow card set to be pretty worn out after this game. The hosts are still seeing more of the ball and asking the questions, but Cavani's strike has rejuvenated PSG visibly.
Suarez gets a yellow card for trying to buy his side a penalty into the PSG box.

Turan denied immediately! The subsitute slots a finish beyond Trapp and it appears to be heading into the back of the net, but his attempt is cleared off the line in dramatic fashion. This contest continues to be carefully poised.
Arda Turan is given a run-out, with Iniesta taking his leave for the hosts.
Neymar gets a yellow card for showing his frustration after a decision doesn't go his way.

Suddenly, PSG's tails are up! There is a lot of space on the break for them to exploit, and Cavani is fed into the box. The visiting goalscorer tries to bend a one-on-one finish beyond Ter Stegen, but the German goalkeeper makes a good save.

GOOOOOOOAL! CAVANI GETS THE AWAY GOAL! The Uruguay international has the ball fall kindly to him just inside the penalty area, and he volleys a wonderful finish into the back of the net! That could just break Barcelona's hope. They need three, at least, now.
Kurzawa manages to head the ball down unselfishly to his teammate, and Cavani lashes home.
Rakitic gets a yellow card for hauling back an opponent cynically, as PSG tried to break.

Messi goes down under pressure from Verratti, after linking up with Iniesta, before PSG head up the other end. Emery is furious on the touchline. Cavani is picked out on the break, but can only earn his side a corner due to a sliding interception from Umtiti. The set-piece is flighted in, before Matuidi eventually shoots wide of the target.

Neymar feeds a pass into Messi on the edge of the box, but the Argentine star is quickly dispossessed. Barcelona just keep retaining possession and putting pressure on, and it appears that eventually it will tell. Trapp hasn't had a great deal to do since the restart, however, it must be noted.

Neymar gets into the penalty area, before going down under pressure from Meunier, but the referee isn't interested at all. PSG just keep giving the ball away, they're playing themselves into trouble repeatedly this evening.
Lucas is replaced by Di Maria, who comes into the game after not being fit enough to start.

Barcelona earn themselves a free-kick on the left-hand side, which Messi curls into the box. It bobbles off the turf and skips through the danger zone, before Rafinha has the chance to shoot on the right. The Brazilian midfielder has a go, but Trapp makes a simple catch.

OFF THE POST! PSG GO CLOSE! Meunier manages to burst down the right and flicks the ball over the head of Neymar, before drilling in a low cross. Cavani meets it, but can only guide an effort onto the outside of the upright!

PSG need to wake up, as three of their four-goal advantage has withered away at Camp Nou already. The home crowd go wild, with the visitors shooting themselves in the foot repeatedly. Emery's men are imploding before everyone's eyes here.

GOOOOOOOOAL! MESSI MAKES IT THREE! The Argentina international keeps his cool, before slotting a neat finish into the bottom-left corner. Barcelona look like they're going to turn this entirely on its head!

PENALTY FOR BARCA! After a snapshot from range for PSG, Barcelona settle back down. Neymar is played to the left byline by Iniesta, before Meunier slips and brings down his opponent as a result. The referee has to have a chat with his assistant behind the goal, and finally gives it!

We are back underway at Camp Nou! Barcelona have 45 minutes to rack up two goals, which would then by enough to take this contest to extra-time this evening. The Blaugrana have hope, and plenty of it, while PSG probably still have Emery's stern words ringing in their ears.

HALF-TIME! What a half from Barcelona! They're halfway to turning this tie around, after a goal from Suarez and one put in his own net from Kurzawa. Luis Enrique's men have really put PSG under siege and it looks likely that more goals could come for the hosts in the second half. Stay tuned!

Suarez opens play out to Rakitic on the right-hand side, before playing a one-two with Iniesta. The Croatia international tries to whip in a cross, but Kurzawa makes a timly block. Moments later, Iniesta finds Messi on the edge of the area, but the Argentine is quickly mobbed. Barcelona are desperate for a third!
There are three minutes of first-half stoppage time.

Barcelona work their way down the right-hand side, but Rabiot covers across brilliantly to help PSG clear their lines. The away side can't muster up a response, Luis Enrique's men just keep rumbling forward relentlessly.
Cavani gets a yellow card for dissent, after being brought down by Pique and demanding a booking for his opponent.

The pressure is ramping up on PSG, with the home crowd at Camp Nou urging their players on once again. Suddenly there is more belief, they're halfway to turning the first leg around. That is more than possible over the next 45 minutes, especially with how the visitors are defending.

GOOOOOOOOAL! BARCELONA MAKE IT 2-0! The hosts break down the left-hand side, with PSG struggling to clear their lines. Iniesta gets ahead of Marquinhos to flick the ball square across the goalmouth, with a combination of Rafinha, Trapp and Kurzawa helping it on its way in!

With less than 10 minutes until the break, Barcelona are still hunting for a second goal. Rakitic drives to the right byline and combines nicely with Suarez, but the two can't quite keep the ball in play at the byline. PSG will be desperate to get into the interval as quickly as possible. There is a stoppage in play, as Lucas goes down with a knock.
Busquets is booked for Barcelona, after being involved in a coming together with Verratti in the middle of the park. That may have been for a word in the referee's ear.

Suarez is fed into the PSG box, but a low strike from the Uruguay international goes straight down Trapp's throat. The away side try to respond with a quick break, but Verratti is eventually robbed of the ball. Emery's men just can't seem to string a counter-attack together at pace.

Rafinha is invited forward once again from the right flank, but a low cross from the Brazilian is gathered up easily by Trapp. Barcelona work the ball from right to left, searching for an opening, but Neymar then is unable to prevent the ball from running out of play at the byline. He claims that Meunier hauls him down, but the referee isn't interested.

Ter Stegen is forced into his first save of the game, after a bursting run forward from Lucas. As Barcelona press on, it is natural that PSG should have some space to exploit. The hosts respond with their own counter, but a cross from Rafinha is turned away for a throw-in by a block.

Barcelona earn themselves yet another free-kick, this time wide on the left flank. The ball is swung into the area, but Pique puts a looping header wide of the target. The Spain international was narrowly offside anyway. A second goal is looking more likely from the hosts than PSG.

Over the bar from Iniesta! The Barcelona captain is picked out in space by a cut-back from the left-hand side, but then drills a shot five yards over Trapp's crossbar. PSG try to threaten on the counter, but an awful flick around the corner from Cavani can't be controlled by Lucas.

Neymar and Messi stand over the free-kick, but the latter then thumps the ball straight into the PSG wall. The rebound is picked up by a Barcelona player and gets lumped back into the box, but Rabiot is present to help out. Suarez manages to earn a corner on the left, but it comes to nothing.

Barcelona's front three link up well on the edge of the penaty area, but an errant touch from Suarez is hoofed clear by Meunier. PSG are congesting the periphery of their box and it is proving enough to frustrate Barcelona so far. Rafinha is brought down in a dangerous area by Kurzawa.
Pique gets a yellow card for going in late on Cavani, scything through the standing leg of the Uruguay international. That was a horrible tackle.

The home crowd are really getting on PSG's backs, with it clear that Les Parisiens have come to limit the damage done to them. Messi bends a cross in from the right, but Trapp punches clear, with the German shot-stopper not looking entirely confident tonight. He is just getting rid of the ball as quickly as he can.

Luis Enrique's men are dominating possession and probing for any weaknesses in this PSG set-up, but Emery has his players well-drilled. There's not a lot of space in between the lines, with Barcelona needing to get very inventive indeed if they are to play their way into the box.

Barcelona have settled back into a period of dominance once again, with PSG sat extremely deep indeed. Emery has Cavani sat about 20 yards inside his own half. Their message is clear: attack us with everything you've got. If the hosts can score again, then things will really crank up a notch.

PSG have managed to ask Barcelona a few questions on the break, with the away side winning a free-kick on the right. Matuidi tries to bend a quick delivery into the back-post area, but the linesman pulls play back for offside on the far side. The hosts head up the other end, which results in Neymar cutting in and shooting with his right foot! The ball dips a few inches shy of the top corner.

Barcelona line up the free-kick that resulted from Draxler's booking, but a shot from Messi sails over the crossbar from around 25 yards out. That wasn't ever troubling Trapp. Luis Enrique will be very pleased with the attitude and approach of his players so far. They're hungry for goals.
Messi drives forward at pace, before getting cynically tripped by Draxler. That is the easiest booking that the referee will have to dish out today.

Lucas whips in a great corner delivery from the left-hand side, but Barcelona head clear at the back post. Finally, PSG are spending some time upfield, taking some pressure off their back four. Emery's men have settled after that early scare from Suarez.

PSG want handball! Draxler breaks down the left-hand side and tries to angle a cross into the box, but a sliding block from Mascherano denies him. The Argentine did block the ball with his arm, though it was accidental, and the visitors might have had a point there.

Barcelona maintain their pressure from consecutive corners, but PSG have been able to deal with them well. On the second, the danger is half-cleared to the edge of the box, but Mascherano can only half-volley the rebound a long way wide of the right-hand post

Neymar drives down the left-hand side, after some great work in midfield from Rakitic to win possession back, but the Brazilian cuts into the box and then into trouble - there was even a reluctant shout for handball there. Moments later, the ex-Santos man wins a corner out on the same flank, but Meunier heads clear.

Barcelona are trying to move the ball forward at pace, probing PSG wherever they can. The away fans might just be a little bit nervous now. As a response, Emery's men try to play out from the back patiently, but Luis Enrique's men are pressing very high and suffocating their opponents.
Matuidi gets the first yellow card of the game, despite protesting furiously, after treading late on Umtiti's toe. That looks to be a harsh decision so soon in the contest.

Barcelona have grabbed this game by the scruff of the neck, with PSG perhaps now rattled by conceding so soon. The hosts are piling players forward to try and control this game, but they'll need to be careful not to allow the visitors the chance to counter at pace.

GOOOOOOOOAL! SUAREZ HAS AN EARLY GOAL FOR BARCA! A cross is swung in from the right-hand side which Trapp and his back four cannot deal with, allowing for the diminutive Uruguay international to nod home from close range. It creeps over the line before it can be cleared! Game on!

We are underway in the first half at Camp Nou! Luis Enrique's side need four goals without reply from PSG to level this tie, with an away goal from Les Parisiens effectively killing off Barcelona's chances of a second-leg comeback.
PSG substitutes: Kimpembe, Krychowiak, Pastore, Di Maria, Areola, Aurier, Ben Arfa.
PSG starting line-up (4-3-3): Trapp; Meunier, Thiago Silva, Marquinhos, Kurzawa; Rabiot, Verratti, Matuidi; Lucas Moura, Cavani, Draxler.
Barcelona substitutes: Arda, Cillessen, Alcacer, Alba, Digne, Sergi Roberto, Andre Gomes.
Barcelona starting line-up (3-4-3): Ter Stegen; Pique, Mascherano, Umtiti; Rafinha, Busquets, Iniesta, Rakitic; Messi, Suarez, Neymar.

TEAM NEWS: Thoma Meunier is preferred to Serge Aurier at right-back for PSG, but there are no other surprises in their back four. Adrien Rabiot and Blaise Matuidi will look to do the running for the visitors' playmaker Marco Verratti. Angel Di Maria is only fit enough for the bench, which means that Lucas Moura and Julian Draxler are set to provide Cavani with ammunition from out wide. Thiago Motta misses out due to injury.

TEAM NEWS: Barcelona go with a three-man defensive line for tonight's game, with Rafinha and Neymar presumably being asked to track back in the wide areas. Javier Mascherano features at centre-back, with Ivan Rakitic given the nod in midfield. Jordi Alba and Sergi Roberto are available from the bench, should the hosts want to switch things around mid-game tactically.

The home side have recently beaten both Celta Vigo and Sporting Gijon by huge margins at Camp Nou, but tonight provides a totally different challenge for the LaLiga club. PSG have picked up considerably over recent months under Unai Emery, with Edinson Cavani free-scoring since Zlatan Ibrahimovic's summer departure. Despite needing four goals without reply to tie the aggregate scoreline up, there is still belief that Barcelona can pull this off.

Hello and welcome to live coverage of Barcelona's Champions League home clash against Paris Saint-Germain, where Luis Enrique's men need to turn over a first-leg 4-0 defeat in order to progress into the next round of the competition. A lot has changed since the first meeting between these two, the hosts' coach has said that he will step down at the end of the season, while Lionel Messi, Neymar and Luis Suarez have found their goalscoring form once again. Could the Blaugrana pull off the impossible?
news: Barcelona claimed a scarcely believable Champions League victory against Paris Saint-Germain that will go down in history as one of the all-time great comebacks, Sergi Roberto netting in the fifth minute of stoppage time to seal a sensational 6-5 aggregate triumph after they had trailed 4-0.

It had looked as though Edinson Cavani's away goal would prove pivotal after Barca had raced into a three-goal lead, but the hosts scored three times from the 88th minute onwards at Camp Nou to complete the biggest turnaround ever seen in the competition.
After being thrashed in the first leg of the last-16 tie, Barca appeared set to fall agonisingly short of a famous recovery in what transpired to be a classic encounter.

Luis Enrique's side were three goals up within 50 minutes and did not allow Cavani's intervention to foil their bid for a slice of history, Neymar scoring twice before setting up Roberto in astonishing scenes, the second leg ultimately finishing 6-1.
Two scrappy first-half goals – one from Luis Suarez in the third minute – and a Layvin Kurzawa own goal gave a rocking Camp Nou hope of a reversal in the tie.

The home side reduced the deficit further early in the second half when Lionel Messi scored his 11th goal of the competition this season from the penalty spot after Neymar was fouled by Thomas Meunier.

But a great finish from Cavani just after the hour mark – his eighth of a Champions League campaign that has been his most prolific – seemed to have made the difference, before the late heroics from Neymar and Roberto.
The crushing defeat sees PSG beaten by Barca in the knockout stages again having suffered the same fate in 2013 and 2015.
Barca, meanwhile, reach the quarters for the 10th straight season, meaning they are still in with a chance of a treble in Luis Enrique's last season at the helm.
Hopes of a remarkable comeback were stirred after only 150 seconds, Suarez getting the goal.

The Barca forward climbed above indecisive goalkeeper Kevin Trapp and sent a close-range header beyond Meunier on the line after Marquinhos and Marco Verratti had both failed to deal with Rafinha's cross.
PSG had a penalty claim rejected when Julian Draxler's cross struck the arm of a sliding Javier Mascherano, who was in as one of three Barca changes from the first leg.
But the hosts kept up the pressure, with Messi sending a free-kick just over and Neymar seeing a curling effort go just wide.

Lucas Moura, starting for PSG with Angel Di Maria only fit for the bench, sent an effort straight at Marc-Andre ter Stegen, but that was as good as it got from the visitors as Barca struck again five minutes before the break.

It was another scrappy goal, with poor defending from Marquinhos allowing Andres Iniesta to chase down Suarez's flick-on in the area and send a clever back-heel across goal which was sliced into his own net by Kurzawa.
The night went from bad to worse for PSG within three minutes of the restart when referee Deniz Aytekin pointed to the spot after consulting with one of his fellow officials.
The Barca award came when Neymar had surged into the area and been felled by Meunier's head after the defender lost his footing, with Messi stepping up and blasting past Trapp from 12 yards.
PSG almost got a priceless away goal in response when Meunier beat Neymar at the other end and squared for Cavani, whose sliding left-footed effort struck the post from six yards.
Unai Emery then brought on Di Maria for Lucas in desperate search of a goal that did arrive after 62 minutes.

A deep free-kick from Verratti led to Kurzawa getting above Ivan Rakitic to head back into path of Cavani and he dispatched a magnificent dipping finish into the roof of the net, sparking ecstatic scenes from Emery and the away supporters.
Ter Stegen made a key save from Cavani a few moments later after Draxler's throughball sent the PSG striker clear to keep Barca – who now needed a further three goals – alive.

Substitute Arda Turan had a shot cleared off the line by Marquinhos and Messi fired wide from a presentable opening, but Cavani's strike appeared to have stalled the hosts' momentum before a frantic finale.
Barca got a fourth with two minutes left, Neymar finding the top corner with an impressive free-kick that left Trapp rooted to the spot.
He struck again from the penalty spot in the first minute of added time, sending Trapp the wrong way after Suarez had been fouled by Marquinhos.
PSG then had to keep out Barca for the remaining four minutes of the five added, but could not do that as Barca rocked the football world.

The LaLiga side threw Ter Stegen into attack to add to the drama, which saw them seal one of football's most stunning victories when Roberto volleyed in Neymar's pass, sending Luis Enrique, the players and Camp Nou into ecstasy.

commentary: Thanks for joining our commentary this afternoon. Until next time, goodbye.
Mark Hughes will be very disappointed with Stoke’s display this afternoon, although he will know that they will not face strikers of Kane’s calibre every week.
The result keeps Spurs’ slim title hopes alive, although Mauricio Pochettino and his men know that they will have to be flawless for the rest of the campaign.
Harry Kane put on a clinic this afternoon, scoring a sublime first-half hat-trick along with notching an assist for Dele Alli’s goal to guide Tottenham to a hammering of Stoke at White Hart Lane.
FULL-TIME: TOTTENHAM 4-0 STOKE
The referee ends the contest.
There will be one minute of added time.
Wanyama catches Allen late and heads into the book.
SAVE! Grant makes another smart stop at his near post to deny Alli a second after the midfielder burst past two Stoke defenders before poking an effort towards the net.
Kane receives a standing ovation from White Hart Lane as he is replaced by Son.
CHANCE! Walker attempts to notch a fifth for the home side with a bursting run down the flank, latching on to Eriksen's pass. However, his low effort is well saved at the near post by Grant.
SHOT! Alli surges down the left flank and drives a low effort at goal, but Grant makes a comfortable save as the ball trickles into his grasp.
Cameron makes his return after a four-month layoff as he replaces Whelan.
PENALTY SHOUT! Shawcross may have gotten away with one as the ball appears to strike his hand in the box as attempted to clear a corner, but referee Moss waved away the shouts for a penalty.
Spurs are doing a solid job of retaining possession to see the game out, but are still offering a threat in the final third to add to their goal tally.
Walker raids down the right flank and does everything well until his attempted cross as he sends the ball into the stand behind the goal.
SAVE! Grant denies Kane a fourth goal with a fine one-handed save low down to his right. The forward's left-footed effort seemed destined for the bottom corner before the keeper acted.
Tottenham are trying to be a bit too intricate with their play in the final third as Walker makes a poor decision, just a minute after a careless offload from Dembele.
OVER! Eriksen tees up Winks on the edge of the box and he cuts back on to his left foot to shoot, only for Martins Indi to deflect his strike over the bar.
Sobhi and Allen combine in the final third and only a good clearance from Davies at the back post stops Arnautovic tapping home from close range.
Wimmer brings down Arnautovic and heads into the book.
Winks comes on to the pitch to replace Vertonghen.
Arnautovic leads the charge from the back and raids all the way to the byline before Wimmer stops his cross at the near post.
CHANCE! Eriksen sends a dangerous delivery into the box from a free-kick and somehow Dier and Wanyama are unable to turn the ball home from close range before Stoke break on the counter.
Sobhi almost releases Berahino through the middle, but Vertonghen just gets a touch to steer the ball back to Lloris ahead of the striker.

BLOCK! Eriksen has an abundance of space to raid into and declines the option to pick out Kane. He goes for goal and Martins Indi makes the block, which is then gathered by Grant before the ball goes out for a corner.
Adam is replaced by Afellay.
Crouch is given a nice ovation from the home fans as he is replaced by Berahino.

OFFSIDE! Grant makes an outstanding save to deny Dier from close range after the defender latches on to Eriksen's free-kick. The offside flag went up against Dier anyway, but it was still a fine stop.

CHANCE! Stoke almost get a goal back as Adam launches an effort towards the near post from the resulting corner, but Lloris saves and the ball is flicked away from Allen by the Spurs keeper before he can pounce.
Stoke earn a chance to threaten as Vertonghen brings down Allen. Adam attempts to whip the ball to the near post, but Davies makes the clearance.

CHANCE! Kane comes within inches of a fourth goal as he attempts to latch on to Eriksen's cross at the back post, but cannot make contact. Worryingly for Spurs the 23-year-old appears to have hurt himself in his fall to the ground.
The tempo of the game has dropped significantly from the first half. It's almost like a training ground contest for the home side now.
Shawcross puts Grant under huge pressure with a short backpass and Alli almost closes down the Stoke keeper, forcing him to clear into touch.
Dier sends the ball long for Alli to control in the box. The midfielder tries an ambitious effort with an overhead kick, but he scuffs the attempt wide of the post.
Confirmation of Wimmer's arrival to replace Alderweireld.
Wimmer will be coming on, but for now Spurs are down to 10 men while they wait for him to arrive.
A worry for Spurs as Alderweireld goes down under his own steam in the centre circle. Given their comfortable lead he could be withdrawn here.
We're back underway at White Hart Lane.
The players are back out for the second half, so we should be underway shortly.
Mauricio Pochettino will be elated with his men at the break, while on the other side Mark Hughes may simply have to tip his hat to Kane's brilliance.

The 23-year-old scored a perfect striker's finish for his first goal, an outstanding half-volley for his second before receiving a nice piece of luck to complete his hat-trick. He even added an assist to his name with a sublime piece of skill to beat Martins Indi to find Dele Alli for the fourth.

Harry Kane has been simply outstanding in the first half. His hat-trick and assist has handed Tottenham a four-goal lead at the break over Stoke, who have had no answer for his brilliance this afternoon.
HALF-TIME: TOTTENHAM 4-0 STOKE
The referee ends the first half.
Kane continues his excellent performance with a sublime assist. Knocking the ball around Martins Indi before sending a perfect ball across the face of goal for Alli to convert.

GOALLLL!!! ALLI JOINS THE PARTY! Kane has the ball on a string at the moment and his touch around Martins Indi creates Spurs' fourth goal. He knocks the ball around the defender before racing into the box and laying the ball on a plate for Alli to convert at close range. A complete and utter hammering.
There will be two minutes of added time.
Stoke have been flat since Spurs' opener and their first attempt at a raid forward ends in disappointment as Crouch's flick-on from Adam's cross travels straight to Lloris.
Alli somehow weaves his way out of trouble in the box away from three blue shirts. He picks out Davies who sends a deep cross to the back post for Kane, but this time the forward cannot connect.
Kane's attempt for a fourth this afternoon is stifled as Stoke don't fall for the same free-kick routine twice, with Sobhi making the interception.
Kane has now scored six goals in his last three games against Stoke.
Alli draws another foul in the final third as this time Arnautovic brings him down to head into the book.
Eriksen claims an assist by simply knocking the ball to his team-mate before he strikes with power to find the net.

GOALLLLL! KANE COMPLETES HIS HAT-TRICK! The 23-year-old has his third hat-trick in nine appearances as his strike from a 30-yard free-kick takes a wicked deflection off the wall to completely wrong foot Grant before nestling in the bottom corner. When it's your day...
Adam is walking a very fine line now as he clips Alli 30 yards from goal after the midfielder turned him with ease. That might be his final warning this afternoon.
Kane has scored five goals in his last three matches against Stoke. He could be in line for more this afternoon.
Eriksen's corner finds Kane on the edge of the box and the forward does the rest with a fine finish.

GOALLLL!!!! KANE NOTCHES HIS SECOND! Spurs double their lead as Kane finishes emphatically from the resulting corner. The ball reaches him on the edge of the box, but he produces a sensational left-footed effort on the half-volley that flies into the bottom corner, leaving Grant with no chance. A sublime goal from the forward.
SAVE! Spurs take a short free-kick to allow Walker to smash an effort at goal from 30 yards and his powerful strike forces Grant to turn the ball over the bar.

A loose pass from Walker allows Stoke to break down the left through Adam. He has Arnautovic free at the back post, but he fails to pick out his team-mate as Walker atones for his error by making the interception.
Kane puts Shawcross under pressure with a swift turn and the Stoke skipper has no choice but to concede a corner by putting the ball out himself.

CHANCE! Kane picks up the ball 25 yards from goal and takes a touch to strike on his right foot. His effort has power and direction, but just not enough curl to bend into the top corner, drifting just wide of the post.

OFF THE BAR! Spurs come within inches of a second goal as Eriksen's corner is headed into the path of Vertonghen on the edge. He strikes the ball with power with his right foot, only to see his effort clatter off the bar and bounce clear.

Neat play between Eriksen and Wanyama opens up space for Walker to drill a dangerous cross to the near post, but Grant comes off his line to parry the ball away from the box. Good keeping from the Stoke stopper.
Adam flies into a challenge with Alli and heads into the book.

SAVE! Crouch should level the scores as he latches on to a low cross to the near post from Pieters. He makes contact with an outstretched leg, but Lloris makes a brilliant save to deny the veteran forward.
CHANCE! Alli fails to take a pass in stride in the box and Stoke clear, but only as far as Walker on the edge. The full-back hammers the ball towards the net, but his strike flies over the bar.
Bardsley flies in with a thunderous challenge on Alli and narrowly avoids a booking, although he does get a talking to from the referee.
Whelan slides in late on Vertonghen and catches the Belgian on the foot. As a result, he heads into the book.
Stoke win a corner thanks to pressure from Crouch, but the resulting cross from Adam is well cleared by Dembele, who rises highest in the box.
The Stoke backline switched off for just a second, but were duly punished Kane, highlighting the quality of the striker.

GOALLL!!! KANE FIRES TOTTENHAM AHEAD! Out of nothing Spurs take the lead as Kane latches on to a loose ball in the box and buries a right-footed effort beyond the reach of Grant into the bottom corner. The 23-year-old notches his 100th goal in his club career.
WIDE! Dembele gifts the ball straight to Allen on the edge of the box. The Welshman fires at goal with a low right-footed strike, but his effort slams into the side-netting.
Spurs are dominating possession, but are yet to register an effort on goal, with the visitors entrenched in their defensive shape.

Spurs knock the ball around the box after excellent work by Kane to open up the Potters at the back. However, both Alli and Wanyama are unable to find space to shoot before Davies' cross to the back post is cleared.

Tottenham are attempting to establish a rhythm in the early stages. They struggled to build a tempo against Gent during the week and Pochettino will be desperate to see his side find their groove their afternoon.

CHANCE! Eriksen beats Shawcross with ease on the left flank and he fires a low ball across the face of goal, but Kane had pulled away for the cutback, allowing the ball to trickle over to the right flank.
A shaky clearance from Pieters puts Martins Indi under pressure at the back, but the Dutchman clears well from the byline to prevent the corner.

Alderweireld surges past Allen to raid into the Stoke half before feeding Walker on the wing. The England man sends a cross to the back post, but he gets too much power on his delivery putting it out for a throw-in.
Slow start to the game as both teams possess the ball for only a few seconds each. This could be a defensive battle from the off.
We're underway at White Hart Lane.
The players are making their way out on to the pitch, so we should be underway shortly.
STAT ATTACK! Following his hat-trick last week Harry Kane is currently on 99 goals in his club career.
STAT ATTACK! Tottenham have won their last two matches against Stoke by a 4-0 scoreline.

Hughes also has stood fast with his same side that defeated Crystal Palace in their last Premier League outing two weeks ago. Peter Crouch continues to lead the line, supported by Ramadan Sobhi, Joe Allen and Marko Arnautovic.

Pochettino has kept faith with the same players that were unable to defeat Gent in their Europa League clash at the Lane on Thursday. Alli retains his place despite his dismissal alongside Harry Kane and Christian Eriksen in a three-man attack.
Stoke subs: Muniesa, Berahino, Afellay, Diouf, Cameron, Imbula, Given.
STOKE (4-2-3-1): Grant; Bardsley, Shawcross, Martins Indi, Pieters; Whelan, Adam; Arnautovic, Allen, Sobhi; Crouch.
Tottenham subs: Son, Janssen, Vorm, Trippier, Sissoko, Wimmer, Winks.
TOTTENHAM (3-4-3): Lloris; Dier, Alderweireld, Vertonghen; Walker, Wanyama, Dembele, Davies; Eriksen, Alli, Kane.
The team news has been confirmed and we'll start with the home side.
Mark Hughes' side have lost just once in their last six game and will be up for the challenge of facing Spurs this afternoon - fresh off the home side's disappointment over their Europa League exit.
Stoke are on course for another solid campaign in the top-flight, but can move above West Ham back into ninth place as the Hammers' draw yesterday knocked them down one spot.

Spurs crashed out of the Europa League during the week, securing only a 2-2 draw against Gent, while Dele Alli was sent off for a horror tackle. The 20-year-old's ban only applies to European football so he will be available, but Pochettino will be demanding a display from the midfielder.

Mauricio Pochettino's men are 13 points behind the Blues following their win over Swansea City yesterday. As a result, Tottenham can ill afford another slip-up in the Premier League unless they are willing to concede the title at this early stage.
Two weeks have passed since Spurs were on the wrong end of a 2-0 defeat to Liverpool at Anfield, leaving them well off the pace of leaders Chelsea at the top of the table.
Good afternoon and welcome to the live commentary of the Premier League clash between Liverpool and Stoke at White Hart Lane.
news: A first-half Harry Kane hat-trick inspired Tottenham to an emphatic 4-0 victory over Stoke City in the Premier League on Sunday.
The England international scored his fourth treble for the club and turned provider for Dele Alli to send Mauricio Pochettino's side into second in the table.

Spurs endured a tough match at Wembley this week as they exited the Europa League at the hands of Gent, but there was to be no hangover from their European travails as they dispatched a dreadful Stoke side in the first half.
Kane - who disappointed in that 2-2 draw with the Belgians - opened the scoring with his 100th goal at club level before making is 2-0 with a sublime half-volley with 32 minutes played.
The 23-year-old's deflected free-kick secured his second hat-trick in as many appearances in domestic competition, and he set up Alli to make it 4-0 before the break to cap a ruthless performance.
It was a routine affair for Spurs in the second half as Stoke accepted their fate, with the home side moving back to within 10 points of leaders Chelsea, while Mark Hughes' side stay 10th.
Spurs enjoyed the better of a very quiet opening but had Stoke's captain to thank for the opening goal.

Glenn Whelan was a little fortunate not to be sent off soon after for a clumsy two-footed challenge on Jan Vertonghen, but only a fine save with his foot from Hugo Lloris prevented Peter Crouch from prodding in an equaliser against the run of play.

Spurs spirits were dampened when they lost Toby Alderweireld to a knock shortly after half-time, but Kane almost gave the home fans another moment to cheer, with only a fine right-hand save from Grant denying him a fourth goal.

Kyle Walker waltzed into the box only to slice a shot wide and he was thwarted by Grant in the closing minutes from close range, but Spurs were largely content to play the possession game as they cruised to what could be an important victory in the battle for the top four.

commentary: That's all from us at the Stadio Renzo Barbera. Thanks for joining us throughout this Serie A clash between Palermo and Inter Milan.

Inter Milan make it six wins in a row in the league and overtake their city rivals in the table. It took the visitors a while to break down the hosts, but the goal eventually came from Joao Mario in the second half.
A disappointing end for Palermo as Gazzi collects his second yellow and a red card.
It looks as if 10-man Inter are going to be collecting all three points. Ever since the red card Palermo haven't looked like scoring and the visitors are cruising to victory after the early drama.
Quaison collects a late yellow card for a foul on Kondogbia.

A cross is headed behind by Santon which presents Palermo with a chance to get players forward, but Quaison's delivery goes all the way through the penalty area and Inter are allowed to counter-attack.
Palermo are struggling to string a number of passes together. A long ball forward to Nestorovski is headed down to nobody as the home side fail to trouble Handanovic.
Right, it looks as if we may get some football again in the last five minutes, rather than the referee blowing his whistle every 20 seconds.
