The game suddenly becomes fairly stretched which allows Bonaventura to open up his stride with a galloping run through the middle of the pitch. However, he is stopped in his tracks by the retreating Falque, who cynically concedes the foul and earns a booking in the process after a tug of the shirt.

After the end-to-end football we witnessed in the first portion of the second half, things have just slowed down ever-so-slightly in terms of how quickly the players are bombing forward. This might be to try and conserve energy for what promises to be an exciting final 10 minutes, though.

First change of the match from Montella and it sees Kucka, who actually scored in the match between Milan and Torino four days ago in the Italian Cup, come on for the disappointing Bertolacci. The latter may have got the first Milan goal, but he has been poor on the whole.

BELOTTI! Torino come SO close to reclaiming their lead! Again, the Milan defenders are guilty of stepping back to allow the attacker room, and the Italian forward takes advantage to pull the trigger with a stunning strike from 25 yards. The luck is with the visitors on this occasion though as it misses the target by a whisker.

Twenty minutes to go in this pulsating Serie A encounter and we are no closer to finding out who can go on to claim the vital three points. If Torino can pull it off, it would be their first win over Milan in the top-flight in 16 years, so certainly about time they stopped the rot!

LJAJIC! HOW CLOSE WAS THAT?! The former Roma forward is awarded far too much space in the final third and eventually skips inside on his right foot before sending a dipping strike high towards the top corner. Donnarumma struggles to get across, but Milan survive as the attempt flashes JUST wide of the left-hand post!
Valdifiori won't be able to continue, and makes way for Sasa Lukic.

Torino take the short corner and after a few passes, Iturbe sees possession around 30 yards out. The substitute moves into space further forward and decides to pull the trigger from range, but the connection isn't great which makes it easier for a member of the Milan backline to make the block and then the subsequent clearance. Poor in the end from the hosts.

A small break in play at the moment as Valdifiori is currently down after taking a nasty fall to the floor after an aerial challenge with a Milan midfielder. After a few moments he attempts to soldier on, but is really struggling to shake off the issue so perhaps he will need to come off. He is still continuing for the moment, though.

Suso commands the ball superbly on the edge of the Torino box and probes to try and find a yard of space to get the shot away. In the end he displays patience to eventually lay a pass down the right channel for Abate who lifts a wicked cross into the danger area from the byline, but Moretti is there to make the important clearance.
Just as Milan equalise, Torino make their opening change as Obi makes way for Juan Iturbe.
GOOOOAAAAALLLLL FOR MILAN! Montella's men are back on level terms! Bacca steps up and confidently dispatches the penalty into the right corner past Hart! Two-two! GAME ON.
Booking for Rossettini as he concedes the penalty.

PENALTY TO MILAN! Rossettini has completely let his team-mates down here as he needlessly hauls Paletta to the floor inside the box even though Hart was ALWAYS going to claim the cross out of the air. Definite spotkick!

What a game we have on our hands now, folks. This game was always going to be a cracker with the way both sides flood men forward, but with the way the play is going it doesn't look like the goalscoring is going to stop now!
Obi sees yellow now, and deservedly so as the tackle was late, and indeed high.
GOOOOAAAAALLLLL FOR MILAN! After a few failed clearances, the ball falls nicely to Bertolacci a few yards out who manages to JUST smuggle a strike over the line past the despairing Hart. Two-one.

Milan continue to pop the ball around in a fashion which is fairly easy on the eye, but like in the first period it is coming without much penetrative threat into the final third. Bacca has been desperately bereft of any kind of decent service, which is probably why Montella has sent M'Baye Niang out to warm up.

Zappacosta displays an impressive turn of pace to drive beyond Bonaventura down the right touchline before attempting to thread a precise pass in behind the Milan defence for the onrushing Ljajic. However, Romagnoli is there for the visitors again to make the interception.

Belotti's passion and desire can sometimes get the better of him, and it does so on this occasion as he goes into the book for a very late tackle on Bertolacci around 35 yards out from the Torino goal.

VITAL block by Romagnoli! Ljajic cleverly reverses a pass down the left wing for the overlapping Barreca who stands a teasing cross to the back post. Belotti uses his neck muscles to bullet a header at goal, but the Milan defender is positioned well and protects his goalkeeper with a solid interception.
We are back under way in Turin!

Half-time at the Stadio Olimpico. Torino are on course to claim the home win as they go into the break with a healthy 2-0 lead over Milan, who have been desperately poor both at the back and in attack. Still plenty of time to recover, though, and the visitors can't really play as badly as they did in the opening 45. Second period to come.
The bookings are coming thick and fast in Turin and the latest guilty party is Romagnoli who cynically halts the Torino counter with a foul on Belotti.

Some lovely interplay from Milan on the edge of the opposition box involving Bacca and Bonaventura, with the latter eventually bursting his way into a shooting position. The strike comes, but it is desperately poor and ends up being sent straight down the throat of the grateful Hart in the Torino goalmouth.

From the Moretti foul, Milan get the free-kick a yard outside the box on the right channel. Suso is the man tasked with the set-piece after winning it himself and steps up to curl a gorgeous attempt up and over the Torino wall, but unfortunately for the visitors it goes INCHES wide of the post. So unlucky!
Moretti is punished with the yellow after a cheap foul on Suso.

GREAT SAVE FROM JOE HART! The Manchester City loanee, who has not had a thing to do so far, does well when called into action for the first time and tips a lovely strike from Suso over the crossbar for the corner-kick. That attempt was definitely goal-bound from the Spaniard!

PENALTY SHOUT FOR MILAN! A speculative cross is swung to the back post inside the Torino box and Bonaventura takes possession in before going down under the high challenge from Zappacosta. The Milan star is actually kicked right on the top of the shin, but the referee fails to point to the spot!

Montella's men are enjoying a nice period of sustained possession at the moment but it is all coming in areas which don't pose any threat to Torino. The biggest problem going forward for Milan is that there is no bridge between the midfield and attack, which is leaving Bacca pretty isolated up top.

Milan really need to sort themselves out here and are very lucky not to be three goals down before even the half-time whistle. Donnarumma is the only player who hasn't really put a foot wrong so far, and thanks to him and the penalty save the scoreline remains at 2-0. Here come Torino again, though...
Donnarumma keeps Milan in with a shout with the saved penalty!

MISSED PENALTY FROM TORINO! Ljajic attempts to catch out the goalkeeper by passing the ball straight down the middle, but Donnarumma remains tall to make the easy save! What a terrible, terrible spotkick.

PENALTY TO TORINO! After some neat work from Falque down the left-hand side, Abate is forced into making the tackle, but does so clumsily and ends up hacking away at the legs of the former Roma winger. Definite pen!

Milan have been pretty awful so far and there are many factors which will have Montella worried. They are defending atrociously, but they have also been equally as ineffective at the other end of the park as Hart hasn't had a save to make between the sticks! Are Bacca, Suso, and Bonaventura even playing?!
Again, the assist was actually an attempted shot, but Falque and Torino won't care!

GOOOOAAAAALLL FOR TORINO! The second comes quickly! After numerous failed clearances from Milan following a cross into the box, the ball loosely falls to the feet of Benassi, who cleverly flicks the ball beyond the despairing defender from 10 yards out! Two-nil.
Yellow for Locatelli after a foul on Belotti.

You can see why so many of Europe's top clubs are interested in making a bid for Belotti. Not only does the Italian hold a predatory instinct in front of goal, which we just saw moments ago, but he also loves a physical battle and is really taking it to Paletta and Romagnoli at the back for Milan.
It was meant as a shot, but Ljajic gets the assist anyway!

GOOOOOAAAAAALLLL FOR TORINO! The hosts take the lead! Falque leaves the defender for dead with a nutmeg down the right wing and moves inside to lay the ball into the path of Ljajic. The former Roma man pulls the trigger with a poorly-connected strike, but Belotti is positioned to poke home from seven yards! One-nil.

Apart from that Belotti strike early on, neither goalkeeper has been regularly tested between the sticks so far. Hart in particular has been nowhere near as busy as he would have expected, especially with the way Torino usually ship goals!

Milan are just starting to feel their way into proceedings a little more now with Romagnoli and Paletta moving the backline all the way up to halfway. Even with the possession they are enjoying, the visitors need to be wary of Belotti who could easily break through on goal on the counter.

Bacca collects the ball to feet on the edge of the box and attempts to dink the ball past Moretti, only for it to bounce off the arm of the Torino defender. Bacca is well within his rights to complain to the referee, but at that distance the centre-back couldn't really have moved out of the way.

There is an interesting battle developing with Paletta and Belotti inside the Milan half, and the defender is starting to be quite proactive in his tackling to try and not allow the talented striker any space. On this occasion, he just gives him a slap to the back to alert him of his presence.

An odd situation ensues just in front of the dugout as Bacca battles away with Rossettini to try and win the ball before sending the Torino defender flying with a shoulder barge. Rossettini actually beats the ball away with his hand while falling to the floor, prompting the Colombian to ask for the yellow, but the referee doesn't do anything and waves play on.

Paletta sees the ball to feet a couple of times at the back within the space of a few seconds, but both times the big defender is forced to play square due to the high pressing of Belotti. It looks like the Milan man has been targeted for some high-tempo pressure from the Torino frontline.

Torino are bossing things at the moment as the Milan trio in midfield have been unable to stamp their authority on proceedings. Valdifiori is the man running things in those central areas, but the hosts need to capitalise on this small period of dominance.

SAAAAVE FROM DONNARUMMA! Belotti breaks the offside trap superbly and latches on to a threaded ball down the channel before running through one-on-one. He lashes a strike at goal from around 12 yards out just to the right, but the Milan stopper is equal to it and makes the solid stop. Great play from Torino!

Almost a horror moment for Milan in the early stages as Paletta goes to clear the ball away from the edge of the box, only for it to cannon off the shin of Belotti before ominously heading towards goal. Luckily for the visitors, their blushes are spared as the ball goes behind for a goal-kick.
We are under way in Turin!
Torino subs: Padelli, Cucchietti, Carlao, Baselli, Maxi Lopez, Gustafson, Iturbe, Lukic, De Silvestri, Boyè, Ajeti
Torino (4-3-3): Hart; Zappacosta, Rossettini, Moretti, Barreca; Benassi, Valdifiori, Obi; Falque, Belotti, Ljajic.
Milan subs: Plizzari, Storari, Ely, Gomez, Vangioni, Zapata, Honda, Kucka, Sosa, Cutrone, Lapadula, Niang.
Milan (4-3-3): Donnarumma; Abate, Paletta, Romagnoli, Calabria; Pasalic, Locatelli, Bertolacci; Suso, Bacca, Bonaventura.
TEAM NEWS...

Torino and Milan actually faced each other as recently as four days ago. On that occasion in the Italian Cup at San Siro, Montella's charges ran out very narrow 2-1 victors thanks to strikes from Giacomo Bonaventura and Juraj Kucka after Belotti had given the visitors the lead in the first half.

Torino are in ninth place at the moment, but have certainly played some exciting stuff this season, scoring plenty of goals. Mihajlovic is in charge of the side from Turin now, and will be hoping the likes of star striker, Andrea Belotti, can inspire a positive result over the team he was at the helm of, unsuccessfully, last season.

Under the tutelage of Vincenzo Montella, Milan appear to be generating the feel-good factor back to the San Siro somewhat after the underwhelming tenures of Sinisa Mihajlovic, Filippo Inzaghi, and Clarence Seedorf. However, after a very positive start to the campaign they have started to slip down the table and are currently down in sixth. They remain five points clear of the Champions League qualification positions, but do have two games in hand over their rivals.
Good evening football fans! Welcome to LIVE coverage of the Italian Serie A encounter between Torino and Milan from the Stadio Olimpico di Torino.
news: AC Milan recovered from two goals down to draw a thrilling Serie A clash 2-2 at Torino, for whom Adem Ljajic missed a spot-kick to make it 3-0.
Torino were rampant in the first half, Andrea Belotti making it eight goals in his last nine Serie A games before Marco Benassi's impressive flick doubled their lead.
The hosts were threatening to run away with it but Ljajic had his penalty saved by Milan goalkeeper Gianluigi Donnarumma before half-time.
And that allowed Milan to launch a rapid second-half fightback, Andrea Bertolacci getting one back before Carlos Bacca scored from a penalty of his own on the hour mark.

Neither side went on to find a decisive third goal, Milan's Alessio Romagnoli sent off a minute from time for a second booking. Torino have only won against the Rossoneri in one of their last 40 top-flight meetings while Sinisa Mihajlovic has failed to beat his former club in three attempts this season.

Fifth-placed Milan have won just one of their last four league games, but sit within four points of Napoli in third ahead of their crunch clash at San Siro on Saturday. Vincenzo Montella's men still hold a game in hand on most of their rivals for a Champions League spot.
Mid-table Torino, meanwhile, have just one victory in six top-flight games after surrendering their lead, although Juventus remain the only team to have beaten them in 10 home games.
Belotti came into the game in fine form and it was he who struck in the 21st minute when Iago Falque found Ljajic and his attempted shot was steered in by the striker.

Five minutes later it was two for the hosts after Milan had twice failed to clear the danger. Belotti picked up the loose ball and linked up with Falque, whose pass was brilliantly flicked in by Benassi, with Romagnoli unable to clear from the goal-line.
Torino then squandered a glorious chance to put the result beyond doubt just after the half-hour mark.

A penalty was awarded when Antonio Barreca made ground down the left wing and went down under a clip from Ignazio Abate, but Ljajic fired a dreadful spot-kick straight at Donnarumma and Falque lashed the rebound wide.
Joe Hart was called upon for first time prior to the break, rising high to keep out a long-range shot from Suso before also denying Bertolacci to preserve his side's two-goal advantage.

But Milan did beat Hart within 10 minutes of the restart, Abate's cross from the right leading to chaos in the Torino defence and Bertolacci defeated the England keeper from close range at the second attempt.
Benassi thought he had made an instant response for Torino but was correctly flagged for offside after prodding in when Donnarumma parried Falque's strike.
An end-to-end clash continued with Hart making a magnificent diving save from Gabriel Paletta's header following Suso's cross, before Milan drew level.

From the resulting corner, Luca Rossettini was all over Paletta, prompting referee Paolo Tagliavento to point to the spot for the second time and Bacca did not make the same mistake as Ljajic, comfortably sending Hart the wrong way for his eighth top-flight goal of the campaign.
Torino attempted to re-assert themselves as Belotti shot off-target with a presentable chance and Donnarumma saved well from Ljajic.
But Mihajlovic's side were forced to settle for an entertaining draw soured slightly by Romagnoli receiving his second yellow for a foul on Belotti.
Key Opta stats:

commentary: Thanks for joining our commentary this evening. Until next time, goodbye.

Vincenzo Montella will be delighted to leave with a point as his side were outplayed for the majority of the match, while their injury problems left them short of quality options especially in the middle of the park. Definitely a point gained for Milan this evening.

Suso's late strike earns Milan a point from the contest after it looked as though Lazio would claim the victory. The home side were the better team, but lacked a clinical edge, much to the frustation of Simone Inzaghi.
FULL-TIME: LAZIO 1-1 AC MILAN
Lazio clear the danger, but the referee brings the contest to an end.
Deulofeu wins a corner for Milan late in the game. One last chance for the visitors to snatch the three points.
Lazio clear the danger from Sosa's free-kick and Inzaghi can breathe again on the touchline.
Milan are doing a fine job of taking time off the clock, while providing a threat in the final third. Suso wins a free-kick in a dangerous position for the visitors.
There will be four minutes of added time.
Suso almost unlocks the Lazio defence again, but De Vrij just gets enough on his block to send the ball out for a corner.
Milinkovic-Savic is booked for a poor tackle on Sosa.
Anderson makes way as Lombardi comes on to the pitch.
Gil replaces Radu for the home side.
Sosa picks out his team-mate in the box and watches the Spaniard find the net.

GOAL!!!!!! SUSO LEVELS FOR MILAN! The Spaniard scores a stunner to get his side back in the game as he holds off two challenges before bending a left-footed strike beyond Strakosha from just inside the box. A splendid effort and Lazio have paid for their missed opportunities.
Lazio have battered Milan in the second half, but have not been able to pull clear. Will they rue these missed chances?

CHANCE! Immobile somehow collects a pass from Lulic when the midfielder was on the ground. He has plenty of time to pick his spot to beat Donnarumma, but the keeper makes a solid save to deny the Lazio forward.
Fernandez is harshly booked for a challenge on Lulic.

CLOSE! Milinkovic-Savic collects Lulic's lay-off on the edge of the box. With no Milan defender in sight he goes for goal with a curling effort, sending his strike inches past the post. Donnarumma had given up on that one.
Final change for Milan as Fernandez replaces Poli.
Milinkovic-Savic lifts an inviting ball into the box for Immobile to attack, but he can only tamely head his effort straight at Donnarumma.
CHANCE! Anderson has space and time to pick his spot on the half-volley after breaking free down the flank. However, he can only blast his effort into the side-netting.
SAVE! Sosa fires at goal from a free-kick from 30 yards and his strike arcs towards the top corner, but Strakosha makes a solid stop to keep the ball out.
Vangioni is caught out at the back by Anderson once again. The Brazilian sends a peach of a low cross into the box, but the ball evades Lulic and trickles past the post.
Anderson collects on the right flank and drives the ball across the face of goal, but Donnarumma comes off his line to palm the ball to safety.
For all of Lazio's dominance in the final third, Milan are starting to come into the contest. Inzaghi will be a concerned man on the sideline.
Milan are almost punished at the other end as Immobile nearly get in between Gomez and Zapata to latch on to Anderson's cross, but the ball just evades the forward to head out of play.
PENALTY SHOUT! Abate is denied a spot-kick by the officials as he collects Suso's pass and is bundled over by Lulic. The visitors cannot believe it.
Suso tries to carve out an opening for his side in the final third, but his cross to the back post has too much power for Lapadula to latch on to.
That's Keita's final action of the game as Lulic replaces him for the home side.
Keita challenges Abate down the left flank and opens up space to cross into the box, but he can only send his effort over the bar.
Lapadula replaces Ocampos for the visitors.
Radu fouls Abate and is booked by the referee.
Abate sends a teasing cross towards the near post for Ocampos to attack, but the ball just evades the striker's foot and lands in the hands of Strakosha.
Lazio break with numbers and Immobile sends the ball into the box for Keita, but this time Vangioni times his challenge to perfection to stop a strike at goal.
Suso vents his frustration with Ocampos as he takes possession in the box for a pass that was meant for Deulofeu behind him and loses possession. It has been that sort of game for Milan.
Lazio have started the second half how they began the first period. They're in complete control of this match and are threatening to put the game beyond Milan.

Keita collects a low pass from Immobile on the edge of the box and then goes down under pressure from Gomez, but the referee dismisses his claim for a penalty. The officials have been spot on this evening.
CHANCE! Anderson and Vangioni lock horns again down the flank and this time the Brazilian is able to blast an effort at goal, but it sails inches past the post.
Sosa replaces Locatelli for Montella's men.
Milinkovic-Savic makes a good run into the box to attempt to latch on to Parolo's low cross, but Donnarumma comes off his line to gather with a brave claim.
Anderson tests Vangioni again down the flank, but the left-back wins the battle as he stops the cross and comes away with possession.
Anderson collects down the right flank and sends a dangerous low cross towards the near post, but Gomez clears the danger with his left foot ahead of Immobile.
We're back underway at the Stadio Olimpico.
The players are back out for the second half, so we should be underway shortly.

The goal will have been a huge blow for Vincenzo Montella as he would have been delighted to get his team back into the break at 0-0. They've been poor thus far and are in need of significant improvement in all areas of the pitch to get a positive result this evening.

After being thwarted for the majortiy of the half by Gianluigi Donnarumma, Lazio capitalise on a mistake by the keeper to take the lead on the stroke of half-time. He stuck out his hands to trip Ciro Immobile and the referee pointed to the spot. Lucas Biglia hammered his effort past Donnarumma to hand his side the lead.
HALF-TIME: LAZIO 1-0 MILAN
GOALLLLLL! BIGLIA FIRES LAZIO AHEAD! The home side take the lead with the final kick of the first half as their skipper holds his nerve from 12 yards, blasting his effort past Donnarumma.
PENALTY TO LAZIO! Immobile goes down under Donnarumma's challenge and the referee points to the spot.
SHOT! Anderson beats the challenge of Vangioni down the flank and shoots at goal with his left foot, but Donnarumma makes the save with ease.
Lazio have lost their rhythm from the opening 30 minutes, which will give Inzaghi cause for concern heading into the break.
Hoedt puts Strakosha under huge pressure at the back as his backpass almost sells the keeper short as Deulofeu tries to close him down. However, the Albanian just releases the ball in time.
Ocampos is struggling for Milan as he loses possession yet again in the final third. Montella could be thinking about a change at the break.
Suso sends a fine throughball for Ocampos to collect on the edge of the box, but the striker fails to take the ball in stride, allowing the home side to clear.

Lazio win the midfield battle and break forward with numbers through Biglia. He finds Immobile on the edge of the box, who lays the ball back into his team-mates' path. However, Biglia drives his strike straight at Donnarumma,
Milan clear a corner into the box, only for Basta to line up a volley on the edge. He strikes with power, but Vangioni throws his body in the way to deflect the ball out for a throw-in.

Anderson runs forward with menace down the right flank and cuts inside into the box to send a cross to the back post. Abate does well to rise highest and clear the danger. The pressure remains on the visitors.
OVER! Deulofeu gets greedy from distance as he has support from his team-mates, but goes for goal. He gets his effort all wrong, sending the ball well over the bar.

CHANCE! Milan have an opportunity out of nowhere as Ocampos seizes possession on the edge of the box. He goes for goal from a tight angle and gets a decent strike on his left-footed effort, but Strakosha holds under pressure from Deulofeu.

SAVE & WIDE! Donnarumma makes a great save at close quarters to deny Hoedt as the defender latched on to a flick-on and poked an effort at goal. The keeper spread himself big to make the stop, while Gomez hammered the resulting clearance straight off Hoedt, but the ball trickled wide of the post.
Milan are under a lot of pressure here as Lazio are beginning to up the ante in the final third.

CHANCE! Zapata puts his team in huge danger as he slices his clearance. Immobile pounces on the loose ball, but Abate gets back at him just enough to force the Italian to send his strike wide of the post.
SHOT! Immobile knocks the ball back into the path of Keita, who hammers the ball at goal first time with his right foot. However, once again the home side are denied by a solid stop by Donnarumma.
Vangioni goes into the book for a lunge on Parolo.
Deulofeu finds space down the left flank with an intelligent run, unfortunately for the Spaniard there's no-one inside the box to collect his cross as Radu chests the ball back to Strakosha.
PENALTY SHOUT! Immobile takes a fine pass from Parolo in stride and goes down under contact from Gomez, but the referee dismisses his claims for a penalty. The striker is furious with the decision.
Radu hits a great ball first time over the top of the Milan defence for Anderson to control. The forward takes a good first touch, but his second is poor as he fires straight at Donnarumma.
SAVE! Lazio break on a swift counter and Parolo feeds the ball inside for Keita to strike first time. However, he scuffs his effort at goal, allowing Donnarumma to save with ease.
WIDE! Vangioni gets free at the back post to head Abate's cross towards goal, but he can only guide his effort past the post.

PENALTY SHOUT! Ocampos takes possession inside the box after collecting Suso's pass. He fires at goal from a tight angle, but De Vrij makes a sliding block. The forward appeals for a penalty as the ball appears to strike the Dutchman's hand, but the referee only awards a corner.

Suso gives the ball away in the middle of the park and he allows Radu to steal possession and raid forward. The defender attempts to find Keita on the left flank, but his pass goes too far in front of the forward and his cross on the stretch lands safely in Donnarumma's hands.
Lazio are having success testing Zapata and Gomez at the back so far. It will be interesting to see how the visitors fare without the presence of Romagnoli and Paletta this evening.

CHANCE! Parolo swings the ball into the box from the right after being allowed space on the flank. Immobile makes a great run across Zapata to head at goal, but he fails to hit the target from six yards, sending his effort wide.

SAVE! Biglia pounces on a loose ball on the edge of the box and he hammers an effort on the half volley towards goal. It appears destined for the bottom corner, but Donnarumma gets down quickly to make the stop, while Immobile is caught offside on the rebound.
CHANCE! Basta lines up a strike from 25 yards and he gets his effort away, only for the ball to strike Gomez and go behind for a corner, despite the best attempts of Donnarumma.
Radu raids forward with menace down the left flank, but he and Keita cannot combine due to pressure from Abate.
Montella's men are doing a fine job of putting the Lazio backline and Strakosha under pressure thus far. The lines of communication are not quite clear at the moment for the home side.

Strakosha struggles under pressure from successive Milan corners as Deulofeu swings in two dangerous crosses from the right. The Lazio keeper will be worth monitoring this evening after his late call into the line-up.

Deulofeu leads a counter for the visitors and he tries to beat the challenge of Hoedt, but the defender knocks the ball out of play. The Spaniard appeals for a penalty, but none of the officials are interested.
SHOT! Keita cuts in from the right and is afforded space and time to fire at goal, but his effort is saved by Donnarumma.
We're underway in this Serie A clash.
The players are making their way out on to the pitch, so we should be underway shortly.
REVISED LAZIO TEAM: Strakosha; Basta, Hoedt, De Vrij, Radu; Biglia, Milinkovic-Savic, Parolo; Keita, Felipe Anderson, Immobile.
BREAKING NEWS: Federico Marchetti has sustained an injury in the warm-up and has been replaced by Thomas Strakosha.

Lucas Ocampos makes his first start for Milan this evening as Montella opts to leave Carlos Bacca and Gianluca Lapadula on the bench. Gabriel Paletta misses out due to suspension, while Alessandro Romagnoli is also absent. Gustavo Gomez and Cristian Zapata come into the centre of the backline.

Lazio have made one change to their side that beat Pescara last week. Stefan Radu comes back into the fold to replace Jordan Lukaku, while Inzaghi retains the strikeforce from their emphatic win last time out.
AC Milan subs: Storari, Plizzari, Lapadula, Honda, Mati, Sosa, El Hilali, Zucchetti, Bacca, Bertolacci.
AC MILAN (4-3-3): Donnarumma; Abate, Gustavo Gomez, Zapata, Vangioni; Pasalic, Locatelli, Poli; Suso, Deulofeu, Ocampos.
Lazio subs: Strakosha, Vargic, Gabarroni Gil, Lukaku, Djordjevic, Crecco, Fortuna, Quissanga, Lulic, Lombardi, Tounkara, Murgia.
LAZIO (4-3-3): Marchetti; Basta, Hoedt, De Vrij, Radu; Biglia, Milinkovic-Savic, Parolo; Keita, Felipe Anderson, Immobile.
The team news has been announced and we'll start with the home side.
I Rossoneri are 11 points off the pace of third-place Napoli and can ill afford any further poor results, making a positive performance this evening imperative.

Milan's bid for the Champions League places has been derailed by their awful form since the turn of the year. Vincenzo Montella's men lost three games on the spin to Napoli, Udinese and Sampdoria, although they did get back to winning ways last time out against Bologna.

Simone Inzaghi’s side bounced back from a run of back-to-back defeats by overcoming Pescara in their last contest, claiming a thumping 6-2 victory on the road. I Biancocelesti know that they cannot afford many slip-ups from now until the end of the term, especially at home.

It's a make-or-break contest for both teams as neither side can afford to lose this evening. Both remain off the pace for the Champions League places with Lazio currently sitting in sixth place, while Milan are one spot below in seventh.
Good evening and welcome to the live commentary of the Serie A clash between Lazio and AC Milan at the Stadio Olimpico.
news: Suso's late strike salvaged a 1-1 draw for AC Milan against Lazio, who missed out on the opportunity to go fourth in Serie A.

A victory would have lifted Simone Inzaghi's side above Atalanta and Inter to within five points of Napoli, who occupy the final Champions League qualification berth, but Suso's 85th-minute goal earned Milan a share of the spoils.

Milan had ended a run of four straight defeats in all competitions with a 1-0 win at Bologna last time out - despite having two men sent off - and although they kept their full allocation on the field at Stadio Olimpico, they created little to trouble the hosts for much of this encounter.

Lazio took the lead in first-half stoppage time when Milan goalkeeper Gianluigi Donnarumma needlessly felled Ciro Immobile inside the area and Lucas Biglia smashed in the resulting spot-kick to Donnarumma's right.

The home side lost keeper Federico Marchetti to a reported knee injury in the warm-up and back-up Thomas Strakosha, having had little to do, was beaten late in the piece as Suso weaved between three Lazio defenders inside the box and placed a shot into the bottom-left corner.
Vincenzo Montella's side remain seventh, four points adrift of the Europa League places and one point ahead of Fiorentina, whom they host on Sunday.

Monday's outing began positively enough for Milan, who forced a succession of corners in the opening 10 minutes, but it was Lazio who threatened first - Biglia stinging the palms of Donnarumma before Immobile headed wide from Marco Parolo's cross.
The hosts maintained the pressure and Balde Keita twice brought comfortable saves out of Donnarumma either side of calls for a penalty when Immobile went down under a challenge from Gustavo Gomez.

Wesley Hoedt was next to go close for Lazio as he volleyed straight at Donnarumma from close range following a corner, Gomez relieved to see the ball trickle wide after smashing his subsequent clearance into the chest of the Dutchman.
Lazio could not afford to be complacent, though, and Lucas Ocampos provided a reminder of Milan's threat with a low shot on the break that was saved by Strakosha.
That was a rare foray forward, though, and the visitors were behind in first-half stoppage time as Biglia thumped home his penalty following Donnarumma's foul on Immobile.

Felipe Anderson fired narrowly wide in the 54th minute and Milan felt they should have had a penalty of their own midway through the second half when Ignazio Abate was bundled over by substitute Senad Lulic.

Montella opted not to bring top scorer Carlos Bacca off the bench but it was another substitute, Jose Sosa, who won the ball back and provided Suso with the chance to make his mark and earn Milan a point.

commentary: Arsenal move into second place as a result of the win! That's the end of our live coverage here from north London, thanks for following along. Goodbye!

An absolutely tremendous match at the Emirates ends in the most dramatic fashion, as Alexis Sanchez snatches 10-man Arsenal the points with virtually the last kick of the match, after it looked like Burnley had secured a draw with Andre Gray's 93rd minute penalty!
FULL-TIME: ARSENAL 2-1 BURNLEY.
COOL AS YOU'D LIKE! It's a dinky penalty at such a crucial moment from Sanchez, but it gets the job done! Three points for Arsenal, surely!

WOULD YOU BELIEVE IT! ARSENAL AWARDED A PENALTY! Sanchez lifts a tremendous delivery in for Koscielny at the far post, and the centre-half is caught by a high boot from Mee, prompting Moss to point to the spot! This is pure, unadulterated, unscripted drama!
Yellow card Ashley Barnes
Mustafi picks up a yellow card and Wenger is sent down the tunnel! Arsenal have completely lost their cool here! What an unbelievable turn of events in stoppage-time!

HE'S DONE IT! Gray smashes it down the middle and for just a fourth time this season, Burnley have an away goal, and it's a huge one for them, as it has them poised to avoid defeat here in north London, a rarity for them!
PENALTY TO BURNLEY! Coquelin can have few complaints as he clearly trips up Barnes, who had crept in from behind the Arsenal midfielder! What a moment this could be for the Clarets!
A chorus of discontent echoes around the Emirates as the board goes up to indicate seven minutes of time added on.
Another change here for the Gunners, their last of the match, sees Hector Bellerin come on to help see this lead out, with Ozil the one replaced.
Arsenal's second change sees Danny Welbeck replace Giroud for the final few minutes - ending the Frenchman's streak of scoring in each of his last nine starts for the Gunners, before today.

Tarkowski is presented with a shooting chance from the edge of the box, but he can't navigate his effort through the crowd of bodies. A smart pass out from the back helps Arsenal break, and Ramsey, who finds himself isolated high up the pitch, does very well to win his side a throw and relieve the pressure.
STAT: Granit Xhaka's sending off was his fifth red card in league play since the start of last season - more than any player in Europe's big five leagues.

It's wonderfully poised as we enter the final 10 minutes at the Emirates. Burnley are in the ascendency, although it's proving somewhat of a slow process, while Arsenal cling to this narrow lead, down a man.

Burnley have adopted some good urgency to their game now, getting forward in numbers as they search for an equaliser. A bit of a scramble in the area proves troubling for the Arsenal defence, with Mustafi down after taking an elbow to the face from Vokes, but the pressure is relieved as Cech is able to collect.
Burnley use the stoppage to make their final change as well, with striker Sam Vokes replacing Defour.
This appears an ominous one for Marney, who is carried off on a stretcher, with his head buried in his hands. He's replaced by James Tarkowski.

Careless and cynical from Marney who slides in to take Ozil to ground, stopping a break. He gets absolutely none of the ball, and winds up being the one to take the worst of the coming together, as he jars his knee. The training staff comes out to attend to him, with Jonathan Moss lurking over, ready to show him a yellow card.
Hendrick, who has been a spectator throughout, is replaced for the final 15 minutes or so by Joey Barton.

Marney wins his side a free-kick high up the pitch, and it's Defour who produces a strong effort from the resulting set-piece, but Cech manages to parry. Successive corners ensue for Burnley, but they come to nothing as Arsenal defend the threat accordingly.
An adjustment here from Wenger, who introduces Francis Coquelin to fill the void in midfield, with Iwobi the one replaced.

In fairness to Xhaka, the challenge looked worse live than it did on the replay. A straight red may be a bit harsh here, especially given how Moss has chose to call the game up to this point, but the Arsenal midfielder only has himself to blame. The pass was sloppy and the ensuing challenge all a bit unnecessary, as there was no immediate threat.

ARSENAL DOWN TO 10 MEN! For the second time this season, Jonathan Moss has sent off Xhaka! It's a sloppy pass from the midfielder, who lunges in with a rash challenge to try and win it straight back from Defour, and after a quick consultation with his assistant, Moss issues a straight red!
STAT: Only one of Burnley's 26 points this season has been secured away from Turf Moor. They have the worst away record in the Premier League this season (D1 L8).
Burnley need to mount a response, and they need to do so in a hurry. They've scored just three times away from home all season, so it's a bit of a daunting task they're faced with here.
Another assist on the season for Ozil, who admirably picked out the head of Mustafi with that delivery.

ARSENAL HAVE THEIR BREAKTHROUGH! For all the quality attacking players the Gunners have out on the pitch, it's Mustafi who breaks the deadlock! It's a first Arsenal goal for the centre-half, who guides a perfect header in at the far post on the end of Ozil's corner.
Lowton threw Sanchez down off the ball as Arsenal broke there, and that will earn him a clear yellow card.

Xhaka does well to win the ball high up the pitch and start Arsenal forward, before laying off for Iwobi. The winger takes matters into his own hands, producing a delicious nutmeg to help him into the area, but he can't get a shot through as Lowton blocks behind!

PENALTY APPEALS DENIED! Referee Jonathan Moss didn't look at all interested in that, which is a real surprise considering the hasty nature of that challenge from Gray, who quite clearly took the feet of Mustafi out from under him! The centre-half was running away from goal, so it was entirely unnecessary from Gray, but that really looked a clear penalty, a sentiment which is confirmed by the replay.
STAT: For the 15th time a side has faced 14+ shots in the first half of a PL game this season. Six have been Burnley (including today).

Arsenal's best moments in attack tonight have come when they've got the ball forward with urgency. Their slow, patient interplay has been incisive, but it's allowed Burnley to get bodies behind the ball, and when they do, there's just been no way through for the Gunners.

FLASHED OVER! And just barely! Very similar to his chance in the first half, Sanchez takes a nice touch to cut in on his right. This time he opts for power, not placement, but his strike lifts narrowly over the bar!

Peter Cech (17) had more passes in the first half than any Burnley player. The Clarets player who came closest? Goalkeeper Tom Heaton. Common sense would indicate if this game continues on as such, it's only a matter of time for Arsenal, but this could also be one of those days where the keeper steals the show. It's on a knife-edge.
Back underway in north London!

Goalless at the break in London, but not for a lack of trying. Burnley started in the ascendency, but it's been all Arsenal since then, as they've sent 14 shots the way of Tom Heaton, who has been by far the busier of the two keepers. Still, for all the Gunners' efforts, the teams have evenly split six shots on target through 45 minutes as we await the breakthrough.
HALF-TIME: ARSENAL 0-0 BURNLEY.

This one looked worse live than on the replay, but Cech did take the brunt of a coming together with Gray there. It looked initially like the striker's knee plowed into the face of the Arsenal keeper, but upon further review, Cech's arm blocked the brunt of the blow - a scary moment either way, but it could have been much worse.

THAT WAS MARKED FOR GOAL! Not entirely sure how Sanchez has missed here! The ball falls kindly for him following a corner. His first touch brilliantly takes him past Boyd, before using the second to open up the angle, but he curls his final attempt agonisingly wide of the far post! It wasn't an easy chance by any means, but you just expected the back of the net to ripple when he let that go.

Sanchez uses the run of Giroud to his left to open up space for a shot, but he can't get the required power behind his effort as Heaton is able to dive across to his near post to make the save. It's not a bad idea, though, from the Chilean. With the sort of form Heaton is in, you can't afford to pass up a shooting chance.
STAT: Arsenal have won six of their last seven meetings with Burnley in all competitions (D1), since a 0-2 loss in the League Cup in December 2008.

Ozil cleverly brings the ball down in the area and pokes it by the last defender to run through on goal, but Heaton reads it the whole way as he flies off his line to intervene, before collecting his own punch just ahead of Sanchez's arrival!

The match is being played almost entirely in the Burnley half, but Arsenal need a bit more impetus in their approach play. They've switched to more of a patient build, which is allowing Burnley to keep organised and avoid having to really scramble at the back.

Giroud is worse for wear following a hard challenge from Mee. That was an incredibly physical slide from the centre-half, but also a perfectly fair one. The Burnley fans certainly appreciated that, and Giroud is able to get up under his own power and walk it off, so no harm, no foul.

AWAY BY MEE! Important, no-nonsense clearance there from the centre-half, following a patient but inquisitive build from Arsenal in attack. The pressure stays on following a corner and Ramsey boastfully plays in a rabona cross that just fails to reach Giroud.
STAT: Only Raheem Sterling (156) has had more touches in the opposition box this season than Alexis Sanchez (155). Burnley's top player in this regard is Sam Vokes (57).

OFFSIDE! Ozil is flagged as he just narrowly mistimed his run, but that should take absolutely nothing away from the quality of that delivery by Sanchez, who placed a peach of a ball over the top, dropping it right at the feet of the German playmaker, who never had to break stride.

Referee Jonathan Moss is forced to bring the game to a temporary halt, after Xhaka takes exception to a foul from Defour. The two go face-to-face, before Barnes comes in to his team-mate's defence, before directing his attention to the referee, after being denied a free-kick he feels he deserved a few short moments ago.

That has to be better from Ozil! Good interplay in and around the penalty area from Arsenal, leads to a Gabriel cross from the right. The initial delivery is cleared, but only as far as Ozil, who has a clear lane for a shot, but scuffs his first-time effort wide of the far post.

Gray is smothered and dispossessed before Arsenal break the other way, with Monreal sprung into space. He pulls back a decent ball for Giroud, but the striker gets under it, slicing an effort miles over the bar from 15 yard.s

STAT: Burnley have had 13 different goalscorers this season, a joint-league high with Manchester City, yet only three of those players have scored away goals (Ben Mee, Ashley Barnes and Sam Vokes all have one away goal each).

Real end-to-end stuff here at the Emirates! Barnes does well to make himself available up top, and plucks the ball out of his feet appropriately before testing Cech with a long-range strike, which is parried behind for a corner.

LOVELY STOP! Impressive reactions from Heaton to dive across and parry Ozil's searching effort from the edge of the area, and he had to react late there with the threat of Giroud getting a touch on the way through. Pressure stays on and Iwobi misses the far post by inches, before Koscielny sends a header straight at Heaton.

SAFE HANDS! Good response, that, from Burnley! They certainly aren't lacking confidence when they get in possession. Lowton drives forward on the break and drills in a low, diagonal cross towards the near post which Barnes attacks, but Cech is off his line to collect in the nick of time!

Possession residing solely with the hosts over the last five minutes, as the Gunners continue to grow in stature. There's a good width about them in attack, with Iwobi and Sanchez combining well with the two full-backs, though they have yet to test Heaton.
STAT: Olivier Giroud has scored in each of his last four Premier League games for the Gunners, his best run since April 2015 (six matches).

NEARLY THERE! After a rather innocent spell in possession, Arsenal carry the ball up the pitch with real purpose. Sanchez is sprung down the left and lifts in an invitingly flat delivery, which Giroud flicks on towards the far post. Ward arrives to acrobatically head clear, however, otherwise it would have fallen perfectly for Iwobi at the far post!

Arsenal have spent much of these opening five minutes pinned back in their end here. It's been an altogether lethargic start from the Gunners, who need to get their footing under them sooner than later, or Chelsea's perfect weekend will continue.

Well contrary to expectation, it's Burnley who start in the ascendency. They win a pair of free-kicks, both of which are lofted in the general direction of the light-blue shirts crowding the Arsenal penalty area, but the hosts are able to snuff out the threat on each occasion.
AND THEY'RE OFF! Burnley get us underway, attacking right to left, on this beautifully sunny Sunday afternoon in London.

Sean Dyche has named an unchanged side to the one which he trotted out in the 1-0 victory over Southampton last weekend, after rotating much of his squad in their midweek FA Cup success over Sunderland.

So, Giroud starts in attack for an unchanged Arsenal team, the France striker looking to net for a sixth straight game. Bellerin, Coquelin and Welbeck are all among the substitutes. Burnley start with Gray and Barnes in attack. Barton is on the bench despite scoring the winner against Southampton last weekend.
BURNLEY TEAM (4-4-2): Heaton, Lowton, Keane, Mee, Ward; Boyd, Marney, Hendrick, Defour; Gray, Barnes.
ARSENAL TEAM (4-2-3-1): Cech, Gabriel, Mustafi, Koscielny, Monreal; Xhaka, Ramsey; Iwobi, Ozil, Sanchez; Giroud.

STATS: Burnley have lost their last five visits to Arsenal in all competitions, since a 1-0 league win in September 1974, while Gunners forward Alexis Sanchez has scored three and assisted another in his two appearances in this fixture.
Burnley, meanwhile, sit 12th, but could rise as high as ninth if they can pull off an upset at Emirates Stadium.
Manchester City's draw with Tottenham and Liverpool's defeat to Swansea City have opened the door to Arsenal. They could move up to second with victory today.
Hello and welcome to our Live Text Commentary of the Premier League clash between Arsenal and Burnley at Emirates Stadium.
news: Arsenal moved up to second in the Premier League after downing Burnley 2-1 in a thrilling match on Sunday, despite being reduced to ten men.
The Gunners took the lead through Shkodran Mustafi's header in the second half, before Granit Xhaka received his marching orders for a two-footed lunge on Steven Defour.
And Arsenal's title hopes were on course to suffer a huge blow when Andre Gray scored a penalty after Francis Coquelin fouled Ashley Barnes inside the box.
However, Ben Mee soon gave away a penalty for a foul on Laurent Koscielny and Alexis Sanchez saved the day by beating Tom Heaton.

Arsenal, now five points behind leaders Chelsea - who face Hull City later on Sunday - have an FA Cup tie away to Southampton and league game against Watford to come before a crunch meeting with the Blues at Stamford Bridge on February 4.

Burnley, meanwhile, stay 13th, having gone unrewarded yet again for a determined showing, as home form continues to be the most likely method of securing top-flight status for last season's Championship winners.

The Clarets fans who made the journey to the capital could be forgiven for not recognising their team in the first half. Burnley had lost eight of their nine previous league matches on the road this season, but they were unexpectedly defiant during the opening 45 minutes in London.

A 0-0 draw at Manchester United in October was the only prior occasion Burnley had returned from an away game with anything to show for their efforts and perhaps another heavyweight engagement inspired Sean Dyche's men to raise their level. Goalkeeper Tom Heaton proved equal to the task when called upon to make saves from Mesut Ozil, Koscielny and Sanchez.

Given Burnley's struggles outside the home comforts of Turf Moor, that goal initially appeared potentially fatal to the visitors' chances, until Xhaka earned a straight red card for a lunging, studs-up challenge on Defour.
The away team had toiled without reward as they attempted to trouble Cech, a cause not helped by the worrying sight of Marney being stretchered off with 15 minutes to go.

commentary: That's all from us here today, thanks for joining us and we hope you'll be able to join us again soon.

It’s all over here at the bet365 Stadium and Stoke secure all three points after a first-half brace from Marko Arnautovic. Middlesbrough did have a goal ruled out for offside midway through the second half but rarely threatened Lee Grant’s goal otherwise, and had to rely on Victor Valdes to keep the score at 2-0 on several occasions.
Full-time: Stoke City 2-0 Middlesbrough

Wonderful save from Valdes!!! Ramadan once again involved as he plays Afellay clean through on goal, but Valdes reads the midfielder’s poked effort really well and gets down to his left to keep the score at 2-0.

Huge appeals for a Stoke penalty as Ramadan goes on an outstanding run before pulling the ball back towards Allen who flicks the ball towards goal from five yards out, only for it to be blocked by a sliding Gibson, with Stoke players feeling he used his arm to do so.
There’s going to be five minutes of added time to be played.
Middlesbrough are awarded a free-kick 40 yards out from goal which Guedioura takes, but the delivery isn’t great and Stoke are comfortably able to head the ball clear.
Martins Indi isn’t going to be able to continue and Ibrahim Afellay comes on in his place, meaning Cameron will drop back into the centre of defence alongside Shawcross.
Martins Indi has gone with a nasty looking knee injury sustained as he stretched to clear the ball. He looks in some discomfort here and may well have to leave the field.

Super save from Valdes!! Cameron picks out Ramadan who is unmarked at the back post, and his downwards header looks to be heading for the bottom corner but Valdes gets down really well to his left to keep it out.
Stuani and Gestede combine well to lay the ball off for Guedioura on the edge of the Stoke penalty box, but the substitute’s curling effort goes well over the bar and into the crowd.
Middlesbrough look to break forward through Traore down the right, but once again the final ball into the middle is a poor one and Diouf is able to bring the ball away for Stoke on the far side.
Another change for Stoke now as Crouch, who took a nasty blow to the leg just moments ago, is replaced by Saido Berahino.
De Roon has been shown a yellow card for dissent towards the referee.
That change doesn’t appear to have gone down too well with Alvaro Negredo on the bench, who is sat shaking his head knowing he won’t be coming on now.
Aitor Karanka is making his final change now as Leadbitter is replaced by Adlène Guédioura in midfield.

Stoke have regained control of this game again and Allen has a half-chance to make it 3-0 as Diouf fires a low cross in to towards him from the right, but the Welshman fails to make a clan connection with his shot from 12 yards out and Middlesbrough survive once again.

Traore concedes a needless foul on Pieters close to the left-hand corner flag in the Middlesbrough half and Stoke will have another chance to put the ball into the middle. That was a challenge born out of frustration from Traore as the Stoke left-back was going nowhere, but fortunately for Traore the free-kick comes to nothing.
Middlesbrough have certainly improved in the last quarter of an hour, and are getting more runners up in support of Gestede, but they’re still struggling to create any real threat on Grant’s goal.

Stuani appears to be bundled to the floor by Diouf as he makes a driving run down the left-hand side but instead referee Pawson penalises the winger for handball as he falls to ground. That looked harsh but he’s certainly looked lively since coming on has Stuani.

Gestede flicks the ball into the Stoke penalty box with a header and Leadbitter gets on the end of it but is denied by Grant, who came off his line quickly to smother the effort and has taken a blow in the process. It looks as though he's going to be fine to continue though.
Stoke are going to be forced into making their first change now as Arnautovic leaves the field with a knock. Mame Biram Diouf is the man who comes on to replace him.

Arnautovic skips away from Friend and chips the ball to Ramadan at the far post but the ball won’t sit down for the Egyptian and the Middlesbrough defence are able to get back and clear the ball. Cameron then regains possession for Stoke and picks out Crouch who is denied by Valdes from close range, but the flag is up anyway so the goal wouldn’t have counted.
Stuani goes from goal from 25 yards out but doesn’t get enough bend on the ball and it goes well wide of Grant’s goal. The last five minutes have been much better from the visitors though.

Disallowed goal!! Leadbitter swings in a free-kick from the right after a foul on Traore the right-hand side, but the flag goes up for offside as Gibson slides the ball into the back of the net from close range!

Allen plays a lovely one-two with Arnautovic on the edge of the box before winning his side a corner on the left hand side. Gestede heads the corner clear at the near post but that was a nice bit of play from the two Stoke midfielders, who are getting beyond Crouch really well at the moment.

A half-chance for Martins Indi as he gets up well to meet Whelan’s corner seven yards out from goal, but he fails to get a good connection on the header and it slides across the face of goal and out of play.

Middlesbrough win a free-kick in a good position in the middle of the field, but Leadbitter takes it short to Traore on the right, and Ramadan then tackles the winger extremely well as he looks to get down the outside of him.
Gestede does well to hold the ball up just inside his own half and draws the foul from Pieters. The fact that he’s had to drop so deep to get the ball will be a concern for Middlesbrough though.

It looks as though Stuani has gone out to that left-hand side in a straight swap for Ramirez, but Aitor Karanka will certainly be looking for him to get into the box to support Gestede, particularly if Middlesbrough can free up Traore down the right-hand side.

Friend, who endured a difficult first half, has space to cross from the left but wastes the opportunity by hitting it straight out for a goal kick. You feel if Middlesbrough are going to get back into this game they’re going to need to get better service into Gestede.

Arnautovic has acres of space on the right to whip in a cross towards Crouch, but Bernardo intercepts in at the near post and diverts the ball out for a corner. Whelan then finds Crouch from the corner but the striker is going away from goal and his header is a weak one, making it easy for Valdes to gather in.
Kick-off! Cameron gets the second half underway for Stoke.
Middlesbrough are making one change at the break, with Cristhian Stuani coming on in place of Ramirez, who was pretty ineffectual in the first half.

Aitor Karanka may well turn to Alvaro Negredo on his bench early on in the second half, with Gestede looking extremely isolated as the lone striker for Middlesbrough. Mark Hughes meanwhile will be asking for more of the same from his Stoke side, who have looked solid at the back for the majority of the half.

Stoke lead at the bet365 Stadium thanks to two Arnautovic goals, the first of which was wonderfully taken after being picked out by Whelan. Middlesbrough did lose Ayala early on to injury, but have looked disorganised at the back at times and have barely threatened the Stoke goal, with Leadbitter’s deflected long-range effort as close as they have come.
Half-time: Stoke City 2-0 Middlesbrough
Johnson nutmegs Friend before being pulled back by the left-back, who is subsequently shown a yellow card by referee Pawson.
We’re into two minutes of added time at the bet365 Stadium.

It’s been a good response from Middlesbrough with their travelling fans chanting for their side to attack, but the final ball from Traore is easily cleared by Martins Indi, with only Gestede in the middle to aim for.
Crouch did the sensible thing there by simply heading the ball into a dangerous area.

GOOOAAALLLLLLL!!! Arnautovic doubles Stoke’s lead! Whelan swings in a corner from the right after Allen’s cross had been well blocked by Friend, and Crouch rises highest at the far post to head the ball into the middle of the six yard box, where the Austrian winger is waiting to flick the ball past Valdes and into the back of the net.

Close!! The closest Middlesbrough have come so far as Leadbitter’s 30-yard effort deflects narrowly wide of the goal with Grant scrambling frantically across his goal. Leadbitter then heads over to take the corner himself and picks out Ramirez on the edge of the box, but his first-time volley goes high over Grant’s goal.

Leadbitter gives the ball away cheaply to Crouch just inside the Stoke half but the striker can’t pick out Allen who’d made a good run into space through the middle. The quality of this game hasn’t really improved since the goal in truth.

Leadbitter lifts a free-kick into the Stoke penalty area after a foul on Gestede 35 yards out from goal. Bernardo gets up well and flicks a header towards goal, but he has very little pace to work with and Lee Grant can easily catch the ball without having to move.

Fabio plays the ball down the touchline towards Gestede, but Bruno Martins Indi is too strong for the Middlesbrough striker there and Stoke easily get possession back once more. Gestede is looking pretty isolated up front for Middlesbrough though.
Neither side have played particularly well so far today, but Stoke have been the better of the two sides and arguably deserve the lead on the balance of play.
The long ball forward from Whelan from close to the halfway line was a superb one, but Arnautovic still had a lot to do to finish but he certainly did it well.

GOOOOAAAALLLLLL!!! Arnautovic gives Stoke the lead!! Whelan plays a long ball forward into the Middlesbrough penalty box, and Arnautovic shows a wonderful bit of skill to flick the ball past Friend with a superb first touch, before taking the ball around Valdes and slotting the ball high into the net, avoiding the recovering defenders on the line.
The away fans are certainly the more vocal of the two sets of supporter here, but their side are struggling to make any real impact on the game at the moment.

Fabio plays a long ball forward and Marten de Roon appears to be clean through on the edge of the penalty area, but he can’t control the ball as it drops over his shoulder and Stoke are able to regain possession.

Erik Pieters gets in behind the Middlesbrough defence on the left-hand edge of the penalty area and has lots of time to try and pick out Crouch in the middle, but the left-back rushes his cross and slices it straight out for a goal kick. Middlesbrough will be concerned with how easily he got in behind there though.
Shawcross becomes the first player to be shown a yellow card by referee Craig Pawson for bringing down Traore inside the Stoke half.

Friend heads the free-kick clear before Middlesbrough give the ball away cheaply and Allen appears to have space to shoot 25 yards out from goal, but trips over just as he’s about to pull the trigger. Ryan Shawcross then wins the ball back again for Stoke but wastes a golden three-on-two opportunity by rolling the ball too close to Valdes with Crouch and Arnautovic waiting.
Stoke win another free-kick as Traore is penalised for leaning into Johnson on the right-hand side, and Whelan will have another chance to get the ball into the middle.

Stoke are starting control this game now with Ramadan getting on the ball and linking up well with Arnautovic once again, but having spread the ball wide to Geoff Cameron on the right, the danger passes as the midfielder crosses straight into the arms of Valdes.

OFF THE BAR!!! Stoke work the ball really nicely across the top of the box before Allen picks out Arnautovic on the right-hand side of the area, and the winger finds Ramadan at the back post with a fierce low cross but the Egyptian can only turn the ball against the crossbar from six yards out.

Ramadan Sobhi shows off some clever footwork to play the ball into Allen who has space close to the halfway line, but his ball forward towards Arnautovic has far too much pace on it and goes straight out for a goal-kick.
Victor Valdes slices a back-pass from Friend straight into touch, rather epitomising the scrappy nature of the game so far with neither side really getting going as yet.

Middlesbrough are being forced into an early change here as Daniel Ayala has to leave the field with an injury. Bernardo Espinosa comes on in his place but that’s a big blow for Aitor Karanka so early in the game.

Gestede plays a lovely back heel into Gaston Ramirez on the right-hand edge of the Stoke penalty box, but his control lets him down as he looks to cut inside onto his favoured left foot and Stoke are easily able to clear the danger.

Adama Traore does well to track back and steal possession away from Glen Johnson inside the Middlesbrough half before Rudy Gestede looks to be clean through on goal after a long ball over the top, but the linesman’s flag goes up against the striker.

Marko Arnautovic gets down the outside of George Friend on the right-hand side and the Middlesbrough left-back pulls the Austrian back, handing Stoke a free-kick in a dangerous area on the right-hand side of the box. Glenn Whelan swings in the free-kick but Friend makes up for the foul by heading it clear at the near post.
Kick-off! Middlesbrough get the game underway.
The players are heading out onto the pitch, kick-off is not far away now!

The two sides shared the points when they met at the Riverside Stadium on the opening day of the season, with Xherdan Shaqiri’s wonderful free-kick securing a 1-1 draw after Alvaro Negredo had opened the scoring for Middlesbrough.

Middlesbrough meanwhile make five changes from the defeat at Palace, with George Friend, Adam Clayton, Grant Leadbitter, Adama Traore and Rudy Gestede all coming into the side. Bernardo Espinosa, Stewart Downing, Adam Forshaw, Alvaro Negredo and Cristhian Stuani are the men who drop out.
Mark Hughes makes just two changes to his Stoke side that was beaten at Spurs, with Glen Johnson replacing Phil Bardsley at right-back and Geoff Cameron coming in for Charlie Adam in midfield.
Subs: Guzan, Barragan, Bernardo, Guedioura, Forshaw, Stuani, Negredo
Middlesbrough (4-3-2-1): Valdes; Fabio, Ayala, Gibson, Friend; de Roon, Clayton, Leadbitter; Traore, Ramirez; Gestede
Subs: Given, Bardsley, Berahino, Afellay, Adam, Diouf, Walters
Team news: Stoke City (4-2-3-1) Grant; Johnson, Shawcross, Martins Indi, Pieters; Whelan, Cameron; Arnautovic, Allen, Ramadan; Crouch

Last weekend’s 1-0 defeat to Palace left them without a Premier League win since before Christmas, and their lack of goals will be a huge concern to manager Aitor Karanka, with his side having scored just 19 times in their 26 games this season.
Middlesbrough in contrast are currently 17th in the table, and are only outside of the relegation zone due to their superior goal difference over Crystal Palace.
They do though sit 10th in the Premier League table, and will be looking to extend their impressive recent home record, having not lost a league game at the bet365 Stadium since November.
Stoke have won just once in their last five Premier League games, and were beaten 4-0 by Tottenham Hotspur in their last game, conceding all four goals in the first half.
Hello and welcome to live coverage of the Premier League match between Stoke City and Middlesbrough at the bet365 Stadium.
news: Marko Arnautovic netted his first home Premier League goals since April 2016 as a first-half double helped Stoke City return to winning ways by despatching struggling Middlesbrough 2-0.

Austria forward Arnautovic had not scored in front of his own fans in the top flight in 11 months prior to Saturday's clash at the bet365 Stadium, but he provided the rare moments of quality in what was a scrappy encounter.

Having already set up a gilt-edged chance for Ramadan Sobhi, Arnautovic took matters into his own hands after 29 minutes with a sublime turn and finish, before bundling home his second prior to the interval.

Arnautovic's afternoon came to a premature end through injury midway through the second half, though it mattered little as Aitor Karanka's visiting side failed to find a way back into the contest, with Ben Gibson seeing a strike ruled out for offside.

The victory sees Stoke extend their unbeaten run at home to eight league matches, while Middlesbrough drop into the relegation zone, with fellow strugglers Crystal Palace and Leicester City both claiming vital points elsewhere.
Middlesbrough were handed a blow early on in a physical contest, Daniel Ayala hobbling off with an apparent hamstring injury just six minutes in.
That change seemed to unsettle the Middlesbrough defence and Stoke should have taken advantage 14 minutes in.
Joe Allen and Arnautovic combined brilliantly to tee-up Sobhi, but the youngster could only rattle the woodwork from point-blank range.
Middlesbrough were exposed again soon after, Victor Valdes reacting instinctively to deny Peter Crouch following sloppy play from Grant Leadbitter.

But the away team's luck ran out just prior to the half-hour mark, Arnautovic getting the better of both George Friend and Valdes with a series of exquisite touches before thumping home from a tight angle.

And he wasted little time in adding to his tally, with slack Middlesbrough defending allowing the Austrian to smuggle in Stoke's second three minutes before half-time, moments after Leadbitter had gone close at the other end.
Arnautovic should have turned provider following the restart, but after engineering space with another neat turn, he failed to pick out Sobhi with a disappointing cross.
Gibson thought he had ended Middlesbrough's three-game goal drought in the league when he slotted home on the hour mark, but it was swiftly disallowed.

While Middlesbrough rallied somewhat - Gaston Ramirez trying his luck from range with a stinging strike - Stoke were forced into a change, Mark Hughes taking no risks with Arnautovic after the winger picked up a knock.
Despite Middlesbrough's tame attack, Karanka chose not to introduce Alvaro Negredo from the bench as the game wore on, and the visitors created little going forward.

Indeed, it was Stoke who almost added gloss to the victory late on, Valdes on top form to deny both Sobhi and Ibrahim Afellay as Middlesbrough slumped to a 13th successive away league game without a win.

commentary: FULL-TIME: WATFORD 0-0 MIDDLESBROUGH

Middlesbrough a launch a lofted pass up to Gestede on the edge of the Watford penalty area, but the striker is unable to reach the ball and loses out to Kaboul, who then fires it up the right flank and in search of a yellow shirt.
And deny also receives a late yellow card for his part in the post-challenge fracas.
After trudging halfway down the pitch, Fabio is also booked after receiving a stern talking to from the referee.

It's all kicking off! Britos flies into Fabio and catches the Brazilian with a dangerous sliding challenge, resulting in an angry reaction from the Middlesbrough man. After a bit of pushing and shoving, the Uruguayan is eventually shown a yellow card.

Kabasele goes close! A swinging cross from Kaboul flies into the Middlesbrough penalty area and finds Kabasele in a great position in front of goal, but the Belgian is unable to beat Valdes, who denies him with a diving save to his right.
The fourth official has indicated that there will be four minutes of added time.
Watford have made a late change, with Holebas making way for Juan Zuniga.

And now Prodl goes close! The resulting corner is curled into the middle of the penalty area and finds Prodl in a wonderful position in front of goal, but the defender is unable to make decent contact with the ball and Valdes is just about able to collect it.

Fantastic opportunity for Deeney! The captain breaks through the disjointed Middlesbrough defence before going one-on-one with Valdes, but the goalkeeper quickly closed down the striker and saves a poked shot with an outstretched leg.

Fabio gets himself into a great position thanks to poor Holebas defending and whips a wonderful cross into the Watford penalty area, but just as it's about to reach Negredo, Prodl rises high and nods the ball away from the Spaniard at the vital moment.

Once again, Friend breaks down the left wing on a rare run forward as he tries to get Middlesbrough into the game, but he easily loses out to Kabasele on the edge of the hosts' penalty area. It's all Watford at the moment as they continue to boss the contest.

Cleverley hits the post! A low cross is fired into the heart of the Middlesbrough penalty area and finds Cleverley, who spins quickly and shoots only to see his effort bounce off the far post. It rolls out to Capoue, who immediately fires a follow-up shot towards goal, but his strike flies just a yard or so wide of its intended target. Watford are getting closer...

Gestede, who hasn't been presented with many chances since coming on, does well to wriggle away from three Watford players before shooting from 25 yards out, but his curling effort ends up clearing the top of the crossbar after beating Pantilimon.

Yellow card Stefano Okaka Big call by the referee! Okaka breaks into the right-hand side of the Middlesbrough penalty area and battles with George before going down under a challenge from the defender. The Watford players and fans all immediately scream for a penalty, but the referee isn't at all happy with the behaviour of the Italian and instead books him for going down too easily. Controversial!
Tom Cleverley receives a rousing round of applause from the Watford fans as he makes his way on to the pitch to replace Behrami and make his first appearance for the club.

Friend bursts down the left wing as he tries to latch on to a lofted pass forward, but he's unable to get the better of Kaboul and loses out to the defender. Watford have certainly been the better of the two sides today, but they just can't seem to break down Middlesbrough's back line.

What a chance for Doucoure! Once again, Kabasele causes all sorts of problems over on the right wing before sending a great cross right on to the head of Doucoure, but the Frenchman is unable to find the back of the net and instead sends his headed effort agonisingly wide of the near post.

Kaboul sends Forshaw flying to the ground with a poor challenge, resulting in a free-kick for Middlesbrough over on the left wing. A looping cross is fired in to Leadbitter and over towards Gestede, but it's poorly hit by the midfielder and sails straight into the hands of Pantilimon.

A poor clearance from Valdes can only find Capoue, who bursts forward before being bundled over by a poor challenge from De Roon, resulting in yet another free-kick for Watford in a promising position. Capoue's cross finds Prodl, who then nods the ball over to Deeney, but the captain is unable to reach it and Middlesbrough are just about able to hold on.

Kabasele gets himself into a good position deep down the right flank before winning Watford a corner. It's taken short before Holebas tries to pick out Kaboul with a cross over to the far post, but the Greek defender's pass is poor and sails past the outstretched foot of the Frenchman.
Gomes still seems to be struggling after clashing with Negredo, and he's eventually forced off to be replaced by Costel Pantilimon.
Middlesbrough have made their first substitution of the game, with Stuani making way for Rudy Gestede, who comes on to make his first appearance for his new club.

Capoue goes close! Watford come back once again through Kabasele, who flies down the right flank on a marauding run. His cross finds Deeney and is nodded back to Capoue, who takes a quick touch on the edge of the box before curling a lovely shot just an inch or two wide of the far post.

The ball pinballs around the Middlesbrough penalty area after another dangerous cross is flung into the box. The visitors are initially able to deal with the danger before Kaboul bursts towards the byline before trying to set up Kabasele, but the Belgian loses out at the last moment and is unable to get a shot away from close range.

Behrami battles his way down the right wing, but he's unable to beat Friend and has to settle for a throw-in. It's sent short to Kaboul, who then tries to skip past Negredo, but the defender's first touch is poor and he then gives away a free-kick with a clumsy push.

Chance for Leadbitter! Stuani twists and turns over on the left-hand side of the Watford penalty area before beating Kabasele with a thumping low cross, but Leadbitter's first-time volley fails to hit the target and sails comfortably wide of the goal.

After a few minutes receiving treatment from the Watford medical staff, Gomes is finally able to get back to his feet and the game gets underway once again. It's Prodl who takes the goal-kick though, as the Brazilian goalkeeper still seems to be in some discomfort.

Gomes seemed to receive a blow to the back whilst punching the ball away from danger, and it's left him in a heap on the floor and in serious discomfort. He's still on the ground and it remains to be seen whether he'll be able to continue.

Forshaw and Fabio link up well over on the right flank before the wing-back curls a brilliant cross into the middle of the penalty area, but just as it looks as if it's going to find the head of Negredo, Gomes rushes out to punch the ball away from the striker.

Another dangerous ball is flung into the Middlesbrough penalty area before falling at the feet of Deeney. The captain takes a quick touch before spinning and trying to test Valdes, but De Roon rushes forward before throwing his body in the way of the strike.

Negredo, who has been presented with very few chances in front of goal, breaks into the right-hand side of the penalty area before spinning and finding Fabio. The Brazilian is in a pocket of space on the edge of the penalty area and immediately shoots, but his thumping strike is parried away by Gomes.

And now Okaka goes close! Ben Gibson and Okaka battle for the ball over on the right wing, and it's the latter who comes out on top before being dragged to the ground by the defender. The resulting free-kick is swung into the penalty area and finds Okaka, but the Italian's downward header is well saved by Valdes.

What an opportunity for Kabasele! A curling cross from Holebas takes Friend by surprise and bounces past the defender before falling to Kabasele, who is all alone at the far post, but the Belgian also isn't expecting the ball to reach him and is unable to move his body quick enough to hit the target with his header.
And we're underway once again!
The two teams are making their way back out on to the pitch ahead of the start of the second half. Neither side have made any substitutions during the half-time break.

It's been a somewhat underwhelming opening 45 minutes, with both sides looking slightly tentative in their attacking play. For Watford, Okaka and Deeney have linked up well on a few occasions, but both have so far failed to receive the service needed if they're to break down the Middlesbrough defence. As for Middlesbrough, they scored through Stuani only to have the goal correctly ruled out for offside, and since then they've failed to create too many chances, resulting in them spending the majority of the first half on the back foot.
HALF-TIME: WATFORD 0-0 MIDDLESBROUGH

Middlesbrough are presented with one final opportunity to fire the ball into the Watford penalty area after winning a free-kick just inside the hosts' half of the pitch, but Leadbitter's cross fails to find a blue shirt and is instead headed away from danger by Kaboul.
The fourth official has indicated that there will be just one minute of added time.

Okaka shows great strength once again before teeing up Kabasele over on the right flank, but the latter slightly rushes his first-time cross and is unable to pick out Deeney in front of goal.
