Ajax's lengthy unbeaten run in the contest is under threat once again, but that goal has come entirely against the run of play, it must be said. They need to continue attacking they way they were and avoid opening up unnecessarily - 2-1 away is not a bad result for them.
Good delivery at the end of an inquisitive run from Ankersen.

COPENHAGEN BACK IN FRONT! They've been coming under all sorts of pressure, but all it takes is one chance at the other end for them to restore their lead! Ankersen picks out a towering cross and Jorgensen rises higher than De Ligt to bundle home a thumping header!

FINALLY ON TARGET! Van de Beek has had a number of shooting chances tonight, but has yet to test Olsen... until now. This one was perhaps the hardest chance of all from a tight angle, but he works the keeper, who fumbles the strike behind for a corner.

Copenhagen possession breaks down just inside the Ajax half and Dolberg breaks with pace and determination, before being tripped up rather cynically from behind by Johansson. The free-kick is awarded without hesitation, but the centre-half escapes without a booking.
STAT: Ajax have never lost a European match in Denmark (W1, D2) and Copenhagen have never beaten Dutch opposition at the Parken (D2, L1).

JORGENSEN TO THE RESCUE! Copenhagen carved apart like a hot knife through butter by Traore. He shows great strength and vision to get into the final third and play in Van de Beek, but Jorgensen sprints across and deflects his effort behind from point-blank range!

He got that all wrong! Schone has been one of Ajax's most reliable scorers in Europe over the last few years, and you know he wants to find the back of the net tonight in the city he was born in. He gets a decent look from 25 yards out, but slices an effort miles wide of the far post with his weaker left foot.

Copenhagen are struggling to relieve the pressure on their goal as Ajax ramp up the intensity early in this second half. They're looking a threat as they get forward in numbers, particularly down the left flank through the wonderfully adventurous Younes.
Back underway in Copenhagen!

Rasmus Falk gave Copenhagen the lead inside of 30 minutes at the Parken, but Kasper Dolberg, upon returning to his national stadium, restored parity for Ajax just beyond the half-hour mark. That's where we stand as the teams head into the tunnel with an important 45 minutes ahead in the Danish capital.
HALF-TIME: COPENHAGEN 1-1 AJAX.

ANOTHER STUNNING RUN! Younes is taking the game over here! Remarkable skill on the ball from the winger, who this time beats three Copenhagen defenders, but again he unselfishly squares for Van de Beek instead of having a go himself, and the midfielder can't pick out the bottom corner.

VITAL BLOCK! That's a delightful run from Younes, who dazzles his way beyond a pair of defenders on the edge of the box before squaring for Van de Beek, but the midfielder takes a touch before shooting, which allows Ankersen to dive across and get a crucial block in!
IT'S IN! But it won't count... The ball is lifted into the area and falls for Falk, who produces another exceptional first-time finish, but the offside flag is raised, mush to Ajax's relief.
The tempo has fizzled out a fair bit as we approach half-time. Neither side want to be the one to concede the all-important second goal, and as a result it's plagued the tempo a bit here.

STAT: Ajax are the only unbeaten team remaining in the Europa League proper this season (W5, D3). They have gone 11 successive Europa League games without defeat, four shy of Atletico Madrid’s record.

Ajax in complete control since scoring, dominating possession and dictating the tempo. They needed that goal like a dog needs a bone, and they got it. That will go a way to boost their confidence, not to mention their odds of progressing through to the quarter-finals.

The Parken has been stunned into silence. They aren't used to seeing their side concede here. Copenhagen have kept seven clean sheets from seven in Europe this season, but their run ends here, and it's one of their hometown boys who's done it in the form of Dolberg! Now it's the away fans who have been sent into rapture.
Klaassen picked him out brilliantly there as the skipper provides the assist.

DOLBERG RESTORES PARITY! That will mean the world to him! Left out of Denmark's international squad, Dolberg returns to his native country and scores the first goal at this venue by an opposing team this season in Europe! He gets in front of Ankersen in the area to latch onto Klaassen's cross and guides a lovely finish in at the far post!

NOT FAR AWAY! Good overlapping run from Tete, who picks out Sinkgraven with his cross, but the left-back sees his shot blocked again. The rebound falls for Klaassen, but he can't find the target either, missing at the far post.

HE'S MISSED IT! Ajax continue to play with fire at the back, this time Viergever giving the ball away carelessly - the third one of this first half. It comes straight to Santander, who drives forward and strikes for goal, but can't slot in at the far post, with Cornelius upset he didn't get played through.
Back the other way come Ajax, winning a corner. Again they play it short, as they have with each one previous. It's smartly worked over to Sinkgraven atop the box, but his effort is blocked!

SHOULD BE TWO! Kvist's throw causes all sorts of panic in the Ajax penalty area and it falls to an unmarked Toutouh at the far post, but somehow he fails to strike it cleanly, sending it wide! He had half the goal gaping!
STAT: Copenhagen have kept 13 successive clean sheets at the Parken, last conceding in a 1-1 draw with Aalborg.

That's a nasty challenge from Copenhagen centre-half Jorgensen, who slides into the back of Dolberg to cease his run. The yellow is unavoidably produced, meaning the skipper will be suspended for the return leg in Amsterdam.

Copenhagen have weathered the storm following a spirited response from Ajax to try and restore parity. They win a free-kick in an advanced position, but the delivery has far too much height on it, allowing Ajax to defend it with ease.
SMART STOP! Another giveaway at the back, this one incredibly careless from Traore, gifts ex-Eredivisie player Matic a shooting chance, but he's thwarted at the near post by Onana.

Ceaseless possession and pressure from Ajax, who are really taking the game to the hosts here. The atmosphere is absolutely incredible, though, and that's no doubt sparking Copenhagen's energy levels. It's deafening inside the Parken.

Successive corners for Ajax help them keep the pressure on, and it results in their first chance of the night. The ball bounces into the path of Viergever in the area following a clever touch from Traore, but the centre-half's volley is struck right at Olsen. Moments later, another Ajax attack sees them win a third corner without reply.

STAT: This is the fifth meeting between the two sides in European competition. Copenhagen hold the edge, winning twice, drawing once and losing once, but they have yet to win at home to Ajax (D1, L1), with both victories coming in Amsterdam.

STRAIGHT AT ONANA! A nice opening there for Copenhagen, and there should be plenty more of those as Ajax are forced to open up a bit. The break falls for Cornelius, but he can't get any real power behind his strike as it makes for a comfortable save for Onana in the end.

In all fairness for Ajax, they have responded well to falling behind, commanding plenty of the ball in these early stages. Peter Bosz is understandably anxious on his touchline, however, shouting instructions as his side try to get after this stingy backline.

Ajax enjoying plenty of possession here, but it's all contemplative at best as they struggle to break into the final third. This is a defensively stout Copenhagen side, who will look more like a brick wall at the back for Ajax as they search for that away goal.

This stadium is already hard enough to play in, but that early goal has resulted in an absolutely electrifying atmosphere! It could not have been a worse start for Ajax, who have their work cut out for them now against a Copenhagen side who have not conceded at this venue in over six months.

DREAM START FOR THE HOSTS! It took all of 27 seconds for Copenhagen to take the lead, and Ajax are left stunned! A giveaway at the back from Van de Beek gifts the hosts possession and Kvist lifts a clever ball over the top for Falk, who finishes expertly with a thunderbolt past Onana and in at the far post!
Delicate and accurate chip over the top from Kvist who picks up the assist.
AND THEY'RE OFF! Copenhagen in all white as they get us underway, attacking left to right, with Ajax in black.

Peter Bosz has to cope without his two most relied upon defenders, Joel Veltman and Davinson Sanchez, both of whom miss out through suspension, replaced by Kenny Tete and teenager Matthijs de Ligt. Daley Sinkgraven returns from injury after missing the second leg against Legia, replacing Jairo Riedewald, while youth product Donny van de Beek gets the start in midfield with Hakim Ziyech a surprising and rare omission from the starting XI.

Stale Solbakken makes just one change from the second leg round-of-32 draw with Ludogorets, as William Kvist returns to the side, replacing Aboubakar Keita in midfield. Ex-Ajax left-back Nicolai Boilesen remains on the bench as he's not awarded a revenge start against his former club, following what was a bitter end to his time in Amsterdam.
SUBS: Riedewald, Neres, Westermann, Cassierra, Ziyech, Boer, Nouri.
AJAX (4-3-3): Onana; Tete, De Ligt, Viergever, Sinkgraven; Klaassen, Schone, van de Beek; Traore, Younes, Dolberg.
SUBS: Andersen, Hogli, Gregus, Kusk, Boilesen, Pavlovic, Okore.
COPENHAGEN (4-4-2): Olsen; Ankersen, Jorgensen, Johansson, Augustinsson; Falk, Matic, Kvist, Toutouh; Santander, Cornelius.

Ajax have not reached the quarter-finals in European competition since the 2002/03 Champions League, a lengthy drought for the consistent participants, who have seen their progress on the big stage stagnate in recent years – this is a manageable draw and a realistic opportunity for them to get over that hump.

Copenhagen have relied heavily on their impressive Parken form in Europe this season, maintaining a stellar defensive record, though the goals have dried up a bit for them lately. They will have to be sharp at both ends tonight to make sure they have something positive to take back with them to Amsterdam.

Ajax were dumped from the final qualifying round of the Champions League. They breezed through the Europa League group stage and defeated Legia in the previous round to advance to the last-16, as they remain unbeaten in the competition to date.
Despite losing just once in the Champions League group stage, Copenhagen finished third and were relegated to the Europa League, where they defeated Ludogorets 2-1 on aggregate to reach the last-16.
Hello and welcome to live coverage from the Telia Parken in Denmark as Copenhagen play host to Ajax in the first leg of this last-16 Europa League tie!
news: Andreas Cornelius netted a second-half winner to help Copenhagen to a deserved 2-1 victory over Ajax in the first leg of their Europa League last-16 tie.

The towering striker made the difference with a superb header just before the hour mark after Peter Ankersen's sublime cross from the right, beating Matthijs de Ligt in the air to leave goalkeeper Andre Onana without a chance.

The Danish champions had previously gone a goal up through Rasmus Falk after just 27 seconds, only for Kasper Dolberg to score a controversial equaliser from what seemed like an offside position, but there would be no denying the home side in the end.

Copenhagen were brimming with confidence heading into Thursday's encounter following their superb home form over the past 18 months, last conceding in an official game at Telia Parken back in August 2016 and going unbeaten ever since a 3-2 defeat against Jablonec in August 2015.
Ajax, meanwhile, had every reason for optimism as well, having won five of their eight prior Europa League encounters this term and drawing the remaining three.
It was Copenhagen that dominated proceedings, though, and Cornelius' second-half strike would eventually prove to be decisive.

Copenhagen charged forward right from the start and needed less than a minute to open the scoring through Falk. The midfielder escaped the attention of Lasse Schone after a clever pass from William Kvist and beat Onana with a fine volley from a narrow angle.

The hosts continued to cause Ajax all kinds of trouble early on and Youssef Toutouh could have doubled his side's lead after a long throw-in from Kvist, blasting a shot just wide of the target after Federico Santander had headed the ball into his path.

The Amsterdammers slowly grew into the game and Dolberg restored parity in the 32nd minute with a sublime finish from what appeared to be an illegal position. Davy Klaassen sent in a fine cross from the right and the Denmark international did well to hold off Ankersen before volleying home.

Ajax made an encouraging start to the second half and could have grabbed the lead when the unmarked Schone got a chance to try his luck from the edge of the box, only for the experienced midfielder to aim yards wide.

Copenhagen had struggled to get going after the restart, but they went 2-1 up with their first chance of note after the break, Cornelius beating Onana with a strong header after outmuscling De Ligt in the 59th minute.
Ajax boss Peter Bosz brought on big-money signings Hakim Ziyech and David Neres in the closing stages of the game as the visitors went in search of an equaliser.
Klaassen was unfortunate to be denied by a fine save from Robin Olsen, before Dolberg had a goal disallowed in the 88th minute for a foul on Uros Matic as it ended 2-1.

commentary: Full-time in Cyprus. Anderlecht take a narrow lead into the second leg of this Europa League tie next week as they overcome APOEL with a 1-0 victory, with Stanciu grabbing the only goal of the match in the first half. Thanks for joining us, see you next time!

THREE minutes of added time have been allocated by the referee so not long left for APOEL to find an equaliser. Indeed, it is Anderlecht who are charging forward here, but Acheampong wastes another opportunity by dribbling straight into a couple of defenders.
Last alteration of the match from Anderlecht as Massimo Bruno replaced Chipciu.

SAVE FROM RUBEN! The Anderlecht goalkeeper makes a great save in between the sticks to deny APOEL which also then sees the visitors able to counter. Hanni leads the charge and it is Acheampong who eventually receives the ball to feet, but the subsequent strike is easily saved by Waterman!
Spajic is also booked.

Dendoncker breaks down the right this time and link up well with Appiah before the latter sends a cross into the box which is cleared. APOEL break free on the speedy counterattack, but Chipciu is forced to take one for the team and commits the foul on Barral to see a yellow card.

There is only one team who look like scoring at the moment, and that is APOEL. Anderlecht have moved into deep defensive positions now as they look to take this narrow 1-0 lead into the second leg next week, but there is no room for complacency as the visitors tonight are starting to turn up the heat!
Another Anderlecht change sees the solitary goalscorer, Stanciu, leave the pitch to be replaced by Frank Acheampong.

Within the past five minutes the balls being delivered into the box from APOEL have been much better. The latest comes from a corner which actually allows Artymatas to send an awkward looking half-volley bouncing towards goal, but unfortunately for him it is straight down the throat of Ruben.
Thelin is booked now.

STUNNING SAVE FROM RUBEN! Barral collects the ball into feet inside the box and uses his strength to turn his marker into space before lashing a left-footed strike towards the near corner. The Anderlecht goalkeeper, despite being unsighted, somehow gets down to palm behind for the corner!

Lago has been excellent since being introduced to the action down the left and this time gains a yard on the defender to whip a cracking cross to the front post. De Camargo gets ahead of his marker to latch on to the rare decent delivery, but his glancing header goes forcefully the wrong side of the post. Unlucky in the end.

APOEL are lacking quality in key areas and it is really costing them. At times, Anderlecht have been there for the taking after committing too many men forward, only for them to be let off the hook following various misplaced passes from the home side.
Third and final change from the Cypriot outfit and it sees Ebecilio leave the pitch to be replaces by Kostakis Artymatas. Last throw of the dice from the APOEL coaching staff!

If this game finishes at 1-0, then at least APOEL have next week to try and grab an away goal back in Belgium. However, if they finish like they have been tonight then they have no chance in going through - they just can't get the ball in the back of the net!

That is an awful miss from Barral! The substitute, Lago, does superbly well down the left wing to dash into space, hit the byline, and launch a teasing cross to the back post! Barral takes in to feet, but from a tight angle with markers all around him, fires wide of the post when a team-mate is SCREAMING for the tap-in just inside! The two APOEL players fall to the floor in desperation!
Milanov sees yellow.

There has not been a collection of awful corner-kick deliveries quite like that on display from APOEL here tonight. They have had a tonne of chances to get decent balls into the box, but basically every one of them now has either hit the first man or went desperately long out of play. The players inside the box must be tearing their hair out.

The game has hit a bit of a lull in the past couple of minutes which should actually play into APOEL's hands as at the beginning of the half it looked like Anderlecht were going to score at the very least another goal. A much more positive 10 minutes from the hosts now, though.

First booking of the match for Anderlecht and it goes to Appiah, with APOEL also getting the free-kick in a nice area. However, it is AGAIN a desperately poor delivery as the attackers are left frustrated.

One of Vander's first duties since coming on is to take a free-kick basically at the corner flag on the right flank. Initially, the substitute sends a poor delivery into the box which is easily cleared, and then lets Anderlecht off the hook completely by pulling back Najar for the foul. A good minute or so there from him...
First change of the match from Wieler as he introduces Isaac Kiese Thelin in place of the largely ineffective Teodorczyk. The youngster coming on certainly has pace on him, so keep an eye.

Oh, De Camargo what are you doing? A promising APOEL counter ends with the ball being looped high into the box. Barral looks poised to pull the trigger at the back post, but is actually foiled by his strike partner who nods the ball away whilst trying to desperately stretch to divert a header on target!
Second substitution of the match from APOEL as Efrem, who may indeed have not came out of that fall unscathed after all, leave the action to be replaced by Vander.

Gianniotas sends another corner-kick into the box, with the front post the target this time. Somehow, APOEL fail to find the back of the net even after a mammoth scramble just in front of goal in which two or three shots are heroically blocked by the Anderlecht defence!

A small break in play at the moment as Efrem goes down off the ball clutching his knee after taking a nasty, nasty fall. He landed extremely awkwardly and it is falls like that which can sometimes can ligament damage, but SOMEHOW he comes away from the situation unscathed. That is incredible - what a lucky boy!

Hanni moves away from his central attacker position and collects the ball on the left channel before jinking past the defender with a lovely bit of skill. He looks up and reverses a cross back inside towards the penalty spot, but again APOEL manage to clear by the skin of their teeth.

Anderlecht have started the second half like a house on fire and seem eager to put this tie to bed as early as the first leg. Teodorczyk dances his way into the penalty area, trying desperately to find that elusive yard of space to pull the trigger, only to be forced to pass back out wide to Appiah. The cross is then sent into the middle, but Morais is there to clear with a commanding header.
The second period is under way!

Half-time at the Neo GSP. Anderlecht have been the much better side in this Europa League knockout stage clash and deservedly go into the break with the narrow 1-0 lead following a goal from Stanciu. APOEL are by no means out of this, but they will definitely need to improve in the final third. Second period to come.

Just about the softest yellow card you will see in all of the Europa League action tonight now as Morais goes into the book for a miniscule shove in the back on the goalscorer, Stanciu. Not only will he need to be careful in this game, but the APOEL captain will now MISS the return leg next week.

A scrappy bit of play on the edge of the Anderlecht box now as both teams unintentionally trade possession with wayward passes and attempted clearances. Eventually Morais picks up a bouncing ball with his back to goal and attempts to recycle a cross back into the danger area over his head, but Ruben does well to proactively come off his line to claim out of the air.
APOEL have been forced into an early change as Roberto Lago enters the action to replace Astiz.

Morais may have been unlucky with APOEL's best chance of the match so far, but he needs to be much better in possession in the middle of the park. This time he panics while under pressure and attempts a speculative pass over the top of the Anderlecht defence which is easily blocked on the route through. Barral was free, as well!

The latest entry of the Spajic/De Camargo feud now as the latter does nothing but stand his ground during an aerial battle. The Anderlecht defender jumps on his opponent, wins the header, falls akwardly on to his back, and somehow earns the foul in the process. De Camargo is bemused at that one.

Gianniotas is involved again for APOEL as he opens up his stride down the right wing during a promising counter from the hosts. However, they are forced to settle for another corner as the subsequent cross into the box is turned behind the goal by the retreating Najar.

APOEL have responded fairly well to going behind and definitely have the quality to get themselves back into this. Set-pieces look to be a potential source for an equaliser, as proven by Morais' very unlucky header moments ago!

APOEL HIT THE WOODWORK! A free-kick is swung superbly into the middle of the box and Morais rises high to bullet a header at goal which Ruben somehow turns on to the post! All the chaos soon ends though as the referee blows for a foul, or potentially an offside. That was some save from the Anderlecht stopper, even if the whistle had gone.
A really smart assist for Chipciu. Most players would have just blasted a cross inside!

GOOOOOAAAAAAAAAALLLL FOR ANDERLECHT! The visitors open the scoring! An absolutely dreadful pass out of the back from Astiz sees Anderlecht win the ball and counter with pace down the left and into the middle. After some neat interplay, Chipciu reverses a pass to the edge of the box for Stanciu who displays lovely composure to guide an attempt into the bottom left corner! One-nil

We are just beyond the midway point of the first half now and what has became clear is that these are two relatively evenly matched sides. Anderlecht enjoyed the better opening to the game and arguably have the better individuals, but APOEL are no mugs and on home turf anything can happen. No small feat eliminating Athletic Bilbao from the competition!

After a small delay to sort some pushing inside the box, Gianniotas steps up to fire a corner to the front post for APOEL. Astiz looks to get on the end of it and almost does so after a miscommunication between Ruben between the sticks and one of his defenders, but nobody from the hosts can take down the bouncing ball to pull the trigger!

Tielemans definitely seems to be the main man for Anderlecht tonight as he has been tasked with pretty much every set-piece. On this occasion he actually receives a free-kick short from someone else, but then only succeeds in sending a blistering strike high into the stand behind the goal. That was fairly ambitious, that...

Appiah goes on an overlapping run down the right wing for Anderlecht and, after a few passes in the central area, picks up possession again inside the box near the byline. However, all the intensity leaves the attack as he eventually runs the ball poorly out of play whilst trying to jink past the defender. A nice idea, but not when there is team-mates waiting for the cross inside.

APOEL are given their first corner of the match which gives the home fans reason to get out of their seats in expectancy. However, the delivery is desperately poor, forcing them to sit back down. It was so bad Anderlecht actually break free with a dangerous-looking counter!

Gianniotas, who scored in the previous round against Athletic Bilbao, attempts to affect the game positively here as he goes on a marauding run down the right touchline. However, Najar is no slouch himself and successfully keeps up the pace before eventually earning a throw-in out of the winger.

Anderlecht kind of gain their first shot on goal as Teodorczyk slides in a strike from the left of the box, but he had to get through the defender to do it which results in the free-kick being given to APOEL. Waterman made the save relatively comfortably anyway.

Much, much better from APOEL at the moment as they are just starting to find their feet in terms of possession. However, after a few neat passes, Iannou gifts the ball back to Anderlecht with an attempted pass through the middle to De Camargo which is easily intercepted by the defender.

There is an interesting feud developing between De Camargo and Spajic, with both players not exactly leaving anything to chance with their tackling. On this occasion the APOEL comes out on top following a strong challenge, but is eventually penalised by the referee for the foul. That looked harsh.

Another set-piece for Anderlecht now, which Tielemans will take from the corner flag. The talented Belgian steps up to whip a wicked cross deep into the middle of the box and APOEL really struggle to deal with it, failing to clear with a couple of rash hacks into the air. Luckily for the hosts, Anderlecht are unable to capitalise.

Within the past couple of minutes APOEL have managed to venture into the Anderlecht half but Barral and De Camargo need to work a lot harder to make the ball stick up top. Spajic is giving the latter zero time in possession whatsoever.

This has been very impressive from the Belgian outfit in these very early stages. The APOEL fans were obviously in full voice pre-match to try and catalyse something from the players, but the visitors have been quick to curb any ascendancy thanks to their pressure in the first five minutes.

A positive start to the match from Anderlecht who are taking the game to the hosts early on. Tielemans stands over a free-kick down the left wing and steps up to fire a dangerous delivery into the opposition penalty area, but APOEL survive on this occasion after the clearance.
We are under way in Cyprus!
Anderlecht subs: Boeckx, Deschacht, Bruno, Capel, Acheampong, Thelin, Obradovic.
Anderlecht (4-3-3): Ruben; Appiah, Spajic, Nuytinck, Najar; Stanciu, Dendoncker, Tielemans; Chipciu, Teodorczyk, Hanni.
APOEL subs: Pardo, Lago, Artymatas, Alexandrou, Aloneftis, Vander, Yambere.
APOEL (4-4-1-1): Waterman; Milanov, Astiz, Merkis, Ioannou; Gianniotas, Morais, Ebecilio, Efrem; Barral, De Camargo.
TEAM NEWS...

We are witnessing a little bit of history tonight as this is the first time APOEL will face Anderlecht in a competitive UEFA fixture. The two sides will, naturally, face each other again in the return leg seven days from now, but who will take the more favourable scoreline into the game in Belgium?

Anderlecht, meanwhile, did things in a reversed fashion to APOEL in that they won the first leg 2-0 against Zenit. In the second leg in St. Petersburg, the Russian outfit actually took a 3-0 lead as things looked desperate for Rene Weiler and his charges, but a dramatic last-minute strike from Isaac Thelin ultimately secured the 3-1 away result and the aggregate victory in the process.

The two sides featuring tonight made it to this stage of the competition thanks to wins in the last round over, arguably, much more favoured opposition. APOEL, following a commendable 3-2 away loss at San Mames in leg one, successfully secured a 2-0 second-leg win over Athletic Bilbao a couple of weeks ago with Pieros Soteriou and Giannis Gianniotas grabbing the vital two goals on that occasion.
Good evening football fans! Welcome to LIVE coverage of the Europa League last-16 clash between APOEL and Anderlecht from the Neo GSP in Nicosia.
news: Nicolae Stanciu scored the only goal of the game as Anderlecht took control of their Europa League last-16 tie with a 1-0 win at APOEL in Thursday's first leg.
APOEL had not lost in 19 home games across all competitions, but it was the visitors that started brightly at the GSP Stadium.
And Stanciu finished a well-worked move in the 29th minute that proved to be enough for Rene Weiler's men to take a potentially crucial lead and away goal back to Belgium for next week's return tie.

The hosts, who closed out their domestic regular season with victory over Nicosia rivals Omonia on Saturday, may have headed into the match in fine form but the absence of 22-goal top scorer Pieros Sotiriou through suspension left them light in attack.

Consequently, APOEL failed to find a way through the Anderlecht defence and now have it all to do in the second leg, where they now must record just a second away European win of the campaign to reach the last eight, a task made harder after captain Nuno Morais picked up a first-half booking that rules him out of the match in Brussels.
After a lull, Anderlecht renewed their earlier attacking intent at the beginning of the second half as Chipciu stung the palms of Boy Waterman with a low drive.
The home support simply turned the noise levels up again, though, and only further brave interventions in the Anderlecht defence kept De Camargo at bay.

APOEL's best chance yet arrived at the feet of David Barral with just over 20 minutes remaining, as Ruben clawed Roberto Lago's cross away from the top corner, but he sliced his finish horribly wide of the target.
De Camargo nodded over from Lago's left-wing cross and Barral forced a low save from Ruben with a deflected strike towards his near post, with the keeper then saving from Kostakis Artymatas' volley.
Ruben was finally beaten with Vander Vieira's hopeful deep free-kick from near the half-way line, but the crossbar came to his rescue.
Frank Acheampong almost stole a second goal as he shot straight at Waterman from the subsequent counter-attack, but Anderlecht settled for a slander one-goal lead.

commentary: Thanks for joining our commentary this evening. Until next time, goodbye.

Juventus move 10 points clear at the top of Serie A despite not being at their best this evening. An own goal from Lukasz Skorupski broke the deadlock after Mario Mandzukic hit the bar with a powerful header, while Alex Sandro secured the three points with a crisp strike inside the box.
FULL-TIME: JUVENTUS 2-0 EMPOLI
The referee ends the contest.
SHOT! Alves tries to get on the scoresheet as he hammers an effort at goal from the edge of the box, but Skorupski makes the save.
There will be four minutes of added time.
Alves goes to ground very easily once again. Not the best outing of professionalism from the Brazilian.
Juventus seem content to see this one out after Dybala's near miss. They're keeping possession at the back and are knocking it around with relative ease.
CLOSE! Dybala collects on the edge of the box and attempts to bend his strike into the top corner, but his effort creeps inches past the post.
OVER! Buchel collects 35 yards from goal and tries an ambitious strike, but hammers his effort into the stand behind the goal.
Cuadrado makes way for Pjaca.
OVER! Alves goes for goal directly from Dybala's corner, but can only hammer his effort well over the bar from the edge of the box.
Bellusci goes into the book for a foul on Mandzukic.
CHANCE! Mandzukic threads the ball into the path of Higuain, but the striker just cannot bring the ball down in time before Costa clears it away from him.
Rincon replaces Marchisio for the final stages of the match.

MISS! Higuain is having one of those days in front of goal as he fails to hit the target once again. Alves lifts the ball into the box for the Argentine to attack, but fails to make sufficient contact to guide his effort at goal.
Buchel replaces Mauri for the visitors.

DISALLOWED GOAL! Higuain pounces on the rebound and lifts the ball back to Dybala to slot into the net from close range. However, the offside flag was up against the Argentine as he pounced on the ball.
CHANCE! Pjanic almost makes it three for Allegri's men as he cuts back on to his left foot and drills an effort towards the bottom corner, but Skorupski makes the save.
Dybala replaces Sturaro for the home side.
Alves has had a good game, but his theatrics continue as he hits the deck after being brushed by the arm of Mauri. Completely unnecessary from the Brazilian.
Thiam replaces Marilungo for the final 20 minutes.
Veseli replaces Laurini for the visitors.
CHANCE! Higuain has not been on form today and his poor evening continues as he collects Sandro's pass in the box, but scoops his left-footed strike over the bar.
Empoli have only scored 15 goals this season in their 25 matches. The odds are well and truly stacked against them getting back into this match.
Alves gets his reward for his constant attacking threat down the right flank this evening.

GOALLLLLL!!! SANDRO DOUBLES JUVE'S LEAD! The home side take command of the game as Alves lifts the ball into Sandro's path at the back post. The left-back turns Laurini to curl his effort beyond the reach of Skorupski into the bottom corner. A fine finish.
Empoli waste a chance to threaten from a free-kick and there is feeling that the game is beginning to open up. The next goal will be crucial.
SAVE! Alves bombs down the right flank and he lifts his cross to the back post for Mandzukic to attack at the back post, but his headed effort is stopped with ease by Skorupski.
OVER! Space opens up through the middle of the Empoli defence and Sturaro collects a pass from Mandzukic on the edge of the box, but he can only fire his effort over the bar.
CHANCE! Marilungo slides the ball into the path of El Kaddouri inside the box. He takes a touch to open up space for a shot at goal, but he only blast his effort over the bar.
Krunic puts the pressure on the Juve backline with good pressing on the edge of their own box and Sandro's header back to Neto just has enough pace to reach the keeper.
Marilungo almost escapes the attention of Rugani inside the box, but the defender just does enough to put him off his attempted effort from a tight angle.

GOALLLL!!! JUVE TAKE THE LEAD! Skorupski may have turned this one into his own net, but Mandzukic's powerful header caused the error. He guided his effort from Cuadrado's cross to cannon off the underside of the bar, which then hit the keeper to cross the line.
Alves has been a constant outlet down the right flank this evening, but between Mandzukic's heading and solid defending from Empoli, his crossing has not been rewarded thus far.
CHANCE! Marchisio gives the ball straight to Mauri, who fires at goal from 30 yards. His effort has the power, but given the distance Neto is able to get down in time to make a comfortable save.
El Kaddouri capitalises on further loose play from the home side and drives at goal to the edge of the box. He lines up a strike, but Rugani makes an important block.
CHANCE! Alves stands a cross up into the middle for Mandzukic to head into Higuain's path. The Argentine has time to fire at goal, but he scuffs his effort straight at Skorupski.
El Kaddouri makes a break from the middle of the park and has support outside from Mauri, but his pass to his team-mate is intercepted by Bonucci.
We're back underway in this Serie A match.
The players are back out for the second half, so we should be underway shortly.
Massimiliano Allegri will be imploring his men to find a cutting edge in the second half, while Giovani Martusciello will be delighted with the resolve shown by his team in the first period.

It's goalless at the break between Juventus and Empoli as the home side have failed to fire in the final third. Mario Mandzukic and Gonzalo Higuain have both missed half-chances, although the visitors have defended stoutly for the majority of the contest.
HALF-TIME: JUVENTUS 0-0 EMPOLI
The referee ends the first half.
BLOCKED! Pjanic hammers his first strike straight into the wall before he fires an effort on the half-volley off his own team-mate Mandzukic to send the ball out for a goal-kick.
Krunic makes one of his first mistakes of the game he brings down Sturaro on the edge of the box. Pjanic will take the resulting set-piece.

There's no way through for Juve at the moment as they recycle possession on the edge of the box, but cannot penetrate the Empoli backline. Alves lifts a cross into the box, aiming for Mandzukic, but Skorupski comes off his line to claim.

CHANCE AND PENALTY SHOUT! Juve go up for a handball against Krunic as Sturaro knocks the ball off his arm. The ball travels out to Pjanic on the edge of the box, who blasts an effort towards the net, only to see his strike drift wide of the post.

CHANCE! Higuain drifts into space to collect the ball and he whips a dangerous cross towards the back stick for Mandzukic to attack. The striker stretches for the balll, but once again he cannot make solid contact as he sends his effort wide.

Sandro attempts to beat Krunic down the left flank, but the Empoli midfielder sends him tumbling to the deck. The visitors need to be careful in the wide areas as that's an area where Juve have had success this evening.
Empoli are battling well against the home side and are ensuring that Allegri's men are having to work extremely hard to earn their chances at goal.

CHANCE! Juve open the Empoli defence with a fine attacking move as Cuadrado plays in Mandzukic. The striker has space and time to pick his spot, but he dwells too long on the opening, allowing Skorupski to smother the ball at his feet with the aid of El Hadji.

Not a good moment for Alves as he throws himself to the ground looking for a free-kick. There was no contact from Costa as the Brazilian attempted to con the referee, and he is lucky to escape without a booking there.
WIDE! Alves sends a cross to the back post for Mandzukic to attack once again. The striker beats Laurini in the air, but his header lacks the direction needed to trouble Skorupski.

Sandro gives the ball straight to El Kaddouri, who makes a threatening surge forward. Sturaro comes back to make a sliding challenge and although the Empoli midfielder pleads for a free-kick, the referee does not grant him his wish.
Alves sends a cross to the back post and the ball almost falls for Sturaro to strike, but he is adjudged to have fouled Bellusci before he can pull the trigger on his strike.

Juve have started this match very sluggishly and have lacked any sort of rhythm in their passing game. Allegri will want to see more from Marchisio and Pjanic to get a hold of the match in the middle of the park.

WIDE! El Kaddouri makes a promising break to race away from Rugani and Bonucci, but as both defenders close in on the midfielder, he opts to shoot with his left foot and slices his strike past the post.
Marilungo tries to slide Pucciarelli into the box, but the two players are not on the same page, allowing Neto to gather.
Costa does well to sense the danger on the left flank as he comes across to clear ahead of Cuadrado and wins a free-kick as the winger clatters into him.
El Hadji sends an ambitious pass down the left flank for Pasqual to chase. Alves is nowhere in sight to protect the opening, but it proves to have too much pace for the Empoli left-back to catch.

Sandro hits a peach of a cross-field pass over to Cuadrado on the right flank, but the winger wastes the opening with a terrible cross. The loose ball manages to find Marchisio 35 yards out, but he pulls his strike well past the post.
WIDE! Cuadrado is afforded space and time once again near the edge of the box and he drives a low shot at goal. On this occasion it's an Empoli shirt that diverts his strike past the post.
CHANCE! Mandzukic is inches away from handing the home side the lead as he stretches to poke Cuadrado's strike at goal, but just cannot get enough on the ball to divert it inside the post.
Empoli are not backing down from the challenge of the league leaders in the early stages of the contest as Pasqual has a surge down the left flank and wins a corner.
OVER! Juve keep the pressure on the visitors and Alves sends a dangerous cross to the back post for Mandzukic to attack, only to see his header drift over the bar.

CHANCE! Higuain spurns the opportunity to put his side ahead as Mandzukic heads Sandro's cross into his path inside the six-yard box. He pokes the ball towards the bottom corner, but without the power needed to beat Skorupski.
Marchisio attempts to slide a throughball for Higuain's run behind the Empoli defence, but the ball skips off the surface and goes out for a goal-kick.
The visitors have started the game on the front by winning a couple of free-kicks in Juve territory. However, both deliveries have been underwhelming.
We're underway in this Serie A contest.
The players are making their way out on to the pitch, so we should be underway shortly.

Empoli make two changes from their defeat to Lazio last time out. Giovanni Martusciello brings Jose Mauri and Guido Marilungo into his side, while the club remain without the services of top scorer Levan Mchedlidze.
Neto takes Gianluigi Buffon's place between the sticks, while Claudio Marchisio and Stefano Sturaro get the nod to start in the midfield.

Juventus have made six changes from their win over Porto. Leonardo Bonucci is back in his manager's good graces after an argument between him and Allegri. He starts alongside Daniele Rugani in the heart of the defence, while Dani Alves also comes into the backline.
Empoli subs: Zambelli, Dimarco, Maccarone, Croce, Veseli, Zajc, Barba, Pelagotti, Cosic, Thiam, Buchel, Tello.
EMPOLI (4-3-1-2): Skorupski; Laurini, Bellusci, Costa, Pasqual; Krunic, Diousse, Jose Mauri; El Kaddouri; Pucciarelli, Marilungo.
Juventus subs: Buffon, Chiellini, Benatia, Barzagli, Lemina, Pjaca, Dybala, Asamoah, Lichtsteiner, Rincon, Audero.
JUVENTUS (4-3-3): Neto; Dani Alves, Bonucci, Rugani, Alex Sandro; Marchisio, Pjanic, Sturaro; Cuadrado, Higuain, Mandzukic.
The team news has been announced and we'll start with the home side.

I Bianconeri head into the game off the back of a 4-1 hammering of Palermo in their last league outing, although they lost their five-match run of not conceding. Juve also triumphed during the week in the first leg of their Champions League clash against Porto, displaying their quality on the road.
Empoli are floating narrowly above the relegation zone. They are eight points clear of 18th-place Palermo, but will be desperate to pick up points to ease their concerns.

Juve can stretch their lead at the top of Serie A to 10 points with a victory this evening. Massimiliano Allegri's men have been boosted already today by Napoli's defeat to Atalanta, reducing their threat in the race for the title.
Good evening and welcome to the live commentary of the Serie A clash between Juventus and Empoli.
news: Juventus cruised to a 2-0 win over struggling Empoli in Serie A on Saturday to go 10 points clear at the summit and pile the pressure on Roma ahead of their trip to Inter.

The result was not as comfortable as it should have been given Juve's complete domination, but they eventually made the most of their superiority in the second half and extended their lead at the top of the table, with closest challengers Roma facing a tough journey to San Siro on Sunday.
Milan must secure Donnarumma's future
Juve unsurprisingly controlled the game from start to finish and could not be accused of failing to create enough chances, but their finishing let them down in what was a wasteful first-half showing.
Mario Mandzukic was particularly culpable, as he spurned a host of opportunities and let Empoli off the hook.
But he was crucial to Juve when they did eventually find the breakthrough in the 52nd minute, with his header inspiring a Lukasz Skorupski own-goal.
Alex Sandro wrapped things up with a clever finish 25 minutes from time and Juve comfortably saw out their seventh successive Serie A win.
The hosts were in charge right from the start in Turin and crafted several opportunities early on, with both strikers guilty of missing the target in the first 10 minutes.

Gonzalo Higuain spurned their first chance, prodding wide from close range after Mandzukic's knock-down, before the Croatian followed suit, missing the bottom-left corner when latching on to Juan Cuadrado's teasing cross.
Mandzukic went close again in the 27th minute, meeting Dani Alves' cross from the right and heading past the post after outjumping Vincent Laurini at the back stick.
The Juve striker was then presented with a glorious chance to make amends for his previous mishaps after half an hour.
But Mandzukic overcomplicated things by attempting to dribble around Skorupski when picked out by an inch-perfect Higuain pass and the goalkeeper came out on top.
Miralem Pjanic then also saw a decent 20-yard effort narrowly miss the right-hand post just before the break.
Juve finally broke the deadlock just after the break and Mandzukic was vital.
VIDEO: Fabinho scores cheeky Panenka

The forward's header from Cuadrado's cross struck the underside of the bar, bounced up off the ground and hit the frame of the goal again, before then bouncing off Skorupski and over the line for an own-goal.

The hosts then essentially put the game beyond Empoli just after the hour mark – Alex Sandro collecting Alves' pass in the left side of the area with his back to goal, before spinning and finding the far bottom corner with a perfectly placed effort.

Juve continued their search for more goals right until the end, with Higuain forcing Skorupski into action from close range in the final 15 minutes, but Empoli never looked capable of making them rue their missed chances as the home side eased over the finish line.

commentary: The disappointing draw means that Man City remain in third place, although they now sit equal on points with second-place Tottenham. Stoke, meanwhile, lie three points clear of Southampton in ninth, although they have played two games more than the Saints.

The referee blows his whistle for the final time and the group of Stoke fans camped in the corner of the stadium go wild. Their side certainly did wonderfully well to hold Man City to a very impressive point, although the home side were certainly far from their best and should have done more in front of goal.
FULL-TIME: MANCHESTER CITY 0-0 STOKE CITY

Huge chance for Sane! Another dangerous De Bruyne cross flies into the heart of the Stoke penalty area and looks set to reach Sane, but the German is put off by the defender at the vital moment and is unable to make contact with the ball on the edge of the six-yard box.

Sane twists and turns over on the left-hand side of the Stoke penalty area as he tries to find a way into the box. He's eventually able to do so after skipping past Bardsley, but Shawcross is there to blast the ball out for a throw-in.

Almost a chance for Aguero! A beautiful cross is whipped into the Stoke box by Clichy and almost finds Aguero in front of goal, but just as it looks as if he's going to get a head on the ball, Martins Indi nods it away from the striker with a vital block.
Sobhi denies Man City the opportunity to counter quickly with a cynical challenge over on the left wing, resulting in him being shown a yellow card.
The fourth official has indicated that there will be four minutes of added time. Can Man City find a late winner?

Man City desperately knock the ball around on the edge of the Stoke box as they try to carve out a late chance on goal, but Iheanacho is unable to set up Aguero and the Argentine is out-muscled by Shawcross just as he tries to spin and shoot.

Aguero goes close! The Argentine twists and turns on the edge of the penalty area before flying towards the near post. He then tries to beat Grant with a low strike from close range, but he's unable to test the goalkeeper and instead sends his shot into the side-netting.
De Bruyne steps up and finally chips a cross into the Stoke box from the free-kick, but it's unable to find a blue shirt and the visitors are easily able to deal with the danger.
Stoke have made their final change of the night, with Gianelli Imbula coming on to replace Allen.

De Bruyne spins quickly before embarking on a marauding run towards the Stoke penalty area, but he's brought crashing to the ground by a cynical challenge from Walters and has to settle for a free-kick. Can the home side make it count?

Fernandinho is caught in possession deep inside the Stoke half of the pitch and allows the visitors to counter quickly. They do so through Allen, who flies forward before teeing up Sobhi, but, after skipping past Otamendi, the Egyptian is unable to find the Welshman once again and the attack comes to a disappointing end.
With 80 minutes on the clock, Walters is presented with his first opportunity on goal thanks to a swinging cross from Bardsley, but he's unable to keep it down and fails to hit the target.
Berahino makes his way off the pitch to be replaced by Glenn Whelan for the final 11 minutes of the game.

And now Otamendi goes close! The corner is whipped into the heart of the penalty area and finds Otamendi in a great position in front of goal, but he's unable to hit the target with his headed effort and instead sends it looping over the top of the crossbar.

Another chance for Silva! The Spaniard, who has made a big impact since coming off the substitutes' bench, cuts inside from the right wing before unleashing a great shot from 25 yards out, but it takes a slight deflection off Martins Indi that sends the ball bouncing just wide of the far post and out for a corner.
Man City have made another attacking alteration, with Kelechi Iheanacho coming on to replace Toure.

Another Man City attacking move fails to result in a chance on goal for the hosts, allowing Stoke to counter quickly. Afellay spots a good run forward from Walters and tries to pick out the striker with a cross-field pass, but it's overhit and fails to find the Irishman, who was in a great position inside the home side's half of the pitch.

Clichy, who has looked a bit suspect over on the left wing, is beaten by Cameron far too easily as the American pushes forward on a rare charging run. He skips past the Frenchman and then curls a low cross into the box, but it fails to find a red and white shirt and is well dealt with by the home side.

What an opportunity for Silva! The Spaniard plays a lovely one-two with Fernandinho on the edge of the Stoke box before unleashing a low strike towards the bottom right-hand corner of the net, but the ball rolls just a fraction wide of the far post after beating the outstretched limbs of Grant.

Aguero goes close! The Argentine flings himself towards the near post as he tries to latch on to a bouncing cross from De Bruyne, but he's beaten to the ball by Shawcross once again and is unable to poke his side into the lead.

Another dangerous De Bruyne cross causes problems for the Stoke back line before rolling out to Toure on the edge of the penalty area. The Ivorian immediately tries to test Grant with a thumping strike, but it's poorly hit and sails high over the crossbar.
Diouf gingerly makes his way off the pitch to be replaced by Ibrahim Afellay in a straight swap for Stoke.

Things don't look good for Diouf, who has gone down inside his own penalty area after another City attacking move comes to an end. He was struggling slightly in the first half and it looks as if his game may be over.

Man City keep desperately push forward as they try to carve out a chance on goal, but, after getting himself into a good position over on the left flank, Clichy is unable to pick out a team-mate with his low cross into the heart of the Stoke penalty area.

Fernandinho picks up the ball on the halfway line and immediately tries to tee up Silva with a quick pass forward, but the Spaniard is swiftly closed down by Shawcross and fails to get the better of the defender.

Another attempted Man City attack comes to an end, allowing Bardsley to break down the right wing. The Manchester-born full-back charges into a dangerous position before swinging a cross into the box, but Sagna is there to get a foot on it.

Big miss by Sane! De Bruyne, who has looked far better since the break, fires a low cross into the Stoke box that bobbles past Allen and into the path of Sane, who quickly unleashes a rushed shot that sails high and wide of the goal.

Sagna is trapped by Pieters deep down the right flank and has to settle for a throw-in near to the corner flag, but, despite a few nervy moments under pressure from the Stoke front line, Man City are just about able to clear the danger without too many problems.
Man City have made their first substitution of the evening, with Navas making way for David Silva.

Navas tees up De Bruyne with a lovely pass before the latter fires a great cross towards the near post, where Aguero is waiting. The striker is unable to make contact with the ball, however, and loses out to Shawcross at the last possible moment.

Chance for Aguero! Sane flies past Martins Indi far too easily before spinning and finding Aguero on the edge of the box, but the Argentine's quick shot fails to test Grant and is instead headed over the top of the crossbar by Pieters.

De Bruyne and Sane link up well just outside of the Stoke penalty area before the latter tries to skip into it. He looks to have beaten Bardsley before going down and claiming that he had been fouled, but the referee isn't having any of it and brandishes a yellow card for diving.

De Bruyne charges through the middle of the pitch on a great run before trying to tee up Aguero, but he's unable to do so and sends a poor pass straight to Martins Indi. Stoke then counter quickly through Diouf, but, after doing well to frustrate Clichy, the Senegalese forward is dispossessed deep down the right wing.

The resulting set-piece is launched into the heart of the penalty area and finds Walters in a promising position in front of goal, but he's unable to make decent contact with the ball and ends up sending it away to the left flank.
Big block by Otamendi! Walters rises high and flicks a downward header into the path of Berahino, but the latter is unable to beat Otamendi on the edge of the box and has to settle for a corner.

A deflected pass forward from Kolarov bounces into the path of De Bruyne and finds the Belgian on the edge of the Stoke penalty area, but, not for the first time this evening, Allen is there to dispossess the attacking midfielder with a great tackle from behind.
We're underway once again!
The two teams are making their way back out on to the pitch ahead of the start of the second half. Neither side have made any substitutions during the half-time break.

A few groans ring around the stadium as the two sets of players make their way off the pitch, and it's certainly been one of those games so far. Man City have dominated possession but done very little with it, as their attacking moves seem to lack the zip and creativity that usually characterises them. Stoke are clearly set up to defend, and that's exactly what they've done, with each outfield player willing to drop deep to frustrate the home side's stuttering front line.
HALF-TIME: MANCHESTER CITY 0-0 STOKE CITY

Almost a great opportunity for De Bruyne! Otamendi spots a clever run forward from the Belgian and tries to pick him out with a great lofted pass into the Stoke penalty area, but Grant does well to read the danger and beats the attacking midfielder to the ball at the vital moment.
The fourth official has indicated that there will be just one minute of added time.

Pieters gets himself into a pocket of space deep down the left flank and tries to tee up Diouf with a swinging cross over to the far post, but it's slightly overhit by the Dutchman and fails to result in a chance on goal for the forward, who's quickly dispossessed by Clichy.

Man City fail to break down Stoke's resolute back line once again, forcing Fernandinho into unleashing a long-range strike that deflects out for a corner. De Bruyne steps up and curls a deep cross towards the edge of the penalty area, but Aguero is unable to get the ball under decent control and loses out to Bardsley before he can spin and shoot.

Navas gets the better of Sobhi deep down the right wing before curling a great cross into the heart of the Stoke box and towards the head of Aguero, but Shawcross does well to beat him to the ball and brings an end to another Man City attack.

Allen is caught by a late challenge from Toure, and Stoke are awarded a free-kick in a promising position. It's thumped into the Man City penalty area and finds Diouf over on the right-hand side, but his attempted half-volley is poorly hit and sails several yards over the top of the crossbar.

Toure charges through the middle of the pitch on a great run as he out-muscles Bardsley. He heads towards the halfway line and tees up De Bruyne, who then plays a beautiful through-ball into the path of Sane, but the German's run into the penalty area is slightly mistimed and the linesman's flag is quickly raised as a result.

Sobhi gets himself into a good position over on the left-hand side of the penalty area and quickly tries to skip past Navas, but the Spaniard deals with the Egyptian better than Otamendi did earlier before winning a free-kick for his side after being pulled back.

After successfully bringing the Stoke attacking move to an end, Man City fly forward on one of their own, but a poor cross from Clichy fails to find either Aguero or Sane and bounces harmlessly out of play for a goal-kick.

Toure handles the ball on purpose and gives away a free-kick on the halfway line. It's thumped forward and finds Sobhi over on the left wing, and the Egyptian then spins to pick out Cameron. The American is unable to set up Diouf inside the penalty area, however, and Kolarov just about deals with the danger.

Man City patiently work the ball around midway inside the Stoke half of the pitch as they try to carve out a rare chance on goal, but, once again, their attacking move lacks the intensity needed to trouble the visitors and the Potters are easily able to hold on.

Otamendi pushes into the Stoke half of the pitch and then tries to pick out Sane with a thumping lofted pass up towards the penalty area, but Bardsley does well to dive in front of the winger before nodding the ball safely into the hands of Grant.

Once again, Sane cuts inside from the left flank and darts towards the Stoke penalty area, but Senegalese forward pulls off another great sliding tackle to dispossess the German before being taken down from behind as he tries to power away.
De Bruyne dummies the free-kick before Kolarov steps up and unleashes a thumping strike towards the near post, but Lee Grant is easily able to push it away with a strong diving save.

Aguero picks up possession in the middle of the pitch and immediately charges forward on a marauding run. He beats two Stoke midfielders and then tries to skip past Bardsley, but he's caught by an outstretched foot from the captain and win his side a free-kick in a dangerous position.

Excellent tackle by Diouf! Sane flies into the left-hand side of the Stoke penalty area and tries to latch on to a lovely through-ball from Clichy, but Diouf throws his body in the way of the German before scooping the ball away with an outstretched foot.

The ball pinballs around the middle of the pitch as both sides fail to get it under full control. It eventually falls to Toure, who then tries to set up Navas with an excellent pass down the right wing, but Martins Indi is there to cut out the danger with a great sliding tackle.

Diouf is taken out by a hefty challenge on the halfway line, but the referee doesn't believe he was taken down by a foul and allows play to go on. Man City move the ball around quickly before Aguero shoots from 25 yards out, but his strike is closed down quickly and ends up being deflected out for a corner.

Kolarov commits a clumsy foul on Walters over on the right flank, resulting in a free-kick for Stoke. It's whipped into the penalty area and finds Martins Indi in a promising position, but it takes him by surprise and he can only shin a shot into the hands of Caballero.

Vital clearance by Bacary Sagna! A half-hearted Man City attack breaks down and Stoke hit them on a swift counter. Saido Berahino charges through the middle of the pitch before teeing up Ramadan Sobhi, who beautifully beats Nicolas Otamendi on the left-hand side of the box. The Egyptian then cuts inside and fires a low cross towards Diouf, but he's unable to pick out the striker and loses out to Sagna.

Aguero is picked out on the edge of the box once again, and this time he's able to get the better of Bruno Martins Indi before spinning and finding Fernandinho. The Brazilian is in acres of space and comfortably finds Toure inside the penalty area, but the Ivorian's attempted pass back to the midfielder is poor and fails to reach him.

Aguero picks up the ball just outside of the Stoke penalty area and tries to spin round Phil Bardsley, but the defender sticks close to the striker and does well to out-muscle him. He then tries to burst away on a marauding run, but De Bruyne is there to stop it with a hefty shoulder-barge.

Jonathan Walters is dispossessed on the halfway line, allowing De Bruyne to pick up the ball and immediately launch it out to Navas. The Spaniard takes it down well before swinging a cross towards Sergio Aguero, but it's slightly overhit and can only find the head of Joe Allen.

Leroy Sane is able to get on the ball for the first time this evening and immediately ploughs down the left flank, but he's unable to beat Ryan Shawcross and loses out to the defender on the right-hand side of the penalty area. The two then battle for the ball once again further down the wing, and, once again, it's the Stoke centre-back who comes out on top.

Great chance for Mame Biram Diouf! Erik Pieters gets himself into a pocket of space deep down the left wing before curling a lovely cross into the heart of the penalty area. Clichy slips as he tries to deal with the ball and allows Diouf to reach it, but the striker is unable to beat Willy Caballero with his first-time half-volley from close range.

A poor touch from Yaya Toure gifts Stoke with a chance to counter quickly through Geoff Cameron, but the Ivorian does well to close down the midfielder before poking the ball out for a throw-in with a sliding tackle from behind.

Man City patiently pass the ball around inside the Stoke half of the pitch before Jesus Navas tees up Kevin De Bruyne, who then wins the hosts an early corner. It's sent short and worked over to Gael Clichy, who decides against swinging a cross into the box and instead pokes the ball back to Aleksandar Kolarov on the halfway line.
We're off! Stoke get us underway, attacking from right to left.
The two sides are making their way out onto the pitch, with just a few minutes to go until kick-off.

Meanwhile, Stoke boss Mark Hughes has made four alterations to the team that featured in their last outing, with Glen Johnson, Glenn Whelan, Marko Arnautovic and Peter Crouch making way for Phil Bardsley, Saido Berahino, Jonathan Walters and Mame Biram Diouf.

Pep Guardiola has decided to make three changes to the Man City side that started the win against Sunderland on the weekend, with Nicolas Otamendi, Kevin De Bruyne and Jesus Navas coming into the starting line-up to replace John Stones, David Silva and Raheem Sterling, respectively.
Stoke City substitutes: Given, Muniesa, Imbula, Adam, Whelan, Afellay, Crouch.
Stoke City XI (4-2-3-1): Grant; Bardsley, Shawcross, Martins Indi, Pieters; Cameron, Allen; Berahino, Sobhi, Walters; Diouf.
Manchester City substitutes: Bravo, Zabaleta, Stones, Delph, Nolito, Silva, Iheanacho.
Manchester City XI (4-1-4-1): Caballero; Sagna, Otamendi, Kolarov, Clichy; Fernandinho; Navas, Toure, De Bruyne, Sane; Aguero.
There’s just over 15 minutes left to go until kick-off, so let’s have a look at how the two teams will be lining up this evening…

Thanks to their impressive recent form, Man City start the evening the favourites to leave with all three points, and they certainly have recent history on their side. August’s meeting at the Bet365 Stadium saw them thump Stoke 4-1, whilst the Potters have only managed to win on one of their previous 12 visits to this part of Manchester, with that victory coming in the old First Division before both teams were relegated at the end of the 1997/98 season.

As for Stoke, they enjoyed an easy 2-0 win at home to out-of-form Middlesbrough in their previous league encounter, and it was a victory that moved them back into the top half of the table. Despite this, it’s been a slightly frustrating month or so for the Potters, who have won two, drawn two and lost two of their last six league games.

Sergio Aguero and Leroy Sane both got their names on the scoresheet in Sunday’s win away to Sunderland, and the game against the Premier League’s bottom side proved to be another comfortable one for Pep Guardiola’s men, who have looked far more assured over the past few weeks than they did towards the end of last year. At home they remain particularly strong, with only Chelsea managing to beat them so far.

Bar a somewhat tepid contest against Huddersfield Town three weeks ago, 2017 has proven to be a positive period for Man City, who are unbeaten in their last nine league games across all competitions. A four-game winning run in the league has seen them climb back towards the top of the table, and another victory here tonight will result in them leapfrogging Tottenham Hotspur and moving to within eight points of leaders Chelsea.
Good evening and welcome to our live text commentary of today’s Premier League game between Manchester City and Stoke City at the Etihad Stadium.
news: Leroy Sane missed a great chance to score the winner as Manchester City were held to a 0-0 draw against Stoke City on Wednesday.
The Germany international, who came into the match at the Etihad Stadium having netted in three consecutive appearances, was once again a livewire down the wing.
However, he was left holding his head when he skied his shot after Kevin De Bruyne's cross escaped Joe Allen's reach and found him on the hour mark.
Sane's chance proved to be one of City's best chances of the night, with the youngster unable to make contact with a great delivery for what would have been a guilt-edge chance in stoppage time.
David Silva – introduced for the ineffective Jesus Navas – had already spurned a glorious chance 18 minutes from the end, though he did make a big difference to City's attacking play.
But ultimately Guardiola introduced Silva too late and Stoke held on for a draw despite City's desperate late onslaught.

Stoke were much quicker out of the blocks than their hosts and should have taken an early lead through Mame Biram Diouf when the Senegal forward scuffed a first-time effort straight at Willy Caballero from Erik Pieters' cross.
The visitors continued to look bright in attack and caused problems again in the 15th minute.
Ramadan Sobhi cleverly turned Nicolas Otamendi on the left side of the area and darted towards the danger zone, but Bacary Sagna made a vital intervention before Diouf could pounce.
Diouf was then involved at the other end shortly after, tracking the run of Leroy Sane and producing a marvellous last-ditch tackle to deny him a clear run at Lee Grant and the Stoke goal.
Otherwise, Stoke did a fine job of keeping City at bay, with only an Aleksandar Kolarov free-kick – which Grant saved comfortably – troubling them.

City attacked with more intent after the break and crafted a good opening early on, but Sergio Aguero – captain on the night – saw his 20-yard effort deflected just over after being picked out by Sane.

The in-form German winger then went close with a chance of his own in the 60th minute, receiving De Bruyne's cutback and blazing over from 12 yards as Silva's entrance injected a little more urgency to City's attack.

Silva went close twice in quick succession as the match approached its final 15 minutes – first agonisingly missing the bottom-right corner from just inside the box, before drilling wide of the opposite post from distance.
Aguero almost stunned Stoke at the death when slipped into the left side of the box, but the Argentinian could only find the side-netting as Stoke secured a solid point.

commentary: What a win for Liverpool! The home fans go wild as the referee blows his whistle for the final time, and it's no wonder why. They were given a bit of a scare by Arsenal in the second half but, overall, were excellent throughout as they showed what they're capable of after a poor display against Leicester on Monday evening. As for Arsenal, the defeat is a big blow to their hopes of finishing in the top four, and their abject first-half performance will be a real cause for concern.
FULL-TIME: LIVERPOOL 3-1 ARSENAL

Arsenal desperately try to push forward on one last attacking move, but they're unable to carve out a chance on goal. A thumping pass is then fired up the pitch and towards the visitors' penalty area, but, despite his best efforts, Trent Alexander-Arnold is unable to meet the ball and loses out to Cech.
And now Trent Alexander-Arnold comes on to replace Mane as Liverpool try to run down the clock.
Liverpool have made a late, defensive change, with Adam Lallana making way for Lucas Leiva.

GOAL! Wijnaldum has wrapped up the win! An Arsenal attack breaks down and Liverpool quickly hit the visitors on a wonderful break. Lallana charges through the middle of the pitch before teeing up Origi over on the right flank, and the Belgian then tees up Wijnaldum with a lovely low cross that the Dutchman immediately slots past Cech and into the bottom right-hand corner of the net.
Assist Divock Okoth Origi
The fourth official has indicated that there will be three minutes of added time.

Walcott charges forward before teeing up Bellerin over on the right flank. The Spaniard is quickly closed down by Klavan, however, and loses out to the Estonian before clumsily fouling him from behind near to the byline.

Both sides are really going for it at the moment, as both can clearly sense an opportunity to score a late goal. Arsenal have increased the tempo of their attacking moves and are doing well to put the Liverpool defence under some late pressure.

Almost a chance for Perez! A dangerous cross is fired into the Liverpool penalty area and almost finds the Spaniard in front of goal, but it bounces off the back of Lallana before it can reach him and then bounces out of play.

Origi hits the post! Mustafi and Origi tangle over on the left wing, resulting in a free-kick for Liverpool. It's swung into the box and finds the head of Origi, but he sees his downward header crash off the post after beating the outstretched limbs of Cech.
Coutinho receives a rousing round of applause from the Liverpool fans as he makes way for Divock Origi.

The resulting free-kick is swung into the heart of the Arsenal penalty area and finds the head of Mustafi, but the centre-back is unable to guide his headed effort towards goal and sends it looping over the top of the crossbar.

There's a coming together in the middle of the pitch that leaves Can in a heap on the floor and in serious discomfort after his crunching sliding tackle goes wrong, but it's Xhaka who receives a yellow card for trying to get the German booked.

Matip goes close! Liverpool win themselves a corner over on the right wing that Coutinho curls right on to the head of Matip, but the defender is unable to make decent contact with the ball and sends his effort bouncing into the hands of Cech at the near post.
And the second is Lucas Perez, who replaces Giroud up front.
Arsenal have made a double change as they desperately try to find an equaliser. The first player to come on is Theo Walcott, who takes the place of Welbeck.

Chance for Coutinho! The Brazilian twists and turns just outside of the Arsenal penalty area before finally managing to get a shot away, but there's slightly too much power behind it and it sails a few yards over the top of the crossbar.

Another attempted Liverpool attack comes to an end and gifts Arsenal with an opportunity to counter quickly, but, despite his best efforts, Sanchez is unable to make his way past the halfway line and is dispossessed by Koscielny at the vital moment.

Firmino dances his way into the left-hand side of the Arsenal penalty area on a great run as he brushes off several tackles. He then tries to tee up Mane, but he's unable to get the ball to reach the Senegalese midfielder and Arsenal just about hold on.
Can cynically blocked Sanchez in the build-up to Arsenal's last attacking move, and he becomes the latest player to enter the referee's book as a result.

Another attempted Liverpool attack breaks down, allowing Arsenal to hit them on a quick counter. Sanchez flies through the middle of the pitch before teeing up Welbeck, who then fires the ball over to Bellerin, but the Spaniard's low cross into the box is poor and fails to find a way past Klavan.

Liverpool work the ball around really nicely as they try to carve open the Arsenal back line with a quick attacking move, but it's brought to an end by a disappointing shot from Clyne that sails comfortably over the top of the crossbar.

Bellerin breaks into the right-hand side of the Liverpool box on a wonderful run as he heads towards the byline. He spots a run from Sanchez into the penalty area and quickly tries to set up the Chilean, but Clyne is there to make sure that the attacking midfielder can't reach the ball.

Firmino and Milner try to play a quick one-two between themselves as they attempt to find a way down the left wing, but, once again, Mustafi is there to deal with the danger with a well-timed sliding tackle.

Vital interception by Mustafi! Mane and Coutinho link up really well once again before the Brazilian fizzes a dangerous pass across the face of goal, but Mustafi is just about able to stick out a foot to stop it from reaching a red shirt.

Arsenal immediately win the ball back from the restart and push forward once again, but they're unable to carve out a chance on goal and a cross from the left flank is instead curled straight into the hands of Mignolet.
Sanchez has made a big impact after coming off the substitutes' bench, and it was his pace and trickery that helped set up Welbeck to get Arsenal back into the game.

GOAL! Arsenal have pulled one back! After dealing with the danger at one end, the visitors fly forward at the other. Sanchez sprints through the middle of the pitch and towards the penalty area before teeing up Welbeck with a delightful through-ball, and the forward then chips a lovely shot over Mignolet and into the back of the net.

Xhaka is caught in possession by Coutinho over on the right flank, allowing Liverpool to push forward once again. The Brazilian cuts inside from the wing and then tees up Firmino, but the latter is unable to find a way past Bellerin and is out-muscled by the right-back.

Coutinho steps up and shoots from the free-kick, but it fails to find its way through the wall of yellow camped just inside the penalty area. The ball then bounces out to Wijnaldum, but the Dutchman's follow-up lacks the power needed to trouble Cech.

Coutinho weaves his way towards the Arsenal box on a wonderful run before being hauled down by Monreal, and now it's Liverpool who have been presented with a free-kick in an incredibly dangerous position. Can they make it count?

Iwobi is tripped over by Can as he cuts inside from the right wing, resulting in a free-kick for Arsenal in a promising position. It's chipped in by Xhaka and almost finds Giroud, but the Frenchman is unable to make decent contact with the ball in front of goal before being flagged offside.

Firmino spins round Koscielny with ease after latching on to a chipped pass into the Arsenal penalty area from Mane, but the Brazilian is unable to wrap up a great move by beating Cech and instead fires his close-range shot straight into the hands of the goalkeeper.

Wonderful save by Mignolet! Arsenal come back once again, this time through Monreal. The full-back gets himself into a pocket of space over on the left wing before swinging a cross right on to the head of Giroud, but the striker's bullet header is somehow clawed away by an acrobatic stop from Mignolet.

Sanchez makes an immediate impact as he skips down the left flank and curls a dangerous cross into the heart of the Liverpool penalty area, where Mignolet is just about to get a hand to the ball to push it away from Iwobi's head.
Arsenal have made a substitution during the half-time, with Alexis Sanchez unsurprisingly coming on to take the place of Coquelin.
We're underway once again!
The two teams are making their way back out on to the pitch ahead of the start of the second half.

It's been a near-perfect first half for Liverpool, who head down the tunnel with a well-deserved two-goal lead against a very lacklustre Arsenal side. The visitors have created very little going forward, leaving the Liverpool back line with almost nothing to do so far. At the other end, meanwhile, the Reds' front line has been on fire, with Coutinho, Firmino and, in particular, Mane all causing plenty of problems in front of goal.
HALF-TIME: LIVERPOOL 2-0 ARSENAL

Coutinho causes plenty of problems for the Arsenal defence as he twists and turns on the edge of the penalty area, but he's unable to hit the target with his shot and isnread sends it off an outstretched foot and wide of the near post.
The fourth official has indicated that there will be two minutes of added time.

What a chance for Coutinho to make it 3-0! Lallana charges into the Arsenal half of the pitch before lifting a deflected pass over the head of Mustafi and on to the foot of Coutinho. The Brazilian takes a quick touch before shooting from close range, but it's well smothered by Cech in the middle of the goal.

Liverpool break forward on yet another attacking move as they try to pile further misery on a struggling Arsenal back line, but Lallana's pass into the penalty area and towards Coutinho is slightly overhit and is shepherded out of play by Koscielny.
