Livermore bursts forward and slides the ball into Rondon on the move. The forward breaks into the box, but Martins Indi times his challenge to perfection to stop his progress.
A decent start to the game from both teams. West Brom are ahead and naturally will be the happier of the two sides, but the Potters are carrying a threat themselves.

CHANCE! Chadli causes havoc on the left and there a mild claims for a penalty as the ball strikes Shawcross. Brunt takes over from the deflection and whips the ball across the face of goal, but Morrison and Rondon both fail to connect inside the six-yard box.
Pieters raids down the flank for the visitors and sends a deep cross to the back post that McAuley heads towards his own goal, but Foster is able to gather under pressure.
Stoke press to get back into the game and a cross causes havoc in the box. Arnautovic aims to pounce, but he scuffs his effort at goal, allowing Foster to gather.

GOALLL!!! WEST BROM TAKE THE LEAD! The Baggies are ahead as Morrison notches his second goal of the week. He times his run to perfection through the middle of the Stoke defence to collect Chadli's pass and beats Grant with a left-footed effort into the bottom corner.
Chadli slides a delightful throughball for Morrison and the midfielder does the rest with a neat finish.
Dawson has to take action at the back to clear the danger from an Allen cross into the box. The Baggies then are alert to head the ball away from the resulting corner.
OFFSIDE! Rondon puts the ball into the net, but is offside as he converts from close range. Phillips' shot caused havoc in the box, but the forward did stray beyond the last man.
Brunt bursts forward into space and plays the ball into the channel for Rondon to chase. However, the ball has too much pace for the striker to keep in play as it heads out for a goal-kick.
We're underway at The Hawthorns.
The players are out on the pitch, so we should be underway shortly.
The two sides played out a 1-1 draw at the bet365 Stadium earlier this term, but in their last meeting at The Hawthorns Jonny Evans scored a late winner to secure the three points for West Brom.
STAT ATTACK! West Brom are unbeaten in their last four matches against Stoke, winning three of the contests.
Stoke are unchanged from their draw against Everton. Crouch retains his place leading the line, despite the presence of Berahino along with Wilfried Bony and Mame Biram Diouf on the bench.
Yacob is missing from the bench today due to a suspected appendicitis. He was taken to hospital yesterday and as a result in unable to play.

Pulis has made one change to his side that drew during the week against Boro. Jake Livermore makes his full debut for the Baggies following his move from Hull City, replacing Claudio Yacob in front of the back four alongside skipper Darren Fletcher.
Saido Berahino only makes the bench against his former club. There is no love lost between the Baggies and the forward, who would love dearly to score against Pulis' men this afternoon.
Stoke subs: Muniesa, Berahino, Bony, Diouf, Imbula, Given, Ngoy.
STOKE (4-2-3-1): Grant; Bardsley, Shawcross, Martins Indi, Pieters; Whelan, Adam; Afellay, Allen, Arnautovic; Crouch.
West Brom subs: Olsson, Robson-Kanu, Wilson, Myhill, McClean, Leko, Field.
WEST BROM (4-2-3-1): Foster; Nyom, Dawson, McAuley, Brunt; Livermore, Fletcher; Chadli, Morrison, Phillips; Rondon.
The team news has been announced and we'll start with the home side.

Peter Crouch scored his 100th goal in the Premier League during the week, but it was not enough to secure a victory against Everton. Ryan Shawcross' own goal handed the Toffees a share of the spoils, but Stoke still extended their unbeaten run in the top flight to four matches.

The Baggies kept up their solid run in the current campaign with a point on the road against Middlesbrough during the week. Tony Pulis' men have lost just once in their last five matches in the league ahead the visit of one of his former clubs, who are right behind them in the table.
Good afternoon and welcome to the live commentary of the Premier League clash between West Brom and Stoke at The Hawthorns.
news: Tony Pulis preserved his fine record against former club Stoke City as West Brom edged to a 1-0 Premier League win at The Hawthorns on Saturday.
The Baggies manager is unbeaten against Stoke since leaving the club for a second time in May 2013 and secured a tight victory through James Morrison's early strike.
Morrison netted his second goal of the week in the sixth minute, having struck at the same stage of a 1-1 draw at Middlesbrough on Tuesday.
While West Brom's momentum had been interrupted by a swift equaliser on that occasion, Stoke could make nothing of their first-half possession as the hosts instead created a number of chances.
Pulis' men were not quite so dominant after the interval, but Stoke's struggles continued and Saido Berahino, emerging from the bench against his former employers, made little impact.
With West Brom able to see out the result with relative ease, they extended the gap between the two sides to seven points and consolidated eighth place in the table.
Morrison should have added a second when he failed to prod Chris Brunt's inviting cross on target, while Grant held from Darren Fletcher's low shot.
As the hosts continued to counter at pace, Grant had to be at his best to keep out Salomon Rondon's powerful strike, before Matt Phillips saw an effort deflected narrowly over.
Stoke's maiden opening finally arrived in the final minute of the first half, but Joe Allen directed Marko Arnautovic's delivery straight at Ben Foster.
Charlie Adam and Phil Bardsley both fired over after the break, while the latter also tested Foster, and Mark Hughes then introduced Berahino and Mame Biram Diouf to add further attacking impetus.
However, it was James McClean, another substitute, who almost made a telling contribution at the other end as he forced Grant into a fine save with a drive from distance.

Erik Pieters missed a golden opportunity to level the scores, screwing a header across the face of goal as he met a cross unopposed, and West Brom were able to see out the closing stages to claim maximum>

commentary: And that will do it from the Liberty Stadium as Paul Clement's first match in charge of Swansea ends in a comprehensive defeat to Arsenal. Two own goals either side of strikes from Giroud and Sanchez did the damage. The Gunners move back into the top four provisionally, while relegation still stares the Swans in the face. That's it from me, thanks for joining.
Koscielny comes off second best in an aerial challenge with McBurnie and needs some attention from the physios. That may well bring us to the end of this match as the defender jogs off.
Into the dying moments of this game and the result has not been in doubt for some time. It's almost been a perfect trip to Wales for Arsenal, but they will wait anxiously on news of Giroud's injury.

Arsenal's attack in the last few minutes has turned into a Xhaka shooting gallery. As the defence has collapsed around their attackers, the Swiss midfielder is often the spare man at the top of the box, but his latest effort is swallowed by Fabianski.

There was a chance for Swansea to overload Arsenal there with Borja on the ball, but they fail to cash in on their momentum and the defence can get back to restrict Sigurdsson to a low shot into the arms of Cech.

Poor from Swansea again. McBurnie makes the first mistake by not playing the ball inside the full-back for Borja to attack. Then, the Spaniard tries to follow that up with a poor run down the right, where he's caught offside.
Arsenal have a chance to make it 5-0 as Xhaka puts some power behind a drive, but Fabianski is equal to it with a smart hold. The Polish keeper has done well all things considered.
Sanchez is making a point of showing his displeasure at being substituted. It's all a bit petulant from the Chilean, and will do nothing to smooth over his well-publicised contract negotiations.
Swansea attempt to get some consolation on the scoreboard, as McBurnie makes a good run down the left, but his low cross is missed by both Borja and Fer. That sums up the hosts in this game.
Danny Welbeck also gets a run out as Sanchez departs.
Lucas Perez appears in place of Ozil.
Ramsey is caught late by Fer, who is shown a yellow card.
How about Alexis Sanchez though? That's 14 goals in the Premier League for him this season - no one else has scored more. He didn't sulk at playing wide this evening, and got his reward.

Swansea continue to ship goals by the barrel. That's one shy of a half-century of goals they've conceded in their 21 games so far. It's surely the first thing that Clement has to address if they're to survive.

Sanchez makes it four! Iwobi's clever ball to Oxlade-Chamberlain sees the winger cut it back to Ramsey, and while Routledge makes a good challenge, the Chilean is there to pick up the pieces inside the area!
Cork's game is at an end as Oliver McBurnie replaces him.
How do you account for situations like that? Two own goals in the second half have surely put this match beyond Swansea's reach. It's quite the macabre start to Clement's tenure.
More changes for Swansea as Borja is on for Llorente.

AND THAT'S THREE! Another own goal against Swansea, and this time it's Naughton as the unlucky character. Ozil's ball to Iwobi sees the youngster size up his marker before flinging the ball into the six-yard area, where the defender turns it into his own net.
Some signs that Swansea's interest in this game is not quite put to bed as they create two solid chances in the past few minutes. However, moments later, they're nearly undone on the counter.
Swansea create another shooting opportunity as the ball drops kindly for Fernandez inside the area as Arsenal fail to clear, but he leans back and slides the ball well over the target.
Swansea break forward for probably the first time in the second half, as Routledge takes down a bouncing ball and unleashes a decent strike that draws a comfortable low save out of Cech.
Belated withdrawal for Giroud as Oxlade-Chamberlain comes on.
Arsenal sense the chance for more here as Granit Xhaka's low pass into Giroud is nearly flicked into the path of Sanchez, but a shoddy first touch ends the momentum of that attack.

Big sigh of relief from the Arsenal bench as they open up a cushion against Swansea. They've been far from their peak, and both goals have been scrappy at best, but they have the inside line on three points now.
Nathan Dyer has been withdrawn for Leroy Fer.

ARSENAL DOUBLE THEIR LEAD! Poor Fabianski, there was nothing that he could do about that. The Gunners made their own luck though, forcing the issue in the box and Iwobi's low ball is looped over the keeper by Jack Cork's deflection.
Some more pressure engineered by Sanchez sees the ball pinned in the Swansea area, before the Chilean squeezes in a pass to Ramsey, whose close-range shot is saved by Fabianski!

Swansea are searching for a way back into the game, but they just have to be careful that they don't leave too much space in behind for Arsenal to break, as Sanchez has just very nearly done a couple of times.
No change for Arsenal at the break, as Giroud has appeared for the second half. Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain has been warming up since the first period, and continues to do so on the sidelines.
Off we go again!

And that's half time at the Liberty Stadium with Swansea and Arsenal separated by a Giroud goal from close range. It's not been a classic by any stretch, but Clement will be satisfied with the energy of his side in midfield to force the Gunners into a few turnovers. A lot to play for still. Stay tuned.

SLICED OVER! There's still plenty of life in Swansea, as yet another loose pass from Arsenal presents Nathan Dyer with the ball on the right, but the wide man shows no composure and lashes it over the bar.

DRAMA! Big call from the referee as Ki goes down in the area when trying to attack a flick from Llorente. Replays show that there was a bit of contact from Koscielny, but the Korean did go down easily, and he's booked for diving. Close call!

From joy to worry in a matter of minutes. Giroud and Arsenal have been flip-flopping on bringing him off or waiting until half-time to assess the damage of his injury. It's worth noting that he didn't even celebrate his goal - instead signaling for a substitution.

How about Giroud - that's five goals in as many games for him now, and every one of those has been crucial. He always seems to respond best when his place as a striker is under threat. He's not moving well here though as he appeared to pick up a knock after that goal.
A real test of character for Swansea now. They were enjoying a strong spell of possession before conceding that goal, and it will be interesting to see how they respond to adversity.

GIROUD OPENS THE SCORING! The Frenchman misses a tap-in after a scything Gunners counter, but Sanchez picks up the pieces, crossing for Ozil whose header was blocked, but the striker stroked home the rebound!

Arsenal try to launch that little move that they like so much, when an attacking midfielder, in this case Ozil, plays a one-two with Giroud at the top of the box. However, the Frenchman's return pass to the German is cut out.

Nothing between the sides so far with a little over 10 minutes to go until half time. You get the sense that Arsenal are getting more comfortable on the ball though, with Swansea forced to do a bit of defending.

Terrible. Arsenal launch what looked like a swift and troubling counter, with Ramsey charging and exchanging passes with Ozil down the left. However, he tries to hook the ball over the top for Giroud, who didn't even attempt to touch the ball as he was returning from an offside position.

STINGER! Arsenal are on the attack for the first time in a long while, as Alex Iwobi lays the ball off to the corner for Sanchez, who cuts inside onto his right boot and warms the palms of Fabianski at the near post.

Nearly three seasons on and Arsenal still haven't quite figured out how to get the best out of Sanchez and Giroud at the same time. The Chilean has looked better through the centre this season, but the Frenchman's recent form means that he can't be left out.
Mustafi has been poor from open play, and he gives the ball away to Sigurdsson, but the home side can't quite profit as the ball from the former Tottenham man hands possession right back to Arsenal.

It seems like Mustafi and Koscielny are taking it in turns to challenge Llorente whenever the ball is in the air. Swansea are winning a lot of 50-50's, but are struggling to hold the ball in the final third.

The game has entered a bit of a stagnant period, with both sides trading spells in possession but accomplishing little on the ball. The two target men, Giroud and Llorente, aren't involved in the game much.
Right on cue, a rainbow stretches over the Swansea end of the Liberty Stadium. Is that a metaphor for a new dawn under Clement after the doom and gloom that has been their 2016-17 so far?
Like they did against Crystal Palace and Bournemouth, the Arsenal defence are rocking, as Laurent Koscielny's back-header sells Mustafi short, forcing him to concede a corner under pressure.

OVER THE BAR! First Gabriel then Shkodran Mustafi fail to keep the ball out on the right, and the home side can pounce, with Sigurdsson played in at the top of the box, lashing a shot well over the top.
Clement is not alone in the Swansea dugout of course. Joining him is Claude Makelele, who has returned to the Premier League as the assistant manager of the Welsh club.
FIRST SAVE OF THE GAME! Kyle Naughton gets the ball at the corner of the box and he eschews a cross to Llorente to lash a shot across the body of Petr Cech, who stretches to make a fine stop.

Swansea are knocking it around with some confidence here, and they've already picked off a couple of slack Arsenal passes in midfield. That's where the wide men need to stretch the visitors as Llorente isn't likely to break beyond the defence.
The referee lets a rough challenge in midfield ride, and Aaron Ramsey can come away with the ball, but a pass out wide to Sanchez goes out of play. A little sloppy from Arsenal to start.

Ozil, back in the Gunners team today, scampers down the left channel and cuts a head-height ball back for Sanchez to attack, but Federico Fernandez manages to get there first to make an important clearance.

Good start this by Swansea, although a few attempts to play the ball into the feet of Llorente sees the big striker crowded out. As good as he is with his back to goal, the hosts will also want him making runs into the box to get on the end of crosses.
Off we go!

Mesut Ozil has been ill for the last three games, but is back to full strength to displace Francis Coquelin in the starting XI. Olivier Giroud also heads the attack after his tie winner against Preston in the FA Cup, while Gabriel fills in at right-back.

Neil Taylor and Jay Fulton both make way in the Swansea XI, with Stephen Kingsley and Kieran Dyer taking their places. Fernando Llorente starts up top, with Gylfi Sigurdsson and Wayne Routledge also in attacking midfield.
Arsenal subs: Ospina, Lucas, Oxlade-Chamberlain, Holding, Welbeck, Reine-Adelaide, Maitland-Niles.
Arsenal (4-2-3-1): Cech; Gabriel, Mustafi, Koscielny, Monreal; Ramsey, Xhaka; Sanchez, Ozil, Iwobi; Giroud.
Swansea subs: Van der Hoorn, Fer, Borja, Nordfeldt, Angel Rangel, Fulton, McBurnie.
Swansea (4-2-3-1): Fabianski; Naughton, Fernandez, Mawson, Kingsley; Ki, Cork; Dyer, Sigurdsson, Routledge; Llorente.

After a poor December where Arsenal lost two games and dropped out of the top four, their form has picked up somewhat around the turn of the new year. They've won three of four in all competitions, although that run includes the strange 3-3 draw against Bournemouth.

Clement is Swansea's third manager this season, replacing Bob Bradley, who was sacked after only 11 games. The first of those was also against Arsenal, where they narowly fell 3-2. With the Swans second from bottom, survival is definitely the mantra.

Hello and welcome to our live coverage of the Premier League match between Swansea and Arsenal the Liberty Stadium. Paul Clement takes charge of his first league match at the helm of the Welsh outfit, while the Gunners are looking to get back into the top four.
news: Arsenal put pressure on their fellow Premier League title challengers as they secured a 4-0 victory against Swansea City on Saturday.

Paul Clement, who took over as Swans head coach on January 3, said Arsenal were appropriate opponents for his first league game in charge given the scouting report he had compiled on them while at Bayern Munich, but all his careful planning was undone by ill-fortune and dismal defending.
Swansea had matched the Gunners' intensity early on but a loss of concentration allowed Giroud to turn in from close range after the returning Mesut Ozil's header was not cleared.
Alex Iwobi killed any hopes of a comeback from the league's bottom club after the break, the Nigeria winger forcing own goals in the space of 13 minutes from Jack Cork and Kyle Naughton.

Sanchez capitalised on some more poor defending to add a fourth for Arsenal that moves them above Liverpool - who face Manchester United on Sunday - and into third in the table, five points behind leaders Chelsea.
Swansea started brightly and came closest to breaking the initial deadlock when Naughton forced Petr Cech to tip a low strike around his right-hand post.
Sanchez tested Lukasz Fabianski with a low strike but that was Arsenal's only effort on goal in a sluggish opening half-hour.
Indeed, Swansea were comfortable in dealing with the Gunners' threat, but they switched off for the first time eight minutes before the break to allow the visitors to take the lead.

Swansea thought they had a chance for an equaliser when Ki Sung-yueng went down in the area after being clipped by Laurent Koscielny, making his 200th Premier League appearance, but referee Mike Jones opted to book the midfielder for going to ground too easily.
Arsenal turned up the pressure from the off in the second half and found a crucial second goal with 54 minutes played - albeit in extremely fortunate circumstances.

The latter stages were played out at a pedestrian pace but the glum faces from the watching Swansea board said enough, as Clement suffered the same fate as predecessor Bob Bradley in his first league match in charge - a defeat to Arsene Wenger's side.

commentary: That's all from us today folks, we hope you enjoyed the game!
Despite plenty of chances for both teams, neither side could break the deadlock at the Riverside today, with both goalkeepers pulling off superb saves to keep their sides in it.
FULL-TIME: MIDDLESBROUGH 0-0 EVERTON
That's the full-time whistle!
Everton have a corner, could they steal it late on... No. Funes Mori is beaten to the ball and Boro can clear the ball upfield.
There will be a minimum of three minutes added time played here. Can either side grab a late goal?

WHAT A SAVE! Robles produces a terrific save to deny Rudy Gestede! It looked like it was flying in! Gestede met Ramirez's cross and diverted a powerful header towards goal which looked to be going in the top left-hand corner. However Robles produces a phenomenal diving save to claw the ball over the bar. Half the ground thought that was going in!
Third and final Everton substitution now with Ross Barkley coming off, to be replaced by Gareth Barry.
Gastón Ramírez receives a yellow card for a very poor challenge.
Guédioura has a good opportunity from long range, but he fires his shot well over the bar. Not the best of efforts from the new signing.
That was Negredo's last contribution today, he is coming off to be replaced by Rudy Gestede.

CHANCE! Negredo almost gets his head to the ball after the cross into the box by Traore. Robles was able to watch the ball drift narrowly past his post, but any touch by Negredo would surely have seen the ball end up in the back of the net.

Ramirez has done well for Middlesbrough since coming onto the pitch, he is drifting into the middle of the pitch from the wing and trying to get on the ball at every opportunity and link up with Negredo.

Both teams are struggling to keep possession at the moment, as a result neither side is threatening to score. Everton have had the better chances to get on the board, but have been denied by a number of great saves from Victor Valdes in the Middlesbrough goal.
As we enter the final 15 minutes of the game it is still goalless here at the Riverside. A victory for Boro here would really help them in their battle to stay in the Premier League.
Another Everton substitution as Ademola Lookman comes off and he is replaced by Aaron Lennon.

This game really could go either way at the moment! Middlesbrough have been the better team but the Toffees are starting to create chances of their own once again. Bernado almost gifted Lukaku another chance with a poor ball to Gibson, Luckily the Boro skipper is on his toes and manages to stop the striker from breaking through on goal.

SUPERB SAVE! Lookman isn't picked up in the box after a good ball into his path by Barkley. The youngster then just has Valdes to beat, but once again the Boro keeper makes himself big and pulls off a great save! Lukaku was screaming for the ball to be pulled back into his path, but Lookman tried to put the ball into the back of the net himself, only to be denied by a stunning stop.

The first thing Ramirez does is give away a free-kick in a good position! Bringing down Lookman with a late challenge. Barkley takes the free-kick and goes for goal, but he fires it straight at Guédioura. Poor set piece.
Second Middlesbrough substitution with Cristhian Stuani the man heading off the pitch, to be replaced by Gastón Ramírez.

OFF THE LINE! Gibson met the corner with a superb header, which looks to be heading into the top corner of the goal. However Baines does his job on the post and heads the ball off the line and then Everton manage to clear the ball.
Baines makes a foul throw and Boro counter! Chambers with the long throw which is received by Stuani who wins another corner for the hosts.
Ronald Koeman doesn't look happy about his sides start to the second half and he has made the first change to his side. Gueye is replaced by Enner Valencia, in a more attacking move for the Toffees.

The Boro defence have done well to limit the influence of Ross Barkley and Lukaku today. However both players can change a game within seconds, so Middlesbrough need to be careful as they continue to press for the first goal of the game. Barkley almost had a tap in, after Lukaku passed the ball across the box to him but a combination of Valdes and Gibson makes sure he doesn't get there in time.
Here is the first substiution of the game, with Adam Forshaw being the man coming off against his former side. Forshaw is replaced by transfer deadline day signing, Adlène Guédioura.
Excellent start to the second period by Middlesbrough, but they need to try and make their possession and chances count here!

It's been a while since Middlesbrough beat Everton in the Premier League! They have managed just one win in their last 12 Premier League games against Everton (D4 L7), with goals from Yakubu and Mark Viduka securing a 2-1 victory in October 2006.
Forshaw whips the ball into the box, but Everton manage to clear the initial danger. Negredo then gets his head to the rebound, but his effort is straight at Robles who comfortably gathers the ball.
Another driving run from Traore forces Coleman into making a rash challenge on the edge of the box and Traore is fouled. Free-kick in a good position coming up for Boro!
This is a very positive start to the second half by Middlesbrough. They are causing Everton a lot of problems at the moment, domianting possession and forcing Everton back into their own half.

Traore is looking very dangerous today, if Boro are to score here it is likely that he will have played a part in it. The Boro man used his pace and power to dribble past Coleman and Gueye, he then fires a powerful shot at goal but it was always going wide.
Boro have a corner within seconds of the re-start! Coleman conceding the set piece. The ball into the box is looking for Gibson, but the Everton defence do well and clear the danger.
The second half is underway!

It's goalless here at the Riverside between Middlesbrough and Everton, but both teams have had good chances to score. The Toffees have had the better chances, with Lookman and Lukaku forcing Valdes into making a couple of superb saves to keep the score level.
HALF-TIME: MIDDLESBROUGH 0-0 EVERTON
That's the half-time whistle!
Chambers is back on the pitch now for Boro, looks like he is trying to run off the ankle injury he picked up. Looks like we will be having two minutes of injury time played here as well.
Brief stoppage in play here as Chambers is down injured after his attempt to block Lookman's shot.

GREAT SAVE! Coleman once again breaks down the right, he powers past Fabio before whipping the ball into the box which is superbly chested down by Lookman, who then tries to beat Valdes at his near post. The Boro keeper made himself big and made a very good save. Lookman then has another chance to score just seconds later! This time Callum Chambers blocks his effort.

Coleman has the beating of Stuani down the right flank, the full-back is constantly roaming forward and trying to feed Lukaku in the box. Not long to go until the half-time whistle now, can either side break the deadlock?

Negredo is often being left isolated up top for Boro as the hosts try to pack the midfield. The striker is struggling to link up with his teammates because they are simply too far away on many occasions so far today.
This game is end to end at the moment, both teams are looking lively going forward but they are both making silly mistakes in the middle of the pitch which could e costly. So far no goals here.
The first player to go into the referee's book is Adam Clayton.

HE SHOULD'VE SCORED! Just as Boro looked dangerous at one end, Everton break and almost score! Bernado makes an error on the half-way line which Davies picks up and plays the ball through to Lukaku who is through on goal. The Belgian should've scored as he only had the keeper to beat, but Valdes made himself big and pulled off an excellent save.

Brilliant run from Traore! He beats three Everton players, he looks to take the shot at goal but lays it off to Negredo instead. The ball then comes back to him in the middle of the box but he and Stuani both go far the ball and get in each others way!

CHANCE BORO! There was hesitation in the Everton defence as the ball came to Negredo in the box. Ashley Williams missed the ball and Negredo got the ball to the byline before pulling it back to Stuani, however Williams gets back well to block the shot. A huge confidence boost to Boro!

Everton are starting to ramp up the pressure on Middlesbrough now, looking to break the deadlock. Leighton Baines and Seamus Coleman are getting forward from the full-back positions at every opportunity, which is forcing the hosts deeper and deeper at the moment.

EXCELLENT TACKLE! Traore does brilliantly to dispose of Lookman within the penalty box. The winger uses his pace to get into the box and is about to cross to Romelu Lukaku, when Traore times an excellent sliding tackle and wins the ball back for Boro.

Great play by Fabio down the left flank for Boro! The full-back finds plenty of space down the wing and uses his pace to get away from Seamus Coleman, before whipping a good ball into the box. However his teammates failed to get on the end of it, with Everton marking them well.
Plenty of groans around the Riverside Stadium when the ball goes backwards when in Middlesbrough's possession. These home supporters haven't seen many Boro goals here this season.
Neither side is yet to fashion a clear-cut chance at goal today. Everton saw more of the ball in the early stages of the game, but the hosts have done well and grown into the game.

First corner of the game goes to Boro. Forshaw whips the ball into the box, looking for Ben Gibson but it is well cleared. However the ball then falls to Stuani on the edge of the box, who fires a shot at goal but it goes well wide.

CHANCE BORO! Alvaro Negredo held the ball up brilliantly and layed it off to Forshaw who had made the run from deep. However Forshaw couldn't make his mind up quick enough, he tried to pass to Traore but it was blocked and then when the ball falls back to him in the box Joel Robles is quick off his line to clear the danger.

Good Everton possession here, however they need to be careful as Boro are looking to counter attack at every opportunity. Adam Forshaw just managed to nip the ball off Morgan Schneiderlin deep in the Toffees half. The midfielder goes to take a shot at goal but the shot is blocked.
STAT: The Toffees have kept clean sheets in three of their last four Premier League visits to the Riverside Stadium (losing one), winning all three of those games.
One player who has been very lively so far for Everton today is youngster Ademola Lookman. The winger is always his pace to cause the Boro defence problems.

The Toffees look full of confidence here and will be positive about their chances of taking all three points back to Mereyside tonight. However Boro are so far limiting their possession of the ball to the middle of the pitch and are keeping them away from their final third.

CHANCE! Tom Davies times his run perfectly behind the Boro backline, Seamus Coleman lofts the ball up to him and the 18-year-old is just inches away from getting on the end of the pass with no Boro defenders near him. However Victor Valdes is quick off his line and slides to gather the ball. Good stuff from Everton early on.
There is a good atmosphere here at the Riverside as Boro begin the game well, pressuring the Toffees high up the pitch and limiting the amount of possession they have.

Boro have scored the fewest home league goals this season, scoring just 11 goals. The hosts have also attempted the fewest shots on target in the league this season (56) and are the only side to have failed to post a shot on target in more than one Premier League game.
We're underway!
The teams are out and we will be underway shortly. Stay tuned for all of the match action!

TEAM NEWS: Just the one change for Boro from their defeat at Spurs last weekend as Cristhian Stuani comes into the side, replacing Stewart Downing. Plus there is a return to the bench for Gaston Ramirez. Meanwhile Everton make two changes to their starting line-up, with James McCarthy and Gareth Barry being replaced by Idrissa Gueye and Tom Davies.
EVERTON SUBS: Stekelenburg, Jagielka, Kone, Lennon, Barry, Valencia, Holgate
EVERTON (4-3-2-1): Robles (GK); Coleman, Ashley Williams, Funes Mori, Baines; Davies, Gueye, Schneiderlin; Lookman, Barkley; Lukaku
BORO SUBS: Guzan, Ayala, Leadbitter, Downing, Ramirez, Guedioura, Gestede.
BORO (4-5-1): Valdes (GK); Chambers, Bernardo, Gibson, Da Silva; de Roon, Clayton, Forshaw, Traore, Stuani; Negredo
CONFIRMED TEAM NEWS...

Head-to-head: Middlesbrough have gone eight matches without a win against Everton in all competitions since a 2-1 Premier League home victory in October 2006. The Toffees have won the last four meetings, however they have never won five in a row.

Gaston Ramirez is in contention to return for Middlesbrough after injury, but George Friend is doubtful with a calf strain. Whilst Everton are likely to name the same side that beat Bournemouth 6-3 last Saturday.

Meanwhile, Everton have lost just once in their last eight matches in all competitions - a home defeat to Leicester in the FA Cup. The Toffees now have a comfortable cushion in seventh spot at kick-off, just five points behind Manchester United in sixth and four ahead of West Brom in eighth position.

Middlesbrough welcome Everton today, with the hosts looking to secure all three points in order to put pressure on their relegation-threatened rivals. Boro currently 15th in the table, having only won once in their last nine league games and are only one point in front of Hull City who occupy 18th position. The hosts suffered a 1-0 defeat away at Tottenham last time out, but they did have chances to score and earn a draw.
Hello and welcome to our LIVE match commentary of the Premier League clash between Middlesbrough and Everton at The Riverside Stadium.
news: Victor Valdes pulled-off a string of superb saves as Premier League strugglers Middlesbrough held in-form Everton to a hard-fought 0-0 draw at the Riverside Stadium.

Ronald Koeman's side, who netted six against Bournemouth last time out, came into Saturday's encounter unbeaten in their previous seven league fixtures, but failed to open up a stubborn Middlesbrough backline.
Aitor Karanka's side had Valdes to thank when Everton did manage to get through - the former Barcelona goalkeeper at his best to deny Romelu Lukaku and Ademola Lookman either side of half-time.
Middlesbrough could have snatched the points late on, but Joel Robles - determined not to be outdone by his compatriot at the other end - did brilliantly to tip Rudy Gestede's header over.
1 - Middlesbrough have managed just one win in their last 12 PL games against Everton (D4 L7) - back in October 2006. Neutralised.

The draw leaves Middlesbrough, who face Crystal Palace in a huge clash at the bottom of the table in their next league fixture, in 15th and just two points above the relegation zone as their search for a first league win since December 17 goes on.
Everton, who stay seventh, started positively and could have gone ahead early on had Tom Davies managed to control Ross Barkley's low cross.
In a lively, albeit scrappy, opening, Middlesbrough were the next to go close - Cristhian Stuani heading over from close range 16 minutes in.
Middlesbrough grew into the encounter and only a well-timed last-ditch tackle from Seamus Coleman prevented Adama Traore getting in on goal at the end of a fantastic run.
Middlesbrough goalkeeper Valdes was called into action at the other end soon after, making a fine stop to deny Lukaku following Bernardo's error.
Valdes came to Middlesbrough's rescue again prior to the interval, rushing out to thwart Lookman from point-blank range - Calum Chambers blocking the youngster's follow-up.
Lookman did get the better of Valdes moments later as he tried his luck from distance, but his dipping effort whistled just wide of the left-hand upright.

Traore continued to impress for the hosts after the restart, weaving in from the left flank before unleashing a venomous effort that flashed across the face of goal, while Stuani saw a goal-bound header saved by Robles.
Despite Middlesbrough's strong start to the second-half, Everton got through on the hour-mark, but Lukaku failed to capitalise after latching onto Idrissa Gueye's throuhball.
Ben Gibson thought he had given Middlesbrough the lead with 25 minutes remaining, but Leighton Baines was well-placed to clear the defender's header off the line.
Valdes had to be at his best again five minutes later, sticking out a leg to ensure that Lookman's effort did not nestle into the bottom-left corner.
Middlesbrough rallied in the closing stages and only an instinctive Robles save from Gestede's powerful header ensured that Everton returned to Merseyside with a point.

commentary: Full-time at the Parc des Princes. PSG have put themselves in an outstanding position to knock Barcelona out of the Champions League at the last-16 stage as they record an emphatic 4-0 first-leg victory after goals from Edinson Cavani, Julian Draxler, and a brace from Angel Di Maria. Luis Enrique's men absolutely awful on the night. Thanks for joining us, see you next time!
FOUR minutes of added time have been allocated by the referee. Barcelona don't have to wait too much long before sprinting back to the plane to Spain as quickly as possible.

Even though Rabiot has been brilliant tonight, he has been walking the discplinary tightrope all night long after being booked so early. He takes out Neymar here and the Barca players are demanding the second yellow card be shown, but the referee waves away the protests quickly.

The Barca players almost don't know how to carry themselves at the moment. They are in a position like this so rarely that you can actually see the shock in all of their faces at the prospect of being eliminated from the Champions League so early, even with the second leg to come! Incredible.
Enrique's charges are playing ever-so-slightly better now, with the passing and intensity being cranked up a notch. However, it goes without saying that it is all far too little coming far too late.
The brilliant Draxler makes way now, with Javier Pastore given a short run out.

BARCELONA HIT THE POST! From a corner-kick down the left wing, Pique rises high at the back to recycle the ball back into the danger area. Umtiti, returning of course to the country he used to play in, gets on the end of it but only manages to crash an attempt off the inside of the post! How did he manage to miss that?!

Rabiot has just been superb in the centre of midfield tonight. Every aspect of his game has been excellent from putting in tackles, to passing, to taking on the opposition midfield with penetrating runs. Barca have not been able to handle him.

The Blaugrana finally manage to put together a nice string of passes in the final third after the break. The front three are all involved as a rarity and it is Neymar who is tasked with the resulting strike on goal, but the Brazilian sees his sliced attempt go just beyond the right-hand post with Trapp not seeming particularly perturbed between the sticks.

Barca are reverting back to what they know best, and that is the short, simple passes in the middle of the pitch. However, due to the scoreline you would feel like they would, at the very least, have to gain an away goal at the Parc des Princes to have a chance of going through. That does NOT seem likely.

With Barca now flooding men forward, PSG are going to have huge opportunities to cause more problems on the counter. On this occasion, the home side are electric with their move into the final third and it is Draxler, typically, who leads the charge, but Barca defend well on the edge of their own box.

Rafinha sees yellow now, and it is actually very harsh on the substitute as he barely clips the heels of Nkunku in the middle of the pitch. The very last thing Barcelona need now is for someone to get sent off and for PSG to have the man advantage!
Unfortunately for Rakitic, his reputation will now be blotched by this mess as he comes on for the last portion of the game to replace Iniesta.

GOOOOOAAAALLLL! GOOOAAALLLL FOR PSG! Cavani gets in on the act! Meunier, rather remarkably, goes through a huge chunk of the midfield COMPLETELY unopposed by any Barca player and eventually slips through for the former Napoli man, who lashes an emphatic finish into Ter Stegen's near post! FOUR-NIL!
A cracking assist from Meunier, but he did it without anyone attempting to make a tackle!

Twenty minutes to go in the French capital and the onslaught we were all expecting from Barcelona following the break simply has not came. Indeed, PSG look the more likely side to go on and grab more goals which could potentially take this tie beyond the Catalan side.
Christopher Nkunku is Verratti's replacement in the centre of midfield.

The PSG fans take in a massive sigh of relief as Verratti goes down just outside the centre circle clutching the side of his knee after an altercation with Messi. It does appear as if the Italian simply has a bit of cramp, but it may be something a bit more sinister which would be a huge blow to PSG. Luckily, he walks off the pitch.

VITAL tackle from Alba! Draxler causes more problems again as he shifts possession on to his left foot down the touchline before firing a low cross into the area. Moura meets it and looks poised to pick out a strike to the bottom corner, but the Barca left-back bravely comes in to make the interception.

This had been a quite startlingly bad performance from Barcelona, the likes of which we haven't seen in the knockout stage of the Champions League for many a year. The defence aren't defending, the midfield aren't creating or protecting, and the front three have barely linked up for three passes tonight. Worrying.
The frustration starts to creep in for Barca as Busquets goes into the book for a late tackle now.

First substitution of the match from Emery and curiously, it is Di Maria who is the man coming off to be replaced by Lucas Moura. The Argentine has been quite fantastic tonight, so there surely must be some kind of knock suffered or perhaps an agreement with the manager that he will only last an hour due to a fitness issue. Who knows.

The next part of bad news for Barcelona is that there is still 30 minutes to go in this game and PSG look like they are going to score basically each time they venture forward into the final third. Have we ever seen Messi, Suarez. and Neymar play so collectively bad in the same match before?!
Luis Enrique wastes little time in reacting to that vital third goal as he makes his opening change. The very poor Andre Gomes comes off and he will be replaced by Rafinha.
Great work from Kurzawa for the assist.

GOOOOAAAALLLL! GOOOAAALLL FOR PSG! This is turning into a real demolition for Barca! Kurzawa makes a galloping run down the left wing and then cuts inside before finding the feet of his team-mate. Di Maria easily cuts in past the tackle of Alba before curling a superb strike high into the top left corner! Three-nil!

Neymar, who is probably the only Barcelona player causing PSG problems at the moment with his runs from the left wing, is left hugely frustrated on this occasion as the ball cannons off his foot to go behind for a goal-kick. He was looking for the corner-kick himself, but the referee made the correct decision.

With Thiago Silva currently out injured, Kimpembe had been drafted in for his first ever Champions League start, and the young defender has been hugely impressive against what is the most attacking front three in the world in Messi, Suarez, and Neymar. Let's hope the commentator's curse doesn't strike!

So far, the second period has followed the same formula as the first with PSG continually flooding men forward for more goals. The Ligue 1 champions are clearly trying to blitz Barcelona with as many attacks and potential goals as possible in this first leg before making their way to Camp Nou in a few weeks.

Di Maria pops a lovely diagonal ball down the right wing for the overlapping Meunier who dashes forward before lobbing a pass into the feet of Cavani. The Uruguayan attempts to return the favour to the right-back with a return ball into the penalty area, but Umtiti defends well this time to make the tackle.
We are back under way in the Parc des Princes!

Half-time in Paris. PSG have been massively impressive in the opening 45 minutes as they head into the break with a 2-0 lead over Barcelona thanks to goals from Angel Di Maria and Julian Draxler. Barca simply have not turned up so far, but the second period is still to come.

Draxler is having tremendous fun out there at the moment and seems to have Sergi Roberto on toast each and every time he receives the ball on this left wing. A stepover here and there and the German is basically beyond is marker dangerously towards the byline!

What has happened to Barcelona so far tonight? Normally even when the Catalan side aren't playing well you can at least count on them to keep the ball, but their passing has been rotten at times in the game!
Outstanding work from Verratti for the assist.

GOOOOOAAAALLLLL FOR PSG! The home side double the lead! Messi is robbed of possession by Rabiot far too easily in the middle of the pitch and this allows Verratti to burst forward unopposed before releasing Draxler to the right of the box. The German makes no mistake with the finish and smashes a strike across the keeper into the corner! Two-nil.

Barca are really struggling to deal with the pace and direct running of Di Maria and Draxler so far. Sergi Roberto and Alba's biggest talents certainly lie going forward, and the PSG duo are taking advantage of the defensive frailties.

A decent period of sustained possession from Barcelona at the moment as they look to force PSG into committing an error at the back. However, even though the visitors' command of the ball is decent, the front three are still not being awarded any room at all by the opposition defence.

ANOTHER STOP FROM TER STEGEN! Moments after taking a nasty foul from Gomes, Draxler shows what he can do with a twisting and turning run down the left channel, leaving Sergi Roberto for dead as he goes. The shot is eventually squeezed out towards the near corner, but the Barca goalkeeper reads the situation well to stick out a strong hand.

The latest booking comes for Barcelona now, and it is a very nasty tackle from Gomes which earns him a yellow as he leaves the studs right on the top of Draxler's foot. A sore one for the German to take, but he'll be okay.

This really has been a cracking match so far, and normally in first-leg encounters in the Champions League teams are fairly pragmatic. However, tonight has seen both sides try and build some meaningful attacks, even if PSG are massively outperforming Barca in that department at the moment.

SAVE FROM TRAPP! Barcelona put together their first decent attack of the match and Neymar is the architect as he eats up the space with a cracking run on the left channel. Messi eventually receives the ball before threading a lovely pass into the box for Gomes, but the Portuguese displays a lack of composure as he hits a strike straight at the oncoming goalkeeper.

Meunier gets involved in an attacking capacity this time as he cleverly jinks inside the tackles of Neymar and Alba before sending another, low cross into the box. Cavani lurks around looking for any loose balls, but on this occasion the Barca defence defend well and clear with a few passes forward.

We are just beyond the midway point of the first half now and Barcelona are still to get going with their usual, patient passing game. Yes, the ball is being popped around, but it is coming with an uncharacteristic lack of movement from Neymar, Suarez, and Messi up top. Really not like that attacking trio!

We get our first meaningful glimpse of Messi as the talented Argentine skips past a couple of challenges on the edge of the area before squaring a pass wide to Gomes. The former Valencia man attempts to bulldoze his way through the middle of the defence, and very nearly manages to do so, only for Draxler to clear just before the shot is made.

Some slightly worrying scenes for Barcelona here as Neymar has not looked comfortable at all for five minutes or so. He previously went down clutching his foot only to get up and tie his boot laces, but at the moment he is receiving treatment from the physio. It would be a blow to lose him, but let's see if he can soldier on.

GOOOOOAAAALLLLL FOR PSG! The hosts take the lead! From the Umtiti foul, Di Maria steps up to hit the subsequent set-piece and curls a beauty of a strike into the top right corner! Outstanding! One-nil.

Di Maria has been everywhere in this first half and pops up this time down the right-hand side. He typically cuts inside on his left foot before flashing a pass into the feet of Draxler, but before the German can turn to make his way into the box he is needlessly scythed down by Umtiti, who unsuccessfully protests his innocence. Free-kick to the hosts.

Neymar collects the ball down the left wing this time as he hugs the touchline. The Brazilian then leaves Meunier for dead with a scintillating bit of pace before cutting inside on his right foot, only to find that PSG have recovered well at the back, meaning the passing opportunities are limited.

Barca really need to sort themselves out here as at the moment they are contributing to their own downfall with lackadaisical play at the back. As we all know, they will relentlessly stay to their formula of passing out of defence, but it really is inviting PSG to press as high as possible.

SAAAAAVE FROM TER STEGEN! Rabiot glides through the middle with ease and opens up his considerable stride before releasing a perfect cross into the box for Matuidi. The PSG captain for the night drives forward and manages to get the strike away despite the attentions of Umtiti, but the Barca stopper pulls out a cracking stop with his right hand! That looked a certain goal.

An impressive opening to proceedings from PSG who have clearly been instructed by Unai Emery to take the game to Barca with a high-tempo in the early stages. Ter Stegen in particular is being put under constant pressing from the frontline of the hosts, and doesn't look massively comfortable under the attention.

IMPORTANT BLOCK FROM SERGI ROBERTO! Cavani peels away at the back post and chests down with an assured touch after latching on to a diagonal cross. The Uruguayan then pulls the trigger with an attempt aimed towards the near corner, but the Barca defender comes in with the vital interception before Di Maria blazes over.

Outstanding work from Ter Stegen as the German proactively comes way off his line to intercept a ball through which Matuidi strives to get on the end of. Barca actually got themselves into a bit of a mess there, but were bailed out impressively by their man between the sticks.

We are only three minutes into the game but already we have our opening booking. Deservedly so, too, as Rabiot completely takes out Neymar down the left wing after the Brazilian had opened up his stride with a lung-bursting run into space.
We are under way in the French capital! Who can take the first-leg advantage?
The teams are making their way to the pitch and we are almost ready for kick-off!
Barcelona subs: Cillessen, Rakitic, Denis Suarez, Rafinha, Alcacer, Digne, Mathieu.
Barcelona (4-3-3): Ter Stegen; Sergi Roberto, Pique, Umtiti, Alba; Iniesta, Andre Gomes, Busquets; Messi, Suarez, Neymar.
PSG subs: Areola, Maxwell, Aurier, Lucas Moura, Pastore, Ben Arfa, Nkunku.
PSG (4-3-3): Trapp; Meunier, Marquinhos, Kimpembe, Kurzawa; Verratti, Rabiot, Matuidi; Di Maria, Cavani, Draxler.
TEAM NEWS...

Luis Enrique and his charges were comprehensive winners of Group C up against Manchester City, Borussia Monchengladbach, and Celtic, with the only dropped points coming in an away defeat against the Premier League side. They will fancy their chances against PSG as they have managed to find the back of the net in every tie in history between the two.

In the group stage, PSG were in alongside Basel, Ludogorets, and the eventual group winners, Arsenal. Unai Emery's outfit made an impressive start to the competition proper and took a commanding lead of the table, but a disappointing 2-2 draw against the Bulgarian side in the last fixture in December ultimately extinguished their chances of finish top, leading the way to a fixture against Barcelona in the process.

Overall in the tournament, PSG have faced the Catalan side three times in the knockout stages. The Ligue 1 outfit narrowly ran out winners in the quarter-finals in 1995, but the two subsequent fixtures in 2013 and 2015 have belonged to Barcelona with the latter in particular damaging to PSG as over two legs the aggregate score ended up being 5-1 in favour of the Blaugrana.

Europe's premier club competition is back, and what a way to kick-off the knockout stages than with a meeting of two of the tournament's juggernauts. PSG and Barca are no strangers to each other at this stage of the Champions League in recent seasons, and revenge is certainly on the cards for the French outfit.
Good evening football fans! Welcome to LIVE coverage of the UEFA Champions League last-16 first-leg encounter between Paris Saint-Germain and Barcelona from the Parc des Princes.
news: Angel Di Maria soaked up the love and adoration of the Paris Saint-Germain faithful as his brilliant brace inspired a rampant 4-0 Champions League triumph over Barcelona.

PSG were knocked out of the competition by Barcelona in 2013 and 2015 but Luis Enrique's side now require a comeback unprecedented in Champions League history having been put to the sword in the French capital.
Di Maria, celebrating his 29th birthday, dispatched a free-kick that rewarded PSG's dominant start and Unai Emery's men never relinquished their grip on the first leg of the last-16 tie.

Former Sevilla boss Emery had only beaten Barcelona once in 23 previous attempts but he was well on his way to number two when Julian Draxler scored on his Champions League debut for PSG, as he did in Ligue 1 and the Coupe de France last month.

The visitors completely failed to regroup at the break and a sublime third from Di Maria's magical left foot was followed by Edinson Cavani's 32nd of the season in the 71st minute – capping a night of almost incomprehensible misery for their esteemed opponents.

Di Maria was to the fore in the early stages, setting up top scorer Cavani to have an attempt blocked by Barcelona full-back Sergi Roberto, while Marc-Andre ter Stegen demonstrated his sharp reactions and athleticism to save from Blaise Matuidi.

The hosts made their fast start tell in the 18th minute when, after Samuel Umtiti clattered through Draxler on the edge of the area, Di Maria whipped a fine free-kick beyond a disorganised wall to leave Ter Stegen with no chance.
Before the half-hour, Neymar shrugged off an earlier blow to his foot by gliding forward from his own half and playing in Andre Gomes, who forced Kevin Trapp to save with his feet.

Barcelona's first sustained spell of pressure only served to leave them vulnerable on the counter-attack - Germany winger Draxler skipping past Roberto to be denied by his compatriot Ter Stegen at the near post.
And Lionel Messi found himself in the unusual position of being to blame for an opposition goal five minutes before the interval.

The irrepressible Adrien Rabiot hounded him out of possession with the assistance of Marco Verratti and the Italy midfielder twice exchanged possession with Draxler for PSG's showpiece January arrival to arrow home a low shot.
Half-time did little to clear Barcelona's heads as Rabiot made a nuisance of himself once more, springing onto a second ball and into a crowded area to clip a shot past the far post.
Cavani had to wait for his 32nd of the season when he failed to head in Matuidi's centre but it mattered little as Di Maria brought a raucous Parc des Princes to its feet in the 55th minute.
The move started with goalkeeper Trapp feeding Rabiot, who drove at Barcelona once more.

A combination of Rabiot and left-back Layvin Kurzawa allowed Draxler to tear at a beleaguered defence. He fed Di Maria and, as Andres Iniesta flailed in the challenge, the Argentina star curled in a sumptuous strike from 25 yards.

Di Maria departed to a standing ovation after the hour, although the brilliant but injury prone Verratti did not enjoy such a satisfying end to his evening when he hobbled off in discomfort with 20 minutes to play.
However, the last thing Barcelona needed was fresh PSG legs and they laboured as Thomas Meunier strode forward unchallenged, playing in Cavani to emphatically slam past Ter Stegen.
Umtiti headed against the post in the 83rd minute but Barcelona were unable to move beyond base camp of the mountain they must somehow attempt to scale in next month's return at Camp Nou.

commentary: FULL-TIME! Napoli crash out of the Champions League 6-2 on aggregate, after falling apart in the second half of the home leg this evening. Mertens had opened the scoring for the hosts early on, but goals from Sergio Ramos and Alvaro Morata turned things around in style for Real Madrid. That's all that we have time for, we hope to see you again next time.

GOOOOOOOOOAL! MORATA MAKES IT THREE! That is the icing on the cake for Real Madrid and the insult to injury for Napoli. The Spanish substitute fires home to make it 3-1 on the night, without much fanfare. Ronaldo saw an effort blocked, and his teammate applies the finish.
There are two minutes of stoppage time to play.
Diawara picks up a late booking for a foul on Kroos.

Napoli play their way through a congested midfield third, before Mertens cuts in from the left-hand side and runs into traffic. The hosts maintain their pressure on the flank, but Carvajal comes across well to put the ball into touch. Real Madrid are making it look easy at this point, with Isco drifting into pockets of space dangerously.

Napoli just haven't got the same swagger and zip to their play, with Real Madrid just about getting going. It is the away side who are winning the second balls and battling for possession now, it appears that the hosts are simply willing to wait for the final whistle to arrive.

Chance for Carvajal! The Real Madrid right-back marauds forward and gets to a dropping ball ahead of Diawara, but the Spaniard can only then bounce a terribly hit half-volley onto the turf and over the crossbar.

We're into the final 10 minutes in Naples, with Real Madrid going on the offensive. Lucas Vazquez finds Morata a the back post for the visitors, who then picks out Isco. The ex-Malaga midfielder opts to slow the game down and play backwards, with Zidane's men exuding confidence.
Modric is the next man to be given a rest with a glance to the weekend, with Isco replacing him in midfield.

Ronaldo sees a shot blocked! The Portugal international is found in space at the back post by a crossfield ball, but a half-volley from the Real Madrid forward richochets off Koulibaly and wide of the target to Morata. The substitute takes aim, but can only bundle a shot off a defender and behind. The set-piece is whipped into the box but easily cleared. The tempo of this game isn't quite what it was.
Morata comes into the game for Benzema, and should be nice and fresh after missing out on Real Madrid's recent visit to Eibar due to suspension.

Both coaches have looked to their benches to rest players who probably need to be fully fit for their respective weekend matches, which says everything about this contest. Sergio Ramos' brace has killed off the contest, with Sarri having to instead think about more realistic victories.
Hamsik, who has faded since the start of the second half, is replaced by Zielinski.

Benzema is picked out on the move into the Napoli box, but Reina is quick off his line to race out and gobble up the loose ball. Real Madrid are still keen to get forward, but only as a means to give their back four some respite following a tough opening 50 minutes or so.

Mertens manages to earn a corner from Carvajal on the left-hand side, which is whipped in by Callejon. Navas comes out to punch halfway clear, with Albiol happy to let the ball run entirely out of play. It all looks to be a little too late for Napoli, who aren't making much headway in this second half.

Real Madrid are happy to slow things down and waste time whenever they can, as this contest is theirs for the taking now. Napoli threaten down the right, but an eventual switch of play towards Mertens is cut out nicely by Callejon. The visitors go on the counter as a result, but Lucas Vazquez loses possession quickly.
Milik is given the chance to make an impact in the late stages of this contest, with Insigne coming off. Mertens should probably drift out to the left flank as a result.
Bale is given a rest for the last 20 minutes or so, with Lucas Vazquez deployed out on the right-hand side for Real Madrid.

Good pressure from Navas! Mertens races into space on the counter-attack for the hosts, before bustling his way into the penalty box. The ex-Levante goalkeeper narrows the angle and makes it tough for the Belgian to shoot, with Bale also tracking back well from the right wing. Napoli then win themselves a corner, but the hosts are penalised for more pushing in the area.

Napoli are continuing to see a lot of the ball and work possession from flank to flank, but Navas hasn't had much to do since the restart at all. Rog tries his luck from the edge of the penalty area for the hosts, but the substitute shoots a long way over the crossbar!

Zidane is patrolling his technical area with the same expression as when Napoli were 1-0 in the lead, he really isn't giving anything away. Ronaldo races down the right for Real Madrid, before believing that he has won a corner from Koulibaly, but the linesman isn't interested. Reina gets the ball rolling as soon as he can.

Less than half an hour remains for Napoli to pull off what would be an unbelievable comeback now, they'd need four to go through at this point. Real Madrid are now happy to slow things down, pick up free-kicks where they can, and make the rest of this game very painful viewing for what had previously been a boisterous Napoli crowd.

The atmosphere has been considerably dimmed by those two huge goals from Sergio Ramos, with Real Madrid now having some comfort in this hostile atmosphere. The noise has gone, everything has been deflated, with two dead-ball situations seeming to hammer the nails into their Champions League coffin.

GOOOOOOOOAL! SERGIO RAMOS SCORES AGAIN! The Spain international gets up well again to challenge for a corner, and manages to nod home with the aid of a rather wicked deflection. Real Madrid are flying again out of nowhere!
Allan takes his leave, with Rog coming in to freshen up the midfield.
Allan is booked for coming in late on Casemiro, though the Real Madrid midfielder made a huge meal of very little.

The hosts try and link up with some one-touch interplay inside the opposition half, but Sergio Ramos is the next Real Madrid defender to telepath the danger and make an interception. The home crowd have lost a bit of confidence, and voice, but two goals aren't beyond them.

Mertens tries to lead the charge for Napoli on his own, but Pepe steps out of the visiting back four brilliantly to rob the Belgium international of possession. The home side's belief might have just taken a knock, but they've still got goals in them. It just so happens that now they will need two in order to tie this one up.
Kroos curls in a wonderful inswinging corner delivery which Ramos attacks well.

GOOOOOOOOAL! REAL MADRID HAVE THEIR AWAY GOAL! Sergio Ramos is picked out by a corner delivery from the left-hand side, with the visiting captain rising majestically to thump home a close-range header. That is a huge blow to the hosts' come-back hopes.

The home side are still trying to move the ball at pace and utilise their highly mobile front three, with Real Madrid having little option but to sit back and play it safe. Mertens tries to cut in from the right this time, but Marcelo denies him. The visitors just aren't attacking at the kind of pace that can trouble Koulibaly and company.

Into the side netting from Benzema! The French striker is picked out on the right-hand side, despite being clearly offside, but can only chop onto his right foot and then pummel a low drive wide of the target. Reina is fuming with the linesman there. Napoli respond with a quick counter, but Marcelo covers across to defuse the danger and concede a corner - which comes to nothing.

We are underway in the second half at Stadio San Paolo! As it stands, Real Madrid are going through on aggregate, but one Napoli strike would change that entirely. Zidane's men need an away goal to ease their nerves, and fast.

HALF-TIME! Napoli have a 1-0 lead heading into the interval, courtesy of a neat finish from Mertens, leaving this tie in a very interesting position. The Belgian and Ronaldo have also hit the post this evening, with Zidane's side having a lot of work to do if they are to salvage this one. The hosts have dominate play and the chances, leaving them just a goal shy of going into the next round.
There is one minute of second-half stoppage time.

Marcelo and Benzema combine down the left-hand side, before Diawara comes across to cover and put the ball behind for a Real Madrid corner. Reina punches the set-piece delivery clear, as Napoli continue to look fairly solid defensively. Carvajal, worryingly, goes down painfully near the touchline and doesn't look comfortable at all.

Reina volleys a clearance high upfield, after a poor defensive header looked to put Napoli in trouble. Ghoulam headed high into the air, with Bale nipping at his heels, forcing the Napoli goalkeeper to race out and pump clear. With only a few minutes remaining until the interval, things are looking very positive for the Partenopei.

Sergio Ramos is forced to make a hurried clearance within his own penalty area, which results in Napoli coming straight back at them and Hamsik forcing a near-post save out of Navas. Real Madrid just can't seem to get a foothold in this contest at all. Yet again, the hosts get forward, with Allan pushing on, but Mertens is then penalised for shoving Pepe off the ball in his attempts to get in behind the opposition back four.

Wide from Hamsik! The Slovakian midfielder carries the ball forward powerfully and approaches the penalty area with intent, but Pepe puts just enough pressure on to unsettle the Napoli man. He lines up a shot, but drives the ball both high and wide of the target. The hosts are still threatening regularly.

Insigne goes on a mazy dribble down the left-hand side and manages to win a free-kick right out on the touchline, but Napoli go short rather than gamble on a ball into the box. Allan stabs a fortuitous ball forwards for the hosts, but Mertens can only race onto it and curl the ball onto the outside of the post! So close!

Napoli win themselves a corner out on the left-hand side, which allows for the hosts to load the box with bodies. Koulibaly rises well at the near post and heads goalwards, but the Senegalese defender's effort sails over the target. There's another goal still in this before the break.

Allan brings down Modric cynically in the middle of the park, but the Brazilian midfielder is only given a warning for his trouble. Real Madrid are pressing just a little higher upfield now, after their original approach gifted Napoli the upper hand. Reina has been kept fairly busy, with it being Navas' turn to have a breather.

Casemiro balloons a terrible effort a long way over the crossbar, as Real Madrid continue to fire blanks at Stadio San Paolo. Ronaldo will be wondering how he didn't manage to tie things up on the night, hitting the post in that situation is inexcusable. Napoli are just starting to lose momentum a little bit.

Mertens dribbles his way down the left-hand side and attempts to skip beyond Pepe, but the Real Madrid centre-back makes a good challenge. The visitors respond with a break upfield, which sees Ronaldo race into the box! He shoots to the near side of Reina, after the Napoli goalkeeper was taken out by his own defender, and the ball cannons off the post with the goal gaping! He'll be wondering how he missed that.

Insigne dribbles his way into space on the edge of the box, but a low drive from the Italian is gathered up with ease by Navas. Real Madrid look a little bit stunned, here, as this atmosphere may well be an additional factor on an already tough evening for Los Blancos. It is incredibly hostile.

The stadium has gone absolutely bonkers, with Napoli's fans now baying for blood. The hosts now only need one goal of their own and a clean sheet to get into the next round of the Champions League. Real Madrid have got no choice now but to grab themselves an away goal to ease their nerves.
Hamsik picks the right option and plays a well-weighted pass into the opposition penalty box.

GOOOOOOOOAL! MERTENS OPENS THE SCORING! Napoli play their way forward from midfield, before Hamsik stabs a neat and incisive pass in behind for the Belgian to chase. He scampers into the area and then fires a low finish across the goalkeeper and into the back of the net. Game on!

Bale gets into the Napoli penalty area once again, but Koulibaly stands up the Wales international brilliantly. He uses his strength well to force the Real Madrid winger out to the flank, before shepherding the ball behind for a goal-kick. Great defending.

It is all Napoli in these early stages, with Real Madrid struggling to mount anything more than fleeting counter-attacks. There haven't been too many clear-cut chances to speak of, but the traffic has only been going in one direction. Sarri will want his side to continue with this urgency, they need a quick goal.

Bale is causing the problems in the early stages for the visitors, but Hamsik is the man to track back this time and prevent the ex-Tottenham wide man from whipping in a cross. Napoli kick long immediately from the resulting goal-kick, but Mertens can't get there first. Moments later, it is Bale who threatens again after taking a lofted pass down beautifully. He cuts inside Ghoulam and onto his left foot, but shoots tamely at the goalkeeper.

Napoli continue to move the ball from right to left, and then back again, as they probe for an opening. Hamsik eventually tries his luck from range once again, but the Slovakia international drags a shot across goal and just wide of the right-hand post. Unlucky for the hosts, who continue to pile pressure onto their opponents.

The hosts continue to draw upon the support from their fans, as Sarri's men push forward with real intent. Real Madrid must be hoping that if they can close out the nervy early stages, everything will settle down. Bale drives down the right, before picking out Kroos on the edge of the box, but the Germany international can only lash a volleyed effort straight at Reina.

Zidane appears happy to allow his side to sit deep and frustrate, but Napoli aren't relenting at all. Navas is force to push the ball behind for a corner, after getting low down to his right-hand side to parry a shot from Insigne away from danger. Pepe nods the resulting set-piece clear, but the referee had already blown in Real Madrid's favour for some jostling in the box.

Sergio Ramos makes a vital interception on the edge of his own penalty area, as Callejon looked to burst beyond his compatriot. Real Madrid head up the other end and release Bale down the right, but the Welshman can only just about wriggle free of Ghoulam to deliver a cross. Benzema is the target of the eventual delivery, but it comes to nothing, with the Frenchman bumping into Ronaldo.

The away side continue to dig in and not commit too many players forward, as Napoli have this game by the scruff of the neck already. Insigne finds Hamsik on the edge of the box, but the Slovakian midfielder opts to pass wide rather than shoot. Ronaldo tracks back to get an important foot in ahead of Allan. Eventually, Real Madrid hoof long to relieve the pressure.

Napoli win a corner on the right-hand side, but Navas gets across to cover his near post well and punch the inswinging ball behind for a consecutive set-piece. The second corner is cleared by the first man. Sarri's men are forcing the issue and trying to sneak the early goal that might swing this tie. Hamsik is picked out on the edge of the area, but shoots narrowly wide of the right-hand post.

Napoli enjoy themselves a long spell of possession, with Zidane's men having little option but to sit back and absorb a bit of early pressure. Koulibaly tries to play a quick throughball over the top towards Mertens, but the Belgian striker is caught narrowly offside. Real Madrid are yet to really string a dangerous move together.

Close for Hamsik! The Slovakia international is picked out by a cut-back from the left-hand side, but slices at the air rather than hitting the target. Napoli keep their pressure on, but a cross from the opposite flank is punched away by Navas. Whenever the away side have possession, they are met with a torrent of jeers from the stands.

Diawara feeds a pass forward to Mertens on the edge of the penalty box, before the Belgian spins and sees a shot deflected over the crossbar for a corner. The set-piece is taken short and then flung into the box, but Real Madrid clear their lines. The hosts are streaming forward and showing their intent from the off.

We are underway in the first half in Naples! Napoli need to score early on to send Real Madrid reeling, but an away goal from Los Blancos could well settle this as a contest. The atmosphere is fantastic, and this should be a good one.
Real Madrid substitutes: Nacho, James, Casilla, Lucas Vazquez, Morata, Isco, Danilo.
Real Madrid starting line-up (4-3-3): Navas; Carvajal, Pepe, Ramos, Marcelo; Kroos, Casemiro, Modric; Bale, Benzema, Ronaldo.
Napoli substitutes: Rafael, Jorginho, Maggio, Maksimovic, Zielinski, Rog, Milik.
Napoli starting line-up (4-3-3): Reina; Hysaj, Albiol, Koulibaly, Ghoulam; Allan, Diawara, Hamsik; Callejon, Mertens, Insigne.

TEAM NEWS: Gareth Bale and Cristiano Ronaldo return to the fold for Real Madrid, after sitting out against Eibar at the weekend due to suspension and injury problems respectively. Karim Benzema leads the line, and netted two last time out. Toni Kroos, Casemiro and Luka Modric make up the expected midfield three, with Pepe chosen to partner Sergio Ramos at centre-back given Raphael Varane's injury absence. Keylor Navas remains in goal, despite some errors of late.

TEAM NEWS: The back four is as expected for Napoli, with former Real Madrid defender Raul Albiol partnered by Kalidou Koulibaly at centre-back. Allan is given a start in midfield over Piotr Zielinski, with Amadou Diawara playing in the holding role. Lorenzo Insigne, Dries Mertens and ex-Los Blancos wide man Jose Callejon make up a formidable front three, with Arek Milik able to make an impact off the bench if required.

Real Madrid have lost just three competitive away games since last April, but Napoli boast a home record that sports just one defeat in their last 13 matches at Stadio San Paolo. As fans have been filling up this stadium since the mid-afternoon, there is bound to be a brilliant atmosphere, with Zinedine Zidane's men needing to be switched on after struggling lately against the likes of Valencia, Villarreal and Las Palmas in LaLiga.

Hello and welcome to live coverage of the second leg of Napoli's Champions League knock-out tie against Real Madrid, with the away side travelling to Naples off the back of a 3-1 victory at Estadio Santiago Bernabeu. Maurizio Sarri's men gave a good account of themselves in Spain, regardless of the negative comments made by his club president, and will be high on confidence after beating Roma 2-1 away from home in Serie A last weekend.
news: Sergio Ramos once again rose to the occasion as the centre-back's double saw Real Madrid come from behind to win 3-1 at Napoli and secure progression to the Champions League quarter-finals with a 6-2 aggregate triumph.

The Spain international has come up with the goods on the big stage for Madrid time and time again, including in last season's Champions League final, and he allayed Madrid's fears with two goals in quick succession after the break to turn things around following Dries Mertens' well-taken first-half opener.

The match lived up to its billing in the opening 45 minutes, as Napoli took the game to the reigning European champions and caused them no end of problems from the start, before eventually halving Madrid's two-goal aggregate lead just before the half-hour mark – Mertens scoring his 17th goal in his last 16 games across all competitions.
Both sides were then denied by the frame of the goal, as Cristiano Ronaldo's Champions League goal drought was extended to six matches, while Mertens went close to scoring his second.

But Napoli were made to rue their plethora of spurned first-half chances, as Ramos swiftly restored Madrid's two-goal advantage early in the second half, before then scoring again to take his respective tally for the entire season to 10.
That quick brace left the hosts completely deflated and Alvaro Morata made the scoreline more flattering in stoppage time.

Napoli lived up to Madrid boss Zinedine Zidane's expectations with a purposeful start and carved Madrid open early on, but Marek Hamsik was a whisker away from meeting Lorenzo Insigne's cut-back 12 yards out.
Hamsik did manage to get a shot away a few moments later, though his attempt from the edge of the box went agonisingly wide of the right-hand post.
The hosts' dominance showed no sign of letting up and they eventually broke the deadlock 24 minutes in.
Madrid were dissected by a series of passes and Hamsik fed Mertens into the left side of the box, with the Belgian then coolly slotting into the bottom-right corner.
Ronaldo provided a reminder of his presence shortly after, but his effort came back off the right-hand post after he breezed into the area and skipped past Pepe Reina.
Napoli too were kept out by the post just before the interval – Mertens the one denied after the ball broke kindly for him in the area.

Madrid began the second half with much greater control and intent, and they hauled themselves level on the night within five minutes of the restart – Ramos meeting Toni Kroos' left-wing corner with a glancing header that found the bottom-right corner.
And he was decisive again moments later.
Another Kroos corner – this time from the right – proved too inviting to pass up and Ramos sent a bullet header into the roof of the net via a deflection off Mertens.
