Snodgrass is able to make his first contribution to the game after linking up well with Antonio inside the West Ham half of the pitch, but his cross towards Carroll fails to find the striker and is easily cut out by Fernandinho.
City have made their first alteration of the night, with De Bruyne making way for Fernandinho.
GOAL! Yaya Toure steps up and calmly slots a low strike past the outstretched arm of Darren Randolph and into the bottom left-hand corner of the net. City are flying!

PENALTY! It's gone from bad to worse for West Ham! A lovely pass from De Bruyne bounces into the Hammers penalty area and finds Sterling, who pulls the ball back before being clattered into by Fonte, leaving the referee with no choice but to point to the spot.
And the second is Edimilson Fernandes, who takes the place of Feghouli.
West Ham have decided to make a double substitution as they try to get back into the game. The first player to come on is Robert Snodgrass, who replaces Obiang to make his debut for the Hammers.

Antonio, who has arguably been one of West Ham's best players tonight, flies down the left wing on a great counter-attacking run before cutting inside, but he's quickly closed down by blue shirts and is finally dispossessed on the edge of the box.
There's a slight break in play after a coming together between Sane and Reid, but the two players are able to make quick recoveries after crashing into one another as the German darted forward.

After dealing with the danger, West Ham try to break forward on a quick counter-attack, but Carroll is unable to make it past the halfway line after being clipped from behind by a cynical challenge from Sterling.

Vital interception by Reid! Silva darts into the left-hand side of the penalty area and heads to the byline before pulling the ball back to Jesus, but just as the Brazilian is about to shoot, Reid sticks out a foot to clear the danger at the last possible moment.

Feghouli muscles his way down the right flank once again, and this time his cross into the City box ends up finding Cresswell over on the left-hand side. The full-back doesn't have many options but does well to pull the ball back to Noble, who then chips a pass straight into the hands of Caballero.

An Otamendi clearance can only find Reid, who then quickly works the ball over to Feghouli on the right flank. The Algerian takes a touch and then tries to pick out Carroll with a curling cross, but Stones is there to head the ball away from the big striker.

It's all City as they continue to patiently hold on to possession inside the West Ham half of the pitch. The home side are struggling to get anywhere near the ball and are instead sitting incredibly deep as they try to deny their opponents any more chances on goal.

De Bruyne weaves his way through the middle of the pitch before teeing up Sterling over on the right wing. He cuts inside quickly before firing a cross into the penalty area, but it's headed away from Jesus before it can find the forward in front of goal.

Jesus goes close! Once again, Sane causes problems over on the left wing before curling a lovely cross into the middle of the West Ham penalty area, but it's sent slightly in front of Jesus and the Brazilian is unable to make contact with the ball, despite his best efforts.

Sterling is dispossessed from behind by Cresswell, allowing West Ham to break forward on a quick counter-attack. Antonio charges towards the City penalty area before teeing up Carroll to his right, and the striker quickly unleashes a shot that is well blocked on the edge of the box.
And we're underway once again!
The two teams are making their way back out on to the pitch ahead of the start of the second half. Neither side have made any substitutions during the half-time break.

What a first half performance from City! The visitors have been utterly dominate so far and deservedly head into the half-time break with a three-goal lead. They've been helped by several poor mistakes by West Ham, but have nonetheless looked brilliant on the break. Sane and Sterling have caused plenty of problems down both flanks, whilst Jesus has put in an excellent shift up front to continually frustrate the Hammers' struggling back line.
HALF-TIME: WEST HAM UNITED 0-3 MANCHESTER CITY

Stones makes his way off the pitch to receive medical treatment, but West Ham are unable to make their numerical advantage count as City regain possession once again. They initially try to push forward before instead deciding to hold on to the ball and run down the clock.

Ouch! A long ball is thumped into the City penalty area and finds Reid in a promising position. The centre-back is unable to make decent contact with the ball before stretching to beat Stones to it, but he ends up catching the back of the defender's head with his studs and leaves his opponent with a nasty cut behind the ear.
The fourth official has indicated that there will be two minutes of added time.

A long series of City passes finally comes to an end over on the left wing when one fails to find De Bruyne, and the Belgian then picks up a needless yellow card for a clumsy challenge on Byram as the full-back tried to skip away.

West Ham are really struggling to get anywhere near the ball as they comfortably hold on to possession inside the hosts' half of the pitch. They've been excellent so far, with West Ham already looking dejected and out of ideas.

City toy with West Ham as they patiently pass the ball around deep down the right flank. Bacary Sagna then cuts inside and sprints into the box before trying to set up Jesus for his second goal, but Reid sticks out a foot to stop the ball from reaching the Brazilian.

GOAL! Another lovely piece of play from City! West Ham lose possession inside their own half of the pitch, allowing the visitors to hit them on another great counter-attack. Sane flies towards the penalty area before slotting a great pass through to Sterling, who then unselfishly tees up Jesus to poke the ball into the back of the net for his first ever City goal.
Sterling weighted his pass perfectly to set up Jesus, but, once again, West Ham were sloppy on the ball and caused problems for themselves with poor decision-making when in possession.

What a scuff by De Bruyne! A lovely pass from Jesus flies into the right-hand side of the West Ham penalty area and finds Sterling in a great position. He holds it up well before teeing up De Bruyne, but the Belgian completely fluffs his lines and misses the ball.

City have taken their foot off the pedal slightly over the past few minutes, but they're still looking incredibly comfortable in possession as they calmly knock the ball around the hosts. West Ham are trying to press higher up the pitch, however, and it's a strategy that could help them find a way back into the game.

City patiently work the ball around inside the West Ham half of the pitch before Silva tries to pick out Sane with a chipped pass into the penalty area, but Byram does well to rise high and win the ball in the air.

What an opportunity for Cresswell! Carroll battles brilliant through a sea of blue shirts before setting up Cresswell with an excellent long ball into the box. The full-back darts forward and goes one-on-one with Caballero, but, under pressure from the goalkeeper, he ends up firing his shot safely over the top of the crossbar.

Lanzini goes close! Feghouli holds up the ball over on the right wing before curling a cross over the City defence and into the path of Lanzini, but the Argentine's run forward is slightly mistimed and the linesman's flag is raised as soon as he volleys a shot wide of the far post.

A deflected cross from De Bruyne flies into the heart of the West Ham penalty area and heads towards Sane, but the German is unable to beat Winston Reid in the air and the centre-back does well to head the ball away from danger.

Chance for Sterling! Once again, Sane causes problems over on the left-hand side of the West Ham penalty area before teeing up Silva, who then lifts a cross over to the far post. Sterling rises high and does well to meet it but can't hit the target with his looping header.
Lanzini clumsily loses the ball deep down the left wing before cynically clipping Silva from behind in retaliation, resulting in him becoming the latest player to be booked.

A lofted pass is flung up to Antonio and finds the winger in a promising position, but he receives a blow to the back of the head from Nicolas Otamendi and wins his side a free-kick. Lanzini tries to test Caballero from the set-piece, but his long-range effort is poor and fails to beat the wall camped in front of him.

GOAL! It's 2-0! Sane flies down the left wing on a beautiful run as he skips past Byram with ease. He then sprints into the penalty area and beats Jose Fonte before fizzing a low pass over to the back post, where Silva is easily able to double his side's lead with a cool finish from close range.

Silva steps up and tries to calmly curl a strike into the top right-hand corner of the net, but this time there's far too much power behind the strike and it ends up clearing the top of the crossbar by quite some distance.
Jesus is also shown a yellow card after asking the referee to book Obiang. He doesn't look at all happy with the decision.

Sterling cuts inside from the right flank on yet another marauding run, and he does well to dart past two players before being clumsily fouled just a few yards outside of the West Ham penalty area, resulting in a yellow card for Pedro Obiang.

GOAL! Wonderful play by City! A sloppy pass from Aaron Cresswell can only find De Bruyne, who then bursts forward on a fantastic run. He sprints through the middle of the pitch on an excellent run before playing a quick one-two with Jesus, who sets up the Belgian to calmly slot the ball into the bottom right-hand corner of the net.

Jesus' cut-back was a very clever one, but West Ham shot themselves in the foot with their defending. Cresswell's pass inside was a risk that didn't pay off, leaving the rest of his side's back line out of position.

Kevin De Bruyne's cross from the corner is whipped into a dangerous position inside the West Ham penalty area, but Andy Carroll, who has had little to do so far, is easily able to clear the danger with a well-timed header away.

Sterling cuts inside from the right flank and sprints towards the penalty area before being brought to ground by a careless sliding challenge from Mark Noble. Kolarov steps up and unleashes a curling shot from the resulting free-kick, but it deflects off the wall and out for a corner.

A long throw down the left wing finds Sane next to the corner flag, but the German is immediately put under pressure and has to settle for another throw-in. It's picked up by Lanzini, however, and he quickly tries to kick-start a West Ham counter-attack, but City put good pressure on him to deny him the opportunity to do so.

Jesus falls asleep on the ball and is dispossessed on the halfway line, allowing West Ham to push forward quickly. They work the ball around nicely before Antonio darts down the left flank, but this time Stones comes out on top and pokes the ball out for a throw-in.

A lofted pass is thumped down the left wing and into the path of Antonio, who does well to pick up the ball inside the City box. He puts John Stones under pressure and out-muscles the defender before playing a one-two with Manuel Lanzini, but he ends up straying into an offside position as he receives the ball once again.

A crunching tackle from Byram steals the ball away from Leroy Sane and results in a throw-in for West Ham. They're unable to make it count, however, and Gabriel Jesus darts into the right-hand side of the penalty area on a great run, but his chipped pass over to Sane fails to find the German and is well dealt with by the hosts.

Sofiane Feghouli breaks down the left wing on West Ham's first attack of the evening. He picks out Michail Antonio just outside of the box and gifts the winger a chance to shoot, but his low strike ends up bobbling straight into the hands of Willy Caballero in the middle of the City goal.

After an even start to the game from both sides, a long throw-in from Aleksandar Kolarov is headed out for an early corner by Sam Byram. It's whipped in by David Silva and finds Raheem Sterling on the edge of the penalty area, but his first-time shot ends up flying several yards wide of the far post.
And we're off! West Ham get us underway, attacking from left to right.
The two sides are making their way out onto the pitch, with just a few minutes to go until kick-off.

Meanwhile, City boss Pep Guardiola has made four alterations to the team that featured in their last league outing, with Claudio Bravo, Pablo Zabaleta, Gael Clichy and, most notably, Sergio Aguero making way for Willy Caballero, Bacary Sagna, John Stones and Gabriel Jesus, respectively.

Slaven Bilic has decided to make just one change to the West Ham side that started the win against Middlesbrough a week and a half ago, with new signing Jose Fonte coming into the starting line-up to replace Angelo Ogbonna.
Manchester City substitutes: Bravo, Kompany, Zabaleta, Delph, Fernandinho, Navas, Aguero.
Manchester City XI (4-1-4-1): Caballero; Sagna, Stones, Otamendi, Kolarov; Toure; Sane, Silva, De Bruyne, Sterling; Gabriel Jesus.
West Ham United substitutes: Adrian, Collins, Quina, Fernandes, Snodgrass, Calleri, Fletcher.
West Ham United XI (4-2-3-1): Randolph; Byram, Reid, Fonte, Cresswell; Obiang, Noble; Antonio, Lanzini, Feghouli; Carroll.
There’s just over 15 minutes left to go until kick-off, so let’s have a look at how the two teams will be lining up this evening…

City comfortably thumped West Ham 5-0 when they met at the London Stadium in last month’s FA Cup clash, but they haven’t enjoyed the best of luck when it comes to Premier League games in East London. Last season’s corresponding fixture ended in a narrow 2-2 draw, whilst City have only managed to win a league game away to the Hammers once in the last six years.

As for City, they comfortably won 3-0 against Crystal Palace in the FA Cup but head into this evening’s clash without a victory in their last two Premier League games. A woeful 4-0 thrashing away to Everton was followed by a frustrating 2-2 draw against Tottenham Hotspur in which they surrendered a 2-0 lead, leaving them 13 points behind league leaders Chelsea in fifth place.

All of West Ham’s recent wins have come against clubs that currently sit below them, however, with struggling Crystal Palace and Middlesbrough the latest to fall against the Hammers. They’re yet to taste victory against a club currently lying in the top half of the table, with City winning 3-1 when the two sides met one another in their first league meeting earlier in the season.

After suffering a six-game winless run that saw them slump down the table, things have looked far better for West Ham in recents weeks. They are slowly but surely dragging themselves towards the top half, and a victory here tonight would send them above Burnley and into ninth place. It would represent their third win in a row and sixth in eight league games, their best run since Slaven Bilic took charge at the club.
Good evening and welcome to our live text commentary of today’s Premier League game between West Ham United and Manchester City at the London Stadium.
news: Gabriel Jesus starred with a goal and an assist on his first Premier League start as Manchester City romped to a 4-0 victory at West Ham.
Pep Guardiola made two bold selection decisions in leaving Claudio Bravo and Sergio Aguero on the substitutes' bench and was rewarded with only a second top-flight victory in five attempts.

Kevin De Bruyne put City ahead with his fourth league goal of the season having been set up by Jesus. David Silva swiftly doubled the visitors' lead with his second goal of the league campaign and Jesus struck himself before the break.
Yaya Toure added gloss to the scoreline with a second-half penalty, the midfielder's fourth strike for City since Boxing Day.
Guardiola's side had thumped West Ham 5-0 in the FA Cup last month and were similarly dominant here.
City now move level on points with fourth-placed Liverpool and to within 10 of leaders Chelsea. West Ham stay 11th after their two-match winning streak was brought to an emphatic halt.
Both sides had early half chances, Raheem Sterling volleying wide for City before Michail Antonio shot straight at Willy Caballero – selected over Bravo – from 25 yards at the other end.
City were rampant and Sterling headed off-target from close range after Sane and Silva had combined to create the opportunity.
West Ham threatened to respond, but Cresswell's miserable evening continued as he lashed an effort over with only Caballero to beat having been set up by Andy Carroll's impressive lofted pass.
Jesus fired wide after more good work from Sane early in a second half that started with fewer fireworks than the first.
Slaven Bilic handed Robert Snodgrass his debut from the bench, but City added a fourth before the winger could make an impact.

Aguero was given 17 minutes off the bench from Guardiola, while West Ham's hopes of a consolation were thwarted when Antonio's thumping strike was ruled out after he strayed offside from Snodgrass' pass, City cruising to victory with Caballero barely troubled.

commentary: FULL-TIME! Milan miss the chance to gain ground on third-placed Napoli in Serie A, as early goals from Insigne and Callejon are enough to resign the Rossoneri to a 2-1 defeat. Kucka snatched a goal to make things interesting, with Donnarumma testing Reina at the death with a close-range header, but the come-back proved too much. That's all that we have time for, we hope to see you again next time.

Milan are the team on the offensive in the dying stages, with Napoli happy to put a lot of players behind the ball. Suso slips a pass into Lapadula, who sees an attempted cross blocked, before Strinic scrambles the rebound away.

Lapadula is released in behind the hosts' defensive line, but the Italian striker was caught narrowly offside in the build-up. Fortunately for Napoli, the flag was up, as Tonelli came across and arguably fouled the Milan substitute.
We're into five minutes of stoppage time.

Paletta is picked out by a long ball floated in from the left-hand side, but the Italian defender can only power a header some way over the crossbar. Reina was very confident that his attempt wasn't threatening to creep into the top corner.

Napoli are happy to take their time over any dead balls, as it is clear that the visitors are in a rather precarious situation. Zielinski scampers forward, before trying to slip a pass into Mertens, but places it too far ahead of the target. His team-mate goes berserk, as Milan now have possession back.
Allan is the next man to be taken off for Napoli, with Marko Rog given the chance to work hard for the last five minutes or so.
Niang comes into the game, with Pasalic replaced, as Montella throws caution to the wind. Milan need a goal, and fast.

Milan work the ball down the left-hand side nicely, with Bertolacci bursting into the penalty area, but Tonelli uses his strength well to stand up to the ex-Genoa midfielder and defuse the situation. Narrowly over five minutes are left on the clock, and clear-cut chances have dried up.
Callejon gets a yellow card for dissent, after chasing the referee and shouting in his face. The Spaniard was clearly fouled by Calabria, but the official didn't spot it. Tempers are rising!

Milan earn themselves a free-kick on the right-hand side, with Paletta nodding the ball into the danger area as a result, but the away side clear their lines easily - with a handful of Rossoneri players in offside positions anyway. Lapadula is also penalised for jumping with his arm raised again Allan.

Napoli are plugging up the gaps in their midfield well, with Diawara covering as many blades of grass as he can. Mertens and Insigne are being left up top, with the rest of Sarri's side working back and playing quite conservatively.

Napoli earn themselves a free-kick on the left-hand side, as Gomez is penalised once again. The away side take it short, as they aren't prepared to play risky percentage football given the current scoreline and situation. Narrowly over 10 minutes remain for Milan to turn this one around.

Paletta almost makes a mistake, which Mertens tries to pounce on, but the Milan defender does just enough to scramble the ball clear. Milan have switch to more of a flat midfield five, with Lapadula working alone up top.
Hamsik jogs off for Sarri's side, with Zielinski given the chance to freshen up the midfield, after an exhausting 70 minutes of playing on the counter.
Sosa is also replaced for Milan, with the cautioned midfielder replaced by Bertolacci for the last 15 minutes or so at San Siro.
Bacca takes his leave, after a fairly frustrating night for the Colombian striker, with Lapadula given the chance to make himself a hero once again.

Milan earn a corner on the left-hand side, but Kucka is beaten to the ball aerially and the hosts get another chance to deliver from a second set-piece. It is taken short, with Sosa whipped a cross into the area, but Albiol heads away. Napoli respond with a break, with Mertens found in the box by Hamsik, but Bonaventura tracks back to make a vital tackle.

Bonaventura finds Calabria on the overlap, but a cross from the left-back is cleared easily by Tonelli. Moments later, Strinic is the target, as Milan try and lift a lofted pass down their right, but the Croatia international is equal to it. The Rossoneri maintain their pressure, but a cross from Abate is blocked.

Napoli race forward, with Hamsik trying to stab a pass into the clear for Mertens to chase! The Belgium international gets into the box with some close control, before opening his body up to find the bottom corner, but Donnarumma reads it well and dives low to his left to deny the visitors.

Narrowly over 20 minutes remain for Milan to try and claw themselves back level, but this game is incredibly open. A long ball over the topfinds Callejon, who tries to curl a cute cross to the back post for Insigne, but Donnarumma races off his line to beat the pass away from the danger zone with a big right fist.

Sosa tries to slip a pass into Bacca, but the Colombian takes a poor touch which enables Diawara to get goal-side. The Milan striker is then penalised for fouling the substitute. This is really end-to-end stuff, Napoli are pouncing on any opportunity to hurtle upfield at pace.

Milan win a corner on the right-hand side, but Reina is able to come off his line easily and gobble the ball up. The Spaniard takes his time over his kick, drawing the ire of the home fans, as Napoli need to try and somehow slow the Rossoneri momentum. Allan scampers down the right flank for the visitors, before finding Mertens in the box, but a cross from the Belgian is cleared by Abate.
Diawara is the first man to be injected into the fray by Sarri, with Jorginho replaced having previously made a high-profile mistake. That should freshen up the visiting midfield considerably.

Suso chops inside from the right-hand side, but the Spaniard can only shoot a long way wide of the target. It sails over the crossbar, with Reina having his angles covered easily there. Milan are right in this game, and one mistake from the visitors could lead to an equaliser.

So close for Insigne! The Italy international takes aim from long range, after spotting Donnarumma a long way off his line, but the diminutive forward can only dip a speculative effort onto the roof of the net. Nearly a wonderful goal.

Bacca drives into the penalty area, before taking a tumble, with Albiol bearing down on him - just as Tonelli had in the first half. This time, however, the referee views it as a dive from the Colombian, and books him.

Milan break down the right-hand side, with Abate supporting the attack, but Reina is perfectly happy to watch a cross from the flank sail straight out of play without a problem. This second half could swing either way, and the home fans can sense it. They're making plenty of noise.
Gomez picks up a booking for flying into a tackle late on the right-hand side of the Milan defence.

This game is incredibly open, with neither team able to definitively grab the contest by the scruff of the neck and dominate. Both teams are ideally counter-attacking entities, meaning that they are both taking full advantage of any opportunities to burst forwards.

We are back underway in the second half! Milan need at least two goals to stand a chance of closing the gap on third place in Serie A, but Napoli have been lethal on the counter-attack this evening. Plenty of entertainment is still in store.

HALF-TIME! The referee draws an end to a breathless first half at San Siro, with Milan pushing to try and get back on level terms. Insigne and Callejon put Napoli 2-0 up early on, before a goal from Kucka turned the momentum of the game around entirely. This game could go either way after a 15-minute interval!

Tonelli is given a yellow card, with the centre-back penalised for leaning on Bacca as the Colombia international tried to break into the Napoli penaty box. While the hosts protest for a red, the visitors claim that the Milan striker was making a meal of the challenge.
There is one minute of first-half stoppage time.

Insigne is found out on the left-hand side, and slots a pass infield, with Jorginho then opening play out to the right. He gets the ball back and shoots from range, but the Italy international's effort is blocked easily.

Calabria and Bonaventura try and combine down the left-hand side, but the former fails to offer a final ball. Napoli are happy to retain possession and slow things down as the clock ticks down to half-time, with Sarri needing to let his players regroup as quickly as possible.

We're into the last five minutes of the first half at San Siro, and this contest has been turned on its head. Milan are rushing forward, trying to press and cause problems whenever possible, with Napoli looking far less assured at the back. The away side try to counter, with Jorginho switching the ball out to the left, but a back-post cross then evades Callejon.

Napoli are now the team who will want the half-time break to swing around rather quickly, as Milan are suddenly brimming with confidence. The home fans are getting firmly behind their team and urging them on - they can smell blood.
Strinic is the next man in the book during what has been a fiercely competitive first half. The Croatian full-back shoves Suso to the ground cynically.

GOOOOOOOOAL! KUCKA MAKES IT 2-1! The hosts are back in the game. The Slovakia international helps a high press for Milan, with Jorginho giving possession away. The midfielder scampers into the box, before prodding a good finish beyond Reina.

Napoli are insisting on playing out from the back calmly, but the Rossoneri are starting to push on and cause some problems of their own. Montella's side are pressing and harrying, causing some confusion of their own. Bacca is released in behind by a neat pass from Suso, but the ex-Sevilla forward is caught offside when facing up to Reina.

WIDE FROM GOMEZ! Abate tries to link up with Bacca once again, but the Italian full-back's final ball has been poor so far. In the next attack, the centre-back is picked out by a looping cross from the left, but he glances a long way beyond the far post!

Suso finds Abate overlapping down the right-hand side, with the Italy international attempting to race forward and drill a cross into Bacca. Albiol, however, is present at the near post to slice the low cross away from the danger zone. At last, Montella's men are looking a little threatening.

The opening half an hour have seen Milan blown out of the water, with Reina contrastingly only needing to gather up a couple of easy crosses. Montella will want the half-time interval to come around as quickly as possible, as only one fleeting attack has shown the potential to cause Napoli any harm.

Big chance for Napoli! Callejon manages to beat Calabria, before finding Allan, but a ball then played into Mertens somehow doesn't end up in the goal required to make it 3-0. He has his head in his hands, as Donnarumma makes a simple save from a shot that went straight down his throat.

A few fouls have broken up the flow of play, with Tonelli and Strinic both guilty of poorly timed tackles in recent minutes. Milan try to work the ball out to the right-hand side, through Bonaventura, but Abate's cross is deflected into Reina's grateful arms.
Sosa sees yellow for a late tackle on Allan, with the Argentine getting precisely none of the ball.

Napoli keep the ball in composed fashion, with the away side controlling play with ease. Abate tries to break down the right-hand side for Milan, but the experienced full-back is quickly robbed of possession. The visitors counter, forcing Sosa to make a cynical tackle.

Napoli look to have this Milan side figured out, as Reina has had precisely nothing to do through the opening 20 minutes or so. The Spanish goalkeeper has used his feet a couple of times, but otherwise he has been entirely untested.
Calabria sees yellow for clipping Callejon's heels and coming through the back of the Napoli winger.

Callejon is causing all kinds of problems down the right-hand side, with the home side struggling to deal with the pace and ferocity of Napoli's surges forward. a few desperate fouls are being made as a result, with Calabria guilty of coming through the back of his man more than once.

Tonelli makes a mistake and gifts the ball away to Bacca, but the Colombian striker takes an awful first touch. Napoli try to counter immediately, but Calabria slides in to prevent the Partenopei's attack from turning into a four-versus-one situation.

Milan open the ball out to the left nicely, but are quickly forced long by Napoli's pressing. Insigne hares forward to close down Paletta, who promptly hoofs the ball into the stands. Sarri's men are playing to their game-plan perfectly.

Milan are seeing more of the ball, but the hosts are doing precisely nothing with it. Their back four have all of the time in the world to make their way upfield, with Napoli focusing on pressuring the second ball instead. Bonaventura crosses into Bacca, but a poor touch bounces out to Calabria, who accidentally fouls Hamsik.

Callejon goes down heavily after colliding with Donnarumma, pointing to his ankle as the source of his discomfort. After some lengthy treatment, however, the Spain international is able to get up and play on.

Napoli are looking comfortable, with their front three wreaking havoc on a Milan back four which is missing Romagnoli and De Sciglio dearly. The home side look shellshocked, they're struggling to recover from that quick double-salvo from the visitors. Mertens slips Callejon in behind, but Donnarumma races out to make a good stop.

Insigne rockets down the left-hand side, before checking onto his right foot and dipping a delivery into the area. Mertens goes down while challenging for it in the air, and gets booked for diving - that looked harsh.

Bonaventura shapes to shoot, and then hesitates, with Milan struggling to create anything. Suso tries to whip in a cross from the right, but Albiol rises well in defence to head clear. The home fans don't sound happy at all, their team have started with a whimper tonight.
Mertens has two assists to his name already, pulling the strings as the central figure of Napoli's attack.

GOOOOOOOOAL! WHAT A FINISH FROM CALLEJON! Mertens feeds a pass into the Spaniard, who manages to tuck the ball home from a very tight angle indeed. He is near the right byline, but Donnarumma is still beaten at his near post. Milan are 2-0 behind inside the opening 10 minutes!

Not the start that Montella would have been hoping for! A few mistakes have already crept into the Rossoneri's game, and Insigne has made them pay. Sarri's men are always trying to break with pace and intent, and the home defence weren't able to compete with their approach.
Mertens picks out his teammate with a searching no-look pass from the right flank.

GOOOOOOOOOAL! INSIGNE MAKES IT 1-0! Donnarumma might be disappointed there. Napoli counter through just a few passes, wiht Insigne picked out on the edge of the opposition box brilliantly by Mertens. He thumps a left-footed effort inside the far post, despite the goalkeeper getting a hand to it.

Neither side are prepared to go haring after the ball, with both sides' wingers dropping back into a five-man midfield when out of possession. Neither team want to risk making an early mistake. No chances have been created as of yet, due to a lack of adventure.

It is a quick start in Milan, with both teams prepared to fizz the ball around at pace while retaining possession. Hamsik is released in behind the hosts' back four, and passes into Mertens' feet, but the referee isn't interested when the Belgian takes a tumble. He was claiming a trip from Paletta.

We are underway in the first half at San Siro! Napoli are in the better form heading into this game, but Vincenzo Montella's men know that a victory would keep them right in the race for Champions League football.
Napoli substitutes: Rafael, Sepe, Giaccherini, Maggio, Maksimovic, Zielinski, Gabbiadini, Rog, Pavoletti, Diawara, Lasicki.
Napoli starting line-up (4-3-3): Reina; Hysaj, Albiol, Tonelli, Strinic; Allan, Jorginho, Hamsik; Callejon, Mertens, Insigne.
Milan substitutes: Plizzari, Storari, Antonelli, Ely, Vangioni, Zapata, Bertolacci, Honda, Poli, Cutrone, Lapadula, Niang.
Milan starting line-up (4-3-3): Donnarumma; Abate, Gomez, Gomez, Calabria; Kucka, Sosa, Pasalic; Suso, Bacca, Bonaventura.

TEAM NEWS: Dries Mertens starts once again as a striker for Napoli, with Jose Callejon and Lorenzo Insigne flanking him. There are no surprises in midfield. Lorenzo Tonelli makes a start at centre-back, with Kalidou Koulibaly away at the Africa Cup of Nations. Faouzi Ghoulam is also on international duty with Algeria, meaning that Ivan Strinic is deployed at left-back.

TEAM NEWS: Davide Calabria gets a start at left-back in Mattia De Sciglio's absence for Milan, with Gustavo Gomez partnering Gabriel Paletta due to Alessio Romagnoli being unavailable. Jose Sosa starts in midfield, with Carlos Bacca leading the line. M'Baye Niang is on the bench, with no huge surprises made in terms of team selection.

The away side are unbeaten in their last five games on the road in all competitions, most recently playing out a thrilling 3-3 draw with Fiorentina. If tonight is anything like that match, we should be in for a treat.

Hello and welcome to live coverage of Napoli's trip to face Milan in Serie A, with the home side having the chance to go within a point of their third-placed adversaries tonight if they can pick up a win. The Rossoneri have won just one of their last four league matches, and most recently drew 2-2 with Torino, while Napoli come into this fixture on form.
news: Two goals in the first nine minutes ensured a 2-1 win for Napoli in an enthralling Serie A clash on Saturday.
A sublime Lorenzo Insigne strike and a clever finish from Jose Callejon were enough to give Maurizio Sarri's side all three points, despite Juraj Kucka's finish just before half-time.
Napoli went into the game with only one defeat in 11 league matches against Milan and struck twice before the 10-minute mark thanks to two brilliant moves, with Dries Mertens at the heart of both.
Mertens wasted a good chance for a third before Kucka pounced on some slack defending to get a goal back, giving Milan hopes of coming back from 2-0 down for the second Serie A match in a row.

Chances came and went for both teams in a breathless end-to-end encounter, with Mario Pasalic hitting the crossbar for Vincenzo Montella's side while Mertens twice made a mess of one-on-one opportunities.

Milan continued to press for a leveller in a vibrant San Siro - in which banners could be seen showing solidarity with the victims of the hotel disaster in the mountains of Abruzzo - but Napoli held out for a win that moves them to within a point of leaders Juventus, having played two games more.
For Milan, who have won only one of their last five in the top flight, the seven-point gap to the top three is looking difficult to bridge.
Napoli needed only six minutes to break the deadlock with a spectacular piece of counter-attacking play.

Jorginho won possession and found Mertens, who switched the play first time to Insigne, and the Italy international blasted a left-footed shot into Gianluigi Donnarumma's top-left corner from 20 yards out despite the goalkeeper getting a touch on the ball.

Three minutes later and Napoli doubled their lead, Mertens this time sliding the ball through to Callejon down the right, and the Spaniard steadied himself before slotting beneath Donnarumma at the near post.

Napoli's incisive one-touch passing was causing problems for Milan's high line and Mertens wasted a glorious chance for 3-0 when he beat the offside trap to reach Allan's cross only to scuff his half-volley into Donnarumma's grasp.
Milan should have halved the deficit 10 minutes before the break but Gustavo Gomez steered his header wide when he met Giacomo Bonaventura's cross from the left unmarked near the penalty spot.
But moments later, Kucka kept his composure far better to prod the ball beyond Pepe Reina and into the bottom-right corner after their high press forced Lorenzo Tonelli into conceding possession.
Pasalic headed against the crossbar and Jose Sosa brought a low save from Reina inside the first three minutes of the second half as Montella's side pressed for an equaliser.

Carlos Bacca came inches from turning Ignazio Abate's cut-back over the line before Insigne almost produced one of the goals of the season, twisting his way into space just inside the Milan half before sending a 45-yard chip onto the roof of the net.

Reina denied Bacca following a good run from Bonaventura before Mertens failed to make the points safe for Napoli, as Donnarumma - making his 50th Serie A appearance - saved low to his left to deny the Belgium winger after he broke through the Milan defence.

Callejon became the eighth player to be booked as the game became scrappy in the closing stages, with both teams visibly tiring, but Napoli held out for a result that will give them renewed belief in their title chances.

commentary: Chelsea restore their 10-point lead at the time as another league title moves a step closer. That's all from London Stadium. Thanks for joining us and, until next time, goodbye!
Hazard was the star of the show and he netted the opener in a lightning fast first-half counter. Diego Costa added a second after the break, while Lanzini's late goal was a mere consolation.
There's no clean sheet for Chelsea, but there's no time for West Ham to force an equaliser. There can be no real arguments with the outcome as the league leaders dominated throughout.
FULL-TIME: West Ham 1-2 Chelsea.
It was the hard work of Carroll and Ayew that created that goal, the former pinching the ball from Fabregas and allowing the latter to feed Lanzini.
GOAL! Now West Ham have something to shout about - it's Lanzini! The ball breaks his way and he drills past Courtois. Surely not? 1-2.
Snodgrass leaves Kante in the dust with a smart manoeuvre, but Zouma is across to close him down. It's been a little soul-destroying for West Ham, with Chelsea's defence superb throughout.
There are three minutes to be added in this one. It looks as though it will end 2-0 to the league leaders at London Stadium.

CLOSE! West Ham have been less consistent with their crossing in the second half, but Andre Ayew now delivers. Azpilicueta, though, is there ahead of Carroll to shielda dangerous centre behind. Marvellous defending.
Chelsea again go short from the set-piece, but Fabregas' delivery is too deep. Matic retrieves the ball, but Fonte is across to wrestle back possession for the hosts.
Corner to Chelsea. Kante, again, drives the visitors forward and Willian lets fly from a tight angle on the right. His effort is blocked and runs behind.

Diego Costa is frustrated - and he may have a point. Kante slips a pass in towards the Chelsea forward, and Fonte rather ruggedly lunges into a challenge. There's no free-kick, though, and Diego Costa slowly picks himself up.

This is tough to watch for the home supporters as they start to snake back into the various concourses and the seats empty. A patient attack comes to an end when Snodgrass runs the ball across the touchline.

CHANCE! Chelsea are so methodical in their attacking, with Diego Costa, Alonso, Azpilicueta and Willian all linking up before Fabregas sidefoots over the top. A third for the visitors appears more likely than West Ham scoring at this stage.

The West Ham fans are still in fine voice, but it doesn't look as though it's going to be their day. The hosts still can't break through Chelsea, and Fernandes then concedes a free-kick on the halfway line.
A crucial interception by Fernandes straight away. Matic tees up a cross for Azpilicueta, and his delivery appears to be headed for Diego Costa's right boot until the West Ham substitute nods clear.
CHANGE! And West Ham captain Noble goes off for Edimilson Fernandes.
CHANGE! Moses has been another key performer today. He's replaced by Kurt Zouma.
When the corner finally comes in, it's easy for Courtois, who launches the ball forward for another Chelsea attack. West Ham belatedly recover.
CHANGE! West Ham will be relieved to see the back of Hazard. What a performance. On comes Willian.
Corner to West Ham. Noble dances past Azpilicueta all too easily, but the magnificent Moses blocks the low cross.
West Ham have no option but to throw bodies forward at this stage, but, every time they do, Chelsea seem to pick off the ball and counter. Hazard is again the runner, although he's soon slowed.
West Ham are slowly building forward, but there's no way through the solid Chelsea back-line. Obiang finally shoots a long, long way wide.
Chelsea take the set-piece short, with the subsequent cross half-cleared by Carroll. Azpilicueta arrives to shoot, but slices with both feet and the ball eventually trickles wide.

SAVE! And what a save! Chelsea counter, once again, through Kante and Hazard. The latter appears to have been held up, but nudges a pass through to Costa, who spins and forces a stunning low stop from Randolph. Corner.
CHANGE! And Chelsea have their own substitution, with Matic on for Pedro.
CHANGE! And it's the end of Reid's game, too, in a double-switch. He appears to be injured as Sam Byram takes his place.
CHANGE! That's Feghouli's last action as he's replaced by Andre Ayew.
West Ham appear to have Chelsea penned in, but Feghouli loses the ball and fails to track his runner. The visitors break, but Reid's firm challenge stops Diego Costa in his tracks.

BLOCK! CLOSE! Now West Ham are giving it a go! The corner is cleared, but Snodgrass is able to cross again from the left. The ball breaks for Feghouli and Moses blocks brilliantly on the line. A third dangerous delivery, from Reid, is nodded off target by defensive partner Fonte.
And West Ham quickly counter, winning a corner from Cesar Azpilicueta by the touchline.
Crucial from Fonte as he cuts out Fabregas' pass. He's been given the runaround at times by Hazard, but gets there first this time.

A worrying moment for Courtois! Feghouli spreads wide to Snodgrass, who whips in a cross that bends away from the goalkeeper and looks as though it might find the top corner. It doesn't, but stays in and West Ham keep the pressure on.
A let-off for Reid this time. He completely misses his kick and Moses is in on the right flank. The cross, though, is dealt with by Kouyate.
West Ham are keeping the ball at long last, but, 2-0 down, they need to do more than that. Chelsea are comfortable.

CLOSE! Carroll does well to bring the ball down under pressure from David Luiz, then turning to shoot from 25 yards. There appears little danger of the West Ham man testing Courtois, but his effort just clips the top of the net.
CHANCE! It's nearly three! Chelsea attack through, of all people, Alonso and Moses. The former dances past a challenge into the area on the left, but, under pressure, dinks a finish wide.
It's a long, long way back for West Ham now. Lanzini lets fly as they seek an immediate reprieve, but it causes little problem for Courtois.

GOAL! How about that? Diego Costa has Premier League goal number 49 and it's oh so easy. The corner is delivered from the left, Obiang can only flick the ball on and Diego Costa, clear of Winston Reid, bundles over the line. 0-2.

And now, just like that, a corner at the other end. Moses clears the delivery, Snodgrass is tackled and Chelsea can counter. Hazard plays a glorious pass off his back to Kante, switching the ball for Alonso to win a set-piece.
Corner to West Ham. A rare slack Kante pass presents the ball to Noble, who finds Snodgrass and his cross is deflected out.
That pressure from the visitors soon comes to an end, though, as Pedro's challenge on Lanzini is high. West Ham have a free-kick and an opportunity to start building from the back.
Hazard has already enjoyed a couple of touches in this second half, and Chelsea have the territorial advantage again as they attack from the off.
KICK-OFF: Carroll gets the second half started for West Ham.
The players are back out on the pitch at London Stadium. We're set to go again!

Rather than responding positively to that setback, West Ham have panicked a little and could be further behind. Chelsea need to be a little more ruthless with their attacks - Diego Costa, in particular, has been rather cumbersome on the ball.
It's a deserved lead for the visitors at the interval. West Ham started brightly, but Chelsea have been on top in the latter part of the half and lead through Hazard's superb strike on the break.
HALF-TIME: West Ham 0-1 Chelsea.
West Ham look to end the half with a break of their own, but Lanzini's pass is picked off by David Luiz ahead of Carroll.
Another disappointing delivery from the right for Chelsea. Hazard charges down a clearance and the ball spins for Moses, but his cross is straight at Randolph.

West Ham are living very dangerously! Chelsea counter once again, but both Diego Costa and Alonso get their feet in a muddle in the area and fail to get a shot off. The hosts have to stop allowing Conte's men to attack like that.
YELLOW! Fabregas has been quiet, but he leaves his mark on Cresswell, cutting the West Ham man's run short and taking a booking.
There will be an additional four minutes in this first half as the referee accounts for a number of stoppages.
The delivery, however, is easily picked off by Randolph. A waste.

Corner to Chelsea. Kante passes to the offside Alonso, who leaves the ball for the midfielder to chase after it and keep possession. He then finds Hazard, who plays across to Moses on the right to win a corner.
After that brave intervention, Cresswell is the latest West Ham player to require attention from the physios. That gives Slaven Bilic time to give instructions to his players on the touch-line.

BLOCK! SAVE! It's desperate stuff from West Ham! Hazard races clear on the left, crossing for Diego Costa, who cannot turn a shot towards goal. Moses, though, is steaming in and sees a low finish blocked by Cresswell, before Randolph saves smartly from Pedro's follow-up.

CHANCE! Lanzini moves through the midfield, swaps passes with Noble, and shoots high over the crossbar. By no means a simple opportunity, but, in the centre of goal 20 yards out, he should really have hit the target.
Huge tackle from Obiang! Pedro had space in the area and was working the ball onto his left foot to shoot, but the West Ham midfield dangled out a leg to take possession. Vital.

Kouyate escapes again. He pressures Cahill, then fouls the Chelsea captain, but referee Marriner does not consider it worthy of a booking. Up against the dangerous Hazard, Kouyate is certainly walking a tightrope.
Moses wriggles free on the right wing, but launches a pass for Hazard too far in front of the Belgium international and Randolph catches easily. It's all Chelsea at the moment.

While still waiting for a sight of goal, Diego Costa is becoming more and more involved for Chelsea. He fails to reach a long David Luiz pass, but then harries Jose Fonte as West Ham give up the ball.

Carroll is receiving more treatment as he continues to struggle with that earlier blow to his nose. On the pitch, meanwhile, Courtois just about avoids handling outside his area as he races out to meet Feghouli.

West Ham have lost their composure a little. Another long ball to Carroll is rewarded with a towering flick-on, but Feghouli cheaply concedes possession and Kouyate then clatters Hazard. A final warning for the West Ham man...

Chelsea are almost in again! Diego Costa threads a pass in towards Alonso, who is only just caught by Feghouli before he can get the ball out of his feet. Pedro similarly struggles to control moments later.
West Ham are just regrouping now as they seek a route back into the game. They finally work space for Snodgrass to cross again on the left, but Courtois claims.
Pedro ultimately played Hazard in there, claiming the assist with a neat one-two.

GOAL! A first chance and a first goal - it's Hazard for Chelsea! With West Ham cheaply giving the ball away from that free-kick, the visitors move up the pitch quickly, Hazard swapping passes and sprinting forward. Taking the ball finally just outside the area, he rounds Darren Randolph and slides into the net. Brilliantly brutal. 0-1.
It's Lanzini's turn to take, but he hammers into the wall and Chelsea can break...

Another important headed interception at the back for Chelsea - Carroll denied by Cahill from Cresswell's centre - but West Ham have another free-kick in a dangerous area. Hazard unwittingly fouls Noble around 25 yards from goal.
The second effort - a more rudimentary cross into the box - is overhit and Courtois gathers. Disappointing for West Ham.
Snodgrass will have the opportunity to deliver again from a set-piece as Kante fouls Carroll. An attempt to take the free-kick quickly to Feghouli is denied by Marriner.

The ball is just stuck in the middle third at the moment. Manuel Lanzini does well to pickpocket the dallying Diego Costa, but then takes on a man too many in the Chelsea half and loses out to David Luiz.

West Ham are working hard to prevent Chelsea breaking themselves, with Feghouli snapping at the heels of a visiting player - and committing a foul - in an attempt to stop Hazard from getting on the ball in a dangerous area.
The second delivery is better. Snodgrass tempts Courtois from his line, but Moses heads away and David Luiz then wins a free-kick from Kouyate.
And another corner. Carroll gets the run on Cahill, but the England defender is able to nod the ball wide.
Corner to West Ham. Snodgrass is giving Moses a tough test on West Ham's left-hand side. Crossing time after time, his latest delivery is deflected behind.

And yet West Ham immediately find a solution for that problem - a long hoof to Carroll allows Snodgrass space to cross on the break. His centre skips across the box, reaching Feghouli on the far side and the hosts keep the ball.
Perhaps wary of the sides' respective threats, both managers have their teams sitting very deep when out of possession. The options are limited in attack, to say the least.

Diego Costa has so far seen very little of the ball. He loses possession to Snodgrass when he finally takes a pass, and the West Ham winger is soon charging upfield. A firm David Luiz challenge halts that move.
And now there's a short stoppage for Cahill to replace said shirt, although Marriner insists Chelsea play on without their captain momentarily.
Carroll is back on the pitch, but he chooses not to leap with Marcos Alonso for the next lofted ball. The battle continues elsewhere, though, as Feghouli appears to have torn Cahill's shirt.
With Carroll off the pitch, Thibaut Courtois punches Robert Snodgrass' corner clear. Chelsea look to break through Hazard, Pedro and Kante, but a stray pass brings the attack to an end.
Moses did tremendously to deny Carroll a free header, but the West Ham man is now receiving treatment to a bloody nose as he appeared to be caught by the Chelsea wing-back.
Corner to West Ham - and it all comes from a first cross towards Carroll. Sofiane Feghouli centres, Victor Moses challenges with the big forward and Robert Snodgrass' strike is then deflected behind.

Eden Hazard is finding space both out wide and through the middle. He draws a foul first from Kouyate and, although that free-kick comes to nothing, he soon has the ball back to tease Pedro Obiang into a late lunge.
Now West Ham have the ball. Cheikhou Kouyate has lined up, as expected, on the right of a back four as the hosts opt against matching Chelsea's shape.
In contrast to that direct start, Chelsea are now passing the ball around the back. West Ham are yet to really have any sort of possession.
And straight from the kick-off, Chelsea knock the ball back for David Luiz to launch a long pass in behind the West Ham defence. Pedro cannot quite control.
KICK-OFF: Here we go! Diego Costa gets us started.
The handshakes and other formalities are complete. We are just about ready for the off...
And here they come! Referee Andre Marriner leads the sides out as bubbles, of course, fill the air.
The players are ready in the tunnel, too, with Mark Noble lining up alongside Gary Cahill. The teams will soon take to the pitch.
London Stadium is filling up nicely. We are now just under 10 minutes from kick-off in this London derby...

"This kind of award is better to give at the end of the season and I hope to give this award to one of my players, all of my players," the Blues manager said. "This season, until now, all my players are playing very well and deserve the best."

N'Golo Kante also plays after picking up the Premier League Player of the Year prize at the London Football Awards last week, although Conte believed it was an award that could have gone to any one of his Chelsea players.
Chelsea also have an in-form forward closing in on a half-century in England's top flight - Diego Costa is two away on 48 goals. Cesc Fabregas starts again ahead of Nemanja Matic.

Key performer Michail Antonio is missing for West Ham after seeing red at Watford, but Andy Carroll returns as he chases a 50th Premier League goal. The former Liverpool man's tally currently stands at 49.
Subs: Begovic, Zouma, Terry, Matic, Loftus-Cheek, Willian, Batshuayi.
Chelsea: Courtois, Azpilicueta, David Luiz, Cahill, Moses, Fabregas, Kante, Alonso, Pedro, Diego Costa, Hazard.
Subs: Adrian, Collins, Byram, Masuaku, Fernandes, Calleri, Ayew.
West Ham: Randolph, Kouyate, Fonte, Reid, Cresswell, Noble, Obiang, Feghouli, Lanzini, Snodgrass, Carroll.
Now, how about some team news?

West Ham's campaign has been a little less straightforward - crashing out of Europe early, struggling domestically and losing star man Dimitri Payet - but they have lost just one of their last six league games. They will be looking to regain a place in the top half here.

Antonio Conte's men lost here in the EFL Cup in October, but that was merely a minor blip in an otherwise outstanding season for the Blues - they have been beaten just once more in all competitions since that meeting. Victory today would restore a 10-point lead at the summit.
Welcome to our live text commentary as table-toppers Chelsea visit West Ham United's London Stadium in Premier League action for the first time.
news: Chelsea continued their relentless march towards the Premier League title with a controlled 2-1 win over West Ham at London Stadium.
A much-changed Blues XI were knocked out of the EFL Cup at the same ground in October but Antonio Conte's men were all business this time around.
They absorbed early pressure without coughing up chances and Eden Hazard displayed the devastating, clinical edge West Ham lacked as he scythed through them for a counter-attacking opener.

Conte's side carried menace on the break throughout, although their second came courtesy of poor set-piece defending from Slaven Bilic's side, with Diego Costa needing no second invitation to collect his 18th goal of the season after 50 minutes.
Manuel Lanzini grabbed a late consolation for the Hammers, who remain just outside the top-10, as he rifled home his sixth league goal of the season.

But Chelsea were not to be denied and sit 10 points clear of Tottenham at the summit, although their lead will be cut to eight if Manchester City win their game in hand at home to Stoke City on Wednesday.

Running repairs were the order of the day during the opening stages as West Ham striker Andy Carroll suffered a bloodied nose in an aerial challenge with Victor Moses and Chelsea defender Gary Cahill needed to replace a torn shirt.
West Ham pressed the league leaders back without crafting a goalscoring opportunity before being clinically unpicked on the counter-attack after 26 minutes.

Mark Noble's pass was cut out by N'Golo Kante and Hazard seized upon the opportunity – tearing forward from his own half, exchanging passes with Pedro and accelerate past goalkeeper Darren Randolph to slot home.
Worrying scenes followed as an angry West Ham got on to the field to confront the celebrating Chelsea players, before being led away by security.
Hammers playmaker Lanzini made a similarly darting run towards a more well-manned Chelsea defence but blazed over after a one-two with Noble.

The hosts somehow escaped falling two behind in the 42nd minute when Diego Costa missed his kick from Hazard's low cross, Moses saw his follow-up bravely blocked by Aaron Creswell and Randolph saved from Pedro on the rebound.
But Chelsea had their second within five minutes of the restart as Pedro Obiang could only glance on Cesc Fabregas' corner for Costa to bundle in from close range.
A deft piece of skill from Marcos Alonso saw him breeze past Jose Fonte – continuing a torrid outing for the West Ham centre-half – but the wing-back prodded just past Randolph's far post.
The hosts' willingness to hurl balls into the Chelsea box almost paid off in the 61st minute as Thibaut Courtois saved with his legs from Sofiane Feghouli and Robert Snodgrass headed over.
Randolph remained the more threatened goalkeeper and the Republic of Ireland international reacted superbly to tip around the corner after Costa turned masterfully to get a shot off inside the box.
West Ham kept plugging away commendably for a side safely ensconced in mid-table and  gained some consolation when Lanzini latched on to a loose ball and thrashed past Courtois in stoppage time.
Chelsea, with an FA Cup quarter-final against Manchester United next on the agenda, have their sights firmly trained upon the double.

commentary: The referee brings an end to what was a very comfortable victory for Inter. The home side immediately went on to the front foot and remained there from then onwards, with Empoli really struggling to get back into the game. The visitors offered little in front of goal and were caught out on several occasions at the back, resulting in Handanovic having barely anything to do throughout.
FULL-TIME: INTER 2-0 EMPOLI

And now Pinamonti is presented with a good opportunity! Ansaldi twists and turns as he darts towards the Empoli penalty area on a great run. He then tees up Joao Mario, who unleashes a quick shot that's deflected over to Pinamonti, and the teenager then sees his low strike from just inside the box well saved by Skorupski.

What a chance for Joao Miranda! A curling cross from a corner over on the right wing finds Gagliardini, who nods the ball down to Joao Miranda. It finds the defender in a wonderful position on the edge of the six-yard box, but, despite his best efforts, he can't beat Skorupski with his close-range effort.
The fourth official has indicated that there will be four minutes of added time.

Gagliardini almost makes it 3-0! Pinamonti and Ansaldi link up brilliantly over on the left-hand side of the Empoli penalty area before the latter chips a cross into the middle of the box. It finds Gagliardini in a great position, but the midfielder is unable to beat Skorupski with his bullet header.

Chance for Gabriel! Pinamonti flies down the right flank on a great run before cutting a clever pass back to Joao Mario on the edge of the box. The Portuguese takes a quick touch before setting up Gabriel, but the Brazilian's strike towards goal ends up curling away from the far post.

Slightly sloppy defending from Inter allows Zajc to skip past both Kondogbia and Joao Miranda before unleashing a shot from the edge of the penalty area, but it's poorly hit by the substitute and Handanovic is able to watch the effort sail well wide of its intended target.

Gagliardini charges through the middle of the pitch on a purposeful run before trying to test Skorupski with a long-range effort, but his thumping strike from 30 yards out is overhit and fails to trouble the Polish goalkeeper.
Meanwhile, Felipe Tello has come on to take the place of El Kaddouri in a late change for Empoli.
Eder makes way for Andrea Pinamonti, who comes on to make his Serie A debut.

Gabriel delights the Inter fans as he weaves towards the Empoli box on a wonderful run. He then tries to tee up Candreva with a poked pass over to the right flank, but it's slightly mishit by the Brazilian and sails over the head of the winger.

Handanovic, who has had little to do during what has been a relatively quiet second half for the goalkeeper, is finally called into action by a curling cross-cum-shot from Croce, but he's easily able to palm it away with a diving save to his left.
Empoli have made their second alteration of the afternoon, with Krunic making way for Miha Zajc.

Ansaldi tries to curl a cross into the left flank but loses out to a white shirt, allowing Empoli to counter swiftly. The ball is thumped up the pitch and finds Maccarone, who does well to hold off two Inter defenders before winning his side a free-kick on the halfway line.
Gabriel receives a rousing round of applause from the home fans as he comes on to replace Palacio.

Poor play by Palacio! A half-hearted Empoli attacking move breaks down and allows Inter to counter quickly down the right flank, but Palacio's attempted pass over to the opposite wing is woefully hit and sails harmlessly out of play for a throw-in.

Inter patiently pass the ball around midway inside the Empoli half of the pitch as they try to find a third goal that would surely wrap up the win. Gagliardini does well to chip a lofted pass into the box and towards Kondogbia, who made a good run forward, but the ball hits the Frenchman's hand and results in a free-kick for the visitors.

Ansaldi and Palacio link up well over on the left-hand side of the Empoli penalty area before the latter tries to set up Joao Mario with a chipped cross towards the Portuguese, but Laurini is there to head the ball away at the vital moment.

Maccarone gets a foot on a lofted pass into the Inter penalty area but can't beat Ansaldi, who quickly pokes the ball out for a corner. El Kaddouri tries to pick out the Empoli striker with a curling cross towards the penalty spot, but he's unable to find him and the hosts easily deal with the danger.

Eder gets himself into a good position over on the right wing and tries to set up Palacio with another cross into the penalty area. This one isn't quite as good as his last, however, and misses the Argentine before sailing out for a goal-kick.
Dimarco seemed to pull a muscle when hitting that free-kick a few minutes ago, so he's replaced by Federico Barba for the final 25 minutes of the game.

Empoli are starting to come back into the game as Inter drop off ever so slightly. The home side haven't been quite as prolific in front of goal since doubling their lead, and their reluctance to commit too many bodies forward has allowed the visitors to enjoy more of the possession.

Not far away from Dimarco! Another determined Empoli attack results in a free-kick for Empoli in a decent position deep down the right flank. Dimarco steps up and tries to catch out Handanovic with a curling strike towards the top left-hand corner of the net, but it's slightly overhit and clears the top of the crossbar by a few yards.

An attempted Empoli attacking move breaks down and Inter fly forward on one of their own. Eder twists and turns as he tries to weave his way into the penalty area, but his final touch is poor and knocks the ball into the hands of Skorupski at the near post.

A looping, lofted pass is thumped into the Inter penalty area and finds Maccarone. The striker does well to out-muscle Joao Miranda before taking on Handanovic, but his attempt to chip the goalkeeper is poor and fails to cause any problems for the goalkeeper.

El Kaddouri battles with Joao Miranda deep down the right wing before doing well to win his side a rare corner. It's whipped into the box by the Moroccan and almost finds Cosic, but the defender is unable to make decent contact with it in front of goal.

GOAL! It's 2-0 to Inter! Eder charges down the left wing before firing a wonderful cross with the outside of his boot. It flies over the entire Empoli defence before finding Candreva, who, at the back post, beats Skorupski with a thumping half-volley from close range.
That was a great cross from Eder, who perfectly picked out Candreva with his inch-perfect cross. He's been in great form today and has always looked dangerous with the ball at his feet.

Two great opportunities for Empoli! Krunic plays a beautiful one-two with Pucciarelli on the edge of the Inter box before going one-on-one with Handanovic, but he's unable to lift a chipped shot over the onrushing goalkeeper and is denied by an outstretched hand. The ball then bounces over to Maccarone, but he too is unable to fire in an equaliser.

Another chance for Gagliardini! Joao Mario and Eder link up beautifully over on the left-hand side of the Empoli box before the latter cuts a smart pass back to Gagliardini, but the midfielder's first-time shot isn't hit well enough to test Skorupski and instead sails over the top of the crossbar.

After dealing with the danger, Inter attempt to hit Empoli on a quick counter-attack through Eder, but the striker is unable to make it into the visitors' half of the pitch and is instead brought crashing to the ground by a cynical challenge from Dimarco, who is shown a yellow card as a result.

A late challenge from Ansaldi catches Maccarone from behind and gifts Empoli with a chance to curl a cross into the Inter penalty area from the right wing. It's Dimarco who tries to tee up a team-mate, but it's poorly hit and easily dealt with by the hosts.

Joao Mario cuts inside from the left wing before launching a lofted pass over to the opposite flank, where it finds Candreva. The winger brings it down well and skips past his marker before whipping a cross into the box, but Skorupski is there to cut out the danger.
Inter have made one substitution during the half-time break, with Cristian Ansaldi coming on to replace D'Ambrosio.
We're underway once again!
The two teams are making their way back out on to the pitch ahead of the start of the second half.

So far, everything is going to plan for Inter, who deservedly head into the half-time break with a one-goal lead under their belts. They were in fine form in the early stages of the game as they continually put the Empoli back line under pressure, resulting in Eder eventually beating Skorupski from close range. Since then, however, they've struggled to create too much, with their visitors slowly but surely starting to get themselves back into the game.
HALF-TIME: INTER 1-0 EMPOLI

Inter push forward on one last attack thanks to good play from Joao Mario. The Portuguese cuts inside from the right flank and finds Gagliardini, who then moves the ball on to Kondogbia, but the Frenchman's low shot from 25 yards out fails to beat Skorupski and is easily stopped.

Maccarone breaks into the left-hand side of the Inter box before trying to take on Murillo, but he's slightly too heavy handed in trying to beat the defender and ends up giving away a free-kick before he's able to get a shot away from close range.
Kondogbia becomes the latest player to receive a yellow card after clattering into Croce as the Empoli midfielder was flying down the left wing on a promising run.
The fourth official has indicated that there will be two minutes of added time.

Krunic shows good skills on the right flank as he weaves through a sea of black and blue shirts. He heads towards the Inter penalty area and then plays a quick one-two with El Kaddouri, but the pass back towards the Bosnian is poor and fails to find him in front of goal.

El Kaddouri and Gagliardini battle for a bouncing ball in the middle of the pitch, and it's the Inter midfielder who comes out on top. He's caught by a high foot from the Moroccan, however, and he's shown the first yellow card of the game as a result.

Inter keep putting pressure on Empoli as they desperately try to find a second goal before half-time. This time it's D'Ambrosio who skips into the penalty area after being set up by a delightful pass from Kondogbia, but his attempted cut-back is blocked by the chest of Veseli.

After dealing with the danger, Inter counter quickly down the right flank. Candreva flies forward on a wonderful run before penetrating the box and trying to set up Palacio, but his chipped cross is well met by the head of Uros Cosic.

A clumsy challenge from Jeison Murillo results in a free-kick for Empoli just outside of the Inter penalty area. El Kaddouri steps up and tries to test Handanovic with a thumping strike, but it's sent straight at the goalkeeper and is easily dealt with.

Eder does well to skip past Veseli as he cuts into the Empoli penalty area from the left flank. He then fires a thumping cross-cum-shot that looks set to cause problems for Skorupski, but, once again, the Polish goalkeeper is able to parry the ball away from danger.

Another great save by Skorupski! D'Ambrosio breaks into the left-hand side of the Empoli box on a great run before cutting a lovely pass back to Gagliardini, but the midfielder is denied his first goal for Inter by a fantastic diving stop from Skorupski.

Inter appeal for a penalty, but nothing is given! D'Ambrosio flies down the left wing before trying to set up Eder with a low pass into the box, but as soon as the striker is about to reach the ball, he goes down under a tackle from Diousse. He and the rest of his team-mates all scream to the referee, but he isn't at all interested and waves play on.

El Kaddouri is caught from behind as he tries to spin past Joao Miranda, and Empoli are awarded a free-kick in a dangerous position 30 yards away from the Inter goal. El Kaddouri chips a delightful pass over the hosts' defence and into the path of Manuel Pucciarelli, but, despite his best efforts, the forward is unable to make contact with the ball.

The pace of the game has slowed down somewhat as both sides battle for the ball in the middle of the pitch. Empoli are starting to come back into the game after struggling early on, with El Kaddouri and Maccarone seeing much more of the ball.

Empoli move the ball around nicely deep inside the Inter half of the pitch before El Kaddouri cuts inside from the left wing and shoots on the edge of the penalty area, but the strike is sent too near to Samir Handanovic and is comfortably saved by the Slovenian goalkeeper.

Inter are quickly able to win the ball back after Empoli fail to clear the danger, and they then win themselves a corner on the left wing. It's swung into a dangerous area and almost finds the head of Palacio, but Skorupski dives in front of the Argentine to punch the ball away at the vital moment.

Joao Mario bursts down the left flank on a marauding run before being caught from behind by Assane Diousse, resulting in a free-kick for Inter in a dangerous position. The cross into the box is poor, however, and the Senegalese midfielder is easily able to deal with the danger.

Opportunity for Candreva! The winger continues causing problems for the Empoli defence as he cuts into the penalty area and latches on to a looping cross from Eder, but his thumping, close-range volley is unable to hit the target and flies a few yards wide of the near post.

El Kaddouri is bundled over as he battles with Geoffrey Kondogbia, resulting in a free-kick for Empoli over on the left flank. It's sent short and worked over to Frederic Veseli, but the Albanian is unable to pick out a team-mate with his pass towards the edge of the Inter box.

Empoli patiently pass the ball around after the restart as they try to find a way back into the game, but a sloppy pass down the right wing is unable to find Massimo Maccarone and is instead cut out by a strong tackle from Joao Miranda.

Palacio did well to rise above his marker at the near post before teeing up Eder, but Empoli will feel frustrated at their inability to defend the cross. Inter have started strongly and certainly deserve to be in front.

GOAL! Inter have taken the lead! Once again, Candreva gets himself into a good position over on the right wing before curling a cross into the Empoli penalty area. It deflects off Dimarco and finds Palacio, who then nods the ball over Skorupski. It loops past the goalkeeper and over to the far post, where Eder is easily able to chest it into the back of an empty net from a few inches out.

And now Danilo D'Ambrosio goes close! The wing-back finds himself unmarked at the back post and brings down a cross with his chest before looking to shoot, but he's far too slow on the ball and has it poked away before he can test Skorupski.

What a save by Skorupski! Joao Mario flies down the right flank as he tries to latch on to a loose ball, but he's pushed to the ground by Federico Dimarco and wins his side a free-kick instead. It's whipped into the penalty area by the Portuguese and finds Rodrigo Palacio, but the striker's bullet header is somehow stopped by an acrobatic save from Skorupski.

Slightly sloppy play from Inter allows Empoli to push forward on their first real attack of the afternoon. El Kaddouri does well to cut inside from the left wing before trying to play a quick one-two with Rade Krunic, but the home side have plenty of bodies back to deal with the danger on the edge of the box.

After successfully dealing with the danger, Skorupski quickly sets up Manuel Pucciarelli with a quick throw up the pitch. The forward charges towards the Inter penalty area before teeing up Omar El Kaddouri to his right, but the Moroccan can't find a way past Joao Miranda and ends up firing a cross straight into his stomach.

Candreva gets himself into a good position deep down the right flank once again and sends another dangerous cross into the middle of the box, but this time it's fired slightly too near to Lukasz Skorupski and is well collected by the Empoli goalkeeper.

Antonio Candreva cuts inside from the right wing and skips past his marker before swinging a dangerous cross into the heart of the Empoli penalty area. The ball curls towards Eder and looks set to find the striker, but Vincent Laurini is just about able to get a head on the ball to stop it from doing so.

There's an almost immediate break in play after Daniele Croce is brought down from behind by a crunching challenge from Roberto Gagliardini. It initially looks as if he's hurt his shoulder after falling awkwardly, but he's eventually able to get back to his feet and play gets underway once again.
We're off! Inter get us underway, attacking from left to right.
The two sides are making their way out onto the pitch, with just a few minutes to go until kick-off.

Meanwhile, Empoli boss Giovanni Martusciello has made four alterations to the team that featured in their last outing, with Giuseppe Bellusci, Andrea Costa, Manuel Pasqual and Levan Mchedlidze making way for Frederic Veseli, Uros Cosic, Federico Dimarco and Massimo Maccarone.

Stefano Pioli has decided to make three changes to the Inter side that started the defeat against Juventus, with Geoffrey Kondogbia, Eder and Rodrigo Palacio coming into the starting line-up to replace Brozovic, Ivan Perisic and Mauro Icardi, respectively.
Empoli substitutes: Pugliesi, Zambelli, Mauri, Zajc, Barba, Pelagotti, Thiam, Picchi, Buchel, Tello, Marilungo.
Empoli XI (4-3-1-2): Skorupski; Veseli, Laurini, Cosic, Dimarco; Krunic, Diousse, Croce; El Kaddouri; Pucciarelli, Maccarone.
Inter substitutes: Biabiany, Ansaldi, Sainsbury, Santon, Carrizo, Nagatomo, Gabriel, Pinamonti.
Inter XI (3-4-1-2): Handanovic; Murillo, Medel, Joao Miranda; Candreva, Gagliardini, Kondogbia, D’Ambrosio; Joao Mario; Eder, Palacio.
There’s just over 15 minutes left to go until kick-off, so let’s have a look at how the two teams will be lining up this afternoon…

The main problem plaguing Empoli seems to be their lack of firepower in front of goal, resulting in them scoring just 14 goals all season, the lowest of any Serie A team. That could prove to be problematic this afternoon, as they must now face an Inter side who have conceded just three goals in their previous seven league outings. They are also without a win against the Nerazzurri since 2006, with only one of the last 11 meetings between the two sides not ending in a victory for Inter.

As for Empoli, they have looked better in recent weeks but nonetheless remain in a dangerous position at the wrong end of the table. Eight points now separate the Azzurri and 18th-place Palermo after their narrow 1-1 draw against Torino last weekend, and two wins from five games is their best return since the end of last season.

After embarking on an impressive winning run, Inter were finally beaten by league leaders Juventus under controversial circumstances seven days ago. A fiery end to the game saw Ivan Perisic receive a late red card for dissent, whilst star striker Mauro Icardi was later handed a two-game ban for his outburst at the officials. As a result, Pioli has had to reshuffle his side as they aim to return to winning ways.

It’s undeniable that Stefano Pioli has made a hugely positive impact since taking over at Inter, and the bad start to the season suffered under Frank de Boer now seems to be a distant memory. With seven victories from their last eight Serie A games, the Nerazzurri start the day in fifth place, equal on points with Atalanta but with the opportunity to climb above Lazio if results go their way this afternoon.
Good afternoon and welcome to our live text commentary of today’s Serie A game between Inter and Empoli at San Siro.
news: Inter returned to winning ways in Serie A as goals from Eder and Antonio Candreva earned them a deserved 2-0 victory over strugglers Empoli.
After suffering successive defeats to Lazio in the Coppa Italia and Juventus in Serie A, Inter produced a committed display, despite lacking some of their brightest attacking talents.

Ivan Perisic and Mauro Icardi were both suspended after the tempestuous 1-0 defeat to Juventus the previous week, but Stefano Pioli's combination of Joao Mario, Rodrigo Palacio and Eder in attack quickly paid off when the Italy striker put his side ahead after 14 minutes.
