West Brom move the ball around nicely deep inside the Burnley half of the pitch before Dawson tries to pick out Rondon with a looping cross, but it's sent slightly too near to Heaton and, under pressure from the Venezuelan, the goalkeeper does well to cut out the danger.

Gudmundsson picks up a loose ball on the edge of the West Brom box and quickly tees up Lowton to his right. The full-back sends a deep cross over to the far post, where it finds Arfield, but the midfielder's bouncing cross-cum-shot fails to find a teammate and is easily dealt with by Foster.

West Brom almost double their lead! Burnley almost immediately lose the ball from the restart and allow Morrison to send in another cross from the right wing. Once again it isn't dealt with well by the Burnley back line and rolls out to Brunt, but his thumping strike ends up flying straight into the hands of Heaton.

GOAL! What a start by West Brom! Brunt is left completely unmarked down the right flank and is able to tee up Morrison, who immediately whips a cross into the heart of the penalty area. It should be easily dealt with by Marney but the midfielder ends up poking the ball straight to Phillips, who, on the edge of the six-yard box, spins and fires a rocket of a shot into the roof of the net.

Burnley quickly embark on an early attack through Gudmundsson over on the right flank. The Icelander darts down the wing before firing a low cross into the feet of Vokes in front of goal, but the striker is unable to beat Evans before the ball is thumped away by Nyom.
And we're off! Burnley get us underway, attacking from right to left.
The two sides are making their way out on to the pitch, with just a few minutes to go until kick-off.

Meanwhile, Burnley boss Sean Dyche has made just one alteration to the side that featured against Crystal Palace in their last outing, with Stephen Ward coming into the starting line-up to replace Jon Flanagan, who drops to the substitutes’ bench.

Tony Pulis has decided to name an unchanged West Brom side to the one that started the victory against Leicester before the international break, with Salomon Rondon once again leading the line after successfully recovering from a slight hamstring injury.
Burnley substitutes: Robinson, Flanagan, Tarkowski, Kightly, Boyd, Barnes, Gray.
Burnley XI (4-4-1-1): Heaton; Lowton, Keane, Mee, Ward; Gudmundsson, Marney, Defour, Arfield; Hendrick; Vokes.
West Bromwich Albion substitutes: Palmer, Galloway, Olsson, Gardner, McClean, Robson-Kanu, Leko.
West Bromwich Albion XI (4-2-3-1): Foster; Dawson, McAuley, Evans, Nyom; Fletcher, Yacob; Brunt, Morrison, Phillips; Rondon.
There’s just over 15 minutes left to go until kick-off, so let’s have a look at how the two teams will be lining up this evening…

The corresponding fixture two seasons ago ended in a 4-0 win for West Brom thanks to a Saido Berahino double, but recent games between the two sides have proven to be tight and unpredictable affairs. Burnley have won three of the last seven contests but have traditionally struggled at the Hawthorns, where they haven’t tasted victory since 1969.

As for Burnley, they have looked far more comfortable and confident since making their return to the top tier, and that was evident in what has been an excellent month for Sean Dyche’s men. Victories against Everton and Crystal Palace came either side of a draw against Manchester United at Old Trafford, leaving them a point above West Brom and with a chance of lifting themselves into the top half of the table.

Only three points separate them and the relegation zone, however, so they will be well aware that there is no time for complacency, even at this early stage of the campaign. Another victory today will send them up into the top half of the table, setting them up perfectly for next weekend’s must-win game against struggling Hull City at the KCOM Stadium.

October proved to be a difficult one for West Brom, who, after only losing two of their opening six games of the season, went four games without a victory to send them down to 16th place. However, they managed to bounce back just before the international break with an impressive 2-1 win away to Leicester City and now sit in a far more comfortable 12th place.
Good evening and welcome to our live text commentary of today’s Premier League game between West Bromwich Albion and Burnley at the Hawthorns.
news: West Brom defied the critics to serve up a clinical display in a 4-0 Premier League win over Burnley on Monday.

Tony Pulis' side, not known as one of the top flight's great entertainers, have won few neutral fans, but put on a show to dish out another Hawthorns thrashing to Burnley – who were beaten by the same score on their last visit in 2014.

The Baggies scored three first-half goals – and could easily have had more – to put the match beyond their beleaguered visitors before the interval, with Scotland trio Matt Phillips, James Morrison and Darren Fletcher on target.
Burnley were run ragged at times, but still had chances of their own, Jeff Hendrick spurning the best of them when it was only 1-0.
Distant hopes of a second-half revival were banished by a deserved goal for the lively Salomon Rondon as West Brom sealed their first back-to-back wins of the season.

The result moves the hosts up to ninth, while Sean Dyche's Burnley stay 12th, having taken only one point from five matches on the road and conceding four goals in a league fixture since their last trip to The Hawthorns.

The home side, unchanged from their victory over champions Leicester City before the international break, led after just four minutes as Phillips – who scored the winner at the King Power Stadium – netted in fortuitous circumstances.
Dean Marney inadvertently slid Morrison's right-wing cross into the path of the former QPR forward, who turned smartly to power home from six yards.

Chris Brunt then tested Tom Heaton with a long-range volley as Pulis' men threatened again, with Burnley finally stirring to life in the 14th minute, only for Hendrick to loop a poor effort wide of the far post when well placed.
It took only two minutes to underline how costly that miss was as Morrison capped a swift counter-attack with an excellent side-footed finish after collecting Rondon's pass.
West Brom continued to push forward and Heaton was again called into action just past the half-hour mark to tip Rondon's curler over the crossbar.
There was nothing the England goalkeeper could do to prevent the third going in before half-time, with Fletcher turning in Phillips' back-post delivery.
Dyche introduced Ashley Barnes for Steven Defour at the break and the Clarets were marginally better, though never looked likely to make a game of it.
Indeed, their bad night got worse in the 64th minute when Allan Nyom cut the ball back for Rondon, who spun and fired into the net via a deflection.
The late introduction of Andre Gray did little to impact on the overall picture, though Johann Gudmundsson's free-kick had to be tipped onto the crossbar by Ben Foster.

With the destination of the points long since settled, there was an oddly flat atmosphere, but Pulis and his side can reflect on an excellent night's work ahead of Saturday's trip to struggling Hull City.

commentary: Full-time at the Vitality Stadium. Manchester City move to second in the Premier League thanks to a relatively comfortable 2-0 away victory against Bournemouth, with a strike from Raheem Sterling and an own-goal from Tyrone Mings sealing the vital three points. Only negative for the visitors is an injury to Gabriel Jesus who went off with a knock in the first half. Thanks for joining us, see you next time.

Third and final change from City as Guardiola wastes a little time late on. Leaving the pitch to cheers from the City fans is Sterling, and it is Nolito who is given the one-minute run out from the bench.

Three minutes of time have been signalled by the referee here so not a lot of time for Bournemouth to wait. Back to the drawing board again for Eddie Howe and his men, but if they can just tighten things up at the back they should be able to survive with the quality they possess going forward.

Kolarov picks up the ball around 25 yards out and tries his luck with a distance strike which Boruc saves excellently. The deflection falls to Silva, who AGAIN forces the former Celtic and Southampton goalkeeper into the stop, but the Spaniard was offside anyway.

Silva has been absolutely fantastic for City in the past 10 minutes or so as his expert command of the ball has completely taken out the intensity of any potential Bournemouth ascendancy. The home side simply cannot get the ball to mount any meaningful attacks, and the Spaniard has been a big reason for this.

CITY HIT THE WOODWORK! Mings, goes on an ill-advised walkabout with the ball at his feet inside the Bournemouth box which allows Sane to pounce and win the ball in a dangerous area. The German then skips past Cook before having a crack at goal from five yards or so, but the attempt cannons off the underside of the bar! Full of venom, but no direction on that one.

Very professional stuff from City at the moment as they attempt to run down this clock with some possession in the latter part of the pitch. Bournemouth are doing everything they can to press and press, but the legs are going.

We are just into the last 10 minutes now and it promises to be a grandstand finish if Bournemouth continue to knock at the door of the City defence. On the flipside of that, though, comes the fact that the Citizens are being given increasingly more space in behind the defence.

City are being pretty patient in their possession at the moment which is inviting the Bournemouth attackers to press them high up the pitch. To be fair to Guardiola's men, though, they don't appear to be lacking composure under the intense scrutiny, even if a Cherries goal would change the complexion of the game!

Last throw of the dice from Howe as he makes his third and final change. Leaving the action is Ibe, who has had a few moments of real quality on the right wing, come off to be replaced by Marc Pugh for the last 15 minutes or so.

A good period for the hosts at the moment as they have City camped inside their own defensive third. Fraser is bright again as he takes on the backline with a powerful run before releasing Daniels in behind, but Stones defends brilliantly to dash across and make the sliding block behind for the corner.

Where do Bournemoth go from here? As mentioned previously, they rallied against Everton to score a couple of late goals last week but if they flood men forward here they are going to be picked off by this City attack. Aguero, even though Mings got the final touch, has been buoyed by that second goal for the visitors.

Guardiola reacts quickly to his side going two goals ahead as he makes his second change of proceedings. Entering the action is Nicolas Otamendi and he will replace Toure, which will likely mean Fernandinho moving into his more favoured midfield position and Kolarov going to left-back.

GOOOOAAAAALLLL FOR MAN CITY! They visitors double their lead! Sterling displays some excellent wing play as he twists and turns his way to the byline before firing a low cross to the front post. Aguero is amongst things, but the final touch comes off the despairing Mings who turns into his own net! Two-nil.
Booking for Arter, and deservedly so as he attempts to completely take out Aguero down the right wing. If he had managed to catch the former Atletico Madrid man, that very well could have been red.

SAAAAVE FROM CABALLERO! Afobe makes a decent run down the left channel and collects the ball to feet before dancing his way into the penalty area ominously. Arter eventually receives the pass and steps up to whip a cracking strike at the left corner, but the City goalkeeper is on hand to make the great stop!

Whenever Aguero is injured, it usually takes him a couple of games to get back to his best. With a few matches starting as a substitute, rather than being injured, this time, it appears the same thing is happening has he has been a bit slugging in his pace and passing since being introduced. Clearly he needs to be kept match-fit, but as we all know he does have the quality to pop up with a goal.

The bookings have came thick and fast tonight and the latest guilty party is Sane who horrible rakes his studs down the back of Smith's heel around 30 yards out. The German sees yellow, and the Cherries get the free-kick in a pretty useful area.

The Vitality Stadium faithful all let out a massive sigh of collective relief as Cook very nearly gets into a dodgy position at the back as he looks to dribble his way out of the penalty area. In the end, a lovely bit of composure from the defender, as well as a quick jink sideways, sees him evade the attentions of the predatory Aguero.

Much better from City at the moment as they are regaining some of the dominance that served them well in the first half. De Bruyne in particular is finding his feet again but all the possession isn't necessarily coming with a lot of penetration as Aguero continues to look a bit isolated up top.
Sterling goes into the book now, apparently for a petulant kick-out at a Bournemouth player on the edge of the box. Looks like it may have been on King.

A misplaced pass from Sagna allows King to pounce and interception possession after reading the play very well. He catalyses a Bournemouth counter forward with Afobe and Fraser both involved, but the latter finds himself completely outnumbered on the edge of the box as City recover well to clear.

We get our first real glimpse of what Aguero can do since coming on as he shows superb strength to hold off the attentions of Arter before moving forward and nutmegging the defender. He gets into a shooting position and pulls the trigger, but a duo of deflections means Boruc isn't called into action between the sticks.

Even though Bournemouth lost 6-3 last weekend, they did rally impressively towards the end of the match and it looks like Howe has given them the confidence to do so again here as they have been excellent since the start of the half. Can City weather the storm?

Ibe has been prominent in these early stages on the second period as he relentlessly dribbles towards Fernandinho out of position at left-back. This time, he jinks beyond the Brazilian before reversing a teasing cross back into the danger area, but there are no team-mates waiting inside to smash home!

Toure really needs to watch himself out there as even though he gets the ball in a tackle with Afobe, he does take a chunk of the man too which results in a Bournemouth free-kick. The referee takes into consideration the fact the Ivorian is already on a yellow as he decides not to produce another.
The second period is under way!

Half-time at the Vitality Stadium. It has been an enthralling Premier League encounter so far and it is Manchester City who have edged things so far as they go into the break with a 1-0 lead over Bournemouth thanks to a goal from Raheem Sterling. Three changes have been forced (one for City and two for Bournemouth) so the players should take advantage of the half-time rest!
Second substitution of the match from Eddie Howe and it is another forced one as Wilshere comes off. His replacement will be Benik Afobe which will probably mean the Cherries moving to a 4-4-2.

City are controlling the ball pretty well at the moment but unfortunately for Bournemouth it appears they may be forced into ANOTHER change before half-time as Wilshere has been hobbling about uncomfortably since going in for a challenge with Silva in which he took a nasty knock to the ankle. Let's see if he can keep on going.

A generous FIVE minutes of added time have been allocated by the referee which will be due to the injuries sustained by Jesus and Francis in this first half. The period is just winding down though so we probably won't see too much action.

Mings pops a lovely pass down the left wing to the feet of Daniels, who takes the touch in before feeding a pass in behind the full-back. Fraser speedily gallops into the box and gets in the touch in just before the foot of Kolarov, but the Serbia international ends up defending well to block behind for the corner.

Just under five minutes to go in the first half and City look poised to head into the break with the narrow lead intact. Indeed, if anyone is going to score before the half-time oranges it looks more likely to be them to extend the lead than Bournemouth to equalise.

Sane moves into a more central area this time and attempts to thread a neat pass in behind the Bournemouth defence for Aguero, who bursts a gut to try and get on the end of it. Cook comes in with the slide tackle to intercept but is forced to concede the corner-kick in the process.

Sagna joins in the attack down the right wing and uses the run of Sterling as a shield to get the cross into the box. Aguero meets it, but it is a horrible miscue from the Argentine as his first-time volleyed attempt goes horribly high and wide over the crossbar. Not his best.

Guardiola is screaming at Toure to get back into position during a set-piece, and as Bournemouth take it the ball very nearly gets through to King which is where the Ivorian was supposed to be. Luckily for him, Caballero comes off his line to claim out of the air.

With teams who both play pretty attractive football, you wouldn't have guessed this game to be a hard-fought kind of battle, but the sets of players are really going for it with the tackles flying. There does indeed seem to be no love lost out there, with each refereeing decision fuelling the fire!

GOOOOAAAALLLLL FOR BOURNEMOUTH! WAIT! NO! FOUL! The hosts almost make the perfect recovery from going a goal behind as King brilliantly whips a first-time finish into the corner, but this came AFTER pulling back Stones when trying to make his way into the box. Good decision in the end!

GOOOOOOAAAAAAAAALLLLL FOR MAN CITY! THE VISITORS OPEN THE SCORING! Silva is awarded too much space on the left channel which allows him to fire a low cross into the centre of the box. Cook attempts to clear, but only manages to send the ball straight to Sterling who converts at the back post! One-nil.

SUPERB BLOCK FROM COOK! Sane takes advantage of the defender slipping inside the box which allows him to move square before setting up Sterling who takes the touch before firing the half-volley at goal. Cook makes the brave interception, while Boruc also manages to deny De Bruyne on the rebound!
Fraser is the latest player to see yellow, and deservedly so as he cynically hacks down De Bruyne on the right touchline.

A good period of sustained pressure from Bournemouth at the moment as they probe for an opening around the City box. The hosts string a few passes and possession eventually comes to Wilshere who attempts to pull the trigger from 20 yards, but Stones makes the brave block on the strike.
Tyrone Mings comes on for Francis.
Like City, Bournemouth may also have to make an early substitution as it appears Francis has picked up an injury. Not exactly what you want to see after just 22 minutes of play!

The Bournemouth fans DEMAND a penalty from the referee as they believe the ball has just bounced off the arm of Toure, but the protests are speculative at best and the official shares this view as he quickly waves play on.

SUPERB GOALKEEPING FROM CABALLERO! Ibe picks up possession on the right this time and goes on a marauding run forward before exchanging a tight one-two with Wilshere on the edge of the box. He just manages to burst into the area but the City goalkeeper proactively comes off his line to make the vital interception with his feet.

Fraser collects the ball on the left touchline and opens up his stride with a speedy, jinking run into space. He eventually attempts to whip a cross into the area, but Sagna is no slouch in the retreat and successfully gets back to make the block out for a throw-in.

That injury to Jesus has just interrupted the flow of the game slightly as both sides attempt to find their feet again after the small rest. Aguero certainly looks eager to impress from the bench, which does not bode well for Bournemouth who have been allowing goals to flood in as of late.
Nope, Jesus won't be able to continue, but Aguero is not exactly a bad replacement, is he?

Some worrying scenes for City at the moment as Jesus is currently down injured, seemingly after taking a knock to the ankle from the defender after trying to get on the end of a cross. Sergio Aguero is getting ready on the touchline, but the newly-signed Brazilian may just try and solider on if the management allow.

First booking of the match and it is an early one for Toure as he needlessly scythes down Arter just outside the centre circle. He'll be walking a disciplinary tightrope for the majority of the play now.

De Bruyne is sharp to win the ball in the middle of the pitch before firing a pass down the channel for Sterling. The former Liverpool man displays an impressive bit of fight and pace to burst beyond Daniels to get the cross into the box for Jesus, but Francis is alert to the danger and comes across to make the vital interception.

You would struggle to find a more versatile player in the Premier League than Fernandinho at the moment. The Brazilian usually features as a defensive midfielder only to be deployed at right full-back in recent matches, and tonight he is actually on the left of the four-man backline.

A cracking start to proceedings here at the Vitality as both teams are trying to implement a high-tempo to their passing in the early stages. What is clear from the opening five minutes is that Bournemouth are determined to press the City defence and goalkeeper as much as possible, likely in an effort to combat the visitors playing out patiently from the back.

Tonight we are witnessing two of the most high scoring teams in the league face off, so that would suggest we should see plenty of goals. Hope this hasn't been the commentator's curse, but with the attacking talent on show we will surely see the net bulge a few times?!
We are under way at the Vitality Stadium!
Manchester City subs: Bravo, Kompany, Fernando, Nolito, Aguero, Delph.
Manchester City (4-1-4-1): Caballero; Fernandinho, Sagna, Stones, Kolarov; Toure; Sane, De Bruyne, Silva, Sterling; Jesus.
Bournemouth subs: Allsop, Mings, Smith, Gosling, Pugh, Stanislas, Afobe.
Bournemouth (4-5-1): Boruc; Smith, Francis, Cook, Daniels; Ibe, Arter, Wilshere, Surman, Fraser; King.
TEAM NEWS...

The last clash between the Cherries and Man City took place in the middle of September earlier in this campaign. On that occasion at the Etihad Stadium, Guardiola's charges ran out comfortable 4-0 victors thanks to goals from Kevin de Bruyne, Kelechi Iheanacho, Raheem Sterling, and Ilkay Gundogan, in a result which extended City''s overall unbeaten record against Bournemouth in the league.

Bournemouth, meanwhile, have drastically dropped off in their form since the middle of January and now, despite a very positive first half of the season, find themselves just six points clear of the dropzone. The poor results have came thick and fast since the disappointing FA Cup knockout at the hands of Millwall, and they were compounded last week when Everton took them for six in a 6-3 defeat at Goodison Park.

The low point of Manchester City's season was arguably the humbling 4-0 away defeat at the hands of Everton, but since that loss they are unbeaten in four, through to the next round of the FA Cup, and have won their last two league fixtures against West Ham and Swansea respectively. A major part of the upturn in form can be attributed to Gabriel Jesus, who has hit the ground running superbly since his January move from Palmeiras, scoring three goals in three appearances.

Since the turn of the year, Pep Guardiola has found himself under increasing pressure as City boss, with his team's championship assault seemingly over thanks to their 11-point deficit to Chelsea at the summit of the table. However, if they can secure the victory tonight they will move into second in the Premier League – hardly the position of a team currently in turmoil.
Good evening football fans! Welcome to Monday Night Football as Bournemouth take on Manchester City at the Vitality Stadium in the Premier League.
news: Gabriel Jesus had his storming start to life in the Premier League checked by injury but Manchester City were able to chalk up a 2-0 win at Bournemouth to go second in the table.
Pep Guardiola's side cut Chelsea's healthy advantage to eight points and took a 29th-minute lead on the south coast through Raheem Sterling.
The opener arrived after teenage sensation Jesus, fresh from three goals in his first two top flight starts, departed with a foot problem.
Sergio Aguero has been consigned to the bench by the Brazil international, with speculation over his long-term future at City an inevitable by-product of his demotion.

City's top scorer was denied a 19th goal this season when Tyrone Mings was ruled to have got the more decisive touch to Sterling's 69th-minute cutback but the Argentina star could now have a prolonged opportunity to regain his position as the club's first-choice striker.
Bournemouth remain without a win in 2017 and, having lost Jack Wilshere to injury, boss Eddie Howe will view the six-point gap between his side and the relegation zone with increasing trepidation.
The latest twist in the Jesus-Aguero narrative came inside the first 15 minutes as the Brazil star landed awkwardly when attacking a cross from the right.
He removed his boot to receive treatment on the field before hobbling off, with Aguero afforded a hero's welcome from the travelling supporters.
City goalkeeper Willy Caballero was off his line quickly to make a vital sliding block on Jordon Ibe, a scare that prompted Guardiola's men to shift through the gears.
Sterling saw his 26th-minute shot spin off a sprawled Steve Cook and against the post, with Charlie Daniels blocking Kevin De Bruyne's follow-up.

Yaya Toure then curled a left-footed effort narrowly wide from 25 yards and the pressure told before the half-hour – a Cook deflection from David Silva's low cross this time working in Sterling's favour to leave the England man with a simple finish.
Bournemouth thought they had an instant equaliser but Josh King was correctly penalised for pulling back John Stones before converting.

City were unable to double their advantage before the break as Aguero blazed wastefully over from Bacary Sagna's right-wing centre and a hefty casualty count climbed further in first-half stoppage time.
Having already sent on Mings in place of Simon Francis, Howe faced the worrying sight of Jack Wilshere failing to shake off the effects of a challenge on the excellent Silva.
6 - Pep Guardiola has won all six league games he's managed on a Monday, with an aggregate score of 20-1. Happy.
Benik Afobe came on in Wilshere's place and the home supporters were furious when the already booked Toure brought down the substitute.

Guardiola's men were forced to ride out some early second-half pressure before City got back on the front foot – left-winger Leroy Sane ensuring a thorough working over for Adam Smith was not consigned to the first period.
But the open nature of the contest remained to Bournemouth's liking and Caballero was down sharply to his right to keep out Harry Arter's rasping left-footer.
The sense of City requiring a second was palpable and Aguero was to the fore when it arrived.
The final touch came off the Mings as both men lunged at a Sterling's cutback, the opening goalscorer having danced around an increasingly beleaguered Smith.
Six minutes from time a mistake by Mings allowed Sane to beat Cook and thrash goalwards, but the crossbar denied him the goal his effort deserved.

commentary: That's all from the San Siro! Thank you for following our LIVE coverage of the 2016/17 Serie A season - hope you've enjoyed it. Until next time, see you soon!

Luis Muriel's penalty was enough to give Sampdoria their first victory over AC Milan since August 2012 and inflict a fourth straight defeat for the Rossoneri, who dominated proceedings but severely lacked the cutting edge with any chances that fell their way and were made to pay.
FULL-TIME: AC MILAN 0-1 SAMPDORIA
There goes the final whistle and Sampdoria have the three points!
Đuričić is booked for time-wasting but Sampdoria are now just moments away from victory...
FOUR MINUTES! That is how long that 10-man Milan have to find an equaliser here. Could they do it or will Sampdoria hang on?...

SOSA IS OFF! Milan's misery is compounded as the Argentine is shown a second yellow card in the space of six minutes. He was desperate to get the ball back but mistimed his challenge and the referee had no choice.

WHAT A SAVE! Terrific goalkeeping by Viviano denies Lapadula! The Milan number nine beats the offside trap to latch onto a clever through ball by Suso, but terrific reflexes prevent the number nine from finding the equaliser. Time is running out for the hosts...

We are into the final four minutes at the San Siro and Milan are desperately trying to avert a fourth straight defeat in all competitions. Their recent poor form has seen them slip to seventh in Serie A and they are set to lose more ground on the top three.
Sosa is booked for halting an attempted Sampdoria counter-attack through the centre of the field.
Deulofeu looks to make something happen for the hosts down the right flank. The Spaniard beats his man before his cross almost catches Viviano out at the near post, but the Sampdoria keeper holds on.
SO CLOSE! Duricic is whiskers away from putting the game beyond Milan as he glides past a challenge and into the area, but his shot goes narrowly wide of the far post with Donnarumma beaten.
Meanwhile, a tactical change by Sampdoria sees potential match winner Muriel make way for Ricky Alvarez.
Milan make their final change and new loan signing Lucas Ocampos comes on for his debut in place of Bertolacci. Can he mark it in the best way possible by finding an equaliser?...

WASTED! Milan are now under pressure to salvage a point from this match. They build another neat passage of play with Deulofeu leading the charge once more, but Suso sends the subsequent shot high into the stands.
Replays show that Bacca was visibly unimpressed at being substituted by Montella, but it is fair to say that the Colombian has not been at his clinical best today.
Bacca is also given a breather by Montella, who introduces Gianluca Lapadula for the final 18 minutes.
Meanwhile, a tactical change by Milan sees Ignazio Abate introduced in place of Pasalic. Abate slots in at right-back and Kucka will now move forward into midfield.
Earning the penalty was Quagliarella's final contribution as he is withdrawn and replaced by Schick.

MURIEL SLOTS IT AWAY!!! Against the run of play, Sampdoria lead at the San Siro! Muriel calmly sends Donnarumma the wrong way for his eighth goal of the season and could that secure a first win in 10 over Milan for the Blucerchiati?

PENALTY TO SAMPDORIA! A loose touch from Zapata is pounced upon and launches a counter-attack for the visitors. Quagliarella is then tripped by Paletta in the box and leaves the referee with no choice but to point straight to the spot.
Milan continuing to press for the opening goal of this clash, but cannot afford to keep letting opportunities go to waste here or they will more than likely be punished.
The San Siro is incensed as Bacca goes to ground under a challenge by Silvestre, but the referee remains unmoved and it appeared to be more of a tangle than anything else.
Kucka also has his name taken for a rash challenge.
Suso is the next player into the book for Milan.
JUST WIDE! The Rossoneri are getting closer! A sweeping move including Suso and Bacca sets up Pasalic to let fly from just outside the box, but his powerful strike goes just past the far post.
The home fans are making plenty of noise inside the San Siro trying to inspire their side to the breakthrough. The opening goal is all that has been missing from Milan's performance so far.

STAT ATTACK! The Blucerchiati are looking for their first win over Milan in 10 attempts here. You have to go back to a 1-0 victory in August 2012 for the last time they took three points off the Rossoneri.
Sampdoria make the first change of the day with Fernandes making way for Filip Đuričić.

WOULD'VE BEEN! Bacca goes for the spectacular with an attempted overhead kick from a Milan corner. However, the Colombian does not connect as he would have liked and sends his effort wide of the target, much to his frustration.
NERVY! Bereszynski almost hands Bacca a gift as he underhits his back pass, but an alert Viviano is quick out of goal to intervene and clear the danger.
At the other end, Sampdoria threaten on the counter once again. The ball reaches Praet in the box, but his tame effort is easily held onto by Donnarumma.

OFF THE POST! Milan are a coat of paint away from taking the lead at the San Siro! A dangerous ball from the right fizzes across the area to an unmarked Deulofeu at the far post, but the Spaniard's placed effort rebounds off the woodwork with Viviano well beaten.
KICK-OFF! The referee blows his whistle and Sampdoria get the ball rolling again in the second half.
The teams are back and the second half is just moments away...

We're still goalless at half-time, but Milan were certainly on top during the first 45 minutes. All that was missing from their performance was the opening goal, although Sampdoria did look dangerous when hitting the Rossoneri on the counter-attack.
HALF-TIME: AC MILAN 0-0 SAMPDORIA
And that is the last action of this first period, as the referee blows his whistle for half-time.

Muriel goes on a strong run into the box in the final stages of the first half. However, good defending from Paletta sees him put his body in the way, before eventually drawing a free-kick out of the striker.
Bacca is the first Milan player to have his name taken by Mr Guida.

Along with Donnarumma, Suso has played in every match for Milan in Serie A this season. He has been very inspirational, too, with only Jose Callejon and Mauro Icardi bettering his seven assists in the Italian top-flight.

WHISKERS! The cross just needed a touch! Suso is asking the questions from the opposite flank on this occasion. He plays an inviting ball across the face of goal, but it just evades his teammates and drifts narrowly wide of the far post.

Although the season-ending injury to Bonaventura is a huge loss for Milan, it has presented an opportunity for Deulofeu to really make an impact at the San Siro during the second half of the campaign and the Spaniard has looked lively so far.
From the resulting corner, the danger is cleared but only as far as Deulofeu, whose drilled effort through the crowded penalty area is well held onto by Viviano.

SO CLOSE! Sampdoria are fighting the tide at the moment. Suso gets to the byline and pulls the ball across the six-yard area looking for Pasalic, but a combination of Viviano and the defender clear the danger before the midfielder can tap in.
Montella will be very pleased with the intensity of Milan's play during this first half, but you feel that breaking the deadlock would really settle the hosts down before the break.
The Sampdoria stopper has missed the majority of the season through injury, but has not looked at all rusty so far here and seems very sharp more than anything else.
GOOD SAVE! Milan continue to ask questions and go close again as we approach the half-hour mark, with Bertolacci's shot turned over by an alert Viviano.
Torreira is shown the first yellow card of the game.
At the other end of the field, Pasalic tries his luck from outside the area with a left-footed shot that is well saved by Viviano.
Of course, Linetty was drafted into starting line-up as a late replacement for Edgar Barreto prior to kick-off, and he was so close to making his mark in the best possible way there.

GREAT SAVE! A terrible ball from Deulofeu goes straight to Quagliarella and puts Milan on the back foot. He lays it off to Muriel who, in turn, finds Linetty, but his shot is well kept out by Donnarumma.
GOOD EFFORT! Bertolacci tries his luck from distance with a wonderful effort that seems destined for the far corner, but the outstretched left arm of Viviano pushes it away.
Seventh-placed Milan could move as high as fifth with three points here and they are certainly on the ascendency at the moment. However, the hosts need to strike while the iron is hot...
Bacca looks to latch onto a lofted through ball over the top of the Sampdoria defence, but just starts his run too early and is rightly ruled offside.
Milan turn up the pressure and work their way into the Sampdoria area. However, the visitors have numbers back and are able to block Pasalic's shot at goal.
STAT ATTACK! Bacca has scored in each of the last three meetings between the sides, including the winner in September's reverse fixture.

OUCH! There is a slight break in play here following a clash of heads between Silvestre and Bacca in the Milan penalty area after a Sampdoria corner. Both players receive attention but should be fine to continue.
Nothing comes of the free-kick but, at the other end of the field, Paletta is forced to make a vital interception as Sampdoria threaten to hit Milan on the counter-attack.
The Everton loanee is involved again and brought down about 35 yards from goal. Milan have a free-kick in a decent position here...
Deulofeu looks to make an impact on his first start for Milan and runs with purpose into the heart of the Sampdoria defence. However, the visitors hold firm on this occasion and snuff out his threat.

Marco Guida is the man in charge at the San Siro. It is his second appointment here in the space of five days, having also overseen Inter Milan's 2-1 defeat to Lazio in the Coppa Italia earlier this week.
KICK-OFF! The referee blows his whistle and Milan get the match underway.
HERE THEY COME! The teams are making their way out onto the field and the San Siro is in fine voice.
SAMPDORIA SUBS: Puggioni, Dodo, Alvarez, Schick, Linetty, Palombo, Pavlovic, Cigarini, Budimir, Tomic, Krapikas.
SAMPDORIA (4-3-1-2): Viviano; Bereszynski, Silvestre, Skriniar, Regini; Barreto, Torreira, Praet; Bruno Fernandes; Quagliarella, Muriel.

Meanwhile, Marco Giampaolo, who took over from Montella at Sampdoria at the start of this season, makes just a single alteration to the side that beat Roma last time out. It comes in goal with Emiliano Viviano returning from injury to take the place of understudy Christian Puggioni, who signed a new deal until June 2019 this week. Veteran Fabio Quagliarella will be hoping to cause plenty of problems alongside top scorer Luis Muriel up front, while Milan target Patrik Schick takes his place on the bench alongside Michal Tomic, who receives his first senior call-up.
AC MILAN SUBS: Storari, Lapadula, Honda, Ocampos, Fernandez, Gomez, Poli, Abate, Vangioni, Locatelli, Calabria, Plizzari.
AC MILAN (4-3-3): Donnarumma; Kucka, Zapata, Paletta, Romagnoli; Bertolacci, Sosa, Pasalic; Suso, Bacca, Deulofeu.

Vincenzo Montella is facing his former employers today and makes three changes to the side that were beaten 2-1 by Udinese last Sunday. Everton loanee Gerard Deulofeu makes his first start in place of the injured Giacomo Bonaventura, who has been ruled out for the rest of the season, while Andrea Bertolacci comes into the three-man midfield. Juraj Kucka slots in an right-back as part of a makeshift defence following Milan's recent injury woes across the backline, which also saw Mattia De Sciglio and Luca Antonelli join the casualty list this week. Therefore, Alessio Romagnoli moves across to start at left-back and Cristian Zapata comes into the centre alongside Gabriel Paletta. New signing Lucas Ocampos could make his debut from the bench.

Seventh-placed Milan are looking to end a run of three straight defeats in all competitions here. However, the Rossoneri will take confidence from the fact that they have won each of their last four meetings with Sampdoria, who are 12th but come into this clash off the back of an impressive 3-2 win over second-placed Roma last weekend.
Hello everyone and welcome to LIVE text coverage of the 2016/17 Serie A season! Today, we're at the iconic San Siro where AC Milan welcome Sampdoria in the Italian top-flight.
news: AC Milan's top-three ambitions are in tatters after they suffered a 1-0 defeat to Sampdoria at San Siro on Sunday.
A second-half penalty from Luis Muriel was enough to inflict upon Milan a third Serie A loss in as many games and extend their winless run to five in all competitions.
Vincenzo Montella's side controlled the majority of the play but looked like a team bereft of confidence, as a consistent lack of composure in attack saw opportunities go begging.
Gerard Deulofeu hit the post with their best opening but Emiliano Viviano's goal was largely untroubled after a busy first half in which he made good saves to deny Andrea Bertolacci.

Milan were punished as they continued to push forward, with Muriel converting from the spot after Fabio Quagliarella had been fouled following a counterattack, and Gianluca Lapadula missed a glorious late chance to equalise as Samp followed up an impressive win over Roma with another valuable victory.

Milan - who lost Jose Sosa to a late red card - stay 10 points behind Luciano Spalletti's side in the final Champions League spot, leaving them with a huge task in their bid to return to Europe's top competition.
Deulofeu was handed his first start for the club, while Juraj Kucka and Alessio Romagnoli lined up as full-backs in a makeshift defence as Milan's injury problems continued.

It was down the Milan right that Sampdoria carved out the best chance of the first half after 24 minutes, with Gianluigi Donnarumma reacting well to claw away Karol Linetty's strike from just inside the area after Kucka failed to track his run.

Bertolacci stung the palms of Viviano with two good efforts from 20 yards and Deulofeu was inches from turning Suso's cross into an empty net, as Milan stepped up the urgency in their play in the closing stages of the half.

Deulofeu spurned a glorious chance to open his account two minutes after the restart, the winger placing the ball onto the base of Viviano's left-hand post after being given time and space to steady himself when Suso's cross was parried into his path.

Mario Pasalic steered a shot inches wide from the lively Deulofeu's pass as Samp continued to invite pressure, but frustrations were growing around San Siro as persistent poor play in the final third halted Milan's attacks.

And the home fans were positively irate when Muriel broke the deadlock against the run of play with 20 minutes to go. Cristian Zapata lost the ball near the halfway line and, after Gabriel Paletta bundled Quagliarella to ground inside the area from the resulting break, Muriel confidently swept home the penalty.

Milan turned up the pressure again but Viviano's low stop from Deulofeu's mishit cross summed up their lack of quality in attack, while substitute Filip Djuricic dragged a shot wide of Donnarumma's right-hand psot when he should have made it 2-0.

Lapadula shot straight at Viviano when played clean through on goal by Suso in the dying minutes, and Deulofeu's follow-up effort was blocked by his team-mate's ankle, with Sosa's second yellow card moments later compounding another disappointing day.
